webTitle: Ericsson's Bluetooth to spark mobile war

fields.headline: Ericsson's Bluetooth to spark mobile war
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Telecoms group Ericsson claimed a world first yesterday, saying it would be rolling out its "Bluetooth" mobile phone - allowing customers to access their computers from their handset - this year.
fields.body:
Telecoms group Ericsson claimed a world first yesterday, saying it would be rolling out its "Bluetooth" mobile phone - allowing customers to access their computers from their handset - this year.

Although unveiled yesterday at simultaneous launch ceremonies in London and Singapore, Ericsson's new T36 mobile will not appear in shops until the final quarter of this year and the Swedish company refused to give any details on its price.

When it arrives, the T36 will work in tandem with the futuristic wireless handsfree Bluetooth headset. The company said it would also offer the Bluetooth home base, which will automatically detect the presence of a mobile phone and connect it to a land line when the user is at home, so saving on mobile phone bills and allowing the owner to have just one phone for all their calls.

There are high hopes in a range of applications for Bluetooth, which is being touted as "the fastest growing communications standard ever". Merrill Lynch predicts that, by 2005, Bluetooth, a name derived from a King of Denmark who was famed for getting people to talk to each other, will be found in 1.7bn electronic devices around the globe.

The technology's main selling point is that it does away with the jumble of wires and adaptors that many mobile phone users have to wrestle with. Instead, devices like phones, handsets, computers and peripherals communicate swiftly through the air, thanks to tiny modules measuring only a few centimetres long which are built into them.

Its backers are claiming that the technology will eventually be found in devices ranging from the PC to the fridge, but one of the first gadgets to get the Bluetooth treatment will be the mobile phone.

Five companies - Ericsson, IBM, Intel, Nokia and Toshiba - set up the Bluetooth special interest group in 1997. Further weight was added earlier this year, when Microsoft, 3COM, Lucent and Motorola joined the group, which licences the technology to hardware and software manufacturers.

Ericsson sees itself in pole position to capitalise on the wireless technology. It began work on a short distance radio system in 1994 and donated its research to get the Bluetooth interest group off the ground.

"This is only the beginning," said Ericsson's vice president of marketing, Jam Ahrenbring. "The Bluetooth wireless technology has had an astonishing reception, with close to 2,000 companies signing up during only two years. We are looking forward to seeing creative products and solutions from the other companies."

The arrival of Bluetooth will spark yet another technology war in the mobile phone world. It is already absorbing the impact of WAP "wireless internet" services, higher-speed GPRS (General Packet Radio Service) services for business due to start this summer, and third generation mobile technology, which could bring video and other internet-style content to mobile screens by 2003.

Futurologists predict Bluetooth technology will make it possible to integrate the standard into even the cheapest laptop and desktop computers, printers and other peripherals - as well as household devices like video recorders and hi-fis. Ericsson itself says up to 1bn Bluetooth devices will be sold annually by 2005, with prices falling as market penetration increases.

fields.headline: Passionless romance
fields.standfirst: Romeo and Juliet Theatre Royal, Glasgow ***
fields.trailText: Romeo and Juliet Theatre Royal, Glasgow ***
fields.body:
Compact and colourful, Robert North's Romeo and Juliet premiered in Glasgow this week. First performed by Geneva Ballet in 1990, it suits the Scottish Ballet, where North has been artistic director since 1999.

Having lived and worked in Verona, North and his collaborator, theatre designer Andrew Storer, have set their version of the love story in a chequerboard land of Tuscan tints and cut out castles. Changing scene like a children's pop-up book, the all-in-one set ingeniously fits in cloisters and street corners, bed, bier and balcony. The whole design is clean-cut and attractive, but its colour chart tidiness strikes a curious bland note over this rollercoaster story of love and revenge.

Paring down the glamour and sophistication of previous ballet versions, North has chosen to refer directly to Shakespeare's play, setting his production among respectable families rather than royal ones. Though this sentiment is honourable and makes literal sense, the move to 15th century Italian suburbia subdues the grand passion. West Side Story took Romeo and Juliet out of a courtly context but lost nothing of the conflict of the two central families. Here, their expression is restricted by a modern off-pointe choreography which sets spins, poses and clasping-to-bosoms efficiently but with a lack of personality.

Guest artist Mia Johansson is a petite Juliet, soft on her feet and light as air. She pairs well with another associate artist, Adam Cooper, best known for his Swan in Matthew Bourne's acclaimed Swan Lake. He is a strong, youthful Romeo who lands well. Passion, however, is held on a leash. The bed chamber duet and Juliet's anguish over having to marry Paris are the two moments when North's choreography comes close to portraying heightened feelings.

Other hot spots, marked by Prokofiev's discordantly dramatic score, skim over the heart of the matter. The deaths of Tybalt and Mercutio (danced with wit by Ersin Aycan), the knight's dance, the masked ball (accompanied by that wonderfully pounding music, ably performed here) are danced with stylised simplicity, designed without depth. The climax is brief. Paris is murdered, Romeo commits suicide by poison and when Juliet awakes in the crypt to find her lover dead, she kills herself swiftly by sword. And it is over. Back to business, catch the train home, with the feeling that something is missing.

Until Saturday. Box office: 0141-332 9000.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Offshore  haven
fields.standfirst:
Cold water poured on Sealand security

E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government last night poured cold water on a plan by group of entrepreneurs to establish a "data haven" on a rusting iron fortress in the North Sea in an attempt to circumvent new anti-cryptography laws.
fields.body:
The government last night poured cold water on a plan by group of entrepreneurs to establish a "data haven" on a rusting iron fortress in the North Sea in an attempt to circumvent new anti-cryptography laws.

The US businessmen hope that by basing Haven Co on the self-proclaimed principality, clients for the secure, private servers for e-commerce, email and web hosting will be sheltered from the law which will enable government agencies to intercept internet communications.

However, a Home Office spokesman said: "The UK does not recognise Sealand as an independent state. It is within UK territorial waters. If they set up a computer provider there, we may require them to provide us with an intercept capability."

Sealand declared itself independent in 1967 and its self-styled prince of Sealand says it is not bound by British law.

Haven's chief executive Sean Hastings believes that by basing his company on the platform, potential clients will be able to scape the regulation of investigatory powers bill, which is going through Parliament. It is designed to ensure that law enforcement agencies can still gain access to encrypted information.

Mr Hastings claims that companies that hand encryption "keys" to the government risk exposing private client information and could be liable for breach of confidence.

"Haven Co is for companies that want to have email servers in a location in which they can consider their email private and not open to scrutiny by anyone capable of filing a lawsuit," Mr Hastings said.

fields.headline: Where Brit pop began
fields.standfirst: The Chameleons Academy, Manchester *****
fields.trailText: The Chameleons Academy, Manchester *****
fields.body:
Now that City are back in the premiership and the Chameleons have reformed, Manchester is once again complete. Back in the early 80s, the band troubled the brickwork in venues across the country with their emotionally fraught pre-stadium rock that was years before its time. Guitarists Dave Fielding and Reg Smithies manufactured expansive choral riffs, while drummer John Lever hammered the tom-tom and snare as if trying to knock his drum-kit into a more interesting shape.

With singer-bassist Mark Burgess adding resonant vocal pleas and strong basslines, the Chameleons made a defiant noise amid the doleful clatter of Manchester's declining heavy industry. In the dandified 80s, some blamed the band's eventual demise on a lack of image. They were just four ordinary-looking blokes in drain-pipe jeans and tatty denim jackets.

Opening with Swamp Thing from their ill-fated final album, Strange Times, it was immediately clear that their awesome live display of power and delicacy hadn't been tempered by a 14-year absence. Rivalling Johnny Marr's What Difference Does it Make? for the best guitar intro of the 80s, the picked strings were soon accompanied by a coccyx-trembling bass and drums, while Burgess delivered every word as if his life still depended on it. These were songs to remind you of the hairs on the back of your neck.

With John Lever now attacking the drums as if he was smashing up a lathe, A Person Isn't Safe Anywhere These Days had enough menace to convince you of the title's veracity. And the song's intensity alone had a small gaggle of goths reaching to touch up their face-powder. Yet the Chameleons are too versatile to simply bludgeon their way through, and here they moved towards a haunting, rhapsodic conclusion.

Their irreproachable two-hour set was all about this nerve and bone combination of elegy and anarchy. While epics of despair, Soul in Isolation and Caution, wound themselves ever tighter in pursuit of their death rattle finales, the band's debut single, In Shreds, had an unstoppable belligerence. Second Skin and Don't Fall further enticed the sold-out crowd toward riot status.

Sometimes nostalgia can be well worth the wait.

webTitle: Spin-offs will fund NTL expansion into new markets and technology

fields.headline: Spin-offs will fund NTL expansion into new markets and technology
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cable operator NTL said yesterday it was considering spinning off or creating tracking vehicles for five divisions to help fund heavy expansion into new regions and technology in the next few years.
fields.body:
Cable operator NTL said yesterday it was considering spinning off or creating tracking vehicles for five divisions to help fund heavy expansion into new regions and technology in the next few years.

NTL, Britain's biggest cable operator, said it hoped to kick off with a separate listing for its broadcast business this year and was also aiming for a dual European listing for the group this year in addition to a secondary London listing.

"We will be increasing our expenses through 2000 and will look to finance some of our new ventures either by spinning them off or creating tracking vehicles," said John Gregg, the chief financial officer. "Because of heavy expansion, EBITDA [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation] will move from positive to negative through 2000 but will soon make a recovery."

Among divisions earmarked for possible spin-offs, Mr Gregg listed the business telecoms, programming, interactive and European broadband cable divisions.

First up will be the broadcast business. He said the group would prefer to issue a tracker stock for that division as it was more tax efficient, but might still opt for a spin-off to shareholders.

NTL, which is Nasdaq listed, has said it will seek a secondary listing in London this year and Mr Gregg said the group would also pursue a full European listing, possibly on a new London-Frankfurt exchange.

"Under current London stock exchange rules, we would have to have our domicile in Britain but we are Delaware-based and don't plan to change that. However, things may be different under a merged London-Frankfurt exchange," Mr Gregg said.

If a dual listing was not possible, the group would stick with a separate listing for its European cable business and the secondary London listing to build its European investor base, he said, adding that the group hoped to reach 500,000 digital TV subscribers in Britain by the end of the year - a rise of 200,000 on previous forecasts.

NTL has some 200,000 digital TV subscribers, 1m internet users and more than 10,000 high-speed internet customers.

 Mannesmann bid farewell to chief executive Klaus Esser yesterday in a symbolic end to the fierce takeover battle that finally cracked "fortress Germany".

Speaking to a hard core of around 300 shareholders in Mannesmann's home town of Duesseldorf, Mr Esser said the takeover by Vodafone AirTouch - widely seen as a great deal for shareholder value - had a negative impact on workers.

fields.headline: Song-cycle of humanity
fields.standfirst: Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra/ Riccardo Chailly Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra/ Riccardo Chailly Royal Festival Hall, London ****
fields.body:
There is no doubt that the new critical edition of Mahler's Des Knaben Wunderhorn, which was given its British premiere by Riccardo Chailly and the Concertgebouw Orchestra, is a fascinatingly rich enhancement of the Mahler canon. Using the suggested complement of four soloists, as Chailly did, the song-cycle becomes an almost operatic investigation of tragedy and innocence.

The most immediately striking feature of the new edition is the inclusion of songs from two of the symphonies: Urlicht from the Second Symphony, and Das himmlische Leben, which, in a different orchestration, would become the final movement of the Fourth Symphony.

Placed in the middle of the cycle, Urlicht is transformed into the still, contented heart of Des Knaben Wunderhorn. However, the song means something very different in this context from its function in the symphony. There it provides a premonition of the opening of the pearly gates that the end of the Second Symphony will finally and fabulously achieve. In Des Knaben Wunderhorn, Urlicht is more intimate yet equally affecting. Here, surrounded by St Anthony's Sermon to the Fishes (another song that would form the basis of a movement in the Second Symphony) and the chilling reveille of a soldier doomed to a terrible death, Urlicht - especially in mezzo-soprano Sara Fulgoni's rapt account - was the spiritual epicentre of a profoundly human universe.

Something similar happens to Das himmlische Leben, which does not sound like the clinching vision of heaven to complete a huge, symphonic trajectory, but more like the final panel of a series of images and allegories of childhood. With the cornucopia of rustic folk-tales in Des Knaben Wunderhorn, the sensual imagery in Das himmlische Leben is as important as the transcendent. Barbara Bonney brilliantly balanced child-like wonder with intensely felt piety.

But the star of the show was baritone Matthias Goerne. The full range of the delicate colours of his voice may be best suited to the concentration of lieder, but in the seven songs he performed in Des Knaben Wunderhorn, his gifts as a dramatist were equally valuable. He created a panoply of keenly etched characters, from the terrified drummer boy who has been sentenced to death, to a pair of gleefully fickle lovers in the story of a Hussar and his maiden. Paralleling this variety of dramatic situation, Mahler's orchestrations - and Chailly's conducting - are object lessons in achieving an extraordinary, jewel-like clarity and precision.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Working paranoia
fields.trailText: 6 June: My boss is worried that members of our team are plotting against her. She has told me and a colleague that we are not to speak, go to lunch together or socialise outside of work.
fields.body:
The problem

My boss is worried that members of our team are plotting against her. She has told me and a colleague that we are not to speak, go to lunch together or socialise outside of work. It is all in her head but superiors do not want to get involved as they say she is our manager, and she can manage us as she pleases.

The solution

Yes, she can manage you as she pleases, but this does not include managing and controlling your lives outside of work. You should be free to do want you want, see who you want and talk to whoever you want outside work, as long as there is nothing illegal involved (which would be one of the few grounds for an employer appropriately disapproving of outside activities).

So, I suggest that you keep careful note of any comments your boss makes in reference to your socialising together. Date them, and try to get witnesses to the comments. Then, go ahead and have lunch with whoever you want and certainly, go out with whom you please after work. If there are any repercussions, just calmly point out that there is nothing in your contract preventing you from having lunch with whoever you choose. Your boss won't have a leg to stand on, but, if she makes things awkward for you out of revenge, or tries to force you out, you will have a good claim for unfair dismissal. Speak to your union rep for further advice.

Of course, a more conciliatory strategy would be to invite your boss to join you both.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Goodwin century restores the Zimbabweans' pride

fields.headline: Goodwin century restores the Zimbabweans' pride
fields.trailText: The deaths of close friends, the seizure of hundreds of farms and the slow inevitability of a test series defeat had served to deepen Zimbabwe's misery. But in an atmosphere of utter wretchedness, Murray Goodwin defied England's bowlers yesterday with an unbeaten century that finally afforded an excuse for joy.
fields.body:
The deaths of close friends, the seizure of hundreds of farms and the slow inevitability of a test series defeat had served to deepen Zimbabwe's misery. But in an atmosphere of utter wretchedness, Murray Goodwin defied England's bowlers yesterday with an unbeaten century that finally afforded an excuse for joy.

Goodwin's unbeaten 148, to lead Zimbabwe to 285 for four, still 89 behind England, is not about to save a series. But it has saved his side's soul.

The murder during a robbery of Tony Oates, father of the Mashonaland cricketer Jason, had brought more anguish to a tour that has persistently plumbed the depths - and the players had worn black armbands on the first day as a mark of respect.

"This lifts spirits so much, both among ourselves and back in Zimbabwe," Goodwin said. "It's nice to give some positive vibes, to show people in England that we can play. We knuckled down and showed the public that we are not the worst side."

webTitle: South Africa discover it's not so good to talk

fields.headline: South Africa discover it's not so good to talk
fields.trailText: With allegations of match-fixing gripping world cricket, mobile phones have been banned from the South African team's dressing room.
fields.body:
With allegations of match-fixing gripping world cricket, mobile phones have been banned from the South African team's dressing room.

Ali Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board, told the Johannesburg Sunday Times that the move "was part of an effort to assure the public that members of the South African cricket team are above board."

Hansie Cronje, sacked as captain after admitting taking money from bookmakers, allegedly communicated with bookies via a mobile phone given to him for that purpose.

Bacher said that the ban was implemented on the recommendation of the Qayyum report into allegations of corruption in Pakistan cricket.

The South Africa coach Graham Ford said he did not believe phones had been a problem in the past. "Cellphones were effectively banned for most of the guys anyway," he said, "because they turned them off and gave them to the team manager to be locked away with the rest of the valuables at the beginning of the day's play."

Cronje, along with Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom, was implicated in match-fixing by Indian police on April 7. All four deny the charges.

fields.headline: Keegan's big dilemma
fields.trailText: Option A 4-4-2 : Tried, tested and preferred by Keegan in most of his 13 games in charge
fields.body:
Option A 4-4-2 : Tried, tested and preferred by Keegan in most of his 13 games in charge

Option B 3-5-2: Invigorated England against Ukraine and offers better scope for McManaman

Kevin Keegan has a week to decide whom he wants to pick for England's opening match of the European Championship against Portugal and how he wants to play it. The whom is likely to give him fewer headaches than the how.

The line-up is all but decided. So far as team selection is concerned the only pointer to emerge from Saturday's often shambolic exercise in Malta was the strength of Nick Barmby's case for filling the problematic position on the left.

Barmby's was the most consistent performance in a laborious 2-1 victory over a Malta side who celebrated the centenary of the island's football association by giving everybody a piece of the action. Josif Ilic, the Malta coach, used 11 substitutes and even Keegan brought on six. At times it was like watching a game at Clapham Junction.

Some England players enhanced their importance for Euro 2000 by not appearing. Tony Adams, confined to the team hotel with a stomach upset, nevertheless reconfirmed how essential his form and fitness will be to the centre of a defence which looked flat and vulnerable without him.

Up front Michael Owen will not have felt threatened by the performances of Kevin Phillips, Robbie Fowler or Emile Heskey, although the latter's ability to move wide on the right and turn defenders, as he had done against Argentina in February, again gave the attack a fresh dimension. Owen will partner Alan Shearer in Eindhoven provided the knee injury which forced the England captain off early in the second half does not turn out to be serious.

Tactically the most crucial decision Keegan has to make is whether to revert to the system of three at the back and five in midfield which reinvigorated his team when England beat Ukraine 2-0 at Wembley last Wednesday or stick with the 4-4-2 formation employed in the 1-1 draw with Brazil and again in Malta.

None of which will be relevant if England's passing, per ception and all-round concentration do not achieve a dramatic improvement over the next seven days. While no wise person would judge the team's prospects for Euro 2000 solely on the evidence of a social occasion designed, from the Football Association's point of view, to secure Malta's vote for hosting the 2006 World Cup, the shortcomings in Keegan's side were alarmingly consistent with those that had plagued England's narrow squeak in qualifying.

As Keegan himself said afterwards: "If we play like that in Euro 2000 we'll be home early. We missed a lot of chances and we need to work on the defence as a unit. Too often we were beaten by simple balls lobbed over the top, although of course there is Tony Adams to come back. He's a key player for us."

Adams, however, is unlikely to go through the tournament without suffering some sort of ache or strain. Keegan's confidence in Martin Keown and Sol Campbell is unshaken although again on Saturday Campbell appeared to be suffering from a loss of form and confidence.

At times the ease with which Carmel Bussutil, the stocky 36-year-old Malta captain, lured the Tottenham defender into tackles, then turned inside him with the ball was embarrassing; and the penalty given away by Richard Wright, England's third-choice goalkeeper, which enabled the Maltese to draw level six minutes after Keown had headed in a free-kick from David Beckham, followed one of several instances in which Malta exploited space to the left of goal covered by neither Campbell nor Phil Neville.

Both went missing as Noel Turner found David Carabott, who was then fouled by Wright. Carabott sent the goalkeeper the wrong way with a penalty which then had to be re-taken because of Maltese encroachment. This time the ball hit a post and rebounded into the net off Wright's head, almost a comic remake of the goal he had conceded playing for Ipswich against Barnsley in the First Division play-off final.

As at Wembley, however, Wright made amends, this time saving another penalty from Carabott in the 88th minute to deny Malta a 2-2 draw. In stoppage time, moreover, Wright saved feet first to thwart Nenad Veselji, the man he had brought down for the second penalty. There is nothing wrong with Wright's agility or his handling but prospective England goalkeepers should not be conceding two penalties in one game.

Barmby was the one bright spot in an otherwise grey England performance. "He played very well," said Keegan. "He's a talented footballer with a good football brain." Certainly the Everton man has the intelligence at this level not to attempt ambitious dribbles past defenders or intricately threaded passes when the situation demands a simple ball.

Speed, simplicity, vision and the ability to pass, centre or shoot with either foot have always been Barmby's virtues and Keegan cannot be far off persuading himself that against Portugal the balance he would give England outweighs the fancier notion of allowing Steve McManaman to drift in from the left.

McManaman could still be accommodated if the England coach opts for playing five across the middle. Yet Keegan still has to consider the ability of Dennis Wise, as he showed against Argentina, to get the passing together and the importance of getting Paul Scholes into scoring positions.

Significantly, perhaps, Barmby set up England's winning goal against Malta a quarter of an hour from the end when he neatly evaded a defensive challenge to provide the short cross from the left from which Heskey scored.

Equally significantly the 10 minutes Gareth Barry spent on the field after replacing Beckham reminded Keegan of the advantages that might accrue from having a naturally left-footed defender with attacking inclinations.

England (4-4-2): Wright; G Neville, Keown (Southgate, 58min), Campbell, P Neville; Beckham (Barry, 80), Wise (Ince, 68), Scholes (McManaman, 68), Barmby; Shearer (Heskey, 51), Phillips (Fowler, 58).

webTitle: Schmeichel spot on as goalkeepers steal show

fields.headline: Schmeichel spot on as goalkeepers steal show
fields.trailText: Goalkeepers stole centre stage on the final weekend of preparation for Euro 2000, and if Richard Wright endured a topsy-turvy time in Malta, his highs and lows were nothing compared with events across Scandinavia.
fields.body:
Goalkeepers stole centre stage on the final weekend of preparation for Euro 2000, and if Richard Wright endured a topsy-turvy time in Malta, his highs and lows were nothing compared with events across Scandinavia.

In Copenhagen there was ecstasy for Peter Schmeichel, whose 121st appearance for Denmark brought a first goal, from the penalty spot. In Olso there was agony for Italy's Gianluigi Buffon, ruled out of the European Championship after breaking a hand.

The Parma keeper fell badly trying to save the header by John Carew which gave Norway a 1-0 win. He was replaced two minutes later by Fiorentina's Francesco Toldo, who is expected to start Italy's opening Group B game against Turkey on Sunday.

Dino Zoff resisted any temptation to dig out his old gloves and called up Milan's Christian Abbiati as the third-choice keeper instead. But what goes on between the sticks could be the least of the coach's worries.

Against Norway his strikers Francesco Totti and Filippo Inzaghi failed to seriously test Thomas Myhre. The defence struggled to cope with Norway's aerial threat, and poor marking enabled Carew to nod in a cross by Liverpool's Vegard Heggem in the 53rd minute.

The Norwegians, beaten once in eight games, take on Spain in their first Group C fixture in confident mood. "We played a good match and we were clearly better than Italy," said the coach Nils Johan Semb.

Schmeichel's moment of glory gave Denmark a 2-1 lead against Belgium in a match which ended 2-2.

The former Manchester United keeper converted the spot-kick with aplomb and said afterwards: "I got fed up with looking at the team sheet and seeing 'Goals: 0' next to my number of caps."

Unfortunately for Schmeichel, 'Wins: 0' is what Denmark have achieved in six matches since their play-off victory over Israel last November. Both they and Belgium showed weaknesses in the centre of defence.

There was no shortage of goals either in Nuremberg, where Germany beat the Czech Republic 3-2. Oliver Bierhoff came off the bench to score his first international goals in more than 600 minutes, a penalty and a last-minute header which secured Germany's first win since November after Patrik Berger had made it 2-2.

"We're moving in the right direction," said Germany's coach Erich Ribbeck. "We've still got work to do in some areas, so we won't attach too much importance to the result but I'm still very pleased. The players will take some confidence from it."

Not least Bierhoff, whose place has been under threat. "For me it is clear now I will play from the start," the Milan striker said. And to add to the feel-good factor, Franz Beckenbauer has insisted Germany can retain the trophy they won by beating the Czechs in 1996.

"We are capable of defending our title successfully," the Bayern Munich president said, "not because we will make spectacular progress but because the other teams are not better than we are."

Romania, one of England and Germany's group opponents, beat Greece 2-1 at home without the rested Gheorghe Hagi.

Spain admitted after a 1-1 draw against Sweden that their key striker Raul will go into Euro 2000 carrying an injury. The Real Madrid player did not train last week after straining a thigh muscle during the Champions League final and missed the Sweden game.

He hopes to play some part in a friendly against Luxembourg on Wednesday but Spain's coach Jose Antonio Camacho admitted the situation was far from ideal: "We think he'll be able to play the first official game [against Norway]," he said, "but he'll definitely be in discomfort."

Camacho was pleased with the performance in Sweden, where a Pep Guardiola penalty was cancelled out by a Roland Nilsson spot-kick.

Slovenia, one of Spain's group opponents, ended their preparations with a comfortable 2-0 win over Saudi Arabia thanks to goals from Zlatko Zahovic and Milenko Acimovic. "I think we will be a big problem for all our opponents if we play as we did today," said their coach Srecko Katanec.

Katanec may be encouraged to hear that Yugoslavia, his team's first opponents, lost 4-2 to a South China-Hong Kong Select XI. It ended a Far East tour on which they were twice held to goalless draws by South Korea and beat China 2-0.

France beat Japan 4-2 on penalties in Casablanca after a 2-2 draw which featured a fine goal by Zinedine Zidane and one by Youri Djorkaeff from Nicolas Anelka's cross.

fields.headline: Leicester want quick appointment
fields.trailText: Leicester have received more than 20 applications for the manager's job vacated by Martin O'Neill last week and intend to announce their choice this week.
fields.body:
Leicester have received more than 20 applications for the manager's job vacated by Martin O'Neill last week and intend to announce their choice this week.

"I'm pretty keen to get it sorted this week," said the club's chairman John Elsom. "One of the problems is, of course, summer holidays; most of the football world is away. But I am very keen to do so for the sake of continuity for the players.

"I know they are not coming into training at the moment but I think they will feel more settled when they know who we've appointed."

Gillingham's highly regarded manager Peter Taylor is the fans' favourite and perhaps significantly has refused the offer of a four-year contract worth £150,000 a season to stay with the club he led to the First Division last season.

Inevitably the out-of-work Joe Kinnear will also feature at the interview stage after turning down the Sheffield Wednesday job last week, as may Preston's David Moyes. Intriguingly there has also been a joint application from the current Leicester players Steve Walsh and Tony Cottee.

The immediate futures of O'Neill's assistants John Robertson and Steve Walford will become clear when the new manager is appointed. But Matt Elliott and Neil Lennon, key players both, have recently signed new contracts and have stated that they do not intend to follow their mentor to Celtic.

"Our aim is to sign more players to strengthen the squad for Europe rather than see them leave," Elsom said. "I've made that as clear as possible to Martin. One defection to Celtic is more than enough and the fans wouldn't stand for any more." Leicester have received £1.25m from Celtic in compensation for the manager.

O'Neill, meanwhile, has stated that he wants the £10m-rated Mark Viduka to stay at Parkhead, although the Australian striker's wife is reported to be unhappy with life in Scotland. "Mark is an immensely talented player, exactly the type we need if we are to overtake Rangers," he said. "I know he has had the occasional problem in Scotland. That news travelled down to England but I want to speak to him myself before I make any judgments."

Viduka's international captain Paul Okon has passed a medical at Middlesbrough and is expected to sign from Fiorentina at the end of the month on a Bosman free transfer. The 28-year-old midfielder was a team-mate of Boro's goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer at Marconi and has also had spells with Bruges and Lazio.

Boro are also hoping to complete a £3m deal for Real Madrid's French midfielder Christian Karembeu, who reached a preliminary agreement with the manager Bryan Robson after being shown round the stadium and training ground. Nothing will be finalised until after Euro 2000.

 Terry Venables has been offered £1.3m a year to manage Libya's national team.

Nothing will be finalised until after Euro 2000.  Terry Venables has been offered £1.3m a year to manage Libya's national team.

webTitle: Celtic nations consider joint bid for Euro 2008

fields.headline: Celtic nations consider joint bid for Euro 2008
fields.trailText: Discussions have begun between officials of Scotland, Wales, the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland about the possibility of launching a joint bid for Euro 2008.
fields.body:
Discussions have begun between officials of Scotland, Wales, the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland about the possibility of launching a joint bid for Euro 2008.

David Taylor, the chief executive of the Scottish Football Association, discussed the subject with his Irish counterparts at last Tuesday's friendly between Scotland and the Republic of Ireland in Dublin.

Hampden Park will stage the Champions League final in 2002 but apart from the national stadium and the grounds of Rangers and Celtic, respectively Ibrox and Parkhead, Scotland has no other stadiums that satisfy Uefa's requirements. Unless there is major redevelopment at several other grounds, including Hearts, Hibs, Dundee United, St Johnstone and Kilmarnock, a joint bid will be necessary to secure the tournament.

"When we were in Dublin in midweek, Irish officials broached the subject of the Celtic nations co-hosting the European Championship... in 2008," said Taylor. "We'd have to look at the other stadia and facilities and see whether we would have sufficient facilities on our own or need to co-host.

"If we make a success of staging the Champions League final it will lead to other major opportunities and provide a possible springboard to bigger events. But a downside of co-hosting with so many is that all of us would probably not be guaranteed a place in the tournament."

The Football Association of Wales is expected to agree to modify Mark Hughes's unsigned contract to allow him to play for two more years in the Premiership with Everton.

Hughes moved to Goodison Park from Southampton in March and signed a two-year contract. This was a year longer than the FAW decided to let its coach play on for when a 4-year deal, which remains unsigned, was agreed in December.

It now appears that the two sides have reached an agreement allowing Hughes to continue his managerial duties with the national team while playing for Everton.

"There is absolutely no problem with Mark Hughes. He will sign his contract, because he is doing an excellent job in rebuilding the side," said Phil Pritchard, the head of the FAW's matches committee.

Hughes is expected to retire from playing to concentrate on Wales once his Everton contract expires.

fields.headline: A family holiday in Cuba
fields.standfirst:
We are a family with children aged nine and 14 desperate to travel to Cuba in safety and a fair degree of physical comfort but avoiding all-inclusive resorts. We do love beach holidays but don't want to sit in a compound full of people like us! We want to experience Cuba and meet Cuban people but have fun, too, especially for our children. Any suggestions?
D. Heath
fields.trailText: We are a family with children aged nine and 14 desperate to travel to Cuba in safety and a fair degree of physical comfort but avoiding all-inclusive resorts. We do love beach holidays but don't want to sit in a compound full of people like us! We want to experience Cuba and meet Cuban people but have fun, too, especially for our children. Any suggestions?
fields.body:
 I suggest you avoid hotels and stay in casas particulares (private houses that rent out rooms and usually provide meals). You will eat far better than in hotels and see day-to-day Cuban family life. If you don't speak Spanish, it is well worth the effort to learn even some basics.

Safety is not a problem, assuming you take normal precautions - Cuba is one of the safest countries you can visit, certainly far safer than the UK. You have thousands of beaches to choose from, most of them deserted. If you want a beach resort near Havana then there are a number on the north coast within 60km - avoid Varadero. You can increase your options by hiring a car, which is relatively cheap.

Get a good guide book - Lonely Planet or Travellers Survival Guide are the most detailed - and spend some time in Havana.
Tim Ferguson

 We are an association of casas particulares. You can stay in one of our houses. You can share the house with a family with or without children or you can stay in an apartment on your own. It can be in old Havana, Vedado or anywhere around the island. Check the website at www.geocities.com/casaparticular
Carlos & Daniel

 We have just returned from a tour organised by Havanatour. We stayed in hotels at Las Terrazas (a rural area west of Havana), Havana and Trinidad. Safety was never an issue in our wanderings around both Havana and Trinidad.

Four-star hotels will give you all the physical comfort you could wish for, and the beach near Trinidad is a dream. You cannot help but meet Cubans. You will be incessantly hailed with "Where you from?", so you need some basic Spanish. They will be very friendly and intensely curious about you, even inviting you to their homes, but often after a dollar handout as well.

Avoid 100% tourist areas like Varadero. I can give more details if the questioner wants to contact me direct.
Brian Light
brilight@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: Devolve and thrive
fields.standfirst: The Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now they need to enthuse the public
fields.trailText: The Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly offer a useful lesson in comparative governance. Now they need to enthuse the public.
fields.body:
I didn't see any flags in the streets of Glasgow this week and according to the polls Scottish people are none too impressed by the first year of their new parliament. Its anniversary is worth observing none the less. Forget high-flown stuff about reconvening an institution that shut up shop in 1707 and look at the day to day performance. Coalition has worked (and allowed Scotland to break away on student fees). Backbenchers do a proper job in their committees. The Edinburgh parliament's style (including civilised hours of operation) puts the unmodernised House of Commons to shame. Whatever else gets written in Tony Blair's epitaph, it will say he shifted power away from Westminster. Irreversibly.

The doings at Holyrood and on Cardiff Bay have not exactly set news editors' hearts aflutter, except perhaps for the fight over section 28 (Clause 28, section 2a is the Scottish designation), and the deposition of Alun Michael. But that poses a risk that people in England will not profit from a lesson in comparative governance.

It is worth reading. If law-making is what legislatures are about, Holyrood can claim to have improved productivity. It has passed seven bills (including, finally, the abolition of Scottish feudalism) and has 11 statutes under consideration - not a bad record compared with the one to two specifically Scottish bills that used to be passed by the Westminster parliament each year. Edinburgh committees look at bills in advance. They have made an effort not to dance to the executive's tune, allowing Tommy Sheridan, the sole representative of the Scottish Socialist party, to secure his bill forbidding forced sales of debtors' property. They are holding inquiries on drugs and community care. The Labour-Liberal Democrat executive will find it hard to sideline them over housing stock transfers and council finance (a third of MSPs are former councillors).

In Wales, however, the complaint is that too much time has been spent with lawyers poring over exactly what the assembly's "secondary" powers are. There the relationship between executive and backbenches has not been settled.

Throughout the western world, confidence in public institutions has been sliding so the biggest question to be asked about devolution is whether the new setup has tickled the public's palate. The parliament's leaders have, with the exception of Donald Dewar and Jim Wallace, yet to become household names. But its poor press may not be MSPs' fault. The past year has been marked by atavistic antagonism of two of Scotland's leading papers, the Daily Record, part of the Mirror group, and Andrew Neil's Scotsman - owned by those famous Channel Islanders, the Barclays.

Perhaps press barons, multinationals and (a scandal blew up in Edinburgh earlier this year) lobbyists may find it easier to target small-country politicians. Besides, the parliament scored some own goals. The death this week of Enric Miralles, architect of its proposed new home, has probably not helped public perceptions of mismanagement - the building having started out at £40m but now is likely to cost some £195m. The Welsh assembly's new home will probably cost £30m and that is before a decision is made on physically separating legislature and executive - but Cardiff gets a splendid new building in return.

Yet the new arrangements have their pluses. The chart shows the high proportion of women involved. True, vested interests have been palliated (farmers in Wales for example). They have also been upset - Scottish lawyers do not like MSPs' interest in their appointments and practices. The style in both Edinburgh and Cardiff is participative, so much so that voluntary groups and churches, called in to give evidence, have complained of "fatigue". To make parliament work, says researcher Sue Innes, you need to "build capacity" in civil society, which might entail grants for interest groups so they can attend committee hearings.

The new bodies carry a few Westminster genes. Some 19% of MSPs have been MPs, 15% in Cardiff. But a self- sufficient political class is in formation, not just representatives but lobbyists, aides as well. A question becomes how far the best and brightest begin to see parliament and assembly as the summit of their ambitions, rather than Westminster (or Strasbourg). Cardiff's older guard has been cleared out. Plaid Cymru's Dafydd Wigley is retiring; Tory leader Rod Richard is unlikely to recover. Meanwhile Labour's Rhodri Morgan is carving out a niche for himself at some distance from Millbank. In Edinburgh the race to succeed recuperating Donald Dewar has quietly begun.

Ron Davies, the man destined to lead the new Welsh assembly but for an amble on the common, called devolution a process not an event. Right, the redistribution of power has not ended. The Welsh assembly will, probably after the elections due in 2003, press for more powers. The "B" word (Barnett) hovers over Holyrood, though surprisingly the parliament's allocation has not yet been called into question.

That is because MSPs have focused on practical, do-able politics. Ralf Dahrendorf, the social thinker, recently warned "defenders of democracy do well to remain cautious of regionalism". Small, more homogeneous units might attract authoritarians and become intolerant. So far there have been no signs of such a development. Banality has triumphed in the past 12 months but that is how it should be, in the establishment of an executive and legislature that work. As a result (to borrow Tom Nairn's phrase), Ukanian government looks a lot healthier now than in April 1997.

david.walker@theguardian.com

webTitle: Charting a course to a greener future

fields.headline: Charting a course to a greener future
fields.standfirst: Road to the manifesto
fields.trailText:
Road to the manifesto: Transport and Environment
Labour should be realistic enough to tell the public that Britain's transport system is seizing up - and there is nothing in the short term that can be done to improve the situation.
fields.byline: John Vidal, Paul Brown and Keith Harper
fields.body:
Environment

Environment may no longer be a core issue for New Labour, yet performance in this area explains why the government is perceived as being insufficiently radical, obsessively centralising, and an obstacle to new ideas. And why it is accused of failing to address the issues that most affect people.

The first problem is structural. Government is organised around narrow departments, yet almost all environmental challenges require several departments to work together. We need more of that much-vaunted "joined-up thinking".

There is also a cultural problem. The key government departments - trade, agriculture, environment - too often have, at their core, civil servants biased toward the old industries. They advise their political masters accordingly. We need a whole new approach.

 Renewable energy
A small group of Department of Trade and Industry civil servants has effectively strangled innovation in this area from birth. Other countries see these new markets as hi-tech and exciting but Britain pays little more than lip service. We should be following Denmark, Germany, France and the Nordic countries. They are racing ahead with research and giving tax breaks or advantages to already proven schemes.

Too often in the past 30 years Britain has let slip its lead in innovative industries. The solar industry is growing worldwide but Britain has no coherent programme despite the fact that our two biggest oil companies want to invest in it.

The government subsidises coal by £100m a year, yet turns its back on solar - a modern, hi-tech industry with massive local, global and export potential. We should follow other countries and commit ourselves to a programme, over 10 years, to install 100,000 solar roofs.

 Food
Britain can barely compete in today's world markets. We import huge quantities of organic food to satisfy a home market because the Ministry of Agriculture has failed to respond to the public mood.

Competition will become harder with new global trade laws and the enlargement of the European Union - making foreign industrial scale production of cheap food easier and more obtainable to supermarkets.

We should concentrate resources on producing high-quality foodstuffs, stimulating the organic industry to reduce prices, and employing more people in rural industries. We should commit ourselves to reaching 20% organic production within 10 years.

On GM foods, Labour is widely perceived to be too close to global agribusiness and not to be listening to consumers. It should review its policies, and call a moratorium for two years on further plantings while evidence is reviewed.

 Nuclear power
Nuclear is no longer a strategic essential. It is known to be a big long-term drain on resources. Yet Britain is the best equipped country in the world to spearhead the clean up of nuclear material around the world.

The government should renegotiate contracts with Japan, Germany and other overseas customers and opt for storage of nuclear fuel rather than messy reprocessing - an outdated technology supported by the government. It should invest any money it saves in renewable energies.

 Environment agency
The agency is overstretched and lacking resources. It needs to be beefed up and given real powers. Pollution fines are derisory. Company directors should be made personally responsible for pollution incidents.

 Planning
The countryside does not need to become tarmac and concrete; estates do not have to be built on flood plains. The water supply, as well as rivers and streams, needs protection from pollution and overabstraction.

Transport

Labour should be realistic enough to tell the public that Britain's transport system is seizing up - and there is nothing in the short term that can be done to improve the situation.

The party should admit that we live in an overcrowded island, and still our people want to travel more frequently, at home and abroad. It must try to satisfy their demand, provided that proper safety precautions are maintained.

Labour should also confess that the experiment in setting up a super department covering the environment, transport and the regions has not been a success and has blurred the focus of decision making. In its next term, transport should become a separate department again.

The public has been ahead of successive governments in wanting road and rail transport integrated, even as they recognise the love affair between motorist and car. No government can do much to prevent people using cars - not when official forecasts indicate that road traffic will rise by at least 75% in the next 30 years.

But the government can and should be clearer on what it is trying to do with transport. It promised swift action to clear up the mistakes of its predecessors, notably on rail, but quickly discovered that big changes usually mean investment in infrastructure projects, such as modernisation of the west coast main line, rehabilitation of the London Underground or construction of the Channel tunnel rail link. Or they mean huge planning delays, such as the decision on whether to go ahead with terminal 5 at Heathrow.

As a start, the government should draw up a checklist of public transport improvements to be achieved on a yearly basis, with spending details for each scheme.

John Prescott, transport secretary, has suffered badly in the past three years from the Treasury's penny pinching. He inherited a privatised railway for which financial guidelines until 2002 had already been drawn up. These were predicated on falling passenger use, whereas use has risen by more than 25% as Britons flee the congested roads. But investment has stayed static, reflected in a deteriorating service.

The next Labour government will have to maintain a reasonable level of subsidies to rail from 2002 to ensure that people are not dissuaded from using the railways. It should press for a national travel card interchangeable on bus and rail.

Labour's transport legislation gives sufficient authority to rail regulatory bodies to perform their duties. If the rail companies are to be offered new 20-year franchises they will need to be properly supervised and even taken over by the strategic rail authority should they fail to provide the services they have promised. But rail is such an important national asset that even an otherwise decentralising government should let the authority administer it and not devolve control.

Labour should accept that the fragmentation and privatisation of the railway has failed, and that the public will not tolerate another rail disaster. It should commit itself to reconsidering renationalisation of Railtrack if it fails to provide sufficient investment and relies increasingly on the government to prop it up.

Congestion and workplace charging remain good ideas but are taking time to implement. Labour should promise to assist local authorities in establishing local transport schemes, including traffic calming, while charges are introduced.

The road network will inevitably develop, and key sections of the motorway system will have to be widened, notably on the M25 and M6. But bus lanes must be introduced.

Labour should commit itself to at least one further runway at Gatwick or Heathrow, and back new routes from regional airports such as Birmingham, Leeds-Bradford and Luton.

Soon the report on a fifth terminal at Heathrow will be published. Britain cannot stand back and see other European airports, such as Charles de Gaulle and Schipol, stealing a march on one of our main economic assets. We need a world-class airport - and a world-class transport system.

What's needed

1 A national travel card, covering bus and rail.
2 More bus lanes on motorways.
3 Renationalisation of Railtrack if it fails to invest.
4 Two-year moratorium on all GM plantings, and full review.
5 10,000 solar power roofs installed in 10 years.

What happens next

Do you think we have got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? Write to our letters page, or join the debate at Road to the manifesto

 Next week defence and foreign affairs

Labour should commit itself to at least one further runway at Gatwick or Heathrow, and back new routes from regional airports such as Birmingham, Leeds-Bradford and Luton. Soon the report on a fifth terminal at Heathrow will be published. Britain cannot stand back and see other European airports, such as Charles de Gaulle and Schipol, stealing a march on one of our main economic assets. What happens next Do you think we have got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? fields.headline: Doctors reject government criticisms
fields.trailText: As ministers met at Downing Street today for a summit on the health service, the British Medical Association (BMA) took the opportunity to rebuff the government's "unnecessary attacks" on doctors.
fields.body:
As ministers met at Downing Street today for a summit on the health service, the British Medical Association (BMA) took the opportunity to rebuff the government's "unnecessary attacks" on doctors.

Last week's report on the disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward, who botched operations on hundreds of women but was able to continue in practice for 16 years, said that consultants were sometimes revered as "gods" and no one questioned their performance.

Health secretary Alan Milburn promised yesterday to end such anachronisms in the NHS and fundamentally reform the service: "What we can't have is a situation where the practices of a small minority of doctors tarnish the reputation of the whole medical profession." He singled out some senior doctors as among the obstacles stopping NHS modernisation.

Dr Ian Bogle, the BMA's chairman, said he was "gravely concerned" at Mr Milburn's comments, adding that ministers needed to work with doctors rather than against them. "The spurious notion that caricatures like Rodney Ledward are in every clinic is completely wrong. Ministers should recognise the enormous value they have in the British medical profession.

"If the government wants to get the best out of the medical profession, it should recognise that value, rather than denigrate it. Patients can and do trust their doctors. Talk of confrontation with the medical profession will produce an inevitable defensive reaction among doctors and is unnecessary at a time when we should be working together," he said.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants committee, said: "Looking at the hours that all my colleagues work, I don't think any of us deserve the comments we are getting from the government. I have just come off a week on call when I was working 12 to 14 hours a day. When you are up at 2am trying to help a patient survive, you don't feel very god-like or king-like."

Mr Hawker said that Rodney Ledward was a "one-off" scandal and doctors should not all be tarred with the same brush. "There may be one or two people who think they are kings but most consultants consider themselves to simply be team leaders.

"I think we are a thorn in the sides of the government which is when we can't give our patients the drugs they need, we stand up and say so and I'm sure that makes government administrators uncomfortable. There comes a time when you ask, what is the point in carrying on when all we get back is insults and assaults."

Later Mr Milburn insisted that his comments were not an attack on the work of consultants, but on poor practice in the health service.

"I think Peter Hawker understands that the government recognises that the overwhelming number of consultants do a quite brilliant job for the National Health Service, of course they do," he said this afternoon.

"I believe it is in the interests of the medical profession as much as in the interests of patients to ensure that the bad practices of a very few doctors do not tarnish the good reputation of the medical profession as a whole," he added.

Health ministers from Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland were all involved in today's meeting of the joint ministerial committee. The audit was expected to highlight structural weaknesses in the NHS, as well as under-capacity in hospitals. The absence of national health standards and professional demarcations were also expected to be highlighted as causes of the current problems in the NHS.

BMA leaders have been appointed to some of the six committees drawing up a national plan for reform of the NHS, due to be published this summer. However, there have been differences of opinion over the way of changing consultants' contracts and revalidation, where doctors will have to prove their continuing fitness to practise with annual appraisals of their performance.

fields.headline: The arithmetic of bias
fields.standfirst:
Too much still hangs on privilege

Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: Though he might not enjoy the comparison, Gordon Brown in 2000 is Harold Wilson in 1963. That was the year when the new Labour leader made the speech at a Labour conference in Scarborough which became famous for its promise of a new Britain, forged in the white heat of a technological revolution.
fields.body:
Though he might not enjoy the comparison, Gordon Brown in 2000 is Harold Wilson in 1963. That was the year when the new Labour leader made the speech at a Labour conference in Scarborough which became famous for its promise of a new Britain, forged in the white heat of a technological revolution. The main thrust of Wilson's argument, though, was his complaint that Britain was being held back by the flabby hand of the privileged, while people of talent born without such advantages were being repressed. "For the commanding heights of British industry to be controlled today by men whose only claim is their aristocratic connection or the power of inherited wealth or speculative finance," he said, "is as irrelevant to the 20th century as would be the continued purchase of commissions in the armed forces by lordly amateurs."

In an article in Saturday's Times, designed to disentangle the real issue from the unfortunate froth he created by building his first assault on the rejection of a single student by one Oxford college, Mr Brown made much the same case, arguing less from the precepts of social justice than in terms of economic efficiency - a very proper concern for a chancellor. "Equality of opportunity," he wrote, "is also an economic necessity." By denying thousands without the privileged background of private education their equal chance to get to the top, the nation, in Mr Brown's view, was not just acting unjustly, but reining back on potential success.

The Conservatives say Mr Brown is "attacking excellence" (Michael Portillo in the Observer yesterday) or denying the need for elites. Neither charge is accurate. The term elite is variously defined, but in practice it usually means quite simply those who have got to the top. What Mr Brown is questioning is whether some who might have got to the top in a differently ordered society have in practice been stifled by the system. It is one of the oldest questions in politics and one which always evokes the same complacent response from the forces of conservatism. The equation of existing elites with the triumph of excellence is an old and shabby device. You can trace its lineage from the reactionary clamour when in the 1850s Northcote and Trevelyan dared to suggest that civil servants should be recruited not on the basis of patronage but through competitive examination; or when army reforms put an end to the practice of buying commissions. Of course society has everywhere lightened and loosened up since those days - and especially since Wilson's call for the liberation of talent back in the 1960s. William Hague, from Wath-upon-Dearne comprehensive, is not Wilson's much savoured target, the 14th Earl of Home; Greg Dyke (Hayes Grammar) is hardly John Reith. And surely no previous princess royal would have given an interview to The Grocer.

Yet the best statistics available show how urgent it is for this case to be made once more. Today we report telling new findings from the Sutton Trust, based on admissions to the top 13, and particularly the top five, universities. They confirm that the field from which this country recruits its future elite is "extraordinarily narrow". An assessment in yesterday's Sunday Times, largely hostile to Gordon Brown, estimated that private schools, to which 7% of our children go, account for 80% of the judiciary, 80% of the highest ranks in the army, 40% of the diplomatic service and even for a third of Tony Blair's own life peers.

This is not simply an issue of smug discrimination, though that is still a substantial part of it. It is also a mark of how badly Wilson's aspirations and the measures he hoped would liberate locked-up talent have fallen short of fulfilment over the past four decades. The end of the 11-plus and the general adoption of comprehensive schools, which he saw as one of the mighty engines of change, has failed to deliver. The reasons for that need to come as close to the heart of Labour's new campaign as the imperfections of Oxbridge. Mr Brown was wrong to raise the issue of equal opportunity in the hasty way that he did: on the facts that have now emerged, he owes an apology to Magdalen and specifically to its senior tutor in medicine, and he ought to offer it now. But that in no way disqualifies the wider case he is making. Have we made progress since Wilson at Scarborough? Certainly. Have we come as far as we need to? Certainly not.

fields.headline: A-level playing fields
fields.standfirst:
Behind the 'elitism' furore lies a genuine problem. Top universities do take in too few from comprehensives

Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: Peter Lampl: Behind the 'elitism' furore lies a genuine problem. Top universities do take in too few from comprehensives
fields.body:
When I first put pen to paper I had no idea that publication of my report on university entry for the Sutton Trust would coincide with such a mass of class-ridden hysteria and publicity over the fortunes of one particular schoolgirl; and a general political dogfight.

Gordon Brown's intervention raised the issue of the unfairness of our entry system to the national headlines but it will be a pity if the wood gets lost in the trivia of the trees. The object of today's report is to bring different parties to work together to make the playing field of entry to our leading universities more level.

For the past week we have had a series of anecdotes of various students from both independent and maintained schools, of excellent calibre, who have been turned down by Oxford. It is regrettable that Oxford took the brunt of these attacks because it has done more than most to reform its admissions. Oxford published an access report last year stating clearly that entry should be closer to the ratio of high grades at A-level, one third independent and two thirds state. Its recommendations would go a long way to solving the issue.

This is not just an Oxbridge problem but a leading university problem. The latest figures from the Higher Education Funding Council (HEFC) show that 39% of young entrants at the top 13 universities come from independent schools. But on the basis of entry qualifications and subject mix these 13 universities should have admitted only 28% from independent schools.

The council's figures also showed that these universities are accepting 13% from the bottom three social classes when they should be accepting 17% - about a third more. Figures for the top five universities show an even more exaggerated pattern in favour of independent schools with 48% of young entrants from independent schools compared to a benchmark of 33%. The talent is out there in state schools waiting to be tapped. We believe the unfairness is caused both because a low proportion of suitably qualified less affluent students apply, and by inadequacies in the admissions system. So our report calls for major changes.

The playing field would be much more level if entrance depended on actual A-level performance rather than on predicted results. The present system favours those schools, both state and independent, which have a proven track record of top university success. This is something for the schools and universities to work out together.

The Sutton Trust has commissioned the National Foundation for Educational Research to run pilot tests to look at the possibility of introducing an SAT-type aptitude test. The government and some leading universities have expressed interest. We would regard an aptitude test as being useful in identifying high potential candidates who may be under- achieving academically as well as a complementary measure to be used as part of selection as is done in the US and Singapore.

Universities need to be helped with resources to appoint recruitment officers to get out to secondary schools and colleges in deprived areas and scout for talent. We are funding a recruitment officer at Mansfield College, Oxford, to attract more students from further education colleges.

We need to expand summer schools, such as we and now the government fund, at major universities directed at students from less affluent homes and from families with little or no history of going to university.

I do not mean to sound as if I am criticising the independent schools. They do an excellent job preparing their students for university. So much so that we would like to make the better independent day schools available to all who qualify, by a voluntary system of opening their doors to all the talents, fees to be paid (or subsidised) on a sliding scale. We have a successful pilot example of this running in partnership with the Girls' Day School Trust at the Belvedere School in Liverpool. Additionally we would like leading independent schools to act as beacons for top university entry in their areas and we are funding schemes at Dulwich College and Manchester Grammar school.

If such measures were adopted, we would see the imbalance each year eroded. In the past it has become worse despite the expansion of the university system. But how do we measure progress? For the first time the HEFC has provided us with benchmarks.

We need plans by the top universities - and I am encouraged by their initial response - to make measurable progress towards benchmarks in an agreed time frame. These are working guidelines, not laid-down diktats enforced by penalties. These are benchmarks not quotas. The statistics show that with proper recruitment and admissions procedures, leading universities are able to increase significantly the proportion of students from non-privileged backgrounds without lowering A-level entry requirements and without any form of positive discrimination.

 Peter Lampl is a businessman and educational philanthropist, who founded the Sutton Trust.

fields.headline: Top universities 'waste state school talent'
fields.standfirst:
Britain's future elite 'recruited from an extraordinarily narrow field' as pupils from poorer areas are ignored, says education charity

Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: Oxford and Cambridge are among 13 top universities wasting state school talent, according to a report published today by the Sutton Trust.
fields.body:
Oxford and Cambridge are among 13 top universities wasting state school talent, according to a report published today by the Sutton Trust.

"The field from which the country recruits its future elite turns out to be extraordinarily narrow," the report by the education charity says.

Peter Lampl, chairman of the trust, examined the intake of the students at what are according to unofficial league tables, the 13 top universities in the country: Cambridge, Oxford, York, Warwick, Bristol, Nottingham, St Andrews, Birmingham, Edinburgh, and Durham, and three London colleges, Imperial, University (UCL) and the London School of Economics. Even when their grades are the same, public school students are still considerably more likely than their state school counterparts to win places at the 13.

Independent schools achieve proportionately better A level results. The 7% of students at independent schools account for a third of the top grades at A level.

But the benchmark figures show even when that is taken into account there is unfairness against state schools students and those from poorer areas.

"Independent students have a considerable advantage over and above their level of achievement in accessing leading universities.

"We are not advocating that leading universities take pupils in relation to school population but at a minimum in relation to achievement at A level," the charity's report says.

Oxbridge takes roughly half of its pupils from state school, when state schools provide about two-thirds of top A level grades.

Children from independent schools account for 39% of the entry to the top 13 universities, when on their benchmark figure they should win 28% of places.

About 600,000 people leave the education system every year.

Of the 42,000 who leave in dependent schools, more than 11,000 go to a top 13 university. By benchmark results, only 7,800 should.

But of 300,000 children of the less affluent social classes, only 3,500 get in to a top 13 university. By the benchmark, 4,600 should.

Students are about 25 times more likely to get into a top 13 university if they go to public school than if they come from a lower social class. On the benchmark figure, that is about double what it should be.

Pupils among the less afflu ent social classes account for 50% of the population but only 13% of entry to the top universities.

Of the 200,000 pupils who live in less affluent areas, 1,700 get in to a top 13 university compared to 2,300 that should on the benchmark figure. "In other words, the chances are slim to none and lower than they should be," the report says.

For the top five universities - Cambridge, Imperial, Oxford, LSE and UCL - the figures are worse. There, 48% of entrants from independent schools compared to a benchmark of 33%.

"A number of studies suggest that it is far harder to get the grades you need to get into a top university if you are at a state school and are from a less affluent background than if you are at an independent school," the report says.

"So we should, in a more mobile society, be giving students from less affluent backgrounds a proper chance. The figures for those students should if anything be greater than the benchmark rather than less."

"The reputation of any university depends on the quality of their graduates and it is in the interests of top universities to draw applicants from as wide a variety of backgrounds as possible to ensure that they are admitting the most talented students."

But the trust also says it believes in admission on merit and does not believe in positive discrimination in favour of state schools.

"We believe the imbalance of entry to the top universities is due to two main factors: a low proportion of suitably qualified less affluent students apply and inadequacies in the admissions system which is in need of reform."

At schools with a tradition of top university entrance, pupils "will be encouraged to apply for the right course and university to maximise their chances of getting in and their predicted A level grades become a reliable source on which universities depend.

"Applicants from many comprehensives often do not know or think they are top university material and do not have access to the same information and contacts with these institutions."

fields.headline: Elitism row fuelled by study into university admissions
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited: elitism special report
fields.trailText: The row over elitism in education intensifies today with the publication of a report urging fundamental reform of a university admissions system that is shown to exclude state school pupils even when they obtain high A-level grades.
fields.body:
The row over elitism in education intensifies today with the publication of a report urging fundamental reform of a university admissions system that is shown to exclude state school pupils even when they obtain high A-level grades.

More than 1,000 students every year from the poorer social classes making up 50% of the population do not win the place at a top 13 university that their grades entitle them to. Among the top five universities, nearly 400 lose out, according to the report, based on official figures, by the Sutton Trust, an education charity.

In a letter to the Guardian today, Raymond Plant, master of St Catherine's College, Oxford, from 1994 to January this year, urges the university to move faster to increase admissions from from state schools.

He says: "Things are not getting better fast enough. It is not for us to defend privilege at the cost of excellence. It must be to advance opportunity in pursuit of excellence."

As a Labour peer, Lord Plant will be accused of weighing in behind his party. But he is a rare example of an Oxford insider criticising the university.

The Sutton Trust report, written by its chairman, Peter Lampl, urges top universities to set targets and a timetable for increasing state school entry, and recommends the publication of A-level results before universities select their students to prevent bias.

It proposes two US innovations: the use of scholastic aptitude tests to be used in conjunction with A-levels and the recruitment of talent scouts to unearth bright students from less privileged backgrounds.

The elitism row exploded when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, attacked the decision by Magdalen College, Oxford, to deny Laura Spence, a comprehensive pupil, a place to read medicine. She then won a bursary to Harvard.

But in an article for the Guardian today, Mr Lampl comes to Oxford's defence. "It is regrettable that Oxford has taken the brunt of these attacks because this university has done more than most to reform its admissions".

webTitle: The best satanic scene: The ninth gate

fields.headline: The best satanic scene: The ninth gate
fields.trailText: Antiquarian bookseller Dean Corso (Johnny Depp) pores over a leather-bound 17th-century copy of rare occult tome The Nine Gates Of The Kingdom Of Shadows, as collector Boris Balkan (Frank Langella) stands by a window, gazing out at the skyline.
fields.body:
Antiquarian bookseller Dean Corso (Johnny Depp) pores over a leather-bound 17th-century copy of rare occult tome The Nine Gates Of The Kingdom Of Shadows, as collector Boris Balkan (Frank Langella) stands by a window, gazing out at the skyline.

Corso pauses at a Latin inscription beneath an engraving.

"Silence is golden."

Balkan turns to face him.

"Precisely."

He turns back to the window.

"Ever heard of the De La Demonica?"

"Yeah," Corso shrugs. "I've heard of it. It's a myth, isn't it? A book reputed to have been written by Satan himself."

Balkan exhales slowly.

"No myth. That book existed. Torchia actually acquired it."

He paces the room.

"The engravings you're now admitting were copied by Torchia from the De La Demonica. They form a kind of Satanic riddle. Correctly interpreted, with the aid of the original text and sufficient inside information, they're reputed to conjure up the Prince of Darkness himself."

Corso glances up from the text.

"You don't say."

See also: Bedazzled, Rosemary's Baby, Race With The Devil, South Park: Bigger, Longer And Uncut

Don't see also: End Of Days, Angel Heart, The Devil's Advocate

Pointless trivia: Frank Langella is the long-term partner of Whoopi Goldberg

fields.headline: Passing, Passes and Passed over
fields.trailText: DEFENDING THE INDEFENSIBLE
fields.body:
DEFENDING THE INDEFENSIBLE

It's a fact - Tony Adams is England's defensive daddy. Nobody in their right mind would go into England's opening Euro 2000 game against Portugal without him, and it's unlikely that Kelvin Koogan will leave him out either. But not everything smells of roses at the back, and a big decision still has to be made - who should play alongside him?

A few months ago, most people would have said Sol Campbell. But the man at the centre of a Tottenham defence which ships goals quicker than you can say "and George Graham has a hand in this?" has been systematically ruining the collective confidence of England's back four for a while now, and his display in the Malta match was the last straw. According to rumours seeping out of the England camp, he'll make way for Martin Keown a week today.

The Arsenal defender isn't counting his chickens, though. "You can't worry about whether you are in or not," he said today. "That will do no good to anyone. People ask if I will worry on missing out... but we will have to wait and see what the manager is going to select, and you just have to hope that you are in the team." The Fiver reckons he's got nothing to worry about - he's been solid and dependable, and nobody in the squad is on a hotter goalscoring streak. Apart from Richard Wright, of course.
