HACKED DOWN

Uefa have at last acted to crack down on the scourge that threatens to ruin Euro 2000 before it has even begun. Yes, European football's governing body has eliminated the possibility of factually-inaccurate match reports and clichéd 'colour' pieces by refusing to allow internet sports journalists accreditation to this month's tournament. Apart from the journalists who are producing Uefa's own website, that is. It's lucky the Fiver's planning to cover the whole tournament from its bed.

Journalists without freebies? Why, it's like journalists without alcohol. But if you can stop your tears of sympathy for one minute, the Fiver will explain the situation. Sportal, who produced the rather smart official Uefa site, are one of the 'title sponsors' of Euro 2000 (ie: they've paid Squids10m in "cash or services in kind" to get two seconds to annoy you after every ITV ad break). Uefa say that, because they decided upon broadcast rights back in 1993 when the internet was simply a twinkle in Martha Lane Fox's eye, there is not enough space in the grounds to dole out passes to internet hacks. Yet Sportal have managed to chance upon 40 of them.

In perfect idiomatic English, a Uefa spokesman told the Fiver "I dunno" when asked how it had found room for 40 people where none had existed before. But he went on to claim that Sportal's accredited journalists will only be allowed to produce articles for Uefa's site, not their own, and that internet broadcast rights for Euro 2004 will be sold separately. Which, if true, means that Sportal's Squids10m will have bought them nothing but a bit of PR and the chance to stymie their rivals. No doubt Lord Beaverbrook will be turning in his grave.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I honestly don't think there is one outstanding team in Euro 2000. Some people say Holland, some say France and others go for the Czech Republic" - Kelvin Koogan attempts to convince his friends in the press that England have the toughest group in Euro 2000.

GUUS LEAK

As soon as Celtic realised their season was over (ie: mid-October), they started making seductive eyes at moustachioed managerial maestro Guus Hiddink. The only trouble was, Guus was already in a settled relationship at Real Betis, and didn't appear to want to leave the Primera Liga for some footballing backwater. At least he didn't until Celtic chief executive Allan MacDonald started whispering sweet nothings into his tash, promising him as many Liverpool reserve players as he liked, and even wowing him with tales about the size of his "big club". Finally, after months of persuasion, Guus decided he wanted in - but when he rang Celtic to tell them, all he got was the soulless tone of a disconnected phone line.

It was only after Martin O'Neill's appointment last week that Guus finally realised he'd been jilted - and being the open-minded Dutchman he is, he wanted to know why. "We were in a long, long way and then I don't know what happened," he admitted earlier today while gazing wistfully at some wilted tulips on his mantelpiece. "They haven't phoned me or talked to me since then," he continued. "We had the plans made. I had all the players ready on paper. The honour bestowed upon me in the offer to coach was one of the highlights of my career, and I don't know what happened."

What happened was that mad Martin O'Neill made his first decision since 1996. And ever since, an unseemly posse of wannabee managers have beaten a path to Leicester chairman John Elsom's door. But sadly for Steve Walsh and Tony Cottee, it has emerged that Elsom spoke to Gillingham's Peter Taylor at the weekend before he flew out to Portugal for a family holiday. Now the Fiver's no Morse, but the news that Taylor has refused to sign a new contract, coupled with Leicester's tendency to appoint managers from the lower leagues, must mean something. What do you think could happen soon?

www.breathe.com it's amazing what happens when you breathe

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal are hoping to wrap up their protracted £6m move for Robert Pires this week. "I await the final answer on Monday," revealed the French international. "All things being normal, it is OK."

The Gunners are also lining up a move for Franca, the 24-year-old Sao Paulo forward who scored against England at Wembley - but they face stiff competition from Paris Saint Germain.

Rui Costa has admitted that he wants to leave Fiorentina. "The moment has come to admit that I am ready to leave," said Rui Costa in an email to the press from the Portuguese Euro 2000 training camp. "I have been here for six years, five of those wonderful ones in which I have never doubted that Fiorentina is the only team for me until I return to Benfica to finish my career."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Dave Jones is set to argue his case against Southampton at a Premier League tribunal on June 21. The former Saints boss, facing 17 charges of child abuse later this year, was suspended from his post in February. Officials from the Dell claimed they were taking the step purely to allow Jones to concentrate his efforts on clearing his name, but Jones does not believe he should have been sidelined, even though he remains on full pay.

Fifa president Sepp Blatter has urged Uefa to move England's Euro 2000 clash with Germany from Charleroi to another venue. "I don't know this stadium," Blatter told German daily Die Welt. "I only know the Belgian government told Uefa that they had reservations. They must think about moving the match to another stadium and I am convinced they will reconsider their decision."

Franz Beckenbauer has claimed Germany will be "quite simply out of our depth" during Euro 2000 in an interview with Kicker magazine. "For the first time the German team does not have a real personality, not even Lothar Matthaus," said the Bayern Munich president.

Leeds midfielder Stephen McPhail has verbally agreed a new five deal at Elland Road just 12 months after signing a similar contract at the club.

Celtic star Eyal Berkovic will resist overtures from Turkish side Besiktas and stay in Glasgow, according to his agent Pinhas Zahavi. Berkovic has been linked with a move to Besiktas during the summer but Zahavi insists that the £5.75m-man is "very, very happy" with life at Celtic.

Brazil coach Wanderley Luxemburgo has rejected an offer from Barcelona to become their new manager. "An offer was on the table but the only thing on my mind is qualifying for the World Cup finals," Luxemburgo said.

Newcastle beaten competition from Valencia, Inter Milan and Everton to sign AB Copenhagen striker Peter Lovenkrands. The 20 year-old striker will complete a £1.25m move to Tyneside later this week.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: A Question of Sport Euro 2000 Special (7pm)

Stuart Pearce and Peter Beardsley attempt to be humorous and engaging. We'll leave it up to you to guess how they fare.

Channel 4: Cheer Up Kelvin Koogan (8.30pm)

Don't say that. He's got an irritating smile.

Channel 5: US Major League Soccer (4.30am)

The final of the Harvard Whining Oxbridge Reject trophy.

Sky Sports 1: International Football (7pm, 10.45pm)

The US Cup. Who needs Euro 2000?

World Football Show (12.30am)

Or 'Das World Football Show', as it's known in Germany.

British Eurosport: International Football (7.30pm)

We know this one. It's Holland v Poland.

Football (9pm)

Erm...

Football (11.30pm)

It's a game featuring a round ball, we know that much.

Radio 5 Live: Bogota to Beckham (7.30pm)

Something about tabloid journalism. We've already missed the first part, so to hell with it.

fields.headline: Nailbomber 'used net to build bombs'
fields.trailText: The man accused of the Soho nail bomb is alleged to have used instructions on the internet to make a device that killed three friends on a night out, an Old Bailey jury heard today.
fields.body:
The man accused of the Soho nail bomb is alleged to have used instructions on the internet to make a device that killed three friends on a night out, an Old Bailey jury heard today.

David Copeland, 23, allegedly planted the bomb in the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho, central London, which killed pregnant Andrea Dykes, 27, and friends John Light, 32, and Nik Moore, 31, in April last year.

Copeland is accused of having packed a plastic pipe with flash powder he removed from various fireworks which he sealed in with glue. This was put into a box surrounded by around 1,500 nails of differing sizes, from 6ins down, which acted as shrapnel.

The prosecution says Copeland also used a modified timer and two electrical igniters, powered by batteries, as detonators.

"Each was designed to be lethal and resulted from the defendant's use of two books he downloaded from the internet - The Terrorists' Handbook and How To Make Bombs Book Two," said Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting.

Copeland, an engineer from Farnborough, Hampshire, admitted to manslaughter at an earlier hearing on the grounds of diminished responsibility, but his plea was not accepted by the prosecution. He denies murder.

Mrs Dykes's husband, Julian, a 25-year-old computer programmer from Colchester, Essex, who was injured in the pub attack, sat at the back of the court as Copeland was led in for today's trial.

The court heard how Copeland had pleaded guilty to causing three explosions in the space of 13 days. Each bomb was of the same broad type and hidden inside a sports bag.

The first blast was at Brixton, south London, on April 17, and was followed a week later by an explosion in Brick Lane, in London's east end. These first two bombs caused injuries.

The third device, planted on April 30, caused death and destruction. Mr Sweeney told the jury there were at least 70 people inside the pub that Friday evening.

fields.headline: Violence at Euro 2000 'inevitable'
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Violence at the Euro 2000 tournament is inevitable because the government has dragged its feet over the introduction of new laws to control known hooligans, a leading football supporters' organisation said yesterday.
fields.body:
Violence at the Euro 2000 tournament is inevitable because the government has dragged its feet over the introduction of new laws to control known hooligans, a leading football supporters' organisation said yesterday.

Ian Todd, chairman of the National Federation of Football Supporters' Clubs, said the government had not gone far enough in its efforts to prevent known troublemakers travelling to the competition, being hosted by Belgium and Holland, starting on June 10.

It should have pressed ahead with plans floated last year to make international banning orders on people where there was evidence of them being involved in soccer violence, whether or not they had been convicted, he said. "It is inevitable there will be trouble at Euro 2000. The government is struggling to recover from a situation they made for themselves when they chickened out of introducing that legislation."

But Mr Todd welcomed a pledge by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday that known thugs will be turned back if they try to travel to Belgium and Holland. He said: "I think it is the best they can do in the circumstances."

Mr Straw, writing in the News of the World, said authorities in Belgium and Holland had been given the names of hundreds of people suspected of involvement in football hooliganism.

"They all risk a quick return if they try to travel to the tournament. Police will watch all our ports and airports and report the movement of fans to the police on the continent.

"Eurostar trains will have British transport police aboard, keeping an eye on fans travelling to Brussels."

His pledge came after the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said she was "distressed" at reports that up to 300 people convicted of football violence were free to travel to the Netherlands and Belgium despite being banned from games in Britain. She called for the government to extend domestic banning orders to cover internationals.

The Football Supporters' Association backed government moves to prevent trouble. Paul Thomas, FSA international coordinator, said: "I think the government is doing enough.

"We would not support taking passports from people who have not been convicted and I'm not clear what else can be done at this stage without prejudicing basic human rights."

But, while both the FSA and the National Federation of Football Supporters' Clubs said they would not object to extending the bans, neither thought the move a priority.

A senior Home Office source also dismissed the suggestion, saying legislation could not work at this late stage and that had the Tories wanted to help they would have stopped their own backbenchers delaying attempts to bring in new curbs on hooligans.

The source said British authorities were working closely with those on the continent and up to 1,000 known hooligans could be refused entry to Belgium and the Netherlands during the tournament.

"They all risk a quick return if they try to travel to the tournament. Police will watch all our ports and airports and report the movement of fans to the police on the continent. "Eurostar trains will have British transport police aboard, keeping an eye on fans travelling to Brussels." His pledge came after the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said she was "distressed" at reports that up to 300 people convicted of football violence were free to travel to the Netherlands and Belgium despite being banned from games in Britain. She called for the government to extend domestic banning orders to cover internationals. The Football Supporters' Association backed government moves to prevent trouble. Paul Thomas, FSA international coordinator, said: "I think the government is doing enough. "We would not support taking passports from people who have not been convicted and I'm not clear what else can be done at this stage without prejudicing basic human rights." But, while both the FSA and the National Federation of Football Supporters' Clubs said they would not object to extending the bans, neither thought the move a priority. A senior Home Office source also dismissed the suggestion, saying legislation could not work at this late stage and that had the Tories wanted to help they would have stopped their own backbenchers delaying attempts to bring in new curbs on hooligans. The source said British authorities were working closely with those on the continent and up to 1,000 known hooligans could be refused entry to Belgium and the Netherlands during the tournament.

fields.headline: Government criticised over Kosovo mission
fields.standfirst:
National Audit Office report: Kosovo: the financial management of military operations
MoD report: Kosovo: Lessons from the crisis
fields.trailText: The government was today sharply criticised by the Whitehall spending watchdog for failing to disclose the true cost of the Kosovo  Conflict, as the Ministry of Defence's own report said the Kosovo campaign had highlighted deficiencies in the armed forces' secure communications and  precision attack capabilities.
fields.body:
The government was today sharply criticised by the Whitehall spending watchdog for failing to disclose the true cost of the Kosovo Conflict, as the Ministry of Defence's own report said the Kosovo campaign had highlighted deficiencies in the armed forces' secure communications and precision attack capabilities.

A report by the National Audit Office said the additional cost to the taxpayer of operations in Kosovo was estimated to total £866m over five years.

The MoD has so far disclosed only the expected costs for the first year of the operation - put at £342m. Even these figures were not released until last January - six months after the end of the air war - despite a promise to parliament after the Bosnia conflict that it would in future publish cost details at the outset.

Nor did the MoD's figures include the estimated £50m cost of replacing used ammunition and lost equipment - including an RAF Hercules transport aircraft which crashed on take-off and 12 unmanned reconnaissance "drones". The audit office said the MoD should now report the full costs of the deployment in Kosovo to parliament "at the earliest possible opportunity".

The audit office highlighted a number of failings, in particular, a "real risk" that the RAF would run out of precision-guided "smart bombs" during the air campaign against the forces of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic. The RAF had only been able to keep going because bad weather over the Balkans meant many operations were cancelled and that a quarter of all sorties were aborted without the aircraft launching their weapons.

In addition, Royal Navy Sea Harriers on HMS Invincible found that within two months more than half their stocks of Sidewinder air-to-air missiles were "unserviceable" due to the heat and vibration sustained during take-off and landing, the audit office said.

The report also criticised the six-year delay in supplying the army's new secure Bowman radio system, which meant that Serb forces and even the media were able to "listen in" to their ageing Clansman radios. The Clansman was so unreliable the paratroops in Kosovo found that at any one time up to 35% of their radios were in need of repair and unit commanders had to resort to mobile telephones.

The lack of an effective communications system meant that at times the only working systems were the normal civilian systems and commanders found that they had to compete with the media to "get on air".

Moreover, troops had to spend the cold Balkan winter, with sub-zero temperatures, in tents because of a five-month delay in a £113m contract to provide prefabricated accommodation.

The MoD's own report, Kosovo - Lessons from the Crisis, was also published today. It found that some equipment was below standard, surveillance and intelligence gathering could have been improved, and British aircraft on precision bombing raids were affected to a surprising degree by bad weather.

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon insisted that the military campaign overall had been an outstanding success but said that more money would have to be spent if the shortcomings were to be addressed.

"Nato was right to have acted in Kosovo," Mr Hoon said. "Nato successfully achieved its objectives, averting a major humanitarian catastrophe and enabling 1,300,000 Kosovans to return home. The UK's armed forces played a key role. Our armed forces and civilian support personnel performed superbly. "For any military operation, and particularly a multinational operation of the size and complexity of the Kosovo operation, we examine the lessons to be learned. Many have already been implemented and work is in hand to improve our secure communications and precision attack capabilities.

"The determination of the Nato allies was essential to our success and now we need to work together to ensure that the lessons we have learned are implemented."

webTitle: The truth about Alan Shearer and Mystic Meg

fields.headline: The truth about Alan Shearer and Mystic Meg
fields.standfirst: Out-of-form England players; Shearer and Mystic Meg; the link between Malta and EastEnders; and much more...
fields.trailText: Out-of-form England players; Shearer and Mystic Meg; the link between Malta and EastEnders; and much more...
fields.body:
You'll get a wider view of the Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com
See how you score with fantasy share trading and you could win a 28" wide screen TV at www.breathe.com

EUROTALK

"We are capable of defending our title successfully, not because we will make spectacular progress but because the other teams are not better than we are" - Franz Beckenbauer after Germany beat the Czech Republic 3-2 on Saturday, their first victory since November. Can anybody spell Tutonic Eficiency?

THE EURO-TORIAL

With under a week to go until the start of Euro 2000 in Holland, Belgium and the telly, the votes are in. Every pundit worth their salt - not to mention those who would be better off covered in salt and put in the oven for an hour - has named their preferred England side. Kevin Keegan hasn't, but you can get a pretty good idea of what it will be simply by thinking of the players you'd least like to see singing the national anthem in Eindhoven next Monday.

Phil Neville seems certain to play at left-back despite turning in a total of 0 impressive performances for his country. Keegan's preference for 4-4-2 means Phil's brother Gary will line up on the other side of the pitch, where he has been out of form for some time now. Sol Campbell also appears to be simultaneously playing himself into a bad patch and a place in the first team. Further forward the problems are less manifest, but Paul Scholes hasn't shown himself over the last couple of weeks and Alan Shearer - while winning a lot of good free kicks - isn't doing a lot else.

Now all of these players mentioned are players with the necessary experience at this level. The Nevilles, for example, have been playing European football since they needed a note from their parents and, at the tender age of 25, Campbell has won 33 caps for England. So to play them all may be pragmatic - it'll be what everybody else is doing, after all - but it'll mean watching England will be at best bloody dreary, at worst unbearably painful. Kevin Keegan should do himself a favour, and let Harry Harris pick the team.

NUTRITIONAL SUPPLEMENT

There were over 100 pages of Euro 2000 preview in yesterday's papers, in which Zlatko Zahovic was named as Slovenia's player to watch no less than seven times (wonder why that might be). However, only the News of the World had the foresight to ask Mystic Meg for her views on the England squad. Apparently Alan Shearer "roars with Leo attack and is starred to find his old fire and brilliance. He'll even be moving faster, too." Now that's spooky.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi! I'm Karel Poborsky. You may remember me from Euro 96 - my sensational displays for the Czech Republic had a host of top clubs battling for my services. I eventually signed for Manchester United, where I set the Premiership alight with my scintillating... hold on... where I tripped over my lank hair a lot before being roughly manhandled onto a plane bound for Portugal by an exasperated Scotsman.

Anyway, I'll be bringing you the latest Euro 2000 transfer gossip every morning, starting today!

Manchester United want to sign Marcel Desailly. The Chelsea defender thinks the move would be a "dream".

Derby are interested in Norwegian defender Andre Bergdølmo, according to Planet Football.

Toodle pip!

EURONEWS

Maltese defender Darren Debono claims England's Alan Shearer broke his nose during the friendly between the two countries this weekend. "Look at me, Shearer did this," Debono told several newspapers. "When I came off the pitch my face was so bad my little boy looked at me and cried." Long-term addiction to Shearer is believed to have caused similar problems for former EastEnders star Danniella Westbrook.

Italy's Gianluigi Buffon will miss Euro 2000 after breaking his hand in a friendly. The goalkeeper was injured whilst trying to save John Carew's headed winner in a 1-0 victory. Buffon was expected to be first-choice keeper for the Azzuri this summer, but it is now unlikely that he will even be able to offer relief.

Peter Schmeichel scored his first goal for Denmark this weekend, coolly converting a penalty in a 2-2 draw with Belgium. Sources close to the former Manchester United star suggest this is not the first time Schmeichel has successfully picked his spot.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: A Question of Sport Euro 2000 special (7pm) Stuart Pearce and Peter Beardsley exchange banter. How the programme will fly by.

Channel 4: Cheer Up Kevin Keegan (8.30pm) Watch Scotland beat England but lose but remain happy.

EUROCONTACT

If you want to contact the Euro, email the.boss@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Sarah Cracknell: The singer
fields.trailText: The singer on her 1970 Porsche 911T: Its official colour is antelope (a bit pretentious but funny) - milk chocolate brown in other words.
fields.body:
What do you drive? A 1970 Porsche 911T. Its official colour is antelope (a bit pretentious but funny) - milk chocolate brown in other words.

What does it say about you? People say it suits me because I wear a lot of brown. What do you like about it? I got it at a good price because of its colour. I assume other buyers turned their noses up, but I think it's an edible colour. The only negative thing is that it has a dog-leg gearstick which took an age to learn.

Why did you buy it? It's fast and has a great shape, a classic design - the best Porsche made.

What kind of driver are you? Safe. When I was learning, my dad told me to assume everyone on the road was an idiot. That has stuck with me.

Any bad habits? I keep a dictaphone between my legs while I write songs in the car. I suppose that's dangerous.

Any driving test tales? I anticipated the emergency stop too soon, causing the examiner to hit his head on the windscreen. I failed.

What was your first car? A Citroën 2CV. It burst into flames on the M4.

Ever crashed / got a speeding ticket / got any points, etc? I've had lots of speeding tickets. I forgot the speed limit on an open road in Florida. There was no one around except for the police hiding in the bushes. They pulled us over; when my passenger got out to explain, we suddenly had a gun pointing at us.

Ever experienced road rage? I was being hassled by a flash Audi and when my passenger flicked the Vs we were chased. He cut across us to stop me, then kicked the passenger window in.

Have you ever had sex in a car? I did once in the back of a van at a beach party. I didn't realise that the van was gradually going down a slope towards the bonfire. Everyone knew what I was up to!

What music do you listen to on the road? Nothing. I love the sound of my engine too much.

What's your dream car? I recently drove a Mercedes Pagoda 230SL with the roof off and was impressed.

Who would be your dream passenger? Matt Dillon. I've always fancied him. I was staying in the same hotel as him once and bumped into him in the lift. He invited me out for a drink with his friends but I was too dumbfounded to go.

Sarah Cracknell sings in Saint Etienne. Their new album Sound of Water is out now.

fields.headline: Pop off the tops
fields.standfirst: They're lousy on fuel, handle badly, and leave you with flies in your teeth. But hey, convertibles are fun. Now summer's here,  Simon Hacker  checks out the pick of the bunch
fields.trailText: They're lousy on fuel, handle badly, and leave you with flies in your teeth. But hey, convertibles are fun. Now summer's here, Simon Hacker checks out the pick of the bunch
fields.body:
As well as being thief-friendly, convertibles weigh more than their hard-topped equivalents, use more petrol, cost more to insure, and are structually weaker so they handle like warm lettuce. But last year 43,653 people eschewed the modesty of tin roofs; and the market for wind-in-hair, flies-in-teeth motoring sits solidly at around 3% of new UK car sales.

So why do people want them? Precisely for all these reasons, says automotive trend analyst Steven Jacobs. "It's a sybaritic thing - a cabrio sends out a message that you can afford the implied costs. Even if the hood is up, it signals that you're a fun-loving driver."

Jacobs' argument might explains why the only diesel drop-top you can buy in the UK is from Quantum, a maker of Ford-based kit-cars. Diesel Car magazine says its readers often ask why they can't buy a non-petrol cabrio. Spokesman Mike Orford explains: "Derv and open-topped driving are accepted on the continent - both Audi and VW sell the combination, but you'll never see it here because UK drivers have a bizarre attitude. They automatically accept that cabrio driving is nothing to do with sensible, low-cost motoring."

If you're undeterred and feel you must join the al fresco set, the good news is that the choices are getting more exotic and less mainstream. Along with Vauxhall, Mitsubishi, Nissan and Citroën, Ford no longer offers a hooded option and, while a few of its rivals muster soft-top derivatives of their own chief sellers, the options are as sexy as sequinned wellies. So if you're serious about your purchase, it's better to go for a purpose-built cabrio.

webTitle: Army blocks government role for Fijian coup leader

fields.headline: Army blocks government role for Fijian coup leader
fields.standfirst: Troubled South Pacific island faces political deadlock as military chief refuses to grant rebels' latest demand
fields.trailText: As Fiji's political impasse enters its third week, the signs are that both sides are hardening their positions, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
Fiji's military rulers today signalled their growing impatience with coup leader George Speight, telling him that he could not be part of a new government.

As the island's political impasse enters its third week, the signs are that both sides are hardening their positions. While the military ruled out a role for Mr Speight, the businessman-turned-rebel-leader threatened to hold his hostages for "as long as it takes" for the army to change its mind. Mr Speight had been widely expected to release some 30 hostages at the weekend until the military balked at his escalating demands.

Mr Speight and several gunmen seized prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry and the entire government on May 19, demanding a new constitution that would prevent Fiji's ethnic Indians from leading the country. Since then he has issued one demand after another. The military has agreed to most of them but has drawn the line after Mr Speight demanded to be part of a new government.

The military, which declared martial law last week, said Mr Speight and his supporters could not have any power. "We have stated that this is impossible," Commodore Frank Bainimarama said, adding that "we will not entertain any more demands from George Speight and his men."

The military has offered amnesty to Mr Speight and six others who seized the government. Cmdr Bainimarama said the rebels should accept the "easy way out." Fiji's military ruler said Mr Speight could not end up in control of Fiji "for one simple reason - there's been a lot of talk of backlash, not only by the local community but by the overseas community if any member of George Speight and his team is a member of the interim government."

Mr Speight, who has the backing of members of Fiji's special forces, refused to attend talks with the military today and said it was now up to the military to approach him. The developments make it unlikely that the 30 hostages being held in the parliament building will be released in the immediate future. "I can wait here for as long as I have to," Mr Speight said.

In an interview with CNN, he portrayed himself as a Fijian patriot who was being treated unfairly. "The army is trying to paint me as a rebel and a terrorist, even though I'm a Fijian," Mr Speight said. "The public's support of me will be made clear to the army in the next few days, and I'm confident it will come around."

But in a sign that international pressure is making itself felt, Cmdr Bainimarama said Fiji would face huge problems with its trading partners if Mr Speight or his rebels formed part of the government. The 15-member European Union has warned that it would stop buying any Fijian sugar - the tiny nation's most important commodity - if Mr Speight were to gain power, Cmdr Bainimarama said.

"The military line has been drawn and we have told Mr Speight and his group that beyond this we are not going to negotiate," a military spokesman said. "The hostages should be returned; weapons, ammunition returned and the military bring normalcy back to the whole country."

Although Mr Speight claims to represent all indigenous Fijians, many have rallied against him and expressed support for Mr Chaudhry's government - the first in the country's history to be led by an ethnic Indian prime minister.

Fiji's ethnic Indians control many businesses and Mr Speight wants to prevent them from running the country ever again. Trading partners including the United States, Australia and New Zealand have threatened to impose economic sanctions if Fiji doesn't return to democratic rule.

The 15-member European Union has warned that it would stop buying any Fijian sugar - the tiny nation's most important commodity - if Mr Speight were to gain power, Cmdr Bainimarama said. "The military line has been drawn and we have told Mr Speight and his group that beyond this we are not going to negotiate," a military spokesman said. "The hostages should be returned; weapons, ammunition returned and the military bring normalcy back to the whole country." Although Mr Speight claims to represent all indigenous Fijians, many have rallied against him and expressed support for Mr Chaudhry's government - the first in the country's history to be led by an ethnic Indian prime minister. Fiji's ethnic Indians control many businesses and Mr Speight wants to prevent them from running the country ever again. Trading partners including the United States, Australia and New Zealand have threatened to impose economic sanctions if Fiji doesn't return to democratic rule.

webTitle: Blair wanting change from the NHS pounds

fields.headline: Blair wanting change from the NHS pounds
fields.standfirst: The price of extra funding is Labour's demand for speedy reform of the health service, says the Guardian's political editor, Michael White
fields.trailText: The price of extra funding is Labour's demand for speedy reform of the health service, says the Guardian's political editor.
fields.body:
Tony Blair may be the kind of Oxbridge public schoolboy his chancellor of the exchequer sometimes deplores. But, like the public school environmentalists who rioted in Whitehall on May Day, he is one of the iconoclastic kind who has no time for established ritual and entrenched interests.

The prime minister's impatience at the pace of change shows in his support for Gordon Brown's attack on university admissions, albeit less colourfully expressed. It is evident in his old boss Lord Irvine's attacks on their fellow-lawyers and in David Blunkett's assaults on the "forces of conservatism" in education - which includes teachers and their unions.

This week it is evident in Monday's Downing St summit - a meeting between health ministers from all four home countries - as well as in Alan Milburn's Downing St-backed campaign to get better value out of every NHS pound.

In a week when consultant Rodney Ledward was found to have disgraced his profession with his high-handed mistreatment of women patients over many years, this also gives Milburn an chance to get better contractual arrangements out of NHS consultants, still the dominant figures in British hospitals after more than a decade of management-driven reforms.

What is going on? Mr Blair and Mr Milburn realised last winter that public disappointment with the NHS was dragging the government down. Hence the extra billions which Mr Brown produced - ahead of his July timetable - from the comprehensive spending review.

But in return for an extra £13bn a year - 35% in real terms on the NHS budget - by 2003-4 ministers want better value for the taxpayers' money. That means getting the majority of hospitals to perform as well as the best. "If everyone was as good as the best, we wouldn't have a problem," Frank Dobson used to say.

To achieve that means a mixture of changes: better techniques, medical and managerial, better use of the cheapest and most effective medicines, more flexible working practices which give nurses more responsibility to do what junior doctors used to do.

All that frees up cash and doctors to achieve what fashionable Whitehall jargons calls better "outcomes". Note that word, not "outputs" which was Virginia Bottomley's way of counting "patient episodes" ( the number of people seen) when she ran the Department of Health.

As with schools, jobs, transport and crime, Blair is interested in results and "outcomes" means healthier people. So he appointed a minister to try and tackle ill-health further "upstream", ie before people get sick, though - I note from a Hampshire hospital last weekend - it still hasn't stopped hospitals having vending machines full of salty, sugary junk.

There is talk that when the NHS National Plan (England only) is published next month it will include ideas like the 24-hour "elective surgery" factories and emergency hit-squads to tackle waiting times which (ministers now admit) are more important to most voters than the waiting lists which Labour's 1997 manifesto promised to cut by 100,000.

It has been done - last month - but has cost a lot of money and goodwill. Ministers are learning. They want to reward hospitals which do well with more cash and autonomy.

They have a National Patients Access team designing better ways to ensure "one-stop shops" at hospitals so that we don't go in four times when one journey could see all tests done on the same day. They want better cooperation between health and social services over handling old people whose illnesses "bed block" NHS wards.

The list is endless and Blair and Milburn know that voters are beginning to get impatient. If they fail, they will risk losing the initiative on cash and efficiency to the advocates of EU-style insurance or - far worse - the US market system which, a report found only yesterday, costs twice as much and produces inferior results.

Yesterday's summit saw ministers from the four home countries - including Sinn Fein's Barbara de Bruin - exchanging notes and ideas. Now there's progress of sorts.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
* Last week's cover story about the new editor of the News of the World prompted a fascinating exchange, beginning with a letter to the Guardian readers' editor. A teacher at a Cheshire school writes to inform us that, for all the time Rebekah Wade attended, it was a comprehensive, not a grammar school as we stated. It's a fair cop, we'll correct it, we said. But Ms Wade's office was not at all helpful. We appeal directly to you, Rebekah, was it a comp or a grammar? There's nothing to be ashamed of, we're all friends here. As the teacher writes: "You can rest assured that she is, for good or ill (and I wish her well), a product of the comprehensive school system."

*Reports reach the diary of extraordinary shenanigans over the new series of OK!TV. Producers Carlton and the celebrity mag fell out so badly after the first series that GMTV was finally signed up as substitute at the end of last week. It seems OK!'s sales didn't rise as owner Richard Desmond expected, although he shelled out all the costs for access to stars. Worse still, ONdigital - partly owned by Carlton - failed to jump at the chance to screen his soft-porn Fantasy channel as a quid pro quo. And the final straw, bringing to a head TV frustrations with Desmond's thriftiness, was a big row over a £10 taxi fare to shuttle tapes around. Now GMTV, under its gritty director of programmes, Peter McHugh, has been brought in, because ITV believes that "Desmond doesn't know how to do TV - yet". He wants to make OK!TV as an independent production from a studio within his London Docklands offices, handily vacated by Fantasy. Except, says GMTV crisply, "it's not up to broadcast quality. We're there to make sure it looks like an ITV programme."

*More trouble for GMTV? The BBC's revamped Breakfast TV programme, which will be shared with News 24, is expected to start in October, after the Sydney Olympics conclude. But rumour has it that BBC1 controller Peter Salmon, bursting with public service duty, wants it to end at 8.30am rather than 9am, so he can switch into more attractive lifestyle programming early and get a head start on ITV. Meanwhile, Anthony Howard's Times column - pompously arguing that adults don't watch TV at daybreak because the Today programme suits the British public's morning habits best - has had them choking over their sticky croissants at the breakfast station. What are those 2m-plus couch potatoes doing at 8am then, Tony?

*All change in the world of showbiz hackery: since the Mirror's Matthew Wright announced he was giving up his column, speculation has been rife concerning the identity of his successor. The diary can reveal that it's successors, not successor: Wright's deputy Polly Graham, the Telegraph's entertainment reporter Jessica Callan and the Star's Eva Simpson are being teamed up to form a glamour trio to rival the Sun's rather less aesthetically pleasing Dominic Mohan.

*Regulators are getting ever cosier. While the seemingly doomed independent television commission produces new public consultation plans on a weekly basis, the radio authority and broadcasting standards commission are taking a different route. At a recent seminar on how to regulate the internet, the two bodies were very much in evidence, lapping up the advice from Australian television authority deputy chairman, Gareth Grainger, that Australia's attempt to import detailed television-style monitoring doesn't work. The two bodies are due to announce a further entente cordiale tomorrow and are also working together on research into acceptable radio standards, ie how far loutish DJs can go. All part of a new "joined-up regulation approach" - otherwise known as survival tactics for endangered watchdogs.

*Special thanks from the diary to ex-GQ editor Mr James Brown and his IFG magazine empire, which last week sent a latex version of the enfant terrible's head on a stake to the Guardian's offices. We'll be sure to forward it to Condé Nast, as we know it's just what they've always wanted . . .

webTitle: 'It's a sad day for capitalism when a man can't fly a midget on a kite over Central Park'

fields.headline: 'It's a sad day for capitalism when a man can't fly a midget on a kite over Central Park'
fields.standfirst: Stephen Armstrong  on the world's greatest publicity stunts
fields.trailText: Stephen Armstrong on the world's greatest publicity stunts
fields.body:
Joely Richardson baring her back for Maybe Baby. Chris Evans sleeping with Geri Halliwell. Any Benetton poster you care to mention. Well, almost any rude ad you care to mention. All put together by media manipulators so that a lazy picture desk can fill a dreary newspaper. Oh, the joy of the PR stunt. You can't open your newspaper or switch on your telly without seeing them. It's so this century. Got a product? Get a stunt. That'll give you few column inches in the Daily Star.

Indeed, the ubiquity of the PR stunt means that at one point during Ken Livingstone's mayoral campaign no fewer than 14 separate companies or pressure groups had men dressed up as different animals following him around to shine in his reflected glory. And yet, for all this year's media flyboys' fancy talk, they ain't doing nuthin' that ain't been done before.

On July 5, Improperganda opens at Proud Galleries, London. The exhibition celebrates the noble art of shameless attention grabbing by the PR industry - the grown-up equivalent of those room-to-let ads that say "FREE SEX! Now that I've got your attention" - and it's a blast.

There are nurses sticking plasters on whales, a street full of 50 sofas, a pig standing for president, a flying lion, a trapeze artist swinging from a pair of pants, brothels for pets and men selling fridges to Eskimos. The exhibition is curated by PR stuntmeister Mark Borkowski, who got involved because of a man named Jim Moran. "Jim was a huge influence on this sort of stunt, and he did everything the PR industry is doing today in the US in the 40s and 50s at the advent of television, when the photo-op was becoming an element of the media," says Borkowski.

"Most of the time he came up with the idea, then sold it to the client. He died last year and not a single newspaper gave him an obituary, although I did come across a mention on the internet from a Seattle paper. I wanted to work on this as a tribute."

It was Moran who sat on an ostrich egg for 19 days, four hours and 32 minutes before hatching it to publicise the novel The Egg and I. He searched for a needle in a haystack for 10 days to promote a piece of real estate. He climbed from one horse to another in a Nevada river to urge voters to vote Republican after the Democrats had urged voters not to change horses in mid-stream.

And it was Moran who created the greatest soundbite the world has yet known. To publicise some bizarre product, Moran excelled himself in stuntland and tried to send an extremely short man up into the air above Manhattan's Central Park on a vast kite. Inevitably, the New York cops intervened and banned his foolhardy behaviour. An outraged Moran gave a press conference where he said: "It's a sad day for American cap italism when a man can't fly a midget on a kite over Central Park."

Moran's contemporaries included Harry Reichenbach, an equally unhinged publicist who once booked himself and his piano into the Ritz in New York. After four days, during which he ordered 50lb of raw steak from room service, a bell boy pointed out to a worried management that the strange guest's curious Chinese name might be significant. They broke into Mr TR Zan's room, found a live lion instead of a piano and, bizarrely, right after the story broke, the movie Tarzan was launched.

To sell September Morn, a very poor quality but faintly risqué picture of a woman standing in a lake, Reichenbach hired a gang of teenagers to gaze at it in a shop window then complained to a bishop about the picture's effect on the young. When the bishop turned up, he found idle youths wasting their days in contemplation of filth and started a moral crusade. Within a year, the artist was unable to meet demand, sailors were getting the woman tattooed on their forearms and a smart-arse entrepreneur had started selling tie-in dolls. Reichenbach took the job on a "no win, no fee" basis and was handsomely paid.

Improperganda tells the jaded media industry that it's all been done before. Joely Richardson flaunting flesh for Maybe Baby? Diana Dors floated down a Venetian canal in a backless number to boost her film career, courtesy of Theo Cowan at the Rank Charm School. "A lot of those American guys were using tricks that the Situationists and the Dadaists were using in art," explains Dan Brooke, head of marketing and development at Film Four. "They were the people who influenced us when we were working at the Paramount Channel."

Brooke was the head of marketing at Paramount who invented all the political stunts the comedy channel used to heighten awareness in 1997 and 1998. They followed Peter Mandelson around dressed as Dr Death with posters saying "welcome, Prince of Darkness". They built a mini-dome in his front garden. When Liam Gallagher slagged off the Rolling Stones, they hired karate experts in Mick Jagger masks to hang around Liam's house inviting him to fight. Liam bottled it and called the police.

Brooke's finest hour was the Tory leadership election. As Michael Portillo was unable to stand, he hired a load of actors dressed as Mexicans with posters saying "Portillo for El Presidente" and, complete with band and donkeys, laid siege to College Green outside the houses of parliament. A crazy Mexican appeared in every TV interview. For the second round of voting, ITN built a six-foot stage on the green to keep the clowns out of the picture, but Brooke went to the circus to recruit stilt walkers and kept the Mexicans in shot.

"It's very popular now," he says, "and it's getting harder and harder to be heard. We'd pay about £150 for our stunts then, but the price has soared now."

These days a stunt like that can set you back anything upwards of £15,000. When Freud Communications was hired by Pepsico in 1997 to publicise the fact that Pepsi cans were to become blue, it spent £2m to hire Concorde and paint it blue, taking the stunt to levels that would have had Moran gasping in awe.

"The stunt only works these days if there's a real story or a real strategy backing it up," says Patrick Keegan, a director of Freud Communications, which celebrates its 15th birthday this year. Its first client was Jiffi condoms, whose Freud-inspired slogan You'll Never Put A Better Bit Of Rubber In Your Wife was banned by Westminster council when it was used in a shop window. "A good stunt can put you on the news agenda if it's a slow news day and you seize the right opportunity," Keegan continues. "There's going to be loads of people trying to do Euro 2000 stunts, and someone always does something with strawberries and cream around Wimbledon, but that never gets any coverage. If you get that attention and you get it right, you have to have something to back it up with or people get wise pretty quickly."

Of course, people getting wise has happened before. Moran took a car around America looking for a wife and got the front page of Time magazine - although a newspaper reporter in the midwest wrote a feature about the stunt including the names of every single car manufacturer in the western world with the exception of the machine Moran was trying to shift. The authorities are wising up, too. The standard fine levied by Westminster council for a projection on a public structure such as a building or a bridge is now £20,000.

"That's a lot of expense to go for if all you're going to get is a picture in the Daily Star, so you need to be sure the media are interested before you embark on the stunt," says one PR man who wished not to be identified - probably because he went on to say, "after all, the Star will run anything. Where's the value in that?"

The depressing thing about the exhibition is the impression you inevitably take away that nothing in the news is real. In real life, of course, it's much worse than that. Did the woman teacher on the Challenger die for a publicity stunt, for instance? And if we're talking about Nasa, there's no need for a countdown when you're launching a space rocket. You know what time the beast is going up. The countdown was a Nasa PR man's idea to heighten tension for the TV broadcast. Ever felt cheated?

Improperganda is at Proud Galleries, 5 Buckingham St, London WC2 in July, (tel 020 7839 4942)

fields.headline: The next Friends or ER? The contenders
fields.trailText: Titans/The Fugitive/The Bette Show/Dark Angel
fields.body:
Titans

In a nutshell? A 21st century Dynasty, relocated to Beverly Hills. Former fighter pilot moves back in with industrialist father, who is about to marry his ex-girlfriend.

What's the buzz? From soap king Aaron Spelling (Dynasty, Melrose Place, Beverly Hills 90210), the standard-issue mix of money, sex and intrigue. But in the US it will be up against Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? and could take an early bath.

Stellar cast? Dallas legend Victoria Principal (above), ex-Baywatch beach babe Yasmine Bleeth and lantern-jawed hunk Casper Van Dien (Starship Troopers).

Where might it play in the UK? Channel 5, Sky One, Living.

The Fugitive

In a nutshell? TV remake of the hit movie remake of the, er, 1960s TV show about a murder suspect hunting his wife's one-armed killer while evading FBI pursuers.

What's the buzz? This was the most talked-about show of the screenings, not least because of the considerable amount of money - said to be at least $6m - Warner Bros threw at the one-hour pilot.

Stellar cast? Timothy Daly (Wings, The Object of My Desire) is Dr Richard Kimble, while black actor Mykelti Williamson (Forrest Gump, Three Kings, Con Air, Heat) takes the role of Lieutenant Philip Gerard.

Where might it play in the UK? BBC1, ITV, Channel 4, Sky One.

The Bette Show

In a nutshell? Bette Midler plays Bette Midler, basically, in a sitcom allowing the well-known comedienne to poke fun at her image, fans, looks and ego. Think Cybill, with a shorter, louder female lead.

What's the buzz? Joins long and successful US sitcom tradition of building an ensemble show around an established comedy star's public persona (see Roseanne, Ellen, and so on). Won praise from several UK buyers, but in the US is up against ratings behemoth Who Want to Be a Millionaire?.

Stellar cast? Bette Midler (above), obviously. Kevin Dunn plays her college professor husband and Joanna Gleason is best friend and manager Connie.

Where might it play in the UK? BBC2, Channel 4, Paramount Comedy Channel. JD

Dark Angel

In a nutshell? A genetically enhanced female escapes her military handlers and is hunted in post-apocalyptic San Francisco. Terminator meets Blade Runner.

What's the buzz? Titanic and Terminator director James Cameron's first foray into TV. The two-hour pilot is rumoured to have cost $10m.

Stellar cast? Jessica Alba (Never Been Kissed) plays the genetically modified lead, Max.

Where might it play in the UK? Sky One, BBC2, Sci Fi channel.

fields.headline: Situation (still) vacant
fields.standfirst: It's the best job in independent TV, and the salary is a cool £500,000. So why can't ITV find a new chief executive?  Maggie Brown  reports
fields.trailText: It's the best job in independent TV, and the salary is a cool £500,000. So why can't ITV find a new chief executive?
fields.body:
Nothing seems to be going right for ITV. This morning, its top power brokers sit down to thrash out what new concessions, if any, they will offer the independent television commission (ITC), to end the News at Ten dispute. But at this most difficult of times they are badly handicapped. After nearly seven months of searching they are still without a new chief executive to run the ITV network and finesse their case.

The job of heading up Britain's most popular network and giving it a fresh, brave vision is deemed so important that the right person could now probably name his or her price - but it carries an annual package worth £500,000. This is one of those rare media posts that automatically thrusts the holder into the public eye, and so should be ideal for ambitious advertising executives seeking to broaden their experience. The last person in the job, Richard Eyre, who won the case for moving News at Ten, did just that, and was on the short list to become director-general of the BBC. But the ITV companies have turned the process of filling the post into a Herculean, and very slow, labour.

What seemed like a great opportunity last autumn - when Eyre decided to move into Greg Dyke's shoes at Pearson Television (he joined at the end of January) and top headhunters Whitehead Mann were briefed - now seems a poisoned chalice. Some wonder openly whether an appointment can be expected by the end of the year, and speculate that the people best qualified could be those at the end of their careers, seeking a final two-year flourish before getting out.

ITV chairman Leslie Hill is to embark on the wearying process of a further round of interviews, including some with previously rejected candidates, in effect starting the process all over again. He says slow is good - that the post is so important it cannot be rushed, that having five or six meetings with a candidate is inevitable.

However, ITV initially wanted to make an appointment by early March. Hill is in this uncomfortable position because the person eventually offered the job, Peter Littlewood of Mars, finally turned it down last month, after much transatlantic to-and-froing. He has decided to stay in the US.

Meanwhile, several of the tiny band of suitably qualified British media figures - including Richard Hytner, chief executive of Publicis, Dominic Proctor, chief executive of Mindshare, and Simon Marquis, managing director of Zenith Media - have ruled themselves out. Aspects of the winnowing process clearly annoyed some of them.

Nick Phillips, director general of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, says: "The various leaks about who doesn't want the job have been very unfortunate in PR terms." Whitehead Mann's task soon became what another top headhunter calls "the brief from hell".

This is partly because, just as the hunt began in earnest, conditions changed drastically. ITV's new news-free prime-time schedule came under heavy political attack and critical review. The rapid growth of digital television challenged ITV's refusal to put its services on to Sky. And the proposed merger between Carlton and United - with Granada also signalling its expansionist ambitions - created a climate of uncertainty about ITV's eventual structure and who would really be running the show.

The more candidates examined the post, the more problematic it looked. The ITV network centre consists of a small group of powerful, highly paid executives who control and spend the budget for its main programmes. It also runs ITV2, the near-invisible digital platform, and handles legal, lobbying and strategic marketing issues. However, these tasks are conducted against a backdrop of huge tensions, as the various ITV power blocs jostle, seek to take over one another, and jealously protect their own brands. The London "split" - Carlton sells advertising on weekdays, LWT at weekends, and each tries to woo advertisers and programme funds from the other - provides built-in conflict.

As a senior ITV executive admits: "It's not a chief executive job in conventional terms. You are not accountable to shareholders. It's about being ITV's chief marketeer, a salesman. The horrible truth is that when a baron of ITV rings up to complain you have to keep the politics off the back of [director of programmes] David Liddiment." Another, more positively, describes the chief executive as being ITV's "presence", the front man who talks to the all-important advertisers, appears before select committees for a grilling from MPs, and calms regulatory disputes with the ITC.

"It's a strange job. but not a non-job," says Phillips. "It's the plum station so far as viewers and advertisers are concerned. They need someone imaginative to pull it all together." Whatever stresses ITV is under, the network still accounts for more than 60% of commercial television's revenue. But the selection process confirmed several candidates' fears that the job really involved juggling the conflicting demands of a small set of big egos.

All candidates had to appear before a nominations committee of four senior ITV executives - Malcolm Wall (United), Steve Morrison (Granada), Clive Jones (Carlton) and Donald Emslie (Scottish Television) - with Leslie Hill conducting a preliminary screening. There were delays in getting all four interviewers together, and some did not attend all the interviews, raising suspicions that the process was shambolic and that the real power of appointment lay elsewhere - with the three ITV barons, Michael Green, Clive Hollick and Gerry Robinson.

Another blunder was the selectors' failure to ask for advice from the heads of ITV's three main advertising sales houses, who interact daily with advertisers. This was odd, to put it mildly, since a large part of the ITV chief executive's time is spent keeping advertisers happy.

Life must go on for ITV, meanwhile, despite the embarrassing gap at the top. The summer should see the chief executive touring adland, touting the all-important schedule for autumn, ITV's most lucrative season. The network's marketing and commercial director, John Hardie, is standing in.

Already, much of the goodwill generated by Eyre, with his ingenious invention of peak-time targets to arrest audience decline, has evaporated. "What Eyre did was to say 'we're not going down with a sinking ship'. In a funny sort of way that appealed to advertisers," says a key observer. "He signalled that we will not give up without a fight. People will forgive a lot for leadership like that.The job is really about being the focal point for the whole [ITV] brand."

Phillips counsels optimism, arguing that the job's drawbacks are those that will increasingly come to the fore in modern media businesses: "ITV are not the only people in the world who have to balance competition one day with co-operation the next. It can be done."

fields.headline: My media: Celia Brayfield
fields.trailText: My idea of heaven is a new issue of House & Garden, a nice hot bath and a glass of chilled white wine.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I take the Times and Guardian. I also get the Sunday Times, because I feel I have to have a Sunday paper, although today's are so pathetic. I grew up in the age of really great Sunday papers - Harold Evans's Sunday Times and the Observer - papers that formed my whole way of life and thinking.

Magazines: I always read Private Eye. I really enjoy Prospect and the New Statesman. The Week I also enjoy, but I'm trying to live without it now. So much print, so little time. My idea of heaven is a new issue of House & Garden, a nice hot bath and a glass of chilled white wine.

Books: It's difficult to read books I like while I'm writing. I end up mopping up the writer's style, which can be catastrophic. I belong to a reading group, which is great for structuring your reading and letting people turn you on to new stuff. The book I've most enjoyed recently was Chocolat by Joanne Harris. I've had a Hardy period, an Austen period, and a French and Russian period. The biggest mistake of my holiday-reading life was Alan Clark's diaries - it was too heavy to hold up.

Film: I absolutely love films. Tom Cruise is a really interesting actor. I will go and see anything John Travolta is in - I am quite astounded by what he can do. I love Anthony Minghella's films. Also, Gone with the Wind and any Fred Astaire musical. I've seen The Magnificent Seven about 14 times - it's an extraordinarily good film.

Television: I was a broadcasting journalist in the real golden age of British television. The overwhelming majority of modern British television completely does my head in - it is so dumbed down. I spend a lot of time with the Paramount Comedy channel. There was a time when it screened Frasier, Father Ted and Drop the Dead Donkey together. That was good.

Radio: Largely in the car and in the kitchen. Radio 4 on Saturday mornings, Classic FM while driving, unless they get too syrupy.

Ads: I like all the ads I'm not supposed to like, basically the lager louts ads. Pity about the products.

Multimedia: Since my Psion crashed, I've been hesitant to replace it. Such a nightmare. My computer was custom-built by the lovely chap up the road. I work on it constantly. Heartswap was very difficult to write because it's a full-on comedy. I found an internet forum for writers enormously helpful.

Celia Brayfield's new novel, Heartswap, published by Little, Brown & Company, comes out on Thursday.

fields.headline: California scheming
fields.standfirst: Every year, Los Angeles hosts a crucial battle in British television's ratings war.  Jason Deans  watches on
fields.trailText: Every year, Los Angeles hosts a crucial battle in British television's ratings war. Jason Deans watches on
fields.body:
Only in Hollywood, where the entertainment business has absolutely no sense of shame, could this be possible. The TV remake of the blockbuster movie remake of the long-running 60s TV drama, The Fugitive, is once again the hottest property in town. The talk, whisper it, is that it could be the next Friends or ER.

Dr Richard Kimble has got that magical ingredient, the much sought after "buzz", courtesy of a time honoured industry ritual - the LA Screenings. This entertainment bun fight, where overseas broadcasters fight to the death for the hottest US import to take back home, is crucial to the making or breaking of a new series. This year, The Fugitive is undoubtedly the must-have show. A dead cert for a translation to British TV screens. It's just a question of which channel will triumph.

Every year, for a fortnight in late May and early June, hundreds of foreign programme buyers flock to Los Angeles to sample the latest televisual offerings from the major studios and a dwindling band of independent producers. The gathering takes place after the US networks have placed orders with producers for new shows for their autumn schedules.

For buyers from the BBC, Channel 4, Channel 5 and Sky, the job is a terrible bind, of course. Two weeks in a $250-plus-per-night Beverly Hills hotel, while being wooed by the world's most powerful media and entertainment companies? Awful. This year, buyers were treated to at least three lavish parties, thrown by Warner Bros, Universal and Paramount, with special screenings of new movies Dinosaurs and Mission Impossible 2. The British contingent also found time to play their regular football fixture against a US studios team. They lost 3-1. Try not to laugh.

The vibrant social side of the event has its professional uses, or so they claim, allowing buyers to pick up the buzz about hot shows, check out what the competition is up to and generally dip a toe into the LA entertainment scene.

In between the fun bits, the serious business of assessing the latest crop of shows goes on in darkened screening rooms on studio lots in Burbank and hotels around Beverly Hills. It is a gruelling schedule: this year British programme buyers will have watched full pilots or promotional clips of around 60 new projects set for an autumn or mid-season debut by one of the six US networks (NBC, ABC, CBS, Fox, WB and UPN) over a 10-day period. The stakes are high - nod off and you could miss the next X Files.

Jane Lighting, chief operating officer and head of TV and content at Flextech, was on her first visit to the LA Screenings this year and admits it is a long way to go to watch a bunch of shows she could look at on VHS cassettes back in London. "But it is incredibly useful to be able to see all the US productions coming up over 10 days," Lighting adds. "You can make comparisons, spot trends and generally find out who's hot and who's not."

In addition to the Fugitive remake, new drama on offer at the screenings included Ally McBeal executive producer David E Kelley's Boston Public, set in a suburban high school, and The Street, which revolves around a group of hotshot Wall Street traders, from Sex and the City creator Darren Star. Trendspotters will have noticed plenty of star sitcom vehicles (featuring the likes of John Goodman, Geena Davis, Bette Midler and Michael "Kramer" Richards) and a continuation of the 1990s paranormal theme, including an X Files spin-off, Lone Gunmen.

Obviously, spotting the potential hits is essential, but trying to avoid snapping up a show that gets cancelled by its US broadcaster after only a handful of episodes is equally important. As BBC controller of programme acquisition, Sophie Turner Laing, points out, there are a number of "death slots" in the US schedules, most notably against the US version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, which will be running four nights a week on ABC this autumn.

Some years a show emerges as a must-have for two or more channels and a bidding war ensues. In 1994, for instance, the BBC scored a notable victory by landing the X Files, but two years ago it lost out to Channel 4 in a bidding war for Sex and the City. "You prefer to wait until the autumn, to see how a show performs in the US," Turner Laing says. "But it's a competitive market and if the trigger gets pulled, you go for it."

There's another significant downside to leaping too soon. If an American acquisition fails to do the audience numbers in prime time, it can end up languishing in a late night slot where it will never find the viewers to justify the price tag. ITV suffered this unenviable fate with Millennium, from X Files creator Chris Carter, after outbidding the BBC for terrestrial rights in 1996. The show had everything: pedigree, buzz, style - but no viewers. ITV came a cropper again the following year with the Kirstie Alley sitcom Veronica's Closet, having beaten rival bids from Channel 4 and Channel 5.

In the past couple of years, British broadcasters have avoided getting into bidding wars, in part as a reaction against the costly failures of the mid-90s. This year, The Fugitive is the nearest thing to a must-have show. Most buyers praise the pilot's impressive production values and expect it to find a home on British TV, but are standing by to see what Channel 4 - which has a first look output deal with the show's distributor, Warner Bros - will do. But Channel 4 controller of acquisitions, June Dromgoole, insists the show is available to all comers, prompting speculation that Warner Bros may be holding out for a big money bid from another British broadcaster.

One development expected to provoke fierce competition between British buyers is the launch later this year of new Channel 4 entertainment service E4, which will be looking to pick up digital, cable and satellite rights to shows that Sky One and Flextech are also likely to be after. Dromgoole says E4 will be "competing in some areas" with Sky One, notably teenage, entertainment and drama programming. Another British acquisitions executive reckons the arrival of E4 will "make things quite awkward for Sky One", which has built a brand around showcasing the best US shows.

E4 has already nabbed rights to the second series of critically acclaimed US drama The West Wing, which premiered this year on Sky One, thanks to Channel 4's output deal with Warner Bros. That relationship should also enable Channel 4 to have its pick of the studio's 2000 offerings.

But Sky One has its own Hollywood ally in the form of 20th Cen tury Fox, a sibling News Corp subsidiary. Fox shows that Sky can expect first dibs on include Boston Public, James Cameron's Dark Angel and Lone Gunmen.

These days, however, even the most popular US shows rarely succeed in prime time on British terrestrial channels against home-grown opposition. It's a long time since Dallas and Dynasty ruled the ratings. Most British acquisitions executives come to the LA Screenings looking for one or two shows that can do a job hitting a certain demographic in a particular slot, usually in the early or late evening schedule.

Jeff Ford, controller of acquisitions at Channel 5, went to LA this year looking for shows that could attract the same male-skewed audience as the likes of Xena: Warrior Princess and Martial Law (cancelled, much to his chagrin, by CBS after two series). Ford picked up paranormal 13-parter The Others (a mid-season 2000 replacement already dropped by NBC) and has bids in on two other series, but was otherwise underwhelmed by what was on offer.

The Channel 5 executive has a low-budget, maximum impact secret weapon up his sleeve, however: the rerun rights to the original 120-odd episode version of The Fugitive, starring David Janssen as the wronged doctor Kimble. No fear of that being axed mid-season.
