Jane Lighting, chief operating officer and head of TV and content at Flextech, was on her first visit to the LA Screenings this year and admits it is a long way to go to watch a bunch of shows she could look at on VHS cassettes back in London. "But it is incredibly useful to be able to see all the US productions coming up over 10 days," Lighting adds. "You can make comparisons, spot trends and generally find out who's hot and who's not." In addition to the Fugitive remake, new drama on offer at the screenings included Ally McBeal executive producer David E Kelley's Boston Public, set in a suburban high school, and The Street, which revolves around a group of hotshot Wall Street traders, from Sex and the City creator Darren Star. Trendspotters will have noticed plenty of star sitcom vehicles (featuring the likes of John Goodman, Geena Davis, Bette Midler and Michael "Kramer" Richards) and a continuation of the 1990s paranormal theme, including an X Files spin-off, Lone Gunmen. Obviously, spotting the potential hits is essential, but trying to avoid snapping up a show that gets cancelled by its US broadcaster after only a handful of episodes is equally important. As BBC controller of programme acquisition, Sophie Turner Laing, points out, there are a number of "death slots" in the US schedules, most notably against the US version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, which will be running four nights a week on ABC this autumn. Some years a show emerges as a must-have for two or more channels and a bidding war ensues. In 1994, for instance, the BBC scored a notable victory by landing the X Files, but two years ago it lost out to Channel 4 in a bidding war for Sex and the City. "You prefer to wait until the autumn, to see how a show performs in the US," Turner Laing says. "But it's a competitive market and if the trigger gets pulled, you go for it." There's another significant downside to leaping too soon. If an American acquisition fails to do the audience numbers in prime time, it can end up languishing in a late night slot where it will never find the viewers to justify the price tag. ITV suffered this unenviable fate with Millennium, from X Files creator Chris Carter, after outbidding the BBC for terrestrial rights in 1996. The show had everything: pedigree, buzz, style - but no viewers. ITV came a cropper again the following year with the Kirstie Alley sitcom Veronica's Closet, having beaten rival bids from Channel 4 and Channel 5. In the past couple of years, British broadcasters have avoided getting into bidding wars, in part as a reaction against the costly failures of the mid-90s. This year, The Fugitive is the nearest thing to a must-have show. Most buyers praise the pilot's impressive production values and expect it to find a home on British TV, but are standing by to see what Channel 4 - which has a first look output deal with the show's distributor, Warner Bros - will do. But Channel 4 controller of acquisitions, June Dromgoole, insists the show is available to all comers, prompting speculation that Warner Bros may be holding out for a big money bid from another British broadcaster. One development expected to provoke fierce competition between British buyers is the launch later this year of new Channel 4 entertainment service E4, which will be looking to pick up digital, cable and satellite rights to shows that Sky One and Flextech are also likely to be after. Dromgoole says E4 will be "competing in some areas" with Sky One, notably teenage, entertainment and drama programming. Another British acquisitions executive reckons the arrival of E4 will "make things quite awkward for Sky One", which has built a brand around showcasing the best US shows. E4 has already nabbed rights to the second series of critically acclaimed US drama The West Wing, which premiered this year on Sky One, thanks to Channel 4's output deal with Warner Bros. That relationship should also enable Channel 4 to have its pick of the studio's 2000 offerings. But Sky One has its own Hollywood ally in the form of 20th Cen tury Fox, a sibling News Corp subsidiary. Fox shows that Sky can expect first dibs on include Boston Public, James Cameron's Dark Angel and Lone Gunmen. These days, however, even the most popular US shows rarely succeed in prime time on British terrestrial channels against home-grown opposition. It's a long time since Dallas and Dynasty ruled the ratings. Most British acquisitions executives come to the LA Screenings looking for one or two shows that can do a job hitting a certain demographic in a particular slot, usually in the early or late evening schedule. Jeff Ford, controller of acquisitions at Channel 5, went to LA this year looking for shows that could attract the same male-skewed audience as the likes of Xena: Warrior Princess and Martial Law (cancelled, much to his chagrin, by CBS after two series). Ford picked up paranormal 13-parter The Others (a mid-season 2000 replacement already dropped by NBC) and has bids in on two other series, but was otherwise underwhelmed by what was on offer. The Channel 5 executive has a low-budget, maximum impact secret weapon up his sleeve, however: the rerun rights to the original 120-odd episode version of The Fugitive, starring David Janssen as the wronged doctor Kimble. No fear of that being axed mid-season.

fields.headline: Selling the unsellable
fields.standfirst: Both Labour and the Conservatives have just appointed new ad agencies to prepare for the next election. But, ahead of his speech to this week's advertising congress in London,  Chris Powell  questions whether an ad ever changed a vote, while below,  Belinda Archer  previews the event
fields.trailText: Both Labour and the Conservatives have just appointed new ad agencies to prepare for the next election. But, ahead of his speech to this week's advertising congress in London, Chris Powell questions whether an ad ever changed a vote, while below, Belinda Archer previews the event
fields.body:
Remember when political parties and advertising agencies used to be frightened of each other? "Selling politics like soap powder" was felt to be an effective jibe against the Conservatives' use of professional advertising help (whereas now it might be taken as an accusation of unimaginative copy). For an agency to work with a leftwing party was seen by other clients as supping with the devil or, at the least, a corporate character flaw, while the suspicion of the left toward advertising was virtually boundless.

Well, over the past couple of months both Labour and the Conservatives have appointed new agencies after going through a shortlisting and pitching process just like any commercial client and no one has been shocked.

It was Margaret Thatcher who, I think unwittingly, changed attitudes. The appointment of Saatchi and the dramatic impact of the "Labour isn't working" campaign woke everyone up to the impact good advertising could have in electoral battles. (I say unwittingly because the agency was actually Saatchi and Saatchi Garland Compton. The brief had been to find an agency with plenty of good solid government advertising experience, which Garland Compton had. Mrs Thatcher must have been as surprised as everyone else with the outcome, especially as she is said to have argued that the poster would be seen as an advertisement for Labour as it had Labour and not Conservative in the headline). Indirectly, it was Mrs T who also changed attitudes on the left. Her proposal to abolish the Greater London Council led to the hiring of BMP and the imaginative posters that made the other side look silly and leaden footed. The campaign created a great majority against abolition and the realisation by the left that advertising could work for them too.

It can be difficult to remember just how far attitudes on the left have come. In the early 70s, stridency was the most used approach, epitomised by the "Out, out, out" and "Kill the bill" kind of demonstrators. It was not usually thought necessary to make messages interesting or relevant to their audience, nor was there any idea that the audience might be other than true believers who had merely dozed off. If they were given vast amounts of detailed information and shouted at loudly enough, the job would be done.

A health union, I remember, ran an advertisement (only in leftwing journals, of course) with the enticing headline "The filthiest sheets in Britain". Somehow you didn't feel the urge to read on. Denis Lyons, a leading PR adviser and left sympathiser called in to advise one union, discovered a letter from its general secretary to the editor of a national paper protesting at a story they had run that began, "While we expect no favours from the running dogs of capitalism . . ."

Advertising media schedulers were forced to exclude any papers with Tory views - thus severely restricting the possibility for conversion - as this was construed to be a donation to the proprietors. Party political broadcasts were largely talking heads of politicians, whose main interest and argument was over whose turn it was to appear and get the extra exposure. If they were feeling especially inventive, the format of the broadcast would mimic a current affairs TV programme (more recently, even John Smith had to be persuaded that Newsnight was not the most viewed programme on TV). Research was often seen as dangerous stuff. Michael Foot, famously, wouldn't allow it during the 1983 general election, relying instead on his ecstatic reception at political rallies as a guide.

Nowadays both parties use agencies very much as commercial clients use agencies, but the advertising is pretty different from commercial advertising because it is so adversarial. Brands don't slag each other off in the way that parties do, so why do politicians do it?

Of course they always have - the tone has actually moderated. The charges 18th- and 19th-century politicians threw at each other (and that US candidates still do) would be libellous by today's standards.

National elections are a two-horse race, so attacking the other side is a feasible strategy, which it wouldn't be in most brand markets. It's easier for people to think ill of politicians than for them to respond to promises, but mostly it is the shock-horror-drama of attack that makes it valuable to parties. For the same reason that an aircraft crashing at Heathrow is news and a thousand safe take-offs is not, the evil plans of the other side make good copy and your plans for more crèches do not. It is easier to work the troops into a lather for a fight with tales of the evils perpetrated by the enemy than it is by reminding them of the virtue of your cause, and much of the role of advertising in elections is to rally the troops and set the agenda for the fight.

However, there is attack that is really just empty slagging and attack that has content and bite. Labour's skill in the last election left little room for the Conservatives to frighten the electorate, so they talked of "new danger" and an evil red-eyed Tony Blair which had no effect other than creating a very large hole in their bank balance. In 1992 the Tory tax bombshell ad had effectively frightened some voters out of voting Labour by dramatically presenting (and exaggerating of course) Labour's plans to up taxes. In 1997 Labour effectively pinned voters' economic dissatisfaction onto the Conservatives' "22 tax rises" and won a huge majority mainly by keeping large numbers of fed-up Tory voters at home.

Focus groups always complain about knocking copy, occasionally regulators dream of stepping in, many politicians find it distasteful, but still it goes on, for the very simple reason that it works more effectively than the blandness inherent in the positive. Contrary to popular belief, the greater part of political speeches are given over to the positive, but you wouldn't think so because media coverage focuses on the dramatic and - bar amazing new promises - that is the attack on the other side.

Luckily for us all there are limits and these are imposed by what the British voter will stand. Gratuitous rudeness just doesn't work (remember how media attacks on Red Ken backfired when his appearances on TV showed him to be the south London boy from next door) and is demeaning to the perpetrators (at the last election, the New Labour New Danger campaign elicited the response "well, if that is the best they can say for themselves after 18 years in government . . ."). Attack needs relevance and content if it is to impress.

In putting together my talk for the International Adevertising Association (IAA) congress on this subject I wanted to pull together interesting examples of political advertising from around the world. It might just be me, but I could find nothing very interesting from the last few years. Could the genre be in decline?

The transformation of political attitudes to advertising has led to the internalisation of many of the tricks of the advertising trade by the politicians: regular focus group feedback, distillation of message, continuity of delivery and endless repetition to get it through.

What is the role of the agency now? From the "war room" at Little Rock, the Clinton campaign leadership would ring through their requirements to a copywriter who, armed with a pair of scissors, would cut up some newsreel, lay down a voice track and have that day's rebuttal or attack on air in hours. All the Democrats' work that I've been able to find in recent history, and on both sides in the current primaries, is deathly dull - no room has been left for agency input on strategy or ideas. In the UK there is still, happily, a penchant for bright ideas by the parties, but the relentless pressure of the short term threatens the grip on overall direction. Events crop up almost daily that seem to have the potential to derail; advisers, to be visible, must find threats each week and you finish up with a myriad of things to deal with.

Yet political change is tectonic. For instance, despite all the smoke and noise of political campaigning between the last two elections only two events made a measurable impact on public opinion - the ERM failure and Tony Blair's accession to the leadership. Reassuringly, despite all the talk of spin, it is still real and major political events that shape opinion and too much concentration on the minutiae of battle can be at the expense of the big picture. Big advertising ideas that really work come out of big strategic ideas and it's there that the politicians might need good agencies as much as on the ads for the daily battle.

Chris Powell is chairman of BMP DDB Ltd and is speaking on selling politics at the IAA conference on Wednesday. His book How the Left Learned to Love Advertising is available from BMP DDB,12 Bishops Bridge Road, London W2 6AA

The rattling of a stick inside a swill bucket?: Belinda Archer on the ethics of advertising

Is advertising ethical? Can it really be a force for good, or is it just the ill-disguised work of the devil? Should golden-haired, innocent little children be directly targeted with grubby commercial messages, for instance, and is there not something inherently immoral about a business that flogs people things they can't afford? This week, more than 1,400 adfolk from around the globe are converging on London to discuss such pithy issues at the 37th International Advertising Association world congress.

Throughout the week, leading non-industry names including Bodyshop founder Anita Roddick, Professor Germaine Greer and Nato's Dr Jamie Shea will be tackling various specific ethical topics such as the depiction of women in advertising, whether self-regulation is preferable to statutory controls and the social and human responsibilities of communications businesses.

But on Friday afternoon, delegates will gather for the Great Ethics Debate, hosted by John Hooper, chairman of the European Advertising Tripartite.

A panel of top European and US industry figures and critics will be led through the minefield of such all-encompassing issues as advertising's role in society, advertising to children and ethics in advertising.

To many, the two words "ethical" and "advertising" are mutually exclusive. But must they always trigger a snort of derision? In short, was George Orwell right when he said advertising is just "the rattling of a stick inside a swill bucket"?

Hooper is positive: "Being ethical means that you have professional standards of conduct and I believe that the advertising industry can hold its head up, proud that it has very high standards. Advertising people, for the most part, are solid citizens with high personal morality. They are not rogues and villains. Obviously, there are some who are, but the majority will always marginalise those and are very quick to jump on them."

Critics, of course, point to the fact that advertising can stimulate unnecessary consumption and acquisition - an immoral, if not positively dangerous, activity in poorer countries.

Some go so far as to say it directly causes environmental damage via its fancy commercials for cars, lashing out further at the general moral and economic harm of promoting lifestyles beyond most people's means.

Archbishop John Foley, president of the Pontifical Council for Social Communications at the Vatican, is one of the speakers at the conference likely to be taking such a stance.

Foley tells Media Guardian: "Advertising has to be responsible firstly to the truth and secondly to the human person. It shouldn't exploit the elderly, it shouldn't make people want things they don't want: it should be honest and helpful and those who engage in it should be more responsible."

The issue of advertising's role leads to another thorny topic which will be thrashed out this week by concerned international adfolk: what of advertising to children? This is a particularly tricky area in which all the perceived evils of the profession are crystallised. How can something which fills the heads of wide-eyed, innocent children with exploitative, "buy me" messages be condoned?

Elizabeth Lascoutx, director of the children's advisory review unit in America, a near-militant volun tary organisation which effectively polices kids' advertising and publicises any transgressors of its code, believes it is not a necessarily negative or immoral activity.

"If done properly and in conjunction with media-literacy training in schools, whereby children are shown how to think critically about it, advertising can be constructive in shaping them into informed consumers - something which is crucial in a consumer society," she says.

Others argue that it is impossible to "protect" children from advertising given that adult forms of it are present everywhere and therefore it is best to specifically tailor commercial messages towards kids so they can understand them better. Many of the recent toy crazes among children have also come about without the aid of advertising: Teletubbies, Furbies and even yo-yos all became soaraway successes among youthful consumers without being advertised at all. Most sweets aren't advertised either, they say.

"Children have been pestering their parents for years," says Brown, "but advertising is only one of the dimensions that kids are involved in. There's also peer group pressure in the playground, what they see in shops and on TV programmes. It is too easy to oversimplify the case and say that advertising encourages pester power."

As the adfolk pull off from the IAA congress in their Porsches and sink back into their first-class cabin seats, they might just find themselves considering the wider moral and ethical implications of their money-spinning activities. Unless Hooper is wrong and they are all rogues and villains.

fields.headline: The great outdoors
fields.standfirst: Behind the scenes at Europe's largest festival, Rachel Austin is helping to make it all run smoothly.  Dolly Dhingra  reports
fields.trailText: Behind the scenes at Europe's largest festival, Rachel Austin is helping to make it all run smoothly.
fields.body:
There's not much can prepare you for dealing with customers covered in cow dung or running round in the nude, but a degree in neuroscience is a particularly unusual training for working at Europe's largest outdoor festival. Rachel Austin, who describes herself as an "access coordinator" for the Glastonbury festival, thinks her degree from Nottingham university was probably as good a route as any - certainly, it convinced her not to be a scientist. "I had to do a year's work in pharmaceutical research, which made me realise I wanted to work with people rather than in a room full of test tubes."

And people she got: Glastonbury is licensed for up to 100,000 visitors. At the end of this month, the fields of a remote farm in Somerset will be packed with revellers who have come to see the 300 official musicians, as well as the several hundred other entertainers who descend on Glastonbury for the festival every year.

Austin lives in the same village as the founder of the festival, farmer Michael Eavis. "My mum spoke to Michael - we know him from the village - and she told him that there was no work around here for me. A week later he called and offered me a job. He's eager to employ local people and it's like a family business that has become enormous."

The festival is coordinated from two small local offices where, as Austin explains, "we are only just getting round to technology." As the festival approaches, workers move onto the site and are housed in Portakabins. Austin's main duties involve dealing with applications from market traders, organising hospitality and dealing with general inquiries. Passes have to be issued for both performers and traders, and during festival days Austin has a constant queue of people outside her office. "There are people outside, the phones are going manic and you've got people trying to blag passes. Everybody tries it on - there are always a few who get away with it. But those who really want to come pay for it," she says.

To do her job, she says, she needs a computer, a phone, a book and a pen - "and a can of Coke at my side to keep me awake. One week last year I worked 100 hours." She has no doubts that it is worth it, however. "None of us work for a professional wage but, at the end of day, a lot of causes benefit - our main beneficiaries are Greenpeace, Oxfam and Water Aid, and then there are lots of local charities who provide some hardworking volunteers."

There have been 20 festivals since the first event was held in 1970. Tickets then sold for £1 and included free milk from the farm. Today the price has risen to £87 and excludes the milk. Those who can't afford the price of a ticket can obtain a pass in exchange for mucking in with jobs such as litter picking.

"We don't worry about the weather," she asserts determinedly, "because it's going to be sunny!"

"I had to do a year's work in pharmaceutical research, which made me realise I wanted to work with people rather than in a room full of test tubes." webTitle: You can leave your top on

fields.headline: You can leave your top on
fields.standfirst: It's dated, sexist and, in an age of internet porn, pointless. But however much its detractors might want to ditch it, Page Three is here to stay, says  Roy Greenslade
fields.trailText: It's dated, sexist and, in an age of internet porn, pointless. But however much its detractors might want to ditch it, Page Three is here to stay
fields.body:
When I made the great cultural leap from the Sun to the Sunday Times, I was fascinated to discover that junior executives there had the home phone numbers of cabinet ministers. One of them spotted a page of my contacts book and was just as fascinated to see the numbers of Page Three girls. I can't remember now if we traded Michael Heseltine's weekend number for Sam Fox's private line. But when the story spread of my being on first-name terms with the girls - I think it took about 10 minutes - a lot of male colleagues found reasons to inquire after their health.

It seemed odd to me that non-Sun readers should be in the least bit curious about the models who parade their charms daily in the Sun and Daily Star. I imagined the whole Page Three thing to be a strictly working-class male obsession, a niche market that would gradually wither away. The editor who pioneered the concept felt the same way. Somewhat embarrassed at having started it all, Larry Lamb later thought it inappropriate. When he died a couple of weeks ago, inevitably and sadly it dominated the headlines of his obituaries.

As the years passed and raunchier alternatives became available, in the Sunday Sport and in magazines such as Loaded and FHM, I was sure it was only a matter of time before everyone realised Page Three was a waste of space. It proved to be wishful thinking. Successive editors of the Sun have toyed with dropping it, only to face a barrage of complaints. David Yelland, the latest incumbent, tinkered with the presentation instead. He dropped the silly, if sometimes amusing, captions and his photographers came up with a different way of projecting the models.

Like his predecessor, Stuart Higgins, he has also had to withstand the reasoned hostility of several of the Sun's female executives. They have argued less from a feminist perspective than a belief that publishing daily pictures of young women with bared breasts and wide smiles is an anachronism in the 21st century. Frankly, they have argued, there is no point.

But that, I'm afraid, is totally untrue. The Sun is hoist on its own petard. It cannot afford to get rid of Page Three. The Sun's existence, its very raison d' tre , depends on maximising sales, on satisfying its readers' appetites. The irony is, of course, that it stimulated those appetites in the first place.

In truth, Page Three has become an institution. It exists, in a sense, independently of the Sun. For many people, readers and non-readers, it is the Sun. The newspaper's editor, its journalists, even its owner, Rupert Murdoch, are powerless to do anything about it, however much they despise the need to go on providing it, and despite Murdoch's own prediction years ago that its time was almost up.

So ingrained has Page Three become in the national psyche that even the Sun's rivals feel confident enough to refer to it. Just last week two papers that have long scorned the Sun's nude pictures - the Mirror and the Daily Mail - ran big features about Page Three. The Mirror kicked off, interviewing Linda Lusardi, who, according to the writer, "became a household name more than 20 years ago" as a Page Three girl.

In other words, the Sun's greatest competitor was underlining the success of Page Three, endorsing its place in the nation's affection despite the fact that its own readers, by choosing the Mirror rather than the Sun, have turned their backs on it. There could not be more telling proof of Page Three's status. It was interesting to note too that Lusardi, whom I recall as a truly delightful person, will not be encouraging her daughter to take her clothes off for the cameras. "I have become a prude in my old age," she told the writer.

The next day the Daily Mail, noting how Lusardi's appearance and attitudes have changed, took up the theme by interviewing four other former Page Three models. I have this wonderful image of Mail editor Paul Dacre telling his executives at morning conference: "Cor, that Linda Lusardi looked great, didn't she? We ought to find out what happened to some of the others."

Who came up with the idea is irrelevant. Its significance lies in the fact that the Mail devoted two pages to women whose fame rests entirely on their having modelled for another paper.

None of this surprises Beverley Goodway, who has been the main Page Three photographer throughout its 30-year life span. "It's even more popular now than it used to be," he says. "It is the Sun's signature. You expect it to be there when you buy the paper."

Yvonne Paul, a Page Three model agent since 1970, agrees. "I booked 'em then and I'm still booking 'em today. New girls are contacting me all the time." She is disappointed about the loss of captions but likes the new style of pictures. Goodway says: "I think we've moved the style forward a bit with more fashiony pictures. And the website gets an amazing response." Indeed it does. Page 3.com is the UK's fourth most visited website, beaten only by the portals, with about a million hits a day. "The home of the great British babe" features picture sets of all the latest models along with golden girls down the years. The latest lure is Tara's "tiny pink panties" session.

Though some of the pictures might be considered a little too risqué to get into the paper, they are nothing like as sordid as the pornography widely available on the net. The site is full of inventive, if childish, material, such as the "Mag-nificent 7" which involves the use of a "magic microscope" so that visitors can "analyse every last little inch" of the models "because the beauty's in the detail". And the caption-writers deposed from the paper have the licence to indulge in some of their purple prose: "It is a source of pride that only the highest calibre ladies are admitted to the pantheon of beauty that is Page3.com. But when the wobbly lady warbles - we all have our favourites, do we not?

"Some feel a frisson of excitement at the mere mention of that siren of the south, Leilani. Others mop a bead of perspiration at the faintest whisper of Katie - the true angel of the north - while still others . . ." And so on. The rival Daily Star's website (megastar.co.uk, since you asked) is also very popular, boasting a "definitive babe barometer". The prize in a recent contest offered "a day out with Jade". All modern Page Three girls have a single name: I guess it makes them easier to remember.

So Page Three looks to have a long future in both the Sun and Star. But, ironically, that also threatens the future of the papers too. Despite the undoubted success of the topless pictures, they do restrict the papers' attempts to reposition themselves to win new, young readers. At the Star, that may not matter so much. It knows it has a niche audience and can afford to play up, or down, to it. For the Sun, it is altogether more difficult. Its sales are on the slide and it knows that it has to improve its content if it is to rebuild its circulation. Despite its website popularity, Page Three is really a symbol of its daring past. How can the paper move forward while it remains?

webTitle: Pick Barmby, Football Unlimited readers tell Keegan

fields.headline: Pick Barmby, Football Unlimited readers tell Keegan
fields.trailText: "Last September, I watched a video of qualifying for World Cup 1998 and laughed when I saw Nick Barmby had played for England as recently as the 1997 match against Moldova. How my attitude has changed," admitted Andrew Perrins in the aftermath of England's shambolic performance against Malta.
fields.body:
"Last September, I watched a video of qualifying for World Cup 1998 and laughed when I saw Nick Barmby had played for England as recently as the 1997 match against Moldova. How my attitude has changed," admitted Andrew Perrins in the aftermath of England's shambolic performance against Malta.

But he wasn't the only one to undergo a change of heart. Over the weekend we received another huge batch of emails from Guardian Unlimited readers outlining your ideal England team. In short, Barmby, 3-5-2 and Steven Gerrard are smoking hot, while the Neville brothers, Paul Ince and Alan Shearer are certainly not.

Is Nick Barmby really England's latest saviour/left-winger/left wing-back/play-maker? (*delete as appropriate). According to most of our recent emails the answer is a definite yes. Andy Dawson summed up your mood, writing: "I would play Barmby on the left-wing, especially after the way he played against Malta. He's the only player to have looked comfortable on the left in an England shirt for some time." Some of you went further, with Graham Lacey going as far to call him "the probable England playmaker."

For many of you the man who should give way is Steve McManaman. "Barmby has played himself into the team with two telling performances against Ukraine and Malta. His 100+ minutes showed he is a class player. Compare this to the McManaman's wafer-thin display against Ukriane. Please Kev, don't subject us to him any more," pleaded David Thompson.

There has also been growing support for Steven Gerrard, who is now neck-and-neck with Wise and Ince for the midfield holding role. According to Mark Atherton: "Gerrard gets the nod over Ince due to his outstanding club form and a belief that he will shine as the best young player in the finals."

But not everybody agrees. "Has Paul Ince suddenly become a bad player?" asked Michael Cruikshank. "All of a sudden the knives are out and people are trying to give Gerrard a chance ahead of him...that is diabolical. Ince has experience, tenacity and the mental toughness (he has played in Italy) that few others do. He gives us something in the middle of the pitch that others cannot. He has to start."

Finally (and perhaps predictability) Alan Shearer has received yet more stick after another lacklustre display against Malta. "Shearer has been in the side on reputation alone since Euro 96" wrote Justin Connolly, a view echoed by many. Even those who have picked him have done so reluctantly. "Shearer has to start the tournament at least, as he is our only forward who has scored a few goals at this level, and he can also score from set-pieces (which seems our only way of scoring at the moment)," wrote M.L.Collins.

Keep sending your England teams in to the.boss@theguardian.com - we'll have the results on Thursday.

webTitle: Clinton calls for 'partnership despite differences' with Moscow

fields.headline: Clinton calls for 'partnership despite differences' with Moscow
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton told the Russian parliament today that partnership despite their differences was the right course for the two countries, in a speech that won only lukewarm applause.
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton told the Russian parliament today that partnership despite their differences was the right course for the two countries, in a speech that won only lukewarm applause.

In the first address by a US president to the Russian duma (lower house of parliament), Mr Clinton said Washington and Moscow ought to be able to agree "each step along the way" towards developing defences against nuclear missile attack.

After disagreements yesterday between the US president and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin over Washington's proposals for an anti-missile defence system, Mr Clinton took pains today to stress the shared interests of the two countries.

"On many issues that matter to our people, our interests coincide," he said, adding that both countries had an obligation to focus on common goals. He also listed major differences between Moscow and Washington, including the missile defence plans and the cost of Russia's conflict in Chechnya. America and Russia were not destined to be adversaries, he said, "but it is not guaranteed that we will be allies".

The US president praised Russia's progress towards democracy and a market economy over the past decade and pledged continued support for its reforms.

His 45-minute speech drew polite but not universal applause from the audience of 400 MPs in Moscow. The ultra-nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky shouted at other duma members for applauding Mr Clinton, and told him to lift the blockade on Iraq, withdraw troops from Yugoslavia and not intervene in Russian affairs.

Boris Gryzlov, head of the pro-Kremlin Unity group, welcomed Mr Clinton's conciliatory language on the need for cooperation on the sensitive issue of arms control.

But Mr Gryzlov, whose faction is the second biggest in the duma after the communists, said: "It was wrong to mention the conflict in Chechnya in connection with Yugoslavia. The conflict in Chechnya is an internal affair of Russia, and in Kosovo they committed aggression."

Vasily Starodubtsev, communist governor of the Tula region south of Moscow, said: "Clinton spoke as if he were president of the whole planet, preaching to us how to live."

webTitle: Summits just aren't what they used to be

fields.headline: Summits just aren't what they used to be
fields.standfirst: President Clinton's performance at his last US-Russia summit is disappointing, says foreign affairs specialist Jonathan Steele
fields.trailText: Monday, 1.30pm: President Clinton's performance at his last US-Russia summit is disappointing, says foreign affairs specialist Jonathan Steele
fields.body:
It is a long time since summit visits by American presidents to Moscow were eagerly watched around the world. Bill Clinton's trip was probably the most low-key US-Russian meeting since fears of a nuclear clash were lifted by the end of the cold war: Clinton is a lame duck; Vladimir Putin is a new boy with no clear programme; Russia is no longer a superpower.

Yet, surprisingly, nuclear problems were still the main issue to be discussed because of the American defence programme, known as Son of Star Wars, for building a space-based system for shooting down incoming missiles.

Ironically, the plan has got Russia on the same side of the fence as most Nato countries and against the United States. They see it as an expensive system which will only start a new arms race.

If the US tries to hide behind a high-tech shield, then every country will demand the same. As Putin said at his press conference with Clinton, "We are against having a cure which is worse than the disease."

The big disagreement over the nuclear shield overshadowed the little disagreement over Chechnya. Many observers had hoped Clinton would raise this higher on the agenda, especially as it is a more immediate problem. Scores of young Russian conscripts are dying every month as well as Chechen civilians.

But the White House has decided that it is wrong to touch the new Russian president on his rawest nerve. So there were no strong words about the allegations of atrocities by Russian forces and the need for independent investigation.

Clinton was a little more forthright on the threats to press freedom in Russia, which have mounted alarmingly since Putin came to power. But here too the American president seemed anxious not to cause offence.

If this was meant to be the start of a new friendship, gentle exploratory tact might be the best watchword. But Clinton is leaving office soon. He seems to have decided to end his Russian summits with a whimper, not a bang.

Scores of young Russian conscripts are dying every month as well as Chechen civilians. But the White House has decided that it is wrong to touch the new Russian president on his rawest nerve. So there were no strong words about the allegations of atrocities by Russian forces and the need for independent investigation. Clinton was a little more forthright on the threats to press freedom in Russia, which have mounted alarmingly since Putin came to power. But here too the American president seemed anxious not to cause offence. If this was meant to be the start of a new friendship, gentle exploratory tact might be the best watchword. But Clinton is leaving office soon. He seems to have decided to end his Russian summits with a whimper, not a bang.

fields.headline: Second South Pacific coup
fields.standfirst:
Rebels have today attempted to take over the Solomon Islands less than three weeks after a similar coup in neighbouring Fiji. Derek Brown examines the underlying ethnic tensions in this supposedly idyllic tropical nation
Fiji special report
fields.trailText: Rebels have today attempted to take over the Solomon Islands less than three weeks after a similar coup in neighbouring Fiji. Derek Brown examines the underlying ethnic tensions in this supposedly idyllic tropical nation.
fields.body:
A second South Pacific island nation is in chaos after rebel forces seized the prime minister and took over key installations.

The attempted coup in the Solomon Islands came less than three weeks after a similar upheaval in Fiji, where racist rebels are holding the elected prime minister hostage.

The Solomons rebels, who appear to have been inspired by the Fijian uprising, struck swiftly in the early hours of the morning. They seized prime minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alua and are holding him hostage at an unknown location in the capital, Honiara.

Both rebellions have laid bare the ugly ethnic tensions underlying life in the supposedly idyllic tropical nations of Oceania.

In Fiji, the rebels claim to champion the 51 per cent indigenous majority over the 44 per cent minority of ethnic Indians. In the Solomons, the ethnic divide is more complicated.

Ninety five per cent of the 455,000-strong population are Melanesian by race, but are divided by bitter regional and linguistic rivalries (though the lingua franca is pidgin, the Solomon Islanders speak a staggering 120 different indigenous languages).

The rebel group which overran police stations and other key points this morning calls itself the Malaita Eagle Force (MEF). It claims to represent the Malaitan minority on the main island, Guadalcanal.

For more than a year, the MEF has confronted not only police and other security forces (the Solomon Islands have no conventional army) but also a second rebel group, the Isatabu Freedom Movement (IFM).

The IFM group has run a vicious, intimidating campaign to force thousands of migrants on Guadalcanal back to their native island of Malaita.

The confused and potentially bloody situation in Honiara has raised acute concern in Australia and New Zealand, whose governments are already alarmed by the near collapse of order in Fiji.

There were signals from the Fijian capital, Suva, this morning that the country's new military rulers are losing patience with the flamboyant rebel leader George Speight.

Speight's motley forces are holding some 35 hostages, including the elected ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry.

All the rebels' main demands have been conceded: the prime minister has been deposed, the constitution has been scrapped, and Speight and his cohorts have been promised an amnesty. But the military is digging in its heels over Speight's latest demands for a top job in a new government. Any such concession would be certain to prompt international trade sanctions, and this morning the martial law regime said the rebels must lay down their arms and release their hostages immediately.

fields.headline: Sumatran earthquake leaves thousands homeless
fields.trailText: A powerful earthquake and dozens of strong aftershocks struck the Indonesian island of  Sumatra last night, killing at least 58 people, leaving hundreds injured and thousands homeless.
fields.body:
A powerful earthquake and dozens of strong aftershocks struck the Indonesian island of Sumatra last night, killing at least 58 people, leaving hundreds injured and thousands homeless.

Widespread panic was reported in Bengkulu, a city of about 1.2m near the tremor's epicentre, as people dug through the rubble of ruined buildings in search of bodies and trapped survivors.

The Indonesian Meteorological and Geophysical Service said the quake, measuring 7.3 magnitude, hit at 11:29pm yesterday (1629 GMT) and lasted for several minutes, jolting people from their beds.

The US Geological Survey in Golden, Colorado, estimated its magnitude as 7.9. A magnitude 7 earthquake is capable of causing widespread and heavy damage in urban areas.

Ali Muchtar, Bengkulu health department chief, said 58 people were confirmed dead. Almost 500 people had been reported injured, 255 seriously.

A police officer in Bengkulu said the death toll was expected to rise further as volunteers and emergency workers searched through ruined buildings.

Witnesses said local hospitals were overwhelmed with injured people and were struggling to cope as few staff members had arrived at work. Doctors in Bengkulu treated injured people in an outside parking lot, fearing that aftershocks might bring down the state hospital, the official Antara news agency reported.

Electricity and water supplies had been cut, and many phone lines were down. Medical supplies were running low. The city's airport was closed because of damage to its communications equipment and passenger terminal.

"Many houses have collapsed, and the walls on bigger buildings have been fractured. I helped save three of my neighbours who were trapped under rubble," said Edy, a resident of Bengkulu, which is 60 miles east of the quake's epicenter.

Seismologists said the tremor was centred beneath the Indian Ocean, 400 miles northwest of Jakarta. A magnitude 6 aftershock hit 11 minutes behind the quake, and 53 smaller tremors were recorded before 6am today (2300 yesterday GMT), frightening residents and hampering rescuers, Indonesian seismologists said.

The quake, one of the strongest recorded in Indonesia in recent years, was felt across much of the western half of the archipelago nation, including the capital, Jakarta, and the neighboring island state of Singapore, where many residents fled their homes as the earthquake rattled high-rise buildings.

The US Geological Survey said the quake's epicenter was about 20.5 miles beneath the floor of the Indian Ocean, very shallow in geological terms. However, there were no immediate reports of a tsunami, a massive wave that can be caused by an earthquake or volcanic eruption. In December 1992, a magnitude 7 earthquake triggered a tsunami that killed about 2,500 people on Flores island in eastern Indonesia.

Indonesia, the world's biggest archipelago nation, sits on major fault lines and is prone to frequent seismic upheavals. In Jakarta, President Abdurrahman Wahid offered no immediate emergency response, saying instead that his government had to assess the problem.

fields.headline: The Titanic
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about plans to recreate the ill-fated passenger ship on the net
fields.trailText: 1. The Titanic could return to the high seas after South African millionaire Sarel Gous unveiled £500m plans for a new version of the vessel.
fields.body:
1. The Titanic could return to the high seas after South African millionaire Sarel Gous unveiled £500m plans for a new version of the vessel.

2. It will be a working transatlantic liner like the original, though trade may be affected by the ghost of the original, which rather famously sank on its maiden voyage in 1912.

3. The ship was believed to be unsinkable until it ploughed into an iceberg 400 miles south of Newfoundland.

4. To this day it lies at the bottom of the north Atlantic in two pieces. 1,500 passengers went down with it.

5. Enthusiast Mr Gous has announced plans to rebuild the liner several times before. In January 1998 he said a replica would sail out of Durban, South Africa, for the millennium.

6. Mr Gous is currently in talks with troubled Belfast shipbuilders Harland and Wolff, who made the original, to see if they can do an encore.

7. Recreating the Titanic is a competitive business. Another consortium hopes to have the ship in New York harbour in 2002, on the 90th anniversary of its demise.

8. The Titanic was built before air travel in the golden age of the passenger liner. The Queen Elizabeth (constructed in 1938) was the world's largest liner until it retired in 1968.

9. James Cameron's 1997 movie Titanic revived popular interest in one of the most famous tragedies of the modern age. The film won several awards.

10. The first Titanic movie came out in 1915, directed by Italian Pier Angelo Mazzolotti. Josef Goebbels was behind a 1943 version which told the story as a piece of Nazi propaganda.

fields.headline: Experience by Martin Amis
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to Martin Amis's memoir Experience
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Critics either love or hate Martin Amis, and reviews of his memoir, Experience, had plenty of both. Julie Burchill's attack in the Spectator was so spectacular that it became a mini-news story in its own right, emphasising the fact (acknowledged in the memoir) that writing and celebrity are now inseparable in Amis's life.
fields.body:
Critics either love or hate Martin Amis, and reviews of his memoir, Experience, had plenty of both. Julie Burchill's attack in the Spectator was so spectacular that it became a mini-news story in its own right, emphasising the fact (acknowledged in the memoir) that writing and celebrity are now inseparable in Amis's life.

"What a clogged-up, clod-hopping, plate-juggling great show-off he is," wrote Burchill, "and what a relief it is not to have to read his books any more in case you get laughed at down the Soho Brasserie." (If Burchill prefers not to read Amis's books, shouldn't that perhaps disqualify her from judging the writer's life?)

Her conclusion was particularly brutal: "In the tragedy of Lucy Partington's death and Amis's clumsy attempt to co-opt it as part of a Writer's Own Story, we see the great flaw that runs through all of his work and ends up here naked and unadorned; namely that a lightweight mind attempting to grapple with heavyweight matters is one of the most wretched spectacles metropolitan life has to offer. If only he'd stuck to writing about smoking, shagging and snooker, on the other hand, he might even have been the next Nick Hornby."

Oddly, Hornby was also in the thoughts of William Sutcliffe, who poked rather laboured fun at Amis's pretensions in the Independent on Sunday. "In Experience, Amis seems to have set out to show that what Hornby did for football, he can do for dentistry," wrote Sutcliffe. "Amis's attempt to communicate his passion for dental suffering [did he really want to suffer?] is so desperate that at times you almost feel as if you are reading a mock-heroic satire on a novelist obsessed with his teeth. While I do not doubt the pain that toothache can bring, a more self-aware man would have realised that this simply isn't dignified. Bravely struggling against disease can make for a moving and uplifting memoir, but bravely struggling against toothache is never going to lift you into the pantheon of stoic heroes."

Sutcliffe felt decidedly short-changed: "Despite the insistence of his blurb-writer that this is an autobiography, Amis is curiously reticent about himself and his life. Four hundred pages of this 'autobiography' somehow go by without us ever learning very much about who Martin Amis is, or what he has done with the past 51 years of his life."

Jackie Wullschlager, in the Financial Times, appeared to have been reading a different book. "The core here is family, and it is movingly, beautifully, evoked. Against the backcloth of 50 years of English literary landscape, the raw materials - neurotic, outrageous genius of a father; gorgeous earth-mother Hilly; sophisticated step-mother Elizabeth Jane Howard; stunning girlfriends dropped along the way like a shattering string of pearls; an unknown daughter emerging at 18 - are unbeatable, and Amis makes of them a loving, perceptive, comic portrait."

John Banville, too, writing in the Irish Times, was filled with admiration: "Page for page, it is probably the best piece of prose you are likely to read this year. It is moving, angry, honest, and above all wonderfully stylish; it is packed with incident and anecdote, and very, very funny. Parts of it do not quite succeed, particularly the sections dealing with the author's first cousin, Lucy Partington, who disappeared in 1973, and was later discovered to have been one of Frederick West's victim's - but then, how could such horror be written about successfully?"

Terence Blacker, in the Sunday Times, also had reservations about the treatment of Lucy Partington's murder: "Again and again, throughout the book, he returns to memories and thoughts of Lucy Partington. It is no discredit to him that his careful, heartfelt tribute - the text closes with a letter to her mother, complete with kisses at the end - somewhat unbalances the book."

In all other respects, Blacker thought the book masterly: "In a deceptively cunning narrative weave, casting backwards and forwards from his childhood to his middle age, from his father's marriages to his own, he worries away at the polarities of innocence and experience, love and death. He writes movingly and, as far as one can tell, perceptively about the family relationships which have dominated his life, about his friendship with Saul Bellow, about the discovery of his lost daughter Delilah Seale after 21 years, about his love for his children."

James Wood, in the Guardian, also offered a lyrical encomium to Amis's attempt to come to terms with the truths of his life. "Experience is a beautiful, and beautifully strange book, and it is unlike anything one expected. One feared a trough of plaint: either a sad, Gosse-like reckoning with the father; or an angry, journalistic reckoning with those journalists who have hunted Amis from tooth to tooth. But Experience is not quite a memoir, nor is it quite a portrait of his father, nor is it really an autobiography. It is an escape from memoir; indeed, an escape into privacy. In the very book which might, at first glance, seem most exhibitionist, most shamelessly metropolitan, Amis has softly retreated to the provinces of himself. His book often reads like a letter to his family and closest friends. It is sometimes embarrassing to read; the ordinary reader feels voyeuristic, at times almost uninvited, but very moved. What seems at first just gossip and guestlists - sprays of names offered without explanation, diaristic footnotes, a refusal to universalise - soon becomes a kind of tender defiance, as if Amis wanted the book to vibrate with an atmosphere of wounded privacy."

Ian Hamilton, in the Sunday Telegraph, contrasted the pained, middle-aged Amis with the confident youth who had enjoyed instant literary success in the 1970s. "There is a lot of remorse and recantation in this book," wrote Hamilton, "a book, the author says, of sunderings and breakages, of heart-rending losses and dizzying new gains and a perhaps too-urgent need to exhibit some transfiguration of the self."

Hamilton saw the memoir as an act of catharsis. "This book as a whole is about bearing what is hard to bear, and should perhaps be seen as therapeutic preparation for whatever Amis the novelist comes up with next," he concluded. "One hopes that, in his fiction, he will remain loyal to his former self."

That, surely, is the interesting question: will this be a new beginning for Amis the novelist? Might even Ms Burchill and the cynical denizens of the Soho Brasserie be intrigued to read what Mart writes next?

fields.headline: NHS consultants
fields.trailText:
What is an NHS consultant?
Ask a medical student, and you'll get a one-word answer: "God". The consultant is the top rank of specialist hospital doctor - the cornerstone of the health service as negotiated by consultant leaders at its inception in 1948, and the doctor to whom your GP may refer you if he or she can't resolve your problem themselves.
fields.body:
What is an NHS consultant?
Ask a medical student, and you'll get a one-word answer: "God". The consultant is the top rank of specialist hospital doctor - the cornerstone of the health service as negotiated by consultant leaders at its inception in 1948, and the doctor to whom your GP may refer you if he or she can't resolve your problem themselves.

Why are consultants in the news?
Unfortunately, for all the wrong reasons. The medical profession has been rocked by a string of scandals involving consultant surgeons - such as James Wisheart, the consultant largely responsible for the high number of deaths during paediatric heart surgery at Bristol Royal Infirmary in the late 1980s and early 1990s; and Rodney Ledward, the self-styled "fastest gynaecologist in the south-east", who botched a string of hysterectomies during his 16 years in the William Harvey hospital, Ashford, Kent. The inquiry report into the Ledward case has criticised the "closed and closet atmosphere" in which juniors were reluctant to question their seniors - a situation with which doctors in many hospitals will be familiar.

What is the government doing?
Since his days as health minister in 1997, health secretary Alan Milburn has seen curbing consultant power as fundamental to NHS reform. He wants to make inroads into consultant self-regulation, currently the responsibility of the general medical council. But it also comes down to money - the government wants a new grade of lower-paid specialist doctors, which in the long term means fewer consultants and more work done for less.

How much are consultants paid at the moment?
A consultant of five years' standing is currently paid £63,640 basic. This can be topped up by a "distinction award", the most valuable of which is worth an additional 95% of basic salary (awarded to a privileged few). But consultants can also choose to sacrifice one-eleventh of their NHS salary in return for the freedom to earn an unrestricted amount from private practice. Rodney Ledward earned lucrative fees this way - but if the government were to achieve its stated aim of reducing NHS waiting times to zero, much of the private market would disappear.

So what do the consultants think of the government plans?
Thy are not impressed. They fear the government, which has put them under enormous pressure to meet its targets on reducing waiting lists, is now betraying the majority by capitalising on the failings of a rogue few. At the British Medical Association's annual consultants conference last Thursday, they unanimously rejected the government's plans for a new specialist grade. But they did also pass a motion of no confidence in the general medical council, with BMA consultant leaders claiming it neither protected patients nor guided doctors.

So what does the future hold?
Consultant leaders are currently in negotiations with the government over reforming their contract for the first time since 1948. While they will probably give way on professional self-regulation, they also have much to gain: the European working-time directive demands a maximum 48-hour week, far less than most consultants currently work. If this were followed strictly, they warn, the health service as we know it would collapse. Whether this is true or not, one thing is for sure: the power of the consultant is by no means at an end.

The medical profession has been rocked by a string of scandals involving consultant surgeons - such as James Wisheart, the consultant largely responsible for the high number of deaths during paediatric heart surgery at Bristol Royal Infirmary in the late 1980s and early 1990s; and Rodney Ledward, the self-styled "fastest gynaecologist in the south-east", who botched a string of hysterectomies during his 16 years in the William Harvey hospital, Ashford, Kent. The inquiry report into the Ledward case has criticised the "closed and closet atmosphere" in which juniors were reluctant to question their seniors - a situation with which doctors in many hospitals will be familiar. What is the government doing? Since his days as health minister in 1997, health secretary Alan Milburn has seen curbing consultant power as fundamental to NHS reform. He wants to make inroads into consultant self-regulation, currently the responsibility of the general medical council. But it also comes down to money - the government wants a new grade of lower-paid specialist doctors, which in the long term means fewer consultants and more work done for less. How much are consultants paid at the moment? A consultant of five years' standing is currently paid £63,640 basic. This can be topped up by a "distinction award", the most valuable of which is worth an additional 95% of basic salary (awarded to a privileged few). But consultants can also choose to sacrifice one-eleventh of their NHS salary in return for the freedom to earn an unrestricted amount from private practice. Rodney Ledward earned lucrative fees this way - but if the government were to achieve its stated aim of reducing NHS waiting times to zero, much of the private market would disappear. So what do the consultants think of the government plans? Thy are not impressed. They fear the government, which has put them under enormous pressure to meet its targets on reducing waiting lists, is now betraying the majority by capitalising on the failings of a rogue few. At the British Medical Association's annual consultants conference last Thursday, they unanimously rejected the government's plans for a new specialist grade. But they did also pass a motion of no confidence in the general medical council, with BMA consultant leaders claiming it neither protected patients nor guided doctors. So what does the future hold? Consultant leaders are currently in negotiations with the government over reforming their contract for the first time since 1948. While they will probably give way on professional self-regulation, they also have much to gain: the European working-time directive demands a maximum 48-hour week, far less than most consultants currently work. If this were followed strictly, they warn, the health service as we know it would collapse. Whether this is true or not, one thing is for sure: the power of the consultant is by no means at an end. webTitle: June 5: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 5: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Mission:Impossible 2 holds on to US top spot, Arnie turns down guns, Dr Who rumours, Spinal Tap on DVD, and Gabriel Byrne and Nick Moran on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Mission: Impossible 2 fell off 53% from its opening weekend box-office total, to narrowly retain the top spot with an estimated $27m takings in US cinemas. Second to Cruise and co came the Martin Lawrence comedy Big Momma's House, which opened with a $25.6m haul. Disney's Dinosaur took third place with $12m.

 Arnold Schwarzenegger has refused to pose with a gun for the marketing campaign of his latest film, The 6th Day. The film, directed by Roger Spottiswoode (Tomorrow Never Dies), is an action movie about a man who is cloned and must fight to rid himself of his double. While that struggle is highly likely to involve heavy artillery, Arnie will have none of it on the poster, despite MGM's pleas. "If people say movies lead to violence," he growls, "we should make a concession."

 Ain't It Cool News report that former Dr Who producer Philip Hinchcliffe, helmsman during the show's 1970s golden years, is to oversee production of the sci-fi classic's much-mooted transfer to the big screen. Highlander director Russell Mulcahy is "95% on to direct," claims the site's correspondent. The report goes on to cite Terence Stamp as most likely to play the eponymous timelord.

 This Is Spinal Tap is to be released on a DVD boasting more than 100 minutes of extra footage, including never-before-seen outtakes. Four music videos, three commercials, a press conference and a TV appearance round out the package. The original "band members", Christopher Guest, Michael McKean and Harry Shearer are scheduled for a live performance on VH1 later this month.

 Gabriel Byrne has been approached to appear in the Star Wars sequels, claims the actor in an interview in the Irish press. "The people from Star Wars called the other day to offer me something, but I don't know what it is yet," he says in Dublin's Evening Herald. "It's probably already been announced on the internet," he adds, wrongly, "but I still don't know myself."

 Lock, Stock star Nick Moran has joined Gary Oldman and Catherine Deneuve on Paramount Pictures' $50m feature, D'Artagnan. Directed by Peter (End Of Days) Hyam, D'Artagnan follows one of the three musketeers who seeks revenge for his parents' murder amid the mayhem of pre-revolutionary France.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Lots of little rumours fried and served with chips and a wedge of lemon. In a basket.
fields.trailText: Arsenal are hoping to wrap up their protracted £6m move for Robert Pires today, reports Planet Football. "I await the final answer on Monday," revealed the French international. "All things being normal, it is okay."
fields.body:
Arsenal are hoping to wrap up their protracted £6m move for Robert Pires today, reports Planet Football. "I await the final answer on Monday," revealed the French international. "All things being normal, it is okay."

Arsenal are also chasing Franca, the Sao Paulo forward who scored against England at Wembley - but face stiff competition from Paris Saint Germain, claims Planet Football.

They also report that Norwegian left-back Andre Bergdølmo has been watched by Derby manager Jim Smith.

Celtic manager Martin O'Neill is preparing a bid for Everton midfielder Don Hutchinson, reports the Daily Express.

Another player who could be on the move is Nicky Butt. According to the Mirror, Sunderland have bid £7m for the Manchester United midfielder.

The Mirror also reports that Manchester City are ready to splash out £6m to sign Fulham's Chris Coleman and Leeds' Alfe-Inge Haaland.

Manchester City have joined Southampton and Everton in expressing an interest in Aston Villa's Mark Draper, according to Teamtalk.

Frank Leboeuf is talking up a move to Napoli, reports Teamtalk. "I have seen everything I want to see and won everything I meant to win," the French international has admitted. "It's been a good experience but now I want something different. I would really love to be able to train and play in a warmer climate. I've been told Zola is likely to join Napoli and, all things considered, I would not be unhappy to go with him."

According to the Daily Mail, Walsall are hoping to appoint 34-year-old Tony Dorigo as their player-coach.

fields.headline: Oscars saviour burgled
fields.trailText: The man awarded $50,000 for finding dozens of missing Oscars days before this year's Academy Awards ceremony has lost $40,000 of it to burglars who broke into his apartment
fields.body:
The man awarded $50,000 for finding dozens of missing Oscars days before this year's Academy Awards ceremony has lost $40,000 of it to burglars who broke into his apartment.

Hapless Willie Fulgear complained: "I didn't get a chance to even enjoy my money." Fulgear said he returned from a holiday to discover housebreakers had made off with a safe containing the money and jewellery.

Police spokesman Ed Funes corroborated Fulgear's story and TV broadcasts showed Fulgear's apartment being dusted for fingerprints and photographed for damage. Fulgear received his reward from Roadway Express, the company responsible for the shipment of the statuettes. The 61-year-old salvage man found 52 of 55 missing statuettes in a skip in LA's Koreatown district. Three Oscars remain missing.

webTitle: The Matrix shines at MTV Awards

fields.headline: The Matrix shines at MTV Awards
fields.trailText: The Wachowski brothers' The Matrix has won three prizes, including best movie, at the annual MTV Movie Awards.
fields.body:
The Wachowski brothers' The Matrix has won three prizes, including best movie, at the annual MTV Movie Awards. At the ceremony in Los Angeles, Keanu Reeves bagged the best male performance gong for his role as Neo, and shared the best fight prize with co-star Laurence Fishburne.

Sarah Michelle Gellar won the best female performance trophy for her role in Dangerous Liaisons refit Cruel Intentions. She was also garlanded with the best kiss award for her clinch with co-star Selma Blair. The night's other big winner was Mike Myers' spoof Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me. The comedy arch-fiend Dr Evil was honoured as best villain, and as part of the best on-screen duo, with Verne Troyer, who played his pint-sized alter-ego Mini-Me.

webTitle: Flag fury casts shadow over assembly's first day

fields.headline: Flag fury casts shadow over assembly's first day
fields.standfirst: Democratic Unionists threaten to disrupt Northern Ireland's newly re-formed cabinet after Sinn Fein ministers refused to fly Union Jack on Queen's coronation anniversary
fields.trailText: Democratic Unionists have today threatened to disrupt Northern Ireland's newly re-formed cabinet after Sinn Fein ministers refused to fly the Union Jack on the Queen's coronation anniversary.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's power-sharing assembly resumed its business after a four-month gap today with the contentious issue of flags hanging over the province's political agenda. Unionists are furious at Sinn Fein ministers Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun's refusal to fly the Union Jack on Friday to mark the anniversary of the Queen's coronation.

The ministers said they would prefer to fly the Irish tricolour from their ministries on state occasions. Their actions have incurred the wrath of Rev Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, which is demanding that the Stormont assembly compel the Sinn Fein ministers to fly the British flag on designated days.

"The Union flag is the national flag and should be flying as right," Rev Paisley said. Mr Paisley is also threatening to disrupt the newly re-formed cabinet by having a succession of DUP activists take turns in holding his party's two posts.

Deputy first minister Seamus Mallon said disruption of the fledgling government would not be tolerated. "They should know full well it is cynical in the extreme, something that simply cannot be tolerated nor will it be," he said, of the DUP's plans. "It's to the detriment of the entire political process and the proper workings of their departments."

 First minister David Trimble and health minister Mrs de Brun were in London today for meetings with Tony Blair on the future of the NHS.

webTitle: England take a step back (in lead boots)

fields.headline: England take a step back (in lead boots)
fields.trailText: So England won 1-0, their first series victory in five attempts and their first win over Zimbabwe. Hooray? Well maybe, baby.
fields.body:
So England won 1-0, their first series victory in five attempts (after losses to Sri Lanka, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa) and their first win over Zimbabwe. Hooray? Well maybe, baby.

Nasser needed a series win and he got one. His team have now not lost a Test in three matches (not bad going by English standards). Mike Atherton is back to his best and England's performance in the first Test was suitably lordly. But at Trent Bridge, England 2000 bore a distinct resemblance to England 1999.

The batsmen were widely expected to fill their boots with plunder, but seemed only to have filled them with lead (Atherton and Mark Ramprakash excluded). Today Nasser Hussain seemed frozen by a boomeranging Nkala and poor Nick Knight toppled over again, head and feet in an 'L' shape rather than 'A' line. Andy Flintoff missed out on a chance to cement his spot for the rest of the summer and Darren Gough showed Ed Giddins that, if he remains in the team, he can have aspirations to move up the order to No. 10.

Zimbabwe deserve some credit. Their batsmen embarrassed England on Sunday, and their bowlers, after being slated at Lord's, made the most of today's conditions and England's footwork. Heath Streak had far better support and the fielding was more than sprightly, with Grant Flower taking another antelope catch to get rid of Gough - which gave England just enough time to get rid of him, the Gerry Liebenberg of the Zimbabwean side, in a five-over fourth innings.

Meanwhile, Brian Lara was out for one and one in the county match against Worcestershire. Perhaps he will do England the honour of auditioning for the walking wicket position in the forthcoming Test series. On today's showing, England will not want to be chasing big totals.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Journalists in public slanging match over The Insider

fields.headline: Journalists in public slanging match over The Insider
fields.trailText: A public spat broke out this weekend at the Investigative Reporters & Editors National Conference in New York over Michael Mann's Oscar-nominated thriller The Insider
fields.body:
A public spat broke out this weekend at the Investigative Reporters & Editors National Conference in New York over Michael Mann's Oscar-nominated thriller The Insider.

The founder of the US current affairs show 60 Minutes, whose failure to air an interview with a tobacco industry whistleblower was dramatised in the movie, launched an astonishing attack on the show's former producer Lowell Bergman (played by Al Pacino in The Insider). Bergman, said Don Hewitt, is "not a journalist I would allow within 100 miles of a TV news show or 1,000 miles of a journalism school."

Hewitt's tirade continued: "When a journalist who professes to be dedicated to the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth conspires with a screenwriter to concoct a movie about himself that portrays him, by name, saying things he never said and doing things he never did, that is not a journalist I would allow within 100 miles of a newsroom." Among Hewitt's allegations was the charge that, far from resigning from CBS in disgust at their conduct (as depicted in the film), Bergman petitioned to work for the station again.

At the end of his speech, Hewitt became embroiled in a slanging match between 60 Minutes reporter Mike Wallace and senior producer David Fanning over Bergman's behaviour. Said Wallace, manhandling Fanning, "That son-of-a-bitch [Bergman] turned on me, he lied, he betrayed me."

Informed of Hewitt's accusations, Bergman responded: "He's entitled to his opinion. He didn't seem to have any problem and in fact on many occasions praised my work and its accuracy and the subjects I chose to cover for 16 years."

webTitle: The innings every young cricketer dreams about

fields.headline: The innings every young cricketer dreams about
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we go behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the performances of the week. Today we talk to Gloucestershire newcomer Chris Taylor, who created history at Lord's
fields.trailText: Chris Taylor, 23, made history on his debut for Gloucestershire against Middlesex last week. Not only was he the first Gloucestershire player to score a hundred in his first Championship match, but he was also the first player from any county to do so at Lord's. After going in to bat on the first morning with his side on 29 for four, Taylor scored 104 in just under four hours, the linchpin of his side's first-innings total of 259.
fields.body:
Chris Taylor, 23, made history on his debut for Gloucestershire against Middlesex last week. Not only was he the first Gloucestershire player to score a hundred in his first Championship match, but he was also the first player from any county to do so at Lord's. After going in to bat on the first morning with his side on 29 for four, Taylor scored 104 in just under four hours, the linchpin of his side's first-innings total of 259.

"It wasn't my first time at Lord's - I'd played there a couple of times for MCC Schools - but it was great just looking around the place. I only found out 20 minutes before the start that I would be playing - I was very nervous. After losing the toss and being put in, we lost a few early wickets so I was a bit anxious sitting in the pavilion.

"When it was my turn to go out, the captain Mark Alleyne was batting and he told me just to relax and enjoy myself. I took it from there. I can't even remember the first ball I received - I think it was from Richard Johnson. When Mark was out [for 33] Jack Russell came in and helped me along too. The wise old heads were a big help!

"I didn't have any targets in mind; it was just a case of staying in. During the innings I got a bit of stick from the Middlesex fielders, but it was no more than I'd expected. I was just so excited: excitement outweighed the nerves, and when I got to 50 I was over the moon.

"To get the hundred I remember I had a ball from Fraser on my hips, which I worked behind square-leg for one. Apparently I didn't call, I just ran! [Jeremy] Snape scrambled through but I was already running towards the balcony, waving everything I could wave! I got a standing ovation from the members too.

"Not long after I got a fullish ball [from Owais Shah] which I tried to drive down the ground but the shot was too loose [he was bowled]. I was a bit gutted because I was dismissed just before tea, at a time when we needed more runs. Justin Langer [Middlesex's captain] congratulated me on the field and Angus Fraser came into the dressing-room later on. When I walked back through the long room, the members were saying "Great!" and I had a few pats on the back.

"Unfortunately none of my family was there, but I had lots of phone calls and a couple of faxes: old club-mates and teachers were phoning to say well done. I also received two bottles of champagne courtesy of the club which was a really nice touch. After a bit of champagne, I was in bed very early that night. I was absolutely shattered.

"This is only my first year on the county staff, though I played some second XI cricket last year. I started a teacher-training course at UWE [Universty of West of England] three or four years ago, but I found that I wasn't able to give 100 per cent to either my course or my cricket so I dropped the course. I only live five minutes from the ground in Bristol, but I didn't watch much county cricket when I was younger - I usually went to watch my dad play club cricket.

"I'm not sure if I'll make the side for the B&H final on Saturday - our one-day squad is very strong at the moment, but I like to think I will."

Chris Taylor was talking to Matthew Hancock. My Day In The Sun appears on wisden.com and cricketunlimited every Monday. Click hereto read last week's column, in which Northants seamer Richard Logan talks us through his first five-wicket haul
