webTitle: Premiership chiefs seek £2bn for TV rights

fields.headline: Premiership chiefs seek £2bn for TV rights
fields.trailText: Chairmen of the Premiership football clubs meet this week to agree the next stage in the bidding for the broadcasting rights to their matches which are expected to fetch up to £2bn.
fields.body:
Chairmen of the Premiership football clubs meet this week to agree the next stage in the bidding for the broadcasting rights to their matches which are expected to fetch up to £2bn.

The clubs are meeting on Thursday and Friday for the league's annual general meeting where they will be given an update by chief executive Richard Scudamore. Most interested broadcasters have made presentations to league officials over the past weeks.

The choice for clubs will be to ask for sealed bids or to hold an open auction. Some clubs are understood to favour the auction method which they believe could generate higher revenues. The league is expected to make a statement on the procedure on Friday.

The main package of live rights for 66 games is expected to be a tussle between BSkyB and Britain's biggest cable company NTL.

Separate reports have suggested that NTL has bid anywhere between £1.25bn and £1.75bn for the main live rights plus the secondary package of 40 games on a pay-per-view basis.

Winners are likely to be announced in July. One insider said there was "sufficient depth and strength of bids to conduct a second round".

Under the current deal, hatched on the eve of Euro 96, BSkyB paid £670m for five years and the BBC won a highlights package for £73m.

This time, as well as the live rights, two highlights packages are on offer and the opportunity to run the Premiership website.

Vic Wakeling, head of Sky Sports is understood to have begun lobbying club chairman to stay with the pay-television group.

fields.headline: Anniversary euro blues
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy: On the 25th anniversary of the referendum on British membership of what we then called the "Common Market", it is tempting to ask what has Europe done for us? fields.body:
On the 25th anniversary of the referendum on British membership of what we then called the "Common Market", it is tempting to ask what has Europe done for us? Actually, it has done a lot - for British jobs, trade, and civil liberties. That's not to mention the absence of the Franco-German conflicts that marred the first half of the 20th century.

If we look back on the major events and trends in British politics since the 1975 referendum - the winter of discontent, Thatcherism, the formation of the SDP, Falklands war, the miners' strike, Black Wednesday, Maastricht, the 1997 general election, boom and bust - at no point in those 25 years did a British PM (Heath apart) take the lead in arguing the positive benefits of British membership of Europe.

That is the saddest indictment of the past two and half decades in British politics. And it is becoming the saddest indictment of the present government that the prime minister has not bucked the trend.

British leaders could have said, on more than one occasion, that we are a European nation, with centuries of history, shared values and culture linking us to the continent. They could have argued that we are a European nation because of our growing trade links with it. And they could have pointed out that other potential collaborators with Britain, such as the United States, Australia and New Zealand, are looking increasingly towards Asia rather than us for their economic futures.

In a world where access to large free markets is key, Europe is the only show in town. Yet too often, we opt to work in political suburbia. The tone was set when we originally decided that the Common Market was something that needn't trouble us. Ever since, a familiar pattern has been followed. When any move forward looks likely to happen in the rest of Europe, we tend to say that it won't happen.

When it happens, we say it won't work. When it works, we say we don't need to be part of it. Then, finally, we realise that we have to be part of it, and enter on terms that are far worse than if we had joined earlier - with the result that the image of Britain in Europe tends to be one of an apparently sceptical Harold Wilson seeking renegotiation, or a handbag-wielding Margaret Thatcher demanding our money back. We lost out in 1957, lost out subsequently and we must not repeat such mistakes again.

Europe has a real impact on real life in Britain. One of the major obstacles to Britain joining the euro is the overvalued pound. But we can't really sort that out for the long-term until we commit to the euro. The government has failed to argue that case and stands culpable as a result.

The costs of this failure of leadership are seen in the decline in public support for Europe. There is a steadily decreasing interest in Europe from the voters.

Nearly 65% voiced an opinion in the 1975 referendum. Yet since the "high" of the 1989 and 1994 European election when 36.8% voted, interest has dropped off markedly - with under 25% voting last year. At the same time, hostility to the euro has increased. The regular Mori poll on whether Britain should join showed just over 20% against in 1992. The figure is now regularly over 30%. Yet the same polling shows that people would be much more willing to support entry if the government takes a strong position. The government could make a difference - if only it had the political courage.

We will continue to lose out if the prime minister doesn't stand up for what he must know is in Britain's long-term, vital, social, political and economic interest. That means setting a date for entry to the euro, consulting the British people through a referendum, and if the people agree, making preparations for British entry two to three years down the line.

I have put this point frequently at Prime Minister's Questions. The PM likes to respond with a cheap jibe, saying that William Hague would never join, and that the Liberal Democrats want to join now.

The former looks increasingly accurate. But the latter has never been true. The PM's own proclaimed policy is to go in when it suits Britain. He is right - we shouldn't join in any circumstances. But we will never get there by doing nothing. If Labour is serious about acting in Britain's interest, then it should be adopting the Liberal Democrat policy, not abusing it.

And if the government doesn't act soon, then public opinion may have been lost forever and the euro ship may have sailed. Then we will never be able to join the euro.

 Charles Kennedy is leader of the Liberal Democrats.

webTitle: Britain faces losing out to the single currency

fields.headline: Britain faces losing out to the single currency
fields.standfirst:
Debate: Giles Radice
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The new Ernst & Young report on inward investment underlines the disadvantages of staying out of the euro. While Britain has retained its position as the biggest single recipient of projects in 1999, its market share has slipped from 28% to 24%.
fields.body:
The new Ernst & Young report on inward investment underlines the disadvantages of staying out of the euro. While Britain has retained its position as the biggest single recipient of projects in 1999, its market share has slipped from 28% to 24%.

Kitty Ussher, chief economist of Britain in Europe, has also shown how the recent strength of the pound in relation to the euro is hitting manufacturing jobs which, in contrast to those in the euro economies, are declining.

The emerging costs of Britain's decision not to join the single currency at the outset make it all the more essential that the government sticks firmly to the policy of deciding early in the next parliament whether the economic conditions are right for Britain to go in then.

Assuming that the next election is held in early summer 2001, the following months could provide a favourable combination of circumstances - making a decision to join much more likely.

The economic and financial committee of the European Council has recently confirmed that Britain already fulfils the Maastricht criteria regarding converging inflation rates and long-term rates, and the ceiling on public deficits and debt. The only question mark is over the exchange rate, which EU finance ministers understandably do not yet consider sufficiently stable.

Turning to the chancellor's five economic tests announced in October 1997, the two key issues are convergence - between the British economy and the economies of the euro area - and flexibility. The questions of the impact on investment and jobs are to a considerable extent dependent on the first two tests.

As to the impact on the City, it is already, thanks to careful preparation, acting as the de facto financial centre of the eurozone. Only if Britain decides to remain out for the longer term would the City be in danger of losing out.

The British economy is already one of the most flexible in Europe. Following the Vodafone-Mannesmann merger, the signs are that the continental economies are already becoming more flexible, with Emu acting as an agent of change. It is also possible that the Lisbon summit, with its emphasis on targets, will encourage further progress.

With regard to convergence between the British and continental economies, the commission expects the eurozone economies to grow 3.45% in 2000 and 3.1% in 2001, while the British economy is predicted to expand at much the same rate. Our short-term interest rates are still about double those set by the ECB, but, as growth in the eurozone picks up, short-term rates could converge as well.

Exchange rate stability remains a problem with the pound having been at least 20% overvalued against the euro. Although the entry rate for the pound will be determined by negotiation with Britain's partners rather than the markets, it would clearly be helpful if the pound fell to a more competitive level against the euro some time before the entry decision was taken.

With the strong recovery of the eurozone economies predicted over the next two years, the markets could begin to turn in favour of the euro. Indeed this may already be happening.

But, it may well be that a firm government statement at an appropriate time of its intention to join the single currency early in the next parlia ment, provided the economic circumstances are right, could itself influence the market decisively.

Political pressures for Britain to join could also have increased. Greece will already be a member, Denmark could well join after its referendum this autumn and Sweden could also be on the brink of entry. By the end of 2001, Britain could be the only EU member which is not also a member of the euro.

The Euro-11 Committee - which France has plans to beef up - could by that time have become the Euro-14 Committee and the real economic powerhouse of Europe.

British opinion may at present be wary of the euro. But polls show that the voters' hostility could be converted to support in a referendum if they thought that joining the euro was in both their and their nation's interest.

By 2001, it should have become very clear that the euro is here to stay; that there would be significant benefits if Britain joins; and that there will be substantial costs if we stay out. The case for British entry is there to be won.

Giles Radice MP, chairman of the European Movement and of the Commons treasury committee, has recently published a European Movement pamphlet - The Case for the Euro

webTitle: Pressure builds on Blair to lead euro drive

fields.headline: Pressure builds on Blair to lead euro drive
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair must stake his credibility on winning a referendum to take Britain into the European single currency to have a hope of reversing public scepticism, a leading pollster argues today.
fields.body:
Tony Blair must stake his credibility on winning a referendum to take Britain into the European single currency to have a hope of reversing public scepticism, a leading pollster argues today.

Bob Worcester, head of Mori, suggests in a pamphlet for a Blairite think tank that the image of those leading the fight for entry to the single currency will prove more significant in swaying public opinion than economic arguments.

Yesterday the former chancellor Lord Jenkins, in a speech to mark the 25th anniversary of the vote in which Britain decided to stay in the common market, warned the prime minister that he must start working now to win round public opinion.

"Too many prime ministers have damaged their reputations by equivocation on Europe," Lord Jenkins, a confidant of Mr Blair, told a European Movement conference in Nottingham. "I pray that Mr Blair will handle matters more decisively."

Professor Worcester argues in the pamphlet that, even with the backing of "credible leaders" such as Mr Blair, chancellor Gordon Brown, and the Conservative pro-Europeans Michael Heseltine and Kenneth Clarke, the "yes to the euro" camp will need the greatest shift in public opinion since the war to win a referendum.

Euro supporters will need to get their vote out, target their campaign on young swing voters and not rely on business leaders.

His analysis for the Foreign Policy Centre, whose patron is Mr Blair and whose president is the pro-Euro foreign secretary, Robin Cook, comes as single currency enthusiasts are putting concerted pressure on the government to launch an early campaign for euro entry.

Frustration is bubbling among supporters within and outside the government over its caution, with tensions emerging publicly by way of briefings and counter-briefings involving cabinet ministers in rival camps.

As well as Mr Cook, ministers keen to join the euro include the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, while Mr Brown is cooler on the issue.

Downing Street yesterday denied suggestions that a specialist "euro unit" was being set up in the Cabinet Office to allow Mr Blair to take control of European issues and end ministerial feuding.

However, he is expected to appoint Sir Stephen Wall, Britain's ambassador to the EU, to replace the departing David Bostock as head of the European secretariat, the Cabinet Office-based unit that co-ordinates EU policy across government departments.

The former prime minister Edward Heath yesterday said pro-Europeans should shoulder some of the blame for the public's failure to appreciate the increased jobs, trade and influence that closer ties with Europe had brought.

Claiming that successive governments had failed to make the European case, he called for a new effort to convince the public of the benefits of joining a single currency to counter "the cumulative effect of 25 years of anti-European propaganda".

Mr Clarke, former Tory chancellor, who is irritated at being left to fight the pro-euro case without public government backing, yesterday told the European Movement conference that Britain would start losing investors because of its failure to say it will join the euro.

"Decisions for the future will be taken now to avoid the risk of investing in Britain when the exchange rate might move up or down against the euro at any time, affecting the prices of exports and imports and the value of investment," he said.

But a spokesman for the Business for Sterling group said: "This is the roar of the euro dinosaurs still wedded to a policy invented in the last century and having no understanding of what a modern economy needs in the internet age."

fields.headline: Innovators compete for £200,000 arts prize
fields.trailText: The man who put the "by heck" into Shakespeare, and the performer who for one glorious night at least brought poetry to the masses, are among six "unsung heroes" shortlisted for the country's richest arts prize.
fields.body:
The man who put the "by heck" into Shakespeare, and the performer who for one glorious night at least brought poetry to the masses, are among six "unsung heroes" shortlisted for the country's richest arts prize.

Barrie Rutter, the flamboyant actor-manager of Northern Broadsides, who dared to give the bard a bit of Yorkshire gristle, and regularly gives the classics the same muscular northern treatment, is probably the best known of the six in the running for the £200,000 Creative Britons awards, which reward "unique individuals" for their contribution to the nation's cultural life.

Rutter put on Blake Morrison's last play in Skipton cattle market, championed the former wrestler, Brian Glover, as a classical actor, and was rewarded with Ted Hughes's dying gift of his last work Alcestis, an autobiographical reworking of Euripides.

He was nominated by another no-nonsense northerner, John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, who said his "factory floor Shakespeare is as far from elitism as could be, though it has never dumbed it down".

Michael Horovitz, the poet behind the Poetry Olympics and the Royal Albert Hall gigs which combined jazz and verse, is another cult figure who the judges praised for his "notoriously selfless" commitment to the work of others, "giving new voice to women, black and gay poets".

Siobhan Davies, known to her friends as Sue, has long been regarded as the mother of modern British dance. Her work for her own company, the Rambert and the London Contemporary Dance Theatre has been internationally acclaimed.

Susan Loppert's work on art therapy, however, is much less celebrated. Since 1993 she has filled the Chelsea and Westminster hospital in London with 1,000 paintings, sculptures and mobiles and introduced weekly programmes of music, theatre and puppetry that have become, according to the judges, "a model for all hospitals, here and abroad".

Outside classical music circles, Peter Cropper, founder of the Sheffield International Music Festival, is not well known. Like all the other nominees, he is a great populariser, insisting on down-to-earth introduction to pieces, and having world-class musicians perform in the round and mingling with audiences.

Sabrina Guinness, a scion of the brewing family, challenged Anneka Rice to build a studio in west London in four days for her YCTV company which trains disadvantaged young people, and those at risk of committing crime, to work in television. Programmes made by the young people have been shown on the BBC, Sky and Carlton.

Colin Tweedy, of Arts & Business, who persuaded Prudential to sponsor the awards, said they pointed up how the arts are a powerful motor for change.

Each of the six nominees gets £20,000 for their own causes. The winner, to be announced on June 28, will receive £100,000 in total.

webTitle: Estate agents do not need to be polite to potential clients

fields.headline: Estate agents do not need to be polite to potential clients
fields.standfirst:
Space is a hot issue for the virtual economy
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Space is a hot issue for the virtual economy
fields.body:
Following a few weeks of relatively high-powered stuff in this column - the collapse of Boo.com, European expansion, Rools securing multi-million pound funding - we thought we'd turn to the slightly more mundane task of searching for offices.

Although not necessarily the most exciting activity we are currently engaged in, it is a real hot area for any dot.com business that has not already secured long-term premises.

For the last six months we have been working in offices provided by the consultancy firm that supported us with initial funding. Though the offices are located in an expensive area - London's Mayfair - we are paying a peppercorn.

This has saved us over £8,000 in the time that we've been here. Savings like this are consistent with our philosophy of ensuring that every penny of our investors' money is spent in the most effective way possible.

This philosophy means that we are looking very carefully at all our major investments, including office space, to ensure that we are getting the best possible deal.

The same philosophy also extends to travel; one busy member of the Rools team has bought a scooter to cut down on taxi expenses and zip around London more quickly - A far cry from the supposed Concorde extravagances of Boo.

However, our present offices are only a short-term solution, and as new recruits arrive we are rapidly outgrowing the available space. We need to find somewhere that can accommodate the planned expansion of the business over the next 18 months plus.

Our specific requirements for the property, in terms of size, rough location, cost and facilities, are clear. Unfortunately, they are also far from unique.

We are entering the market near the top of a commercial property boom which means that suitable, inexpensive premises are hard to find. Our PR agency has been looking for good-sized offices in central London for more than two years.

Many London-based new media companies have been heading for the Clerkenwell area not far from the City. But this influx has eroded most of the initial price advantages that the area once exhibited.

One of our partner technology agencies secured its office space for only £6 per square foot less than three years ago; the same space today would fetch more than £30, an increase of more than 400%.

Even with the top temporarily lopped off the bubbling technology sector we are still seeing some of the classic symptoms of over-demand in the property market. Prices are still rising, contract terms are getting longer - and with less need to work hard to earn their commission, estate agents are becoming increasingly rude to prospective clients: there's plenty of the "don't call us, we'll call you" attitude about.

Recent scepticism over the long-term viability of dot.com businesses has also made it tougher for those at a reasonably early stage to secure property.

Companies that have recently completed the process say that landlords are looking for commitments up to twice as long as those sought from firms in more established sectors. They are also being asked for up to two years' rent in advance

But we are far from disheartened. We have now seen enough properties to be confident that we will find one that suits us and that will represent good value for the business.

We expect to be waving goodbye to our present space within two months. Who knows, perhaps with a few more trips on the scooter we'll even be able to afford a parking space for it.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card.

webTitle: Bulger killers will be spared adult prison

fields.headline: Bulger killers will be spared adult prison
fields.trailText: The killers of James Bulger may never serve time in prison for their crime, it emerged last night, as the Home Office confirmed that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables could remain in local authority care until they are 19.
fields.body:
The killers of James Bulger may never serve time in prison for their crime, it emerged last night, as the Home Office confirmed that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables could remain in local authority care until they are 19.

The pair were placed in secure local authority accommodation in 1993 after they abducted the two-year-old from a shopping centre, killed him and left his body on a railway track in Walton, Liverpool. Their release date will be set by the lord chief justice Lord Bingham, who is currently considering their case.

Eight-year sentences were imposed on Thompson and Venables by the trial judge. They were later raised to 10 years by the lord chief justice and further increased by the then home secretary, Michael Howard, to 15 years.

That tariff was overturned in December after a ruling by the European court of human rights.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, then asked the lord chief justice to set a new term.

A Home Office spokeswoman said no decision would be made on where the killers would be accommodated until he had reached his decision, but they could legally stay in local authority care until they were 19.

A prison service spokeswoman said: "At the moment they are likely to stay in local authority care until the final decision is made by the lord chief justice. Their final placement will depend on their tariff and the parole board review of the case."

Any move into children's homes would mean the two boys would face a less restrictive regime than they have experienced in the secure accommodation where they have stayed until now.

It would give the two boys, who are both 17 and are being held at separate units, more freedom to move around during the day. It would also mean they would no longer be locked in their rooms at night.

Mr Straw would still have to give permission for the boys to leave their accommodation to prepare for any move back into society as part of any possible release.

Any move towards releasing the boys will be seen in some quarters as vindication for the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, who last year was publicly rebuked by the home secretary for calling for their release in an interview in the New Statesman.

Mr Straw wrote to Sir David demanding an explanation for comments, in which he said Thompson and Venables, both aged 10 at the time of the killing, should be released "as early as possible" after reaching 18 "to give them a chance of making a life".

The comments sparked outrage among lawyers and politicians, as well as the family of James Bulger.

webTitle: Police rescue British woman forced to work as a prostitute

fields.headline: Police rescue British woman forced to work as a prostitute
fields.trailText: A British woman who was kidnapped by Albanian criminals while on holiday in Italy and forced to work as a prostitute for almost five weeks has been rescued by Italian police.
fields.body:
A British woman who was kidnapped by Albanian criminals while on holiday in Italy and forced to work as a prostitute for almost five weeks has been rescued by Italian police.

The 18-year-old woman was rescued from an apartment in the centre of Vicenza, northeast Italy, on Friday and her two captors, a man and a woman, were arrested.

"They threatened me and forced me to prostitute myself," the Rome daily Il Messaggero quoted the woman as telling police. "They paid 150,000 to 200,000 lira (£50-£65) to have sex with me, but they kept all the money. I couldn't rebel against them. When I did, they beat me. They listened outside the door to everything I said to the clients."

The girl, whose father is English and whose mother is Latvian, was given a two-week holiday in Rome as a present for her 18th birthday.

After spending two weeks in Rome she extended her stay in April by taking a temporary job in a Florence restaurant run by an acquaintance. She had booked into a hotel in Padua on her way to meeting her acquaintance and was befriended by an Albanian woman who told her she would help her find work with a local pizza restaurant.

However, when she went for what she believed was going to be an interview in Vicenza, she was kidnapped and forced to work as a prostitute.

Police identified her kidnappers as Riza Engjellish, 21, and Violeta Boboci, 25, who rented the flat where the woman was incarcerated. They have been charged with kidnapping, induction into prostitution, threats and violence.

webTitle: Tyson promoter to sue rape centre

fields.headline: Tyson promoter to sue rape centre
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: Boxing promoter Frank Warren last night insisted he would seek to recover his legal costs from the rape crisis centre that failed in its legal attempts to prevent the boxer Mike Tyson from fighting in Scotland.
fields.body:
Boxing promoter Frank Warren last night insisted he would seek to recover his legal costs from the rape crisis centre that failed in its legal attempts to prevent the boxer Mike Tyson from fighting in Scotland.

The centre tried to overturn home secretary Jack Straw's decision to grant Tyson, a convicted rapist, entry clearance to Britain so he can fight at Hampden Park in Glasgow.

It was the second time a women's group has tried to keep the boxer out of the country. But the judge, Lord Clarke, dismissed the petition saying that he would give his reasons at a later date.

The Scottish Nationalist party leader Alex Salmond said Mr Warren was using bullying tactics, but the promoter last night issued a statement accusing Mr Salmond and other politicians of using the issue as a "political football".

His statement said: "I never threatened to bankrupt anyone and I challenge anyone to prove otherwise. All I have said about this so far is that I would be looking to recover my costs, which like the Home Office, I'm entitled to do.

"I have always said any money I recover will be paid to a youth club in Glasgow and the fact that many of my statements have been ignored suggests to me that Mr Tyson and myself are being used as a political football by certain people in Scotland.

"You've got to remember that it's the women's group who brought the court application not me, with the clear intention of stopping the promotion, which would have seriously damaged my business."

Earlier yesterday Mr Warren appeared to reconsider his decision after a live debate with Mr Salmond on the BBC Radio Five Live.

Mr Salmond said: "These are people who actually do things because they actually care about it. You would be well-advised to stop bullying this group and stop carrying forward this vindictive action."

Mr Warren agreed to think again on the question of costs, reported to amount to £10,000 and offered to hold a collection when Tyson fights fellow American Lou Savarese at Hampden Park on June 24.

The centre has said it would continue to protest. A joint women's group had been set up in Glasgow and was plan ning "creative direct action" up to and including the fight.

Sandy Brindley, a volunteer at the centre, said: "We would certainly hope that he would reconsider his decision to pursue us, in light of the amount of money he is going to make from the fight, and the public outrage that has been caused."

Ms Brindley said they had been concerned by reports that there may be a third Tyson fight planned: "If it did seem to be getting the go-ahead, I hope women's groups and survivors of sexual violence will have a part in that process."

Gil Paterson MSP, has also condemned Mr Warren's plans. He said: "This is the tactics of a bully boy, who wants to intimidate and teach women a lesson."

fields.headline: Admin error 'killed' 20,000 troops
fields.trailText: The lives of nearly 20,000 people appeared to have been saved retrospectively yesterday when a glitch appeared in the approved US history of the Korean war.
fields.body:
The lives of nearly 20,000 people appeared to have been saved retrospectively yesterday when a glitch appeared in the approved US history of the Korean war.

For almost 50 years it was accepted that 54,246 Americans had died in the war, which ended in a truce in 1953. The number is engraved on the national Korean war memorial, in Washington.

Now the Pentagon has revised the figure down to 36,940. It is not a matter of thousands of families mourning unnecessarily but rather a case of bungling back at base.

Far away from the battlefields of Asia, an anonymous government clerk laboured away with his ledger sheets at the Pentagon. Burdened with the solemn duty of compiling the final tally of those who had fallen in the three-year war, the clerk performed a calculation of history-warping dimensions.

He took the number of non-battlefield US military deaths during those years - 20,617 - and added the number to the more than 33,000 who actually did die in action in Korea. Only 3,275 of those who died off the battlefield, usually in accidents or of disease, did so in Korea, producing the new total of 36,940.

This new take on military precision appears in today's issue of Time magazine, which says: "In a rare example of inter-service cooperation, a Pentagon memo notes: 'All service historian offices have been advised... and are in agreement with the revision.' "

fields.headline: Inquiry into new organs scandal
fields.standfirst:
Hospital mortuary staff claim they were ordered to dispose of foetuses as if they were clinical waste
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has launched an investigation after hospital staff were ordered to dispose of babies' organs as clinical waste.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has launched an investigation after hospital staff were ordered to dispose of babies' organs as clinical waste.

The inquiry will focus on the inappropriate disposal of organs at the King's Mill centre in Sutton in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire. Mortuary technicians there claim that they were ordered to dispose of foetuses, babies' hearts, brains and other organs along with clinical waste bags.

The staff made video recordings of the disposal of the organs and foetuses in March, within days of the Royal College of Pathologists issuing guidelines for hospitals to check whether specimens had been kept without relatives' permission.

Geoffrey Hulman, a consultant who was in charge of mortuary services at the hospital, has been suspended while the investigation is carried out. Mr Milburn said yesterday that he was extremely concerned about the King's Mill centre allegations.

"My concerns are particularly with the relatives and families," he said. "That is why I have ordered an immediate investigation on which I expect a report as quickly as possible to me."

"The Department of Health has instructed all trusts to have policies in place which allow staff to raise any concerns they have outside the normal management chain. I will expect the inquiry to look at whether such policies were in place at King's Mill."

Mortuary technicians claim the hospital had been retaining foetuses and babies' organs for the last 10 years. The organs were not disposed of properly by cremation at a crematorium, but were merely treated as clinical waste.

Andrew Mayer, a technician at the hospital who was the whistleblower, said staff believed that what they had been asked to do was morally wrong. Mr Mayer, who is being supported by the GMB union, said: "Getting rid of body parts was not a pleasant task but we felt we had to follow our instructions. I honestly believe that the parents of these babies do not realise their baby or part of their baby has been kept in a mortuary storeroom for the last five or six years. They will be very angry when they find out and they will want to know why."

The allegations follow the organ retention scandal at Alder Hey hospital, in Liverpool, where tissue from 893 babies and children was stored without the knowledge of par ents. An independent inquiry into that scandal, ordered by the health secretary, will report back in summer.

Mr Hulman, who was in charge of mortuary services, said yesterday: "I am astonished at how all this has blown up. I have taken advice and at this stage I do not think it would be appropriate to comment with an investigation about to get under way."

The hospital claims Mr Hulman took the decision without the knowledge of the chief executive, John Watkinson. Mr Watkinson last night defended the hospital saying it was working to procedures that had been long established.

"Postmortem examination of foetuses and stillborn babies ceased at King's Mill two years ago. Our practice during the time such examinations were carried out here was for foetuses and stillborn babies to go to the local crematorium where they were treated with sensitivity and cremated following a blessing.

"When tissue needed to be retained for possible postmortem examination, the consent of the parents was obtained and such tissue was subsequently disposed of as clinical waste which was normal practice not only at King's Mill but elsewhere in the health service."

webTitle: Iranian link to bomb on Pan Am 103

fields.headline: Iranian link to bomb on Pan Am 103
fields.standfirst:
Iranians blamed for Lockerbie bombing
Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Sensational evidence that Iran planned and financed the 1988 Lockerbie bombing could cast a new shadow over the trial of two Libyans accused of the murder of 270 people.
fields.body:
Sensational evidence that Iran planned and financed the 1988 Lockerbie bombing could cast a new shadow over the trial of two Libyans accused of the murder of 270 people.

According to a CBS news report last night, an Iranian defector, named as Ahmad Behbahani, who is said to have coordinated Iranian terrorist operations for a decade, has documents to prove his claims.

The CIA is debriefing Mr Behbahani, now in protective custody in Turkey, the CBS News TV programme 60 Minutes reported.

The two Libyans, Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, are accused of planting the bomb on Pan Am 103, and are now being tried before Scottish judges at the former US airbase of Camp Zeist in the Netherlands.

The two, described by the prosecution as members of the Libyan intelligence services, deny the charges, blaming two Syrian-based Palestinian factions, one with links to Iran.

Intriguingly, defence lawyers have also told the court they will seek to incriminate a crown witness, Parviz Taheri. Nothing is known about him, but his name is Iranian.

The explosion over Lockerbie in Scotland killed all 259 Pan Am passengers and crew and 11 people on the ground.

Suggestions that Iran was involved are not new. Early on it was assumed that the incident was in retaliation for the downing of an Iranian airliner over the Gulf in July 1988.

Iran, then still ruled by the revolutionary leader Ayatollah Khomeini, vowed that the skies would "rain blood" after the USS Vincennes shot down the Iran Air flight, killing 290 people.

Tehran, master minding the holding of western hostages in Lebanon, was thought to have ordered the destruction of the Pan Am airliner with the help of the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of PalestineGeneral Command.

It seemed equally plausible to assume that Libya might have wanted to avenge the US and British bombing of Libya in 1986, itself retaliation for an alleged Libyan terrorist attack on US servicemen in Berlin.

In November 1991, the two Libyans were indicted and handed over for trial last year. Hearings began at Camp Zeist last month and are scheduled to last for at least a year.

Scottish legal authorities have said that they will punish any contempt of court, though the absence of a jury means that the case is taking place in a legal no man's land.

Media reports have cast doubts over a Swiss witness who made the timer that triggered the bomb and a Libyan defector now living in the US who was said to have seen the accused loading the bomb on to a feeder flight in Malta.

Other theories have suggested that Palestinian terrorists infiltrated a US intelligence operation which used Pan Am Flight 103 to smuggle heroin, in a complex dirty-tricks, drugs-for-hostages deal.

According to an Iranian defector to Germany, Iran, with Libya and the Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal, plotted the crime.

Tehran, master minding the holding of western hostages in Lebanon, was thought to have ordered the destruction of the Pan Am airliner with the help of the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of PalestineGeneral Command. It seemed equally plausible to assume that Libya might have wanted to avenge the US and British bombing of Libya in 1986, itself retaliation for an alleged Libyan terrorist attack on US servicemen in Berlin. In November 1991, the two Libyans were indicted and handed over for trial last year. Hearings began at Camp Zeist last month and are scheduled to last for at least a year. Scottish legal authorities have said that they will punish any contempt of court, though the absence of a jury means that the case is taking place in a legal no man's land. Media reports have cast doubts over a Swiss witness who made the timer that triggered the bomb and a Libyan defector now living in the US who was said to have seen the accused loading the bomb on to a feeder flight in Malta. Other theories have suggested that Palestinian terrorists infiltrated a US intelligence operation which used Pan Am Flight 103 to smuggle heroin, in a complex dirty-tricks, drugs-for-hostages deal. According to an Iranian defector to Germany, Iran, with Libya and the Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal, plotted the crime.

webTitle: On the path of biology's holy grail

fields.headline: On the path of biology's holy grail
fields.standfirst:
A supercomputer called Blue Gene aims to win the race to decode 'book of life'
Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: A supercomputer called Blue Gene aims to win the race to decode 'book of life'
fields.byline: James Meek  and Michael Ellison in New York
fields.body:
Even as the scientific world holds its breath to see which of two rival teams will be first to decode the "book of life", the secret of our genes, researchers in the US are building a computer 50 times more powerful than anything available today to delve beyond genes into the nuts and bolts mechanics of human existence.

In what will be seen by some as a promise and others as a threat, the supercomputer, nicknamed Blue Gene, could show the way to the holy grail of biology - how to bridge the gap between man as a bag of chemicals and man as a conscious, creative being.

Long before that the designers of the new computer hope it will lead to lucrative, lifesaving medical breakthroughs, building on the data produced by the Human Genome Project and its private-sector counterpart, Celera Genomics.

Six months after IBM announced it was spending the equivalent of £60m on the project, its full scale and importance is starting to emerge. Blue Gene has 1,000 times the capacity of Deep Blue, which defeated the world chess champion Garry Kasparov three years ago, and about 2m times more muscle than today's desktop PCs.

It will use that muscle for a single, deceptively banal task - working out how a single human protein is built from the atoms up.

It might not sound much. But it is the fundamental mechanism of life, and some of the brightest stars of biochemistry have been beating their heads against it for years, without success. Existing computers cannot even accurately model the behaviour of simple water molecules in the human body.

IBM is aiming at a machine that will be able to tackle one quadrillion operations per second, making it easily the fastest computer in the world.

"Breakthroughs in computers and information technology are now creating new frontiers in biology," said Paul Horn, senior vice-president of IBM research.

"One day you're going to be able to walk into a doctor's office and have a computer analyse a tissue sample, identify the pathogen that ails you and then instantly prescribe a treatment best suited to your specific illness and individual genetic make-up."

But even working at a pace 40 times greater than that of today's 40 fastest computers operating in tandem, it will take the IBM machine a year to produce the answer for just one protein.

Ever since the power of supercomputers began creeping towards parity with the human brain, commentators have speculated that machines could eventually rival and surpass our own intelligence.

IBM's announcement shows the way to a subtler but no less momentous way computers could determine our fate - by replicating, in their processors, the entire chemical reaction that is a human organism.

Although theologians and religious believers would disagree, most biologists believe human beings are no more or less than very large and complex collections of atoms - atoms that should join and separate in a predictable way.

It would take computing power far in excess of anything contemplated today to simulate the interaction of all the trillions of atoms in the human body. One scientist likened it to seeking a perfect weather forecast.

Yet Blue Gene is a tiny step in that direction. Its unprecedented power will use the basic laws of physics and chemistry to calculate, a step at a time, how atoms must join to form one of the basic building blocks of life, a big molecule called a protein.

On that submicroscopic scale, our metabolisms work at blinding speed. Blue Gene will use its calculating might to work out the shifting of atoms in slices of time a few quadrillionths of a second long.

"Nature does this day in and day out, second by second, and has done it for billions of years," said IBM's Sharon Nunes. "We really want to understand the fundamental why and how."

If genes, clustered in the centre of the cells of our bodies, make up the recipe book of life - the human genome - proteins are what the body cooks up from the recipes.

Scientists are expected to announce any day that they have cracked the code of the human genome. It is an extraordinary landmark in our understanding of what we are, but it marks the beginning of a massive new effort to understand how the products of the genes, the proteins, work.

Proteins - hormones, enzymes, antibodies - are the messengers, labourers and warriors of the body.

They are made up of several hundred smaller molecules called amino acids. The unique shape these amino acids form when they get together according to a gene's instructions is critical to the protein's job, but scientists still do not understand why what they call "protein folding" happens as it does.

When it was first mooted in the 1980s, no-one imagined the Human Genome Project would be completed as swiftly or as cheaply as it has been. The unforeseen factor was the vast expansion in computing power available to scientists, who were able to automate much of the laborious nitty-gritty of gene hunting.

Now some researchers are arguing a similar effort should be launched to isolate and characterise every protein in the human body - a "human proteome project".

Since the 30,000 to 100,000 human genes may each produce more than one protein, that could mean identifying hundreds of thousands of proteins - a massive task.

With billions of dollars of investment at stake, the same public-private funding and access problems which have dogged the Genome Project are already surfacing in debate about the Proteome Project.

A leading US proteomics entrepreneur, Leigh Anderson of Large Scale Biology Corporation, told the journal Nature last year: "Large-scale proteome research should be carried out in companies rather than through government-sponsored projects."

But Tim Hubbard, a protein specialist now among the leaders of the British end of the publicly funded Human Genome Project, said US government funds were starting to flow into the field, with the UK interested.

"IBM is realising that we are going in the direction of high-performance computing, and they want to get in on the act. It's a good strategy," he said.

From Babbage to Windows

1820-32 Mechanical computing: Charles Babbage designs the first mechanical computers, the analytical engine (to calculate mathematical tables) and the difference engine which, had it been built, would have been the first computer

1890 Punched cards: Herman Hollerith founds the data processing industry with an electric-powered machine based on punched cards, which wins a competition to process data for the US census. Hollerith's company becomes part of IBM, and punched cards - introduced by Joseph-Marie Jacquard to automate weaving in 1805 - dominate data processing until the 1970s

1946 Valve-based computing: John Presper Eckert and John W Mauchly complete Eniac (electronic numerical integrator analyser and computer), the first fully electronic programmable computer, for the US army. It has 18,000 valves (vacuum tubes), and weighs 30 tons

1947 Transistors: The Bell Laboratory scientists William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain develop the germanium transistor. This leads to a new generation of smaller, faster, computers, as well as the portable transistor radio (1952)

1958 Microchips: Americans Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce invent the integrated circuit, which enables vast numbers of transistors and other devices to be put on a single silicon chip. The circuits take over the computer industry

1965 Supercomputing: Seymour Cray develops the CD6600, the first supercomputer, at Control Data Corporation. Cray leaves to design a series of machines that run at the highest possible speed

1971 Microprocessors: Marcian "Ted" Hoff designs the Intel 4004, the first microprocessor or "computer on a chip". Cheap microprocessors power successive booms in pocket calculators, video games consoles, personal computers and other devices

1988 Parallel computing: Danny Hillis designs the Connection Machine, a supercomputer that uses 65,536 cheap microprocessors instead of a small number of Cray-style engines

1993 Intel launches the Pentium microprocessor with 3.1m transistors on a silicon chip. The Pentium and Microsoft Windows 95 bring about an explosion in PCs

1996 IBM's Deep Blue chess computer, developed from Carnegie-Mellon University's Deep Thought, beats the Russian grandmaster Garry Kasparov at chess. This is the first time a computer has beaten a human grand master in tournament play, although Kasparov wins the match 4-2
Jack Schofield

webTitle: Fiery end for Nasa's trail blazing satellite

fields.headline: Fiery end for Nasa's trail blazing satellite
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: About six tonnes of blazing metal hurtled into the Pacific ocean yesterday - all that remained of a $670m (£420m) US satellite that changed the way astronomers look at the universe.
fields.body:
About six tonnes of blazing metal hurtled into the Pacific ocean yesterday - all that remained of a $670m (£420m) US satellite that changed the way astronomers look at the universe.

Nasa chose to destroy the Compton gamma ray observatory while it was still in control of the craft, rather than risk deaths when it finally came back to earth of its own accord.

Compton, which gave astrophysicists new information about quasars, black holes and supernovas, had been intended to spend no more than five years in orbit but actually lasted nine.

Still, some scientists were almost sentimental about its fiery end. "The entire scientific community is disappointed," said Neil Gehrels, a scientist on the project. "I was profoundly saddened. This is a painful time for scientists who have used Compton for the last nine years."

Jim Ryan, a physicist on the project for years, said: "This is not the Nasa that put a man on the moon. Instead of 'can do' it is a shrug the shoulders and 'c'est la vie'."

However, the craft's orbit took it over many large cities, including Mexico City, Miami and Bangkok and Nasa be lieved that there was a one in 1,000 chance of it killing someone if it was allowed to re-enter the atmosphere on its own. The odds dropped to less than one in 29m with a controlled re-entry.

Ed Weiler, the agency's associate administrator, said: "To me, this is a rather simple question. It all comes down to what is the safest thing for innocent people on earth."

The re-entry was Nasa's first deliberate and controlled crash of a satellite. Mission control used rockets on the 17-tonne Compton to send it out of orbit and into the Pacific.

Some of the lighter pieces of debris were estimated to have taken 20 minutes to hit the water. "We got a positive confirmation," said Tom Quinn, director of the re-entry mission. "A job well done."

The agency decided three months ago that Compton's time was up when one of its three stabilising gyroscopes failed. The observatory might have operated for a further 11 years had no more of its equipment failed.

Nasa was not keen to repeat the experience of 21 years ago when pieces of Skylab, the 78-tonne abandoned space station, dropped out of control into the Indian ocean and across a remote part of Western Australia.

Compton was the first major space observatory to make a systematic survey of natural sources of gamma rays, which are both invisible and the most energetic part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

The craft detected more than 2,600 gamma ray bursts. "We discovered they came from everywhere, and from huge distances away," said Mr Gehrels. "We know now they are the biggest explosions in the universe because they are so far away and we see them so brightly."

The satellite's data has helped astronomers to begin to understand how black holes can trigger jets of x-rays and gamma rays at almost the speed of light.

webTitle: PM losing common touch, says Sawyer

fields.headline: PM losing common touch, says Sawyer
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday came under highly personal attack from his party's former general secretary, Lord Sawyer, who accused the prime minister of losing the common touch displayed by Margaret Thatcher in her prime.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday came under highly personal attack from his party's former general secretary, Lord Sawyer, who accused the prime minister of losing the common touch displayed by Margaret Thatcher in her prime.

In his second outspoken criticism of his party in a fortnight, Lord Sawyer - regarded as one of the leading architects of New Labour - said Mr Blair was no longer seen by voters as "our Tony". While people still regarded him as competent and professional, the Labour leader's personal standing had slipped in a way not experienced by Lady Thatcher, Lord Sawyer claimed.

The criticism is the most damaging personal assault on Mr Blair's leadership to have come from a senior party figure. Party strategists have always counted as a plus Mr Blair's personal standing with voters, who in the 1997 general election felt able to trust him in a way they had not felt able to trust Labour in the past.

Last month Lord Sawyer said that Mr Blair had to show more respect for Labour's traditions and achievements, suggesting his "command leadership style" was alienating some in his own party, but the latest criticisms are broader, relating to the prime minister's relationship with the electorate as a whole.

The unfavourable comparison with Lady Thatcher will be regarded as particularly cutting by No 10. The broadside is also an indication that recent attempts by a string of ministers to connect with traditional Labour values with an assault on Oxbridge privilege and elitism elsewhere have not yet convinced even party insiders that there is a sense of connection with the issues concerning voters.

Lord Sawyer told BBC Radio 4's The World This Weekend: "I think that at the election people did feel this Tony Blair is our guy, we like him. There is not so much of that around now."

When Mrs Thatcher was in her prime there was a feeling that "she was very close to the people", he added. "In a sense people don't feel that about Tony, they think he is very competent and very professional but he's not 'our Tony' really and that's what he's got to get."

Mr Blair's standing within his party was lower than in the country as a whole, having been badly damaged over party moves to control leadership selections for the London mayor and Welsh assembly, he said. There was a feeling among party workers that they were not "connected" with those in Downing Street.

Lord Sawyer was backed by the Labour MP Tony Wright, who told The World This Weekend: "I think there is a danger in government on focusing enormous attention on particulars and an enormous amount of attention on presentation of those particulars and then missing the big picture."

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, led the government's defence, dismissing suggestions it had become isolated from voters and stressing the need to maintain a coalition of support from across Britain.

He will today use a speech to the Communication Workers' Union conference in Bournemouth to reinforce the "no turning back" message, underlining government determination to press on with modernisation. It comes amid suggestions from some internal critics that ministers should now ease off on reform, particularly of the public sector, take the "foot off the pedal" and concentrate on rebutting Tory criticisms.

Mr Byers will say: "This is an important stage in this parliament. Voices will call for consolidation and even reconsideration of our objectives and direction. But we need to be clear: our agenda of modernisation and reform, aimed as it is at providing opportunities for all in a world of change, is one which is in touch and relevant to the needs and aspirations of the British people."

fields.headline: Just for fun
fields.standfirst: When you do it for a living, watching TV can be a chore. But even the most seasoned critic occasionally finds something genuinely enjoyable.  Mark Lawson reveals all
fields.trailText: When you do it for a living, watching TV can be a chore. But even the most seasoned critic occasionally finds something genuinely enjoyable.
fields.body:
Whereas psychologists and gynaecologists are sensibly barred from allowing a professional interest to become personal, critics should sometimes cross that line. Being a TV reviewer essentially means reviewing first episodes: this is the 54th of these Monday columns, and no show has yet been mentioned twice. But television - the art form most designed to be addictive - isn't experienced like that. The real test is the series which you continue watching for interest rather than income.

A couple of letters from readers have asked whether it's possible for a critic ever to watch television for sheer enjoyment. Well, yes. Before the TV reviewer's equivalent of the General Medical Council, I would have to confess to having formed a deep relationship with two of the subjects sent to me for analysis.

Hearts And Bones (Wednesday, 9.30pm, BBC1) concludes its first series in a mid-week slot because European football takes the Sunday night position which it's filled so impressively. This drama - which follows a group of thirtysomethings from student idealism in Coventry to compromise jobs and relationships in south London - was conceived by the BBC in envy of ITV's mid-life middle-class ensemble piece Cold Feet, but has grown up to show its own distinct identity.

Writer Stewart Harcourt takes a recurrent but compelling theme in literature: the hunger for another life. The plot consists of interlocking frustrations which revolve around Emma (Dervla Kirwan), who stayed with Mark (Damian Lewis) after a student pregnancy. In the opening episode, she finally married Mark - a decent but stolid teacher - but the ceremony proved to be a trigger to impermanence rather than a declaration of their durability.

She married with make-up masking a love-bite from hen-night infidelity with her boss - an indiscretion secondary to her organising torment: her deep and nervously returned love for her husband's brother, Richard (Hugo Speer).

In summary, this narrative can sound a little Dallas, but writing and acting reject melodrama for the genuine messy terrors of grown-up emotion. Hearts And Bones coincided with Channel 4's Anna Karenina (another extra-critical habit of mine, though milder than the two described here) and, in Emma, Kirwan and Harcourt have given us a plausible contemporary equivalent of that character and her dilemmas. Using the old reliable of infidelity to secure the audience's loyalty, Hearts And Bones also explores less developed territory. One episode focused on a parent's death from cancer.

One example of the cleverness in the writing is that Harcourt helps to establish realism by ignoring the neatnesses of fiction. Two of the central characters are redheads; two have the same first name. Most dramas would have one of each. The use of voiceover to give the characters' inner thoughts is irritating and unnecessary because the acting is good enough to suggest the unsaid. But perhaps that device could go in the well-deserved second series just commissioned.

My second current viewing obsession is Coupling (Friday, 9.30pm, BBC2), a comedy by Steven Moffat. Like Hearts And Bones, this results from scheduler's envy. British commissioners have long dreamed that some local comedy lab would clone Friends or Seinfield. Moffat's managed to cross them while creating a series which feels highly original.

Whereas the American model sitcoms were intended for US mass audience transmission, Coupling, on BBC2, can be more daring in its treatment of sex. The second episode was devoted entirely to size anxiety in men and included an inspired visual gag involving an improbably long bedroom drawer.

Last week's episode - in which Susan (Sarah Alexander) discovered a porn video belonging to new boyfriend Steve (Jack Davenport) - was a Men Behaving Badly set-up but climaxed in a daringly long speech (certain to paralyse most sit-com producers with size anxiety) in which Steve, at a dinner party, attempted to justify his most cherished cassette, Lesbian Porn Inferno, as an art film. Two other guests at the table - each mistakenly believing through a plausible dialogue misunderstanding that the other was gay - ended up in bed together because each arrogantly believed that homosexuals could be converted.

While Friends and Seinfield draw on a tradition of American cinematic and theatrical gag-writing, Moffat's scripts brilliantly utilise two characteristics of European comedy: surrealism and farce. This week's episode - set entirely in a bar - begins with routine laddish chat about the breasts of an attractive woman drinking alone. But, when Jeff (Richard Coyle) chats her up, she proves to be an Israeli tourist who speaks no English. The same lengthy scene is then played twice from the different linguistic perspectives - first with Jeff speaking English and the woman speaking Hebrew and then with their tongues reversed.

Through this trick, viewers learn the term Israelis use for breasts. Subsequently - in what must be a first for English sitcom - Moffat gets two huge pay-off laughs from a word of Hebrew. Comic writing of astonishing originality and invention.

In a critical version of the Uncertainty Principle, I've now turned them back into work by writing about them. But work's rarely been so pleasurable, and I'll watch every future episode without a notebook.

fields.headline: Blair gets tough with doctors
fields.standfirst:
'Consultant is king' culture must end, NHS summit at No 10 will be told

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today returns from paternity leave to chair a Downing Street summit on health service reform that is set to curb the overriding influence of consultants as part of the creation of a new regulatory framework.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today returns from paternity leave to chair a Downing Street summit on health service reform that is set to curb the overriding influence of consultants as part of the creation of a new regulatory framework.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will brief the prime minister on the detailed results of an NHS audit that has persuaded them that the government must move to end the "consultant is king" culture set in stone at the creation of the service in 1948.

The summit, including health ministers from the devolved administrations and dismissed by the Tories as evidence of a lack of Labour ideas, will discuss the early details of the national plan for the NHS, due to be published in July. Crucial will be moves to curb the power of consultants, whom Mr Blair and Mr Milburn see as one of the obstacles in the way of NHS modernisation.

The joint committee on health reform is expected to discuss in detail recommendations put forward to the NHS review by the Royal College of Nursing. Ministers are considering RCN proposals for a radical shake-up of the existing regulatory mechanisms governing the health service in order to move away from the professional self-regulation that has allowed cases such as the blundering gynaecological surgeon Rodney Ledward to slip through the net.

Mr Blair, who has been studying health papers while spending a fortnight's leave mainly at Chequers, has also personally asked that an RCN proposal to create a new class of specialist nurse for the elderly should be put on today's agenda. He and Mr Milburn believe that such nurses could help solve the problem of elderly patients being forced to stay in hospital after they are well enough to leave because of a lack of suitable intermediate care with appropriate staff.

A discussion paper commissioned by the RCN from Celia Davies, professor of healthcare at the Open University, and submitted to the review, suggests creating an independent regulatory body in which medical practitioners, whether doctors or nurses, would share a governing role with representatives of other "stakeholders", including employers, ancillary staff and patients.

The RCN's director of policy, Pippa Gough, said her organisation was concerned that a series of parallel reviews of regulation of health and social care staff would end up creating a piecemeal solution.

She said: "We have got a myriad of fragmented changes going on and none of these things seem to be joining up. We want to look for a system that would suit us all. With stakeholder regulation, no one authority would have overall power. Obviously within that the idea that the consumer is king, rather than the consultant, is absolutely key."

Government sources said the proposal was being examined, and stressed that Mr Milburn favoured radical reform of the general medical council, the doctors' regulatory body.

Yesterday, the health secretary told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost: "What we can't have is a situation where the practices of a small minority of doctors tarnish the reputation of the whole medical profession."

The Ledward case, in which a consultant botched operations on women for 16 years, was not unique but part of a recurring pattern, he said. "All too often there has been a pattern of poor performance, poor practice by a doctor that has gone on for many years. Very often people in the hospitals have known about it. It has been gossiped about but nobody has done a damn thing about it. That is just unacceptable."

A spokesman for the GMC said it recognised the need for a culture change, and had already instituted reforms including new guidance and performance procedures. But he appealed to Mr Milburn not to use the Ledward report as a "battering ram" against doctors, saying the case highlighted failures in NHS management as well as the existence of "rogue doctors" in the system.

Mr Milburn's audit, billed as a "hardnosed factual stock-take of current strengths and weaknesses" in the NHS, has established that Britain lags far behind other European states in doctor-patient ratios, having only 1.7 practising doctors per 1,000 population, against an EU average of 3.1.

Amid findings that the life expectancy rate for British women is also lower than the EU average, and that cancer survival rates - notably breast and colon cancer - are significantly poorer than on the continent, the plan will also signal extra investment in the government's priority areas of cancer, heart disease and mental health, sources say. The audit has also unearthed low-cost ways to improve preventive healthcare.

webTitle: Greece steps up bid to regain marbles

fields.headline: Greece steps up bid to regain marbles
fields.standfirst: Elgin marbles: special report
fields.trailText: Greece brings its battle to retrieve the Elgin marbles to London today with a package of proposals and arguments that New Labour officials are reportedly finding increasingly hard to resist.
fields.byline: Helena Smith  in Athens and  Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
Greece brings its battle to retrieve the Elgin marbles to London today with a package of proposals and arguments that New Labour officials are reportedly finding increasingly hard to resist.

George Papandreou, the Greek foreign minister, is expected to tell British politicians that the wonders need no longer be a cause of friction but one of friendship between the two countries.

Testifying before the Commons culture committee as part of its inquiry into the illicit trade of antiquities, Mr Papandreou is expected to say that the repatriation of the ancient carvings does not mean the British Museum will have to relinquish ownership of the 2,500 years old marbles or see its gallery being denuded of classical Greek art.

It is thought Mr Papandreou will also try to disabuse the committee of the long-held notion that Athens is incapable of both hosting and caring for the antiquities.

With a new international airport under construction and vast sums of European Union money being poured into infrastructure projects in the capital, Greeks say the argument that the British Museum is better placed to house the monuments no longer exists. "If they return the marbles will be the centrepiece of the rehabilitation of Athens' ancient city centre, of its links with its past and transformation into a vibrant modern European capital," said one culture ministry official.

In a clear change of strategy last month, Athens' new culture minister Theodore Pangalos, said Greece no longer saw the question of ownership of the artwork but that of their location as the issue of import.

"Global links mean the role of museums is changing," said a culture expert in Athens. "They are more open, less fixed. So why not have the British Museum establish a branch in Athens' new Acropolis museum where we could both share curatorial responsibility for the marbles?"

The Greek government has already proposed that the capital's cash-strapped British Archaeological School could assume the job of looking after the antiquities. It made the proposal in a new dossier outlining its claims which it delivered to the British parliament last April.

In recent months, Mr Papandreou has repeatedly said that the restitution of the marbles, removed from the Parthenon temple by the seventh Earl of Elgin in 1801, would revitalise bilateral cul tural ties by opening the way to a permanent exchange of archaeological exhibitions. Shortly before the culture select committee's visit to Athens in March he told the Guardian: "The British Museum will not be left empty. Greece is very willing to exchange whatever exhibition of other Greek artworks the museum may want."

Greek sources say the cultural exchange could be jointly overseen by archaeologists in Athens and curators in London.

Greek officials view their contact with the select committee as a critical part of the campaign to regain the marbles although the 11 cross-party members can only make recommendations and have no power to negotiate on behalf of the government.

William St Clair, senior research fellow of history at Cambridge University, said the plan could satisfy the needs of both Britain and Greece.

Mr Clair who wrote a book revealing that the British Museum had damaged the Elgin Marble during cleaning in the 1930s said: "The question of ownership seems to be less important than the question of trusteeship, access and questions of conservation and also the question of where they would be located in Athens, near the monument where they form a part, and if agreed to by the British government then this proposal would be excellent."

He said the plan for co-curatorship was a way of displaying all of the Elgin marbles together, as nearly half were still in Greece."That is a different proposal from any I've heard. When they were in Athens the public would be able to see them in their original context, because that's the only way you can really understand their meaning. The best bits are in London, but about 40% are still in Athens as is the Parthenon itself and the Acropolis site."

He said the British Museum had in the past failed to take proper care of them: "In the late 1930s many of the marbles were very badly damaged, their surfaces scratched by metal tools and abrasives, by the British Museum.

"The British Museum for the last 60 years had a secret policy to prevent the public, parliament and the scholarly community from knowing this. The claim that they've been looked after well does not stand up to scrutiny."

fields.headline: Highgrove's happy day
fields.standfirst:
Why did The Grocer have to spoil it?

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Sometimes The Royals seems even more ingeniously scripted than The Royles. Only 18 months ago Charles and Camilla were pictured blinking against the flashlights as they left the Ritz after their first public engagement together. That was described as a breakthrough. Now the Queen has been to a party despite knowing that Camilla would be there.
fields.body:
Sometimes The Royals seems even more ingeniously scripted than The Royles. Only 18 months ago Charles and Camilla were pictured blinking against the flashlights as they left the Ritz after their first public engagement together. That was described as a breakthrough. Now the Queen has been to a party despite knowing that Camilla would be there. This is described as a moment of history. Camilla curtsied; they chatted; everyone seemed very pleased, especially Charles. The Duke was away, said to be engaged with his horses. True or false? Take your pick. And then, just when everything was going so well, what do we get but the unexpected twist all audiences long for. Charles's sister has given an interview to The Grocer, dismissing his cherished or ganic farming and lauding genetically modified food, which he hates.

To accept Camilla's presence must have been tough for the Queen. She seems to be far more rigorous about these moral questions than most of her subjects. who may mostly conclude that it's good to see a stable relationship flourishing in a family which sometimes seems to be not very good at them. Of course we are loudly assured that even this moment of history should not be construed to suggest they will ever get married. There are difficulties with the church on that, as well as with the Queen. Even so, it would not be surprising if already the theme of marriage was being pencilled in for the next big twist in the tale, as soon as we're over this one.
