webTitle: Trustee of Keir Hardie's cloth cap

fields.headline: Trustee of Keir Hardie's cloth cap
fields.standfirst:
"I imagine that Prescott convinced himself that what he said was true"

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott is the best deputy leader in Labour party history. Too many of his predecessors - Morrison, Bevan, Brown, Healey and Hattersley - were failed leaders who accepted the job as a consolation prize.
fields.body:
John Prescott is the best deputy leader in Labour party history. Too many of his predecessors - Morrison, Bevan, Brown, Healey and Hattersley - were failed leaders who accepted the job as a consolation prize. Prescott regards it as worthwhile in itself and therefore realises that his principal task is to support the leader. That is the one aspect of the role which I once thought I discharged with credit. However, I never suggested that Kinnock had won the men's singles at Wimbledon or invented the Hovercraft. So I have begun to wonder if I failed in my duty. For none of those claims is less plausible than Prescott's Gillingham assertion that "the values that motivated Keir Hardie are the same ones that motivate Tony Blair".

I console myself with the thought that, for all its good intentions, Prescott's encomium may not have been good deputy-leadership. Indeed it very probably damaged the cause he hoped to promote. The fact that he thought it necessary to confirm Tony Blair's philosophic convictions was an admission that he knew the leader's ideological integrity to be in doubt. That is hardly surprising since - government policy aside - the prime minister is careful never to call himself a socialist or even a social democrat. But the Downing Street press office has never let the evidence stand in the way of a good soundbite. So it is reasonable to assume that some bright spark thought that Prescott - who always looks, and sometimes sounds, like the embodiment of traditional Labour values - could convince disillusioned party workers that Blair was, at least in spirit, wearing Keir Hardie's cloth cap. I take it for granted that they were concerned with Hardie's image rather than his ideas.

Because John Prescott is an honest man, I can imagine him convincing himself that what he said was true. And it is certainly an idea to conjure with. Perhaps Tony Blair does believe that "considering the increasing burden which private ownership of land and capital is imposing on the useful members of the community, the poverty and destitution and general moral and physical deterioration resulting from a competitive system", the time has come for "the foundation of a socialist commonwealth built on the common ownership of land and capital". I certainly hope so. But if those sentiments - the substance of the first resolution which Hardie moved in the House of Commons - were also the theme of an early Blair speech, much to my regret I missed it.

My hope that Tony Blair does have Hardie-like attitudes, is heightened by the prospect of the prime minister emulating Labour's first leader on the occasion of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. When the Victorian House of Commons sent the Duke of York congratulations on the birth of his daughter, Hardie observed that "the life of one Welsh miner is of greater commercial and moral value to the British nation than the whole royal crown put together from the royal grandmamma down . . ." I wait with impatience to hear the PM's views on the royal grandmamma on that glorious day in July.

Whether or not the Prescott rearguard action was justified by the facts of Tony Blair's political convictions, I doubt that the heroic defence of the prime minister's Labour credentials will have done much to console disgruntled members of the party. "Put up to it by Alastair Campbell," they will say. Much of the deputy leader's strength, and most of his popularity, depends on him being outside the Downing Street publicity machine. So although the extraordinary comparison will not have increased the prime minister's socialist credibility, it may well have reduced Prescott's reputation as the last bastion of traditional socialist values. Rightly or wrongly the party think of him as "the resistance movement", working underground and waiting for the glorious day of liberation. That belief prevents thousands of Labour supporters from tearing up their party cards.

Twenty years ago, when the Labour party had made itself unelectable, a handful of us - Denis Healey, Peter Shore, John Smith, Denis Howell and I - came together to form a wholly ineffectual organisation. I am embarrassed to admit that, after much argument, we called it Labour Solidarity. But I gladly concede that we never expected that alone it could change history and drag the party back into the mainstream of politics. We just aimed to demonstrate that the real Labour party was not dead but sleeping. Because of our existence, men and women who might have jumped ship hung on in the hope of surviving to see the reincarnation of the real Labour party. Sad to say, the same sort of people are looking for similar signs today. John Prescott's existence provides one. His value to the party is too great for his reputation to be sacrificed by palpably foolish claims about Tony Blair's convictions.

Perhaps Tony Blair does believe that "considering the increasing burden which private ownership of land and capital is imposing on the useful members of the community, the poverty and destitution and general moral and physical deterioration resulting from a competitive system", the time has come for "the foundation of a socialist commonwealth built on the common ownership of land and capital". I certainly hope so. But if those sentiments - the substance of the first resolution which Hardie moved in the House of Commons - were also the theme of an early Blair speech, much to my regret I missed it. My hope that Tony Blair does have Hardie-like attitudes, is heightened by the prospect of the prime minister emulating Labour's first leader on the occasion of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. When the Victorian House of Commons sent the Duke of York congratulations on the birth of his daughter, Hardie observed that "the life of one Welsh miner is of greater commercial and moral value to the British nation than the whole royal crown put together from the royal grandmamma down . . ." I wait with impatience to hear the PM's views on the royal grandmamma on that glorious day in July. Whether or not the Prescott rearguard action was justified by the facts of Tony Blair's political convictions, I doubt that the heroic defence of the prime minister's Labour credentials will have done much to console disgruntled members of the party. "Put up to it by Alastair Campbell," they will say. Much of the deputy leader's strength, and most of his popularity, depends on him being outside the Downing Street publicity machine. So although the extraordinary comparison will not have increased the prime minister's socialist credibility, it may well have reduced Prescott's reputation as the last bastion of traditional socialist values. Rightly or wrongly the party think of him as "the resistance movement", working underground and waiting for the glorious day of liberation. That belief prevents thousands of Labour supporters from tearing up their party cards. Twenty years ago, when the Labour party had made itself unelectable, a handful of us - Denis Healey, Peter Shore, John Smith, Denis Howell and I - came together to form a wholly ineffectual organisation. I am embarrassed to admit that, after much argument, we called it Labour Solidarity. But I gladly concede that we never expected that alone it could change history and drag the party back into the mainstream of politics. We just aimed to demonstrate that the real Labour party was not dead but sleeping. Because of our existence, men and women who might have jumped ship hung on in the hope of surviving to see the reincarnation of the real Labour party. Sad to say, the same sort of people are looking for similar signs today. John Prescott's existence provides one. His value to the party is too great for his reputation to be sacrificed by palpably foolish claims about Tony Blair's convictions. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Kosovo faces invasion of salesmen
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: British firms will this week relaunch their campaign to gain a bigger share of work in the £2.5bn reconstruction of Kosovo after being beaten to the punch by European rivals in the year since the conflict ended.
fields.body:
British firms will this week relaunch their campaign to gain a bigger share of work in the £2.5bn reconstruction of Kosovo after being beaten to the punch by European rivals in the year since the conflict ended.

A delegation led by Richard Caborn, minister for trade, will mark the anniversary of the Serb withdrawal from the province this week by offering British assistance to help Kosovo develop the infrastructure, education and training skills needed to relaunch the economy.

Britain set up a Kosovo taskforce a year ago with the explicit aim of helping British firms win a far greater share of contracts to rebuild the province than had been the case in other parts of the region such as Bosnia - dominated by US groups. Mr Caborn said yesterday he was pleased with the progress made by British firms. "I'm very satisfied with the work we have done there and we have got a lot of credit, not least through the role of Tony Blair during the conflict."

But Eric Pearson, director of international contracts for Taylor Woodrow, the construction and house-building firm, said money for many infrastructure projects had dried up and British firms had been left behind European competitors.

"We need a more pro-active government approach and the opening of aid budgets to companies across the EU," he said.

Taylor Woodrow was part of a consortium including National Grid and Scottish and Southern Energy given a £1m contract to restore and maintain the supply of fuel to two power stations outside the capital of Pristina and to rebuild the plants there.

The plants are run on open-cast lignite. Mr Caborn said this was an example of how the British had been ahead of the game.

"Kosovans are a can-do nation and the people want to get on and start rebuilding the country _ We can help them become a major exporter of energy in the medium term based on their supplies of lignite."

But Mr Pearson said: "We thought this would prepare the way for other UK companies looking for work in Kosovo. But we have not been back in there since as there's no money available. We wanted to be involved and expected the power station contract would lead to more commercial orders but no."

"We would like to be in there helping people but it is frustrating and we've effectively been told by military friends to steer clear. We could throw money into it but it would be into a black hole and we would be better putting our business development budget into the areas we focus on," he said.

webTitle: US and Russia clash over missile shield

fields.headline: US and Russia clash over missile shield
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton and Vladimir Putin last night clashed over hotly contested US plans for a national missile shield, with the Russian leader using his first summit with the president to tell him his scheme amounts to a cure worse than the disease it is designed to treat.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton and Vladimir Putin last night clashed over hotly contested US plans for a national missile shield, with the Russian leader using his first summit with the president to tell him his scheme amounts to a cure worse than the disease it is designed to treat.

The last US-Russian summit of the Clinton years and the first of the Putin era saw the two sides agree that global strategic stability in the 21st century faced a fresh threat from so-called rogue states and the proliferation of ballistic missile technology. But they differed profoundly over how to tackle the dangers.

The leaders pushed through deals on a multibillion dollar programme to dispose of tens of tonnes of weapons-grade plutonium and on an ambitious joint early warning system aimed at countering the risk of accidental launches of nuclear missiles. But on the crucial issue of the summit, they agreed to disagree.

"We agreed to a statement of principles ... that makes clear there is an emerging ballistic missile threat that must be addressed," Mr Clinton said as the summit concluded in the Kremlin. "But we have not yet agreed on how best to do so."

Mr Putin said that the row over National Missile Defence (NMD) was "one of the most difficult issues to solve. There are a lot of problems there".

The NMD row represents the first big clash over arms control between the US and Russia for years, recalling the confrontation of the cold war. Mr Putin said there was a "commonality" between them - the possibility of new threats. But he added: "We're against having a cure which is worse than the disease."

The $60bn (£37bn) NMD programme, dubbed "son of Star Wars", has upset Washington's Nato allies and triggered criticism last week from the German chancellor Gerhard Schröder. It dominated the Moscow summit yesterday whose central result was the joint "statement of principles on strategic stability".

To proceed with NMD, Washington must persuade Russia to amend the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, signed by Richard Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev, or ditch it altogether.

The Putin concessions were to admit there is a risk posed by states such as North Korea, Iran, and Iraq, and to agree to keep negotiating, with US and Russian experts commissioned to draft a report.

Both sides agreed that "the international community is facing a mounting menace of the proliferation of mass destruction weaponry and its delivery means. They agree that problems related to the menace must be considered and solved on the basis of mutual cooperation and account of each other's interests."

America argues that the "strategic environment" has changed dramatically since the end of the cold war, requiring a more flexible approach. Mr Putin seems to be winning the battle for public opinion at home and in Europe by appearing flexible on arms control while insisting there can be no amendments to the ABM treaty.

Despite the enormous gulf between them, the presidents were full of praise for one another. Mr Putin referred to the US leader as a "comfortable and pleasant partner", while Mr Clinton said the Russian president was "fully capable of building a prosperous, strong Russia while preserving freedom and the rule of law". He criticised Russia's war in Chechnya, however.

For economic reasons, Mr Putin is keen to pursue deeper strategic arms reduction agreements with the US. Mr Clinton made clear that here he could hold Russia hostage if it refused to budge on missile defence and the ABM amendments.

Mr Putin wants a new deal with the US reducing nuclear arsenals to 1,500 warheads. Mr Clinton said it would be difficult to go below 2,000 unless there was a breakthrough on NMD.

webTitle: Business back in contention after learning rules of the game in Seattle

fields.headline: Business back in contention after learning rules of the game in Seattle
fields.standfirst: World Trade Organisation: special report
fields.trailText: Not so long ago trade was boring - a subject dealt with by a close-knit group of bureaucrats off the radar screen of public awareness. Then came the battle of Seattle, when a ragtag army of trade unionists, environmentalists and anarchists gave the forces of globalisation a bloody nose by derailing plans for a new round of trade liberalisation talks. The "victors" have been crowing about their success ever since.
fields.body:
Not so long ago trade was boring - a subject dealt with by a close-knit group of bureaucrats off the radar screen of public awareness. Then came the battle of Seattle, when a ragtag army of trade unionists, environmentalists and anarchists gave the forces of globalisation a bloody nose by derailing plans for a new round of trade liberalisation talks. The "victors" have been crowing about their success ever since.

In reality, the talks were doomed even before the first brick or bottle was thrown. Governments with irreconcilable positions on agriculture and labour standards saw to that. But there is no doubt that governance of the global trading system has moved from being a subject for quiet diplomacy to the stuff of high politics.

If, however, the protesters think they have done anything more than contribute to delaying the start of a new trade round, they are mistaken. The US Congress has just paved the way for China's entry to the World Trade Organisation by approving permanent normal trade relations - an event of truly historical proportions which will eventually open the biggest closed market in the world. The wheels are well and truly back on the free trade bandwagon. It is only a question of time before it begins moving again.

The US presidential election will probably prevent the launch of a new round of talks before next year but once a new incumbent is in the White House the process will accelerate. Not necessarily because of an ideological predisposition towards free trade on the part of either Al Gore or George Bush Jr but because it is companies, not governments, who are in the driving seat of globalisation. While governments fumble over attempts to devise new rules and regulations to govern their behaviour, companies are moving on, using new technology to reach expanded international markets. Governments must catch up.

To succeed in their ambitions multi-national companies are increasingly beginning to realise that they must behave responsibly, operating according to a broader set of principles, such as the trade-environment link, rather than simply focusing on the bottom line. Post-Seattle, with the support of civil society now essential for financial success, trading responsibly is the bottom line. If you don't believe that, try asking BP or Monsanto.

So far, the most visible evidence of changing attitudes in the business community is the proliferation of individual company mission statements. But talks reaching a climax this week in Paris at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development have the potential to produce something more significant. For the past 18 months or so representatives of the world's 29 richest industrial nations - plus Argentina, Brazil and Chile - have been locked in negotiations over the so-called guidelines for multinational enterprises, a voluntary code of conduct for multinationals first drawn up in the 1970s and now being updated.

After extensive consultations with unions, employers and non-governmental organisations (NGOs), the OECD's executive committee in special session will sit down today and tomorrow to discuss a draft text which it hopes will satisfy all interested parties.

The text first lays down a set of general principles by which all businesses should abide, including respecting human rights, contributing to sustainable development and promoting the welfare of employees, and then goes on to detail specific responsibilities in several key areas, including disclosure, employment and industrial relations, the environment, taxation, science and technology, consumer interests and combating bribery.

Of course, none of the commitments which companies are asked to make is legally enforceable. Unscrupulous companies could flout them at their will without suffering formal sanctions. However, post-Seattle, they will do so at their peril.

The guidelines represent an opportunity for all sides in the globalisation debate to rebuild trust. If agreed, they will give something to everyone. If the unions and NGOs give them their blessing, they will be publicly acknowledging what business is so keen to emphasise - that multinationals can and do fulfil an important role in promoting development through their investment activities. While the saner NGOs have always been prepared to acknowledge this, their voices have been largely unheard in the public debate since Seattle, to the detriment of the poor.

In a new paper*, staff from the development research group at the World Bank illustrate the harm that would be inflicted on the poor if governments were to listen too hard to the protesters at Seattle and retreat from open markets. Using data from 80 countries over four decades, the paper shows that growth spurred by open trade or other macro policies (good rule of law, low government spending) benefits the poor as much as it does the typical household. In fact, income of the poor rises one-for-one with overall growth. As the paper says, this does not imply that growth is all that is needed to improve the lives of the poor. But it does demonstrate that attempts to block free-trade, though well intentioned, are misguided.

If the business lobby can sign up to the guidelines, it will be demonstrating to civil society that it is more than just an uncaring profit machine. But to ensure the guidelines are more than just window dressing there will have to be effective mechanisms for holding companies to account if they transgress. There are plans for OECD countries to have contact points which will deal with complaints and disputes. In Britain's case, it will be the Department of Trade and Industry. Unions and NGOs have legitimate concerns about the ability or willingness of a department devoted to promoting the interests of British business to act as an impartial judge.

International trade and investment is unstoppable. To avoid playing into the hands of the extreme right, which would prefer minimal regulation, the left has to acknowledge that rules of the game are necessary to prevent a slide into anarchy. The OECD's guidelines for multinational enterprises have the potential to become a small part of the framework for future governance of the global economy. A lot more hard work on the part of governments will need to be done to convince critics that free trade is good for them and for the people they say they are trying to protect. Agreement from all sides on the guidelines would be a good start.

*Growth Is Good for the Poor. David Dollar, Aart Kraay (www.worldbank.org/research)

fields.headline: Rory Carroll @ Belgrade
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Welcome to public relations Serbian-style, a shifting landscape of indignation, charm and aggression. Kosovo is lost, but one year on the Serbs reckon the propaganda battle is there to be won
fields.body:
The lights dim, the hall falls silent and on the screen arcadia appears in soft focus. Horses gallop across sun-drenched meadows. Birds soar above jagged peaks. Children skip in a playground. Dew speckles bulging red grapes. Couples with perfect teeth whoosh down ski slopes. A scientist makes a breakthrough in a laboratory. Bare breasts jiggle on the beach. The sun sets over a medieval monastery. This was Serbia before the bombing, announce our hosts. An appreciative murmur ripples across the guests. Another video starts to the accompaniment of a furious pianist.

Clouds darken, buildings explode, smoke seeps from the horizon, people run, an elderly woman opens her mouth to scream but cannot, the whole screen is aflame. That, dear colleagues, is what your shameful, perfidious and Jesuitically cruel lies made possible, you disgraceful tools of Nato, announce our hosts, the Federation of Yugoslav Journalists, and therefore the government.

Welcome to public relations Serbian-style, a shifting landscape of indignation, charm and aggression. Kosovo is lost, but one year on the Serbs reckon the propaganda battle is there to be won. Dusan Djordjevic, director of the state newsagency, Tanjug, warms to his theme. Dear colleagues, it is a pleasure to greet you, you who have been so unprofessional, servile and dishonest. You literally disgraced yourselves. (Murmured appreciation again ripples around the hall, because most of the 70 assembled foreign journalists assume they are exempted, and are happy to let the hosts pay for the hotel, meals and half the air fare. )

Ostensibly the aim of the four-day charabanc to factories, bridges and press conferences is to highlight Serbia's need for help in reconstruction, yet other impulses intrude. Production figures for the Zastava car factory mutate into an angry diatribe. Why did you do this, why?

Defiance and pride, never scarce here, undermine some of the presentations. A video on reconstruction shows breakneck repairs restoring the lost arcadia without help. Paeans to self-sufficiency and resourcefulness abruptly end in pleas for aid. Question and answer sessions develop a rhythm. The Iraqi pledges solidarity with Serbia. Likewise the Jordanian, Syrian, Armenian, Georgian and Chinese. The Slovakian grovels over his country's collaboration with Nato. Some Brits, Yanks and Italians spoil the mood by asking when Mr Milosevic will be overthrown. Waiting outside to interview us are TV crews from state-controlled channels who will that night cite our presence as proof of international support. Some sign a declaration confirming it.

Occasionally the real world intrudes. In the wall over the left shoulder of the receptionist at our hotel, the Intercontinental, is a bullet hole from the shootout that killed Arkan. Four-hour queues snake from petrol stations, some of which have bought all their own stocks and resell it on the black market 20 metres from the pumps. Everybody bitches about the opposition being divided, ineffectual and vain. Shops and bars are full of smartly dressed people but they say things are worse than ever. Jobs are scarce. Those that pay real money scarcer still.

Back in the conference another appeal for sanctions to be lifted veers into a tirade about the victimisation of a peace-loving state and fabricated horror stories about Kosovo. A catalogue of the 982 Serbs murdered in Kosovo in the past 12 months hits home, but many other presentations are too emotive and crude to be of interest. Organisers look hurt as more journalists peel away.

What has been achieved is uncertain but according to Serb television, Nato's big lie is now poised to unravel. On the final morning is the last throw of the dice, a trip to Belgrade's brewery. No explanation why or what it means, but the hosts are insistent: "Just drink."

webTitle: Complementary medicine gets a boost from arthritis charity

fields.headline: Complementary medicine gets a boost from arthritis charity
fields.trailText: Complementary medicine received a boost yesterday after a medical charity announced it is switching its focus to alternative therapies in its efforts to beat arthritis, after spending 60 years backing conventional drug-based research.
fields.body:
Complementary medicine received a boost yesterday after a medical charity announced it is switching its focus to alternative therapies in its efforts to beat arthritis, after spending 60 years backing conventional drug-based research.

Until now, the Arthritis Research Campaign, the fifth largest medical charity in the UK, has only funded work into mainstream drug-based research.

But the organisation said the huge rise in the number of arthritis patients who seek relief from chronic pain through alternative medicine had prompted it to reconsider its position.

The charity announced that it aims to work with complementary therapists and scientists to work out ways of testing how effective different therapies are, and to fund studies.

Much complementary therapy, including dietary supplements, homeopathy, herbalism, hypnotherapy and acupuncture, remains scientifically unproven, the charity said.

Despite this, one in three people had tried complementary therapies, and 66% of rheumatoid arthritis sufferers used diet supplements, hypnotherapy or homeopathy to help alleviate their pain.

Launching the new initiative yesterday, the chief executive of the campaign, Fergus Logan, said: "New medicines and treatments have traditionally been developed under a convention which says in a nutshell 'Don't use it if you can't prove it'. But in complementary medicine, it is often believed that proof is provided by use."

fields.headline: Grey power bites back
fields.standfirst:
Pensioners have shown they have political clout. Now the challenge is for them to learn how to use it

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Pensioners have shown they have political clout. Now the challenge is for them to learn how to use it
fields.body:
There are several things you can do with 75p. You can treat yourself to a regular portion of fries at McDonald's, pick up a copy of the Telegraph on a Saturday, or a decent-sized aubergine from the supermarket. The one thing you cannot do with that sum of money, it is now patently clear, is present it to older people as a weekly rise in their state pension and expect them to vote for you in large numbers.

Deep down a government as poll conscious and image-obsessed as this one must have always known that. But when it expressed its determination to keep the pension index-linked it was more than just a mathematical calculation. There was political arithmetic there too. Labour figured that a sizeable number of pensioners would not vote for it anyway and the rest would have little choice but to continue doing so, because the alternatives are worse.

The trouble is the government got its sums wrong. The numbers were crunched on the understanding that older people are capable of complaining but not fighting back. It had become trapped in a paradigm of patronage which understands pensioners at worst as burdens on the public purse and at best as victims of vagaries ranging from bad weather to street crime.

It is not a mindset particular to Labour. As the bunting unfolds and the guest list is drawn up for the Queen Mother's 100th birthday party, it is a view that will underpin a national obsession. Strip away the patriotic paraphernalia and you are left with a popular figurehead of an unpopular family who derives her support from the fact that she is old and therefore people think she doesn't really matter. The nation will coo at her frailty and marvel at the very resilience of her years but they do not expect her to say or do anything but wave and smile. We may be her subjects; but she is our object.

But to regard pensioners as recipients of, rather than agents within, the political process is at worst patronising and at best naive. "The only time you see old people in the papers is when they've got a black eye and they've just been mugged," says 82-year-old Peggy Jones. "But we're not after sympathy. We're after a decent income, proper healthcare, and a good transport system. We want what everybody else wants."

Peggy, who lives in Brighton, belongs to a pensioners' group which organises meetings and lobbies everyone from MPs and councillors to bus companies and health boards about pensioner's demands. Attendance at their monthly meetings occasionally hits 100, but is more often between 30 and 40 a time. "It's not huge numbers," says Isla Robertson, 67. "But it's a far better turnout that you get at most Labour party meetings." Isla and Peggy are part of a growing movement that any political party ignores at its peril. In America they have earned the name the Grey Panthers; throughout Europe they are labelled as the advocates of grey power. But demographically, politically and economically, it is a global force that has come of age.

Pensioners make up one quarter of the nation's electorate; within a few decades it will be more like a third. Moreover, they are more likely to vote than almost any other group. They may not all be radical; but many, if not most, are angry and are feeling bitterly disappointed by this government. This is the generation who helped build the welfare state and are now being told they are a burden upon it. It will soon include many who were politicised during the 60s. Not all of their criticisms of this government are necessarily fair. But politics isn't fair. Labour has offered pensioners what it thinks they need rather than what pensioners have said they want. Now they are being punished.

At the last pensioners' parliament in Blackpool, attended by more than 2,000 delegates and organised by the lobby group the National Pensioner's Convention, dissidents argued for direct action, sit-ins and for their vote conditional on Labour returning the link between pensions and average male earnings. They remain a minority but their numbers, like their frustration, is growing. And they are not going to shut up for the price of a cup of tea and a pat on the head.

Labour found this out the hard way during last month's local elections. Three quarters of the Labour councillors who lost their seats in last month's local elections said pensioners, angry at the miserly increase, had largely contributed to their defeat. Until then the government responded to pensioners by doing what it always does when criticised by those who expect more. It presents a list of all it has done, and expects scales to fall from the eyes of the detractors and gratitude to come rolling in.

"Every time I write to my local MP," says Robertson, "they tell me all the things I should be thankful for - the heating allowance, the free eye tests, waiving the TV licence fee and all of that. But I don't want concessions. I don't want charity. I want a decent income so I can be independent."

Now a government which has started its life rebranding both Britain and itself as young and trendy, has been forced to redirect its message. Within 10 days of the local elections the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, was calling for more positive images of older people in the media. The chancellor now plans to up the pension next month by between £2 and £3, regardless of inflation. William Hague, sensing an Achilles' heel, has been throwing around spending commitments like confetti. The substance of his offers - which are flimsy, particularly given the Tories' record on pensioners while in government - is not as important as the fact of them. Older people are on the agenda.

They are not, in Britain at least, yet setting the agenda. Experience from Europe and America suggests that it will not be long before they start doing so. In the key swing state of Florida pensioners are a crucial constituency. In 1994 parties representing the elderly won seats in parliament in both the Netherlands and Luxembourg and more than 100,000 votes in Belgium. By the end of the decade most of these groups had split or faded. But British pensioners can learn as much from their fall as their rise. Most of these parties collapsed for the same reasons that most pressure groups of this kind do. Pensioners may be be united by age but they are divided by class, gender, race or region. Once the main parties had incorporated the principal demands of pensioners into their manifestos the need for separate parties became obsolete.

But they forced their demands into the mainstream by uniting around a common cause and remaining independent. At present British pensioners remain divided between charities, consumer groups and campaigning organisations which have links with Labour which are too close to exercise any real political leverage. Politicians have only just begun to realise the potential of grey power; British pensioners, have so far, only just begun to capitalise on it.

webTitle: Mugabe regime prepares to axe white judges

fields.headline: Mugabe regime prepares to axe white judges
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe's government stepped up its attack on Zimbabwe's white minority yesterday by launching an assault on senior judges of British descent.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe's government stepped up its attack on Zimbabwe's white minority yesterday by launching an assault on senior judges of British descent.

In a series of comments in the state-run media, the government accused judges sitting in the supreme and high courts of being ill-qualified to pass judgment in politically sensitive cases, on the grounds that legally, they were not citizens of Zimbabwe.

Several high court judges, black and white, are planning to make a public protest today against the claims. There are fears that the accusations will be followed by a direct attempt to have white judges removed from the bench.

The escalation of antagonism against the white minority signals an attempt to weaken the position of Zimbabwe's judiciary, widely seen as one of the last bastions of independence in the country. The courts have made several rulings against the Mugabe government.

Two of the five supreme court judges are white, including the chief justice, Anthony Gubbay. Four of the 20 high court judges are also white.

The accusations against the white judges were made by Jonathan Moyo, a government spokesman and the architect of the campaign by Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party in the general election on June 24 and 25.

"No sane Zimbabwean should expect the judiciary to be headed by a foreigner - especially a British - 20 years af ter our independence, just like it would be insane to have a foreign or British president or speaker of parliament," he said in the state-owned Sunday Mail newspaper.

Mr Moyo claimed that Mr Gubbay had not renounced his claim to British citizenship properly, and therefore was not a Zimbabwean citizen.

He also reiterated the government's new policy, introduced two weeks ago, that all Zimbabweans of British descent should have renounced their claims to British citizenship, under both Zimbabwean and British law, by December 1985. Those who did not have been stripped of their Zimbabwean citizenship.

"Among those who allegedly did not comply is chief justice Gubbay," Mr Moyo said. "Justice Gubbay and his affected colleagues face serious questions about the legal and political legitimacy of their positions as judges."

Similar accusations were levelled in radio and television news bulletins from the state-owned Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC). The allegations were also made in the weekly Mirror newspaper, whose publisher and editor is a member of Zanu-PF.

The citizenship office has stated that an estimated 86,000 people are no longer Zimbabwean citizens - this means that they are no longer eligible to vote.

The government has also issued a new policy stating that permanent residents are not eligible to vote, despite clauses in the constitution which say clearly that they do have that right.

A high court judge, Michael Gillespy, yesterday refuted the government's allegations that he was not a Zimbabwean citizen.

"I am a citizen of Zimbabwe and I have never had any other citizenship," he said, adding that he was "contemplating instructing attorneys to take legal action against those making these statements".

Britain's shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, who made a 36-hour visit to Zimbabwe at the weekend, called on the Commonwealth to increase the number of its observers at the forthcoming elections from the current 44 to 300 to 500. "It is essential that observers should stay for at least two or three weeks after the election, to reduce the chance of violent retribution," he added.

Mr Maude was responding to widespread reports that government officials are threatening to beat and even kill rural Zimbabweans if they vote for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. Twenty-eight opposition supporters have been killed since April 1.

"It is absolutely clear that what is going on is a deliberate policy of state terrorism which derives directly from the head of state," Mr Maude said. "From what I've heard and seen it is very hard to see how this can be an open and fair election. There has been gerrymandering, rigging of electoral rolls and widespread intimidation."

webTitle: Short snubs Greenpeace to back oil project

fields.headline: Short snubs Greenpeace to back oil project
fields.trailText: Britain will tomorrow throw its weight behind a project backed by the World Bank to build a controversial oil pipeline between two African states - despite fierce opposition from environmentalists and human rights campaigners who warn that it will evict local tribes from their ancient rainforest.
fields.body:
Britain will tomorrow throw its weight behind a project backed by the World Bank to build a controversial oil pipeline between two African states - despite fierce opposition from environmentalists and human rights campaigners who warn that it will evict local tribes from their ancient rainforest.

In a move which puts her at odds with groups such as Greenpeace, Clare Short, the international development secretary, will cast Britain's vote on the World Bank's executive board in favour of releasing funding for the pipeline between Chad and Cameroon.

The government expects the project to be approved with overwhelming support.

Defending Britain's position, Ms Short told the Guardian: "Chad and Cameroon are two desperately poor countries ... In oil, they have an incredibly valuable resource that can be used to accelerate their economic development and reduce poverty. At the moment both countries are too poor to afford basic public services for the majority of the people.

"In a few years, the pipeline could greatly increase government revenues - allowing them to increase their investment in health, education, environment, infrastructure and rural development."

The World Bank plans to provide loans and assistance worth around $365m (£240m) to the privately managed project which will cost $3.7bn.

Although the public money represents a small proportion of the total cost, it is seen by the oil companies involved as enhancing the project's image.

The project, headed by a consortium including Exxon, Petronas of Malaysia, and Chevron, will pump an estimated 900m barrels of oil from southern Chad over a period of about 25 years and move it 1000km through a purpose-built pipeline to Kribi on the Cameroon coast. The pipeline will criss-cross through the Bagyeli people's ancestral forests.

Ms Short said: "The involvement of the World Bank in this project will help to ensure that the oil resources are used for pro-poor development and improve transparency in the management of public finances; and it means that social and environmental safeguards are much stronger than would otherwise have been the case.

"With this project, as with others, Britain will use its influence to insist that all the appropriate controls are in place and that they are implemented rigorously and monitored closely as the project proceeds. Our concern is to make the project work for the poor of Chad and Cameroon."

The World Bank says it has taken steps to make sure the pipeline will have only a minor impact on the natural and human environments, including burying it underground and minimising the amount of rain forest that will be lost as a result of construction.

But Greenpeace said the project should be abandoned altogether. Spokesman Paul Horsman said: "This is a project which should not go ahead.

"It will destroy rare rain forest, evict local people and lock these countries into fossil fuel production when the World Bank should be encouraging the development of sustainable, indigenous renewable energy supplies."

He claimed that opposition to the project in Chad and Cameroon had been stifled by intimidation. " If you stand up to oppose it there, you are liable to be shot," said Mr Horsman.

Ms Short said the World Bank had estimated that the project could result in nearly $2bn in revenue for Chad and $500m for Cameroonover the 25-year production period.

About 80% of Chad's 7m people live on incomes of less than $1 a day.

The country's president, Idriss Deby, has done his best in recent months to convince the World Bank it should give the green light.

But opponents remain concerned about the involvement of Petronas in the consortium. In neighbouring Sudan, the company is active on two oilfields which have come in for bad publicity on human rights recently, particularly in North America.

The US government has imposed sanctions against the Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company, a consortium operating in Sudan and of which Petronas is part.

fields.headline: Ritblat homes in on Liberty
fields.standfirst: £514m share stake brings together shopping mall tycoons who believe big is beautiful
fields.trailText: John Ritblat, chairman of British Land, is expected to hold talks with Liberty International - in which he has just taken a 29.9% stake - about creating Britain's largest commercial property business.
fields.body:
John Ritblat, chairman of British Land, is expected to hold talks with Liberty International - in which he has just taken a 29.9% stake - about creating Britain's largest commercial property business.

Such a deal would bring together Lakeside in Essex and MetroCentre in Gateshead with Sheffield's Meadowhall centre and the Broadgate office development in London.

British Land is expected to confirm this morning that it has paid £514m for the stake. Its trophy assets are Meadowhall and Broadgate, while Liberty owns 75% of Capital Shopping Centres, which in turn owns Lakeside and MetroCentre.

The deal values Liberty at £1.73bn and involves British Land paying 550p per share compared with a market price of 466p. About 55% will be paid in cash, with the balance met by the issue of British Land shares at 450p each.

The stake was sold by Standard Bank of South Africa after a five-month auction handled by Morgan Stanley.

British Land is expected to describe the investment as "strategic" and sources close to the company say it does not intend to make a full bid at present. However, Mr Ritblat is thought to have suggested a merger to Donald Gordon, Liberty's 69-year-old South African chairman, who built up the company from scratch.

It is not known how Mr Gordon reacted when Mr Ritblat telephoned him over the weekend to break the news of the shares purchase.

Liberty's managing director, David Fischel, said last night: "We're taking a mature approach to this and do not see it as hostile. We've known for some time that Standard Bank has been looking to sell its stake and that British Land was one of the parties it was talking to.

"Donald Gordon and John Ritblat have known each other for many years. It's good the sale is finally out of the way. British Land has made a shrewd investment."

Mr Ritblat and Mr Gordon have both talked openly about their belief that the property sector needs to be consolidated and shaken from its current state of lethargy.

But price could be a sticking point if British Land does de cide to mount a full bid. Liberty's published net asset value is about 700p per share and - although British Land paid a healthy premium to the current share price to buy Standard Bank's stake - it would almost certainly have to increase it again to persuade Mr Gordon to deal.

Analysts say that British Land does not have the re sources to bid on its own and would need to find a partner. George Soros, the US investor, has done several deals with Ritblat and is seen as one possible candidate.

Under the takeover panel's rules, British Land cannot increase its stake beyond the level of 29.9% it has just bought without having to mount a full bid.

British Land's move is likely to increase interest among City investors in the property sector, which until recently had been out of favour.

That view started to change last week when MEPC, the third largest company in the sector, was bought by Hermes, the pension fund manager, and General Electric of the US for £1.9bn.
fields.bodyText: John Ritblat, chairman of British Land, is expected to hold talks with Liberty International - in which he has just taken a 29.9% stake - about creating Britain's largest commercial property business. Such a deal would bring together Lakeside in Essex and MetroCentre in Gateshead with Sheffield's Meadowhall centre and the Broadgate office development in London. British Land is expected to confirm this morning that it has paid £514m for the stake. Its trophy assets are Meadowhall and Broadgate, while Liberty owns 75% of Capital Shopping Centres, which in turn owns Lakeside and MetroCentre. The deal values Liberty at £1.73bn and involves British Land paying 550p per share compared with a market price of 466p. About 55% will be paid in cash, with the balance met by the issue of British Land shares at 450p each. The stake was sold by Standard Bank of South Africa after a five-month auction handled by Morgan Stanley. British Land is expected to describe the investment as "strategic" and sources close to the company say it does not intend to make a full bid at present. However, Mr Ritblat is thought to have suggested a merger to Donald Gordon, Liberty's 69-year-old South African chairman, who built up the company from scratch. It is not known how Mr Gordon reacted when Mr Ritblat telephoned him over the weekend to break the news of the shares purchase. Liberty's managing director, David Fischel, said last night: "We're taking a mature approach to this and do not see it as hostile. We've known for some time that Standard Bank has been looking to sell its stake and that British Land was one of the parties it was talking to. "Donald Gordon and John Ritblat have known each other for many years. It's good the sale is finally out of the way. British Land has made a shrewd investment." Mr Ritblat and Mr Gordon have both talked openly about their belief that the property sector needs to be consolidated and shaken from its current state of lethargy. But price could be a sticking point if British Land does de cide to mount a full bid. Liberty's published net asset value is about 700p per share and - although British Land paid a healthy premium to the current share price to buy Standard Bank's stake - it would almost certainly have to increase it again to persuade Mr Gordon to deal. George Soros, the US investor, has done several deals with Ritblat and is seen as one possible candidate. Under the takeover panel's rules, British Land cannot increase its stake beyond the level of 29.9% it has just bought without having to mount a full bid. fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

A Texas-based consultancy specialising in "union-busting" is planning to open office in Britain and claims it has already been approached by a number of top 100 British companies who are worried about the new Employment Relations Act.

A subsidiary of Interpublic, the New York-based marketing company, has emerged as the favourite to buy a 10% stake in Arsenal football club.

Sunday Business

Orange , the mobile phone group sold by Vodafone to France Télécom last week, has drawn up ambitious plans to merge with both Holland's KPN Mobile and Finnish rival Sonera , possibly creating a group worth £135bn.

Henry Kaufman, the famous Wall Street economist, believes the US is headed for recession due to the delayed reaction of Federal Reserve in raising interest rates and failing to choke off the rise in financial asset prices.

Aegon , the Netherlands insurance group which owns Scottish Equitable, has emerged as the front runner to buy Scottish Provident , the life assurer which has decided to review its mutual status.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers will launch a rescue package for the hard-hit textiles industry this week, though extra funding may be limited to £5m.

Sunday Telegraph

British Energy is close to winning a contract to run Canada's largest nuclear power station. The deal, worth up to £700m, makes it one of the British firm's most ambitious forays overseas.

The Inland Revenue is examining the tax treatment of staff bonuses paid from an offshore trust at Durlacher, the high-flying internet investment firm.

John Duffield, ousted boss of Jupiter Asset Management, is planning to sue the fund management group's parent Commerzbank. His claim could run into millions of pounds.

Sunday Times

The Budget proposal to scrap double taxation relief for multinationals based in Britain will cost Vodafone AirTouch £500m in a full financial year - wiping out half the group's profits at current levels.

A transatlantic "super-alliance" is being considered by BA, the Dutch carrier KLM , and American Airlines, as the US airline continues its attempt to takeover its American rival Northwest Airlines .

Mail on Sunday

The reshaping of WH Smith by chief executive Richard Handover has claimed two more executive scalps, with the divisional finance and marketing directors at the high street retail arm leaving the group.

A new hole in the pension scheme of a subsidiary of Geoffrey Robinson's failed TransTec engineering concern has come to light. Problems with the fund at Earby Light Engineers date back to 1995 - three years before TransTec bought the company.

Sunday Express

Standard Life policyholders will get much larger payouts than previously thought if the insurer sheds its mutual status. Internal figures suggest even many ordinary policyholders could get more than £10,000 in free shares.

NTL and ONdigital, the media groups that are challenging BSkyB for the rights to broadcast live Premiership matches, are understood to have complained to the European competition authorities over the handling of the sale of the rights.

webTitle: Opec hopes new secret rules will stabilise market

fields.headline: Opec hopes new secret rules will stabilise market
fields.trailText: Any dealer trying to second-guess Opec's next oil policy move normally needs very strong nerves. But the world's most volatile commodity market looks set for unusual predictability this week, as the organisation of petroleum exporting countries prepares to activate a new mechanism to tame wild price swings.
fields.body:
Any dealer trying to second-guess Opec's next oil policy move normally needs very strong nerves. But the world's most volatile commodity market looks set for unusual predictability this week, as the organisation of petroleum exporting countries prepares to activate a new mechanism to tame wild price swings.

The unprecedented step by the oil cartel promises to be a learning experience for everyone concerned, not least because some of the workings of the informal pact remain confidential.

"Everyone is taking this seriously," says Peter Gignoux of brokers Salomon Smith Barney. "But since the rules haven't been published anywhere, we are all just going to have to learn them when the time comes."

That time could come very soon. Under the mechanism, the cartel automatically raises or cuts output by 500,000 barrels per day if the 20-day moving average price for a "basket" of crudes leaves the $22-28 range.

If current prices stay high, the average will exceed $28 in the next few days, prompting the president of Opec, Ali Rodriguez, to call for increased output in line with the new mechanism.

On paper the scheme looks elegant. But people are questioning whether it will be sturdy and flexible enough to rein in prices easily swayed by turbulent international politics or shifts in a secretive physical trade.

Bears and bulls could trample the fledgling device if key unknowns like the intentions of Iraq - not a party to cartel supply restraint - and changes in global inventories produce surprises.

And in a market where unreliable data make predictions difficult, some dealers suspect that Opec may tinker with the mechanism even as it cranks into operation, unable to resist the perennial urge to haggle over production policy.

The pact's timetable for any increase in supply - and whether the extra crude will be measured against actual production or from formal output ceilings - has not been disclosed.

And if prices fail to retreat obediently within the band, how long would it be before another output rise?

Roger Diwan, of the Petroleum Finance Company, says the vagueness of the accord's terms helps maintain cohesion among a group of producers with varying economic needs and political outlooks. "They will leave as much uncertainty as needed to keep a consensus," he said.

Consensus was crucial to Opec's engineering of a price rally in 1999, rewarding income-starved exporters with higher earnings following the painful slump in 1998.

But experts are divided as to whether any more Opec crude is needed at present, and some of them say that there was a hefty increase in inventories last month, with members already pumping 500,000 barrels per day above the quotas agreed earlier this year.

This week's expected trigger of the mechanism may coincide awkwardly with a renewal of the UN oil-for-food plan for Iraq. The present six-month plan expires on June 9, although a smooth rollover looks likely.

An Opec meeting in Vienna on June 21 may want to review any output increase triggered by the mechanism.

Financial institutions involved in the energy industries are watching the mechanism with interest because oil price instability is the scourge of producers and consumers trying to plan for the future.

But stability remains elusive for several reasons. Accurate supply and demand data are not available. All those involved in the market - Opec, the financial institutions, oil majors and consumers, have their own agenda.

Sarah Emerson of Energy Security Analysis says the mechanism would have only limited effect, and would be a licence to print money. "It's fatally flawed. But speculators will love it," she said.

webTitle: Cadbury and Danone hint at Nabisco takeover

fields.headline: Cadbury and Danone hint at Nabisco takeover
fields.trailText: Cadbury Schweppes is considering a joint £10bn bid with France's Danone for US-based Nabisco, the Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies group, according to weekend reports.
fields.body:
Cadbury Schweppes is considering a joint £10bn bid with France's Danone for US-based Nabisco, the Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies group, according to weekend reports.

Cadbury is expected to shoulder up to £4bn of the cost - making it the largest offer in the British company's history - while Danone would fund the other 60%.

Last month Cadbury, which has been looking for a big confectionery purchase, said it had expressed an "exploratory interest" in parts of Nabisco and Danone said it was holding preliminary talks with the American food company.

At the time the company declined to comment on speculation it might join Danone in carving up Nabisco and had nothing more to say on the subject yesterday.

"You would expect a company such as Cadbury Schweppes to explore the options available," a spokeswoman said.

The main attraction for Cadbury is said to be Nabisco's US sugar confectionery business, while analysts say it makes strategic sense for the French group to extend its reach into the United States.

The British company is variously reported as having be tween £3bn and £5bn available for acquisitions.

A total of 13 interested parties have already signed confidentiality agreements with Nabisco and a Cadbury-Danone joint bid would have to compete with companies such as RJ Reynolds Tobacco, current favourite Philip Morris, as well as American financier Carl Icahn.

Danone is the world's leading biscuit producer thanks to its domination in Europe and Asia, but until now its US interests have been mainly in mineral waters and dairy products.

Acquiring Nabisco, including the company's stake in United Biscuits, would help the French company realise its goal to become the world's biggest biscuit maker.

Nabisco's sweets operations would be a catch for Cadbury, which has had its room for expansion in America curtailed by a licensing deal with its rival Hershey, which has exclusive rights to sell Cadbury chocolate products in perpetuity.

Cadbury's previous biggest deal was the £1.5bn purchase of Dr Pepper/Seven Up, which it completed in 1995.

If the joint bid with Danone goes ahead, it will be the first time a French and a British company have joined forces to mount such a big offer.

webTitle: Move to take Soros-backed firm private

fields.headline: Move to take Soros-backed firm private
fields.trailText: Delancey Estates, the George Soros backed property vehicle, is understood to be on the verge of being taken private.
fields.body:
Delancey Estates, the George Soros backed property vehicle, is understood to be on the verge of being taken private.

The decision is believed to have been prompted by chief executive Jamie Ritblat's frustration with the stock market's valuation of property companies. Delancey's shares trade at a discount to net asset value of nearly 30%. On Friday they closed 90.5p, valuing the business at £233m.

Mr Ritblat, son of British Land boss John Ritblat, was quoted in weekend reports as saying: "The market's view on the sector doesn't seem to be willing to change. We're not going to rush into anything - but we are keeping our options open."

Mr Delancey and Mr Ritblat were not returning calls yesterday.

The move comes less than a week after MEPC, Britain's third largest quoted property company, threw in the towel and bowed to investor dissatisfaction with its failing share price and took itself private in a £1.9bn cash deal.

On Friday Prestbury, the property group run by entrepreneurs Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray, confirmed it was to liquidate its assets two years after coming to the market. Mr Leslau blamed institutional investors with the quoted property sector as a whole for the decision to sell Prestbury's assets and return capital to shareholders.

Mr Soros owns about 40% of Delancey. He has invested £100m in the firm through Quantum Realty Fund and Tivadarn, a family trust.

In September Delancey paid £173.4m for smaller rival Milner Estates.

fields.trailText: ou report how Israel "has kept Palestinians penned into the stifling and crowded confines of the West Bank and Gaza by imposing a permit regime" (Palestinians feel heat of Tel Aviv beach apartheid, June 3). A few pages later you reproduce the letters of a Jewish family in the unspeakable horror of a Nazi concentration camp (Letters from Belsen).
fields.body:
 You report how Israel "has kept Palestinians penned into the stifling and crowded confines of the West Bank and Gaza by imposing a permit regime" (Palestinians feel heat of Tel Aviv beach apartheid, June 3). A few pages later you reproduce the letters of a Jewish family in the unspeakable horror of a Nazi concentration camp (Letters from Belsen). How is it possible that Jews, of all people given the racism they suffered, can be so cruel and racist towards the Palestinian Arabs? And get away with it so successfully?
Michael Knowles
Congleton, Cheshire

 Suzanne Goldenberg helps to explode the myth about Israel being a "liberal democracy". How can one explain the absence of international condemnation, economic boycotts and demonstrations we used to in response to South African apartheid? Perhaps it is because the victims are only Palestinians and therefore are potential terrorists anyway.
Ali El-Hadi,
Maureen Ryan
London

 As I read yet another story about how the Nazis deprived Jews of their everyday rights and then their lives, I wondered how unbearable it must be to be in the Middle East with a functioning memory. Chinese rulers have always recognised history as amirror by which they know they must be judged. Who will look in the mirror of persecution in the Middle east and learn to see?
Charis Dunn-Chan
Poole

fields.headline: Don't blame the consultants
fields.trailText: Oh dear! I find myself, as an Oxbridge-educated NHS consultant, on two of Andrew Adonis's hit lists. (Search for enemies in super class war, June 3). It seems to matter not a jot that I, like many of those who figure on both those two lists, went to a state comprehensive school, do virtually no private work and have opted to offer my services to a very deprived community.
fields.body:
Oh dear! I find myself, as an Oxbridge-educated NHS consultant, on two of Andrew Adonis's hit lists. (Search for enemies in super class war, June 3). It seems to matter not a jot that I, like many of those who figure on both those two lists, went to a state comprehensive school, do virtually no private work and have opted to offer my services to a very deprived community.

Number 10 should beware of listening to thinktankers who extrapolate from their narrow metropolitan perspective, pouring contumely on some of our most dedicated and hard-working people. Labour will lose far more votes than they gain.
Dr RA Davies
Prince Charles Hospital Merthyr Tydfil

 I am pleased that you support radical reform of the NHS, which is long overdue, (Leader, June 1) but disappointed that you feel it necessary to combine this with the anti-consultant rhetoric obligatory to successive governments. I am an NHS consultant, I earn less than 10% of my salary from private practice and would give it up tomorrow if NHS beds and operating time were more freely available. As it is, the patients I treat in the private sector take pressure off the grossly pressed NHS provision.

I would dearly love to do two more operating sessions per week; that way I would do less semi-urgent cases out of hours and have more job satisfaction. What am I currently doing with the rest of my time? Attending endless meetings trying to square the circle of the demands on the service with the inadequate facilities to provide such a service; wasting a lot of time in my office due to inadequate secretarial support and IT provision; competing with other departments for overloaded investigational services; explaining to patients I see in outpatient clinics why they cannot be admitted for treatment within an appropriate time scale and devising strategies to cope with the consequences.

Give me five operating lists and two outpatient clinics a week and take the above problems away from me. That is what I would call "productivity". I would be happier and so would my patients.
Richard Spicer
The United Bristol Healthcare NHS Trust

Labour will lose far more votes than they gain. I am an NHS consultant, I earn less than 10% of my salary from private practice and would give it up tomorrow if NHS beds and operating time were more freely available. As it is, the patients I treat in the private sector take pressure off the grossly pressed NHS provision. I would dearly love to do two more operating sessions per week; that way I would do less semi-urgent cases out of hours and have more job satisfaction. What am I currently doing with the rest of my time? Attending endless meetings trying to square the circle of the demands on the service with the inadequate facilities to provide such a service; wasting a lot of time in my office due to inadequate secretarial support and IT provision; competing with other departments for overloaded investigational services; explaining to patients I see in outpatient clinics why they cannot be admitted for treatment within an appropriate time scale and devising strategies to cope with the consequences. Give me five operating lists and two outpatient clinics a week and take the above problems away from me. That is what I would call "productivity". I would be happier and so would my patients. fields.headline: Sea heroes
fields.trailText: The decision of the Royal Navy's historical section to claim the main kudos for the rescue of the British Expeditionary Force from Dunkirk is only stating what has been present in the majority of the serious histories of the time (Flotilla regroups, June 3).
fields.body:
The decision of the Royal Navy's historical section to claim the main kudos for the rescue of the British Expeditionary Force from Dunkirk is only stating what has been present in the majority of the serious histories of the time (Flotilla regroups, June 3).

It is surely time for the navy to claim its rightful status as the real agent for the prevention of the German invasion in the autumn of 1940. The RAF did, of course, perform a wonderful job in support, but it was the presence of our vastly superior naval forces poised on either side of the invasion area on the south coast that made the German admirals (who knew that the invasion fleet would have been obliterated by the Royal Navy) back-pedal so consistently and furiously.
Dr Richard Dawson
Southport, Merseyside

webTitle: Serbs spark crisis for UN in Kosovo

fields.headline: Serbs spark crisis for UN in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations mission in Kosovo was plunged into new difficulties yesterday as Serb leaders withdrew from the province's interim administrative body and demanded effective self-rule in their own strongholds, in protest at killings of Serb civilians by Kosovan Albanian extremists.
fields.body:
The United Nations mission in Kosovo was plunged into new difficulties yesterday as Serb leaders withdrew from the province's interim administrative body and demanded effective self-rule in their own strongholds, in protest at killings of Serb civilians by Kosovan Albanian extremists.

As the security council prepares to meet next week to review the first 12 months of the mission in Kosovo, Serb leaders announced that they would be sending a delegation to New York to demand amendments to resolution 1244 - the mandate for the UN effort - to protect Serb rights in Kosovo and allow the establishment "of functional self-rule" in areas occupied by Serbs.

In addition, moderate Serb leaders say that they have already asked European officials in the region to send anti-terrorism experts to back up the Kosovo protection force and the UN's international police force.

The statement by the Serb national council, meeting at the ancient monastery of Gracanica, comes amid disillusionment among many officials serving with the UN mission over the resurgence of ethnic violence and organised crime in Kosovo, and the apparent unwillingness of senior officials to take on the ethnic Albanian leaders suspected of involvement in both.

The Serbs' decision is doubly embarrassing for the UN mission, which is preparing to mark the first anniversary of its mandate this weekend and has been making strenuous efforts to persuade Serbs to share its vision of a multi-ethnic democratic society.

But the Serb community is angry about an eruption of violence in the last week that has left eight of their members dead in four incidents.

The most recent took place early last Friday, when a car hit an anti-tank mine which had been planted overnight on a British-controlled road a few miles from Pristina. Two men died, and a woman and two children were injured.

The decision to withdraw from the Albanian dominated administrative council is also a blow for Bernard Kouchner, the head of the UN mission, who had recently managed to persuade moderate Serbs, backed by the Serbian Orthodox church, to attend the council as observers prior to full involvement.

It comes amid a campaign for voter registration for the region's first local elections, scheduled for the autumn. While more than 250,000 ethnic Albanians have been persuaded to register, only a few thousand of the province's remaining 95,000 Serbs - from a community originally numbering 250,000 - have registered to vote.

Following the meeting yesterday, Father Sava, a moderate Serb leader who has backed Serb involvement in Kosovo's nascent democratic process, indicated that many Serb leaders wanted to end cooperation with the UN, rather than suspending their involvement until the security council meets.

"The international community has got to decide whether Kosovo is going to be a lawless place or move towards being a democratic society," he said. "At the moment, the international community is not really prepared to take the lead against Albanian terrorism or confront the problem of organised crime."

He added: "We are aware of the efforts that are being made to protect Serb people, particularly in the British sector which seems determined to work in an even-handed way. But in the last two months of our cooperation with the UN administration we have seen a resurgence of organised crime all over Kosovo."

The rise in the violence and intimidation against the remaining Serb community comes despite intense efforts to make Serbs feel secure. Many Serbian villages south of Pristina have been turned into virtual fortresses, protected by checkpoints, watch towers and constant helicopter and ground patrols.

However, despite a ratio of one peacekeeping soldier for every three Serbs in Kosovo, the Nato-led troops have been powerless to prevent the latest outbreak of violence.

fields.headline: Centralised chaos
fields.trailText: The implied threat from David Blunkett to the role of local councillors in education, along with talk of the NHS taking over responsibility for care for the elderly and child protection, suggests a real risk of "local choice" being removed(Leader, June 2). The list of council-provided services under threat does not stop there.
fields.body:
 The implied threat from David Blunkett to the role of local councillors in education, along with talk of the NHS taking over responsibility for care for the elderly and child protection, suggests a real risk of "local choice" being removed(Leader, June 2). The list of council-provided services under threat does not stop there.

Ministers that talk of removing service responsibilities from locally elected representatives must make clear what they think the alternative to local democracy is. What exactly is the government's view of the future of local democracy? Does it really think it can run 25,000 schools from Whitehall? The result would be a bureaucratic nightmare.

The history of the health service shows how difficult it is to run responsive local services from Whitehall. Do we really want to replicate this in education and other vital local services? Removing the role of councillors will separate schools from the communities they serve, constituting the worst kind of social exclusion that a government committed to "joining up" local services has perpetrated so far. The nightmare scenario we might face is centralised government in which local democracy plays virtually no part.
Sir Jeremy Beecham
Chair, Local Government Association

 Coordination of community education services needs planning systems that are open and accountable. Headteachers are vital but their main aim should be the effective running of their individual schools. Local education authorities (which are not just town hall education departments but the whole council) provide that layer of community planning. They bring together teaching professionals and others along with their own activities - social services, leisure, community education and youth services - to support young people's learning and development.

If you centralise control and standardise provision you reduce the development of a coordinated yet diverse range of local schools .
Kevin Maton
Coventry
kevin.maton3@virgin.net

 David Blunkett's speech to the National Association of Head Teachers' annual conference doesn't square with the one he gave three weeks earlier at a conference the Education Network organised. Far from saying that elected councillors have no future place in schools, Mr Blunkett congratulated the 300-plus local authority elected councillors and officers for working in partnership with both the government and schools to deliver the government's key education policies.
Martin Rogers
The Education Network

fields.headline: Peace and sense in sight
fields.standfirst:
Ethiopia must not be blinded by victory

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Even the optimists would hardly dare to pronounce the world's most senseless war finally to be over. Wars which begin as irrationally as the fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea are never likely to terminate neatly.
fields.body:
Even the optimists would hardly dare to pronounce the world's most senseless war finally to be over. Wars which begin as irrationally as the fighting between Ethiopia and Eritrea are never likely to terminate neatly. Nevertheless there is at least a chance for peace now that Ethiopia's forces have reconquered all the territory on its disputed border which Eritrea unexpectedly occupied in May 1998. Over 19 days the Ethiopian army drove forward into the contested area and well beyond it, seizing several Eritrean towns. Prime Minister Meles Zenawi says he has made his point and has given the orders for a partial pullback. He has told the international team of mediators which is conducting indirect talks in Algiers that he is willing to abandon all the undisputed territory.

But his victory has come at a fearful price. Some 120,000 people are thought to have died in the two-year conflict, many in the last three weeks. To say that this was an "old-fashioned" war in which the bulk of the dead were soldiers rather than civilians is of marginal comfort, since most were pathetic conscripts from urban shanty-towns or drought-threatened villages, and many died in pain from untended wounds. The war has also caused terrible displacement, with as many as 1.5m Eritrean civilians estimated to be on the move, either to Eritrean towns away from the front or into neighbouring Sudan. A huge humanitarian aid effort will be needed, if they cannot soon return to the farming areas from which they come. On the Ethiopian side, the war had less effect than once seemed likely on the delivery of relief for the 10m people facing drought. Foreign-donated grain has been arriving in large quantities and in spite of the army's demands enough lorries have been kept free to transport it.

The issue now is to ensure that the ceasefire turns into a lasting peace agreement. Ethiopia wants guarantees that the Eritreans will not reenter the disputed territory. Once again, the United Nations will find itself having to mount a ground mission, at least of truce observers and possibly of larger forces.
