fields.headline: Excellence and equality
fields.trailText: As someone who failed his 11-plus and was brought up in a disadvantaged area but has spent a lifetime in universities, including nearly six years as master of an Oxford college, I am passionately concerned about developing greater opportunities while maintaining centres of excellence in higher education.
fields.body:
As someone who failed his 11-plus and was brought up in a disadvantaged area but has spent a lifetime in universities, including nearly six years as master of an Oxford college, I am passionately concerned about developing greater opportunities while maintaining centres of excellence in higher education.

State schools produce two-thirds of the suitably qualified leavers for the subjects available at the top five British universities, but get only half the places. Private schools, which produce one-third of the suitably qualified leavers, get half the places. The bias in favour of private schools cannot be explained away as simply the product of low standards in state schools. The figures show that no matter how hard some state school pupils struggle and how well they perform in their exams, they simply do not have the same chance to secure entrance.

Goodwill and a desire to change, which in my experience were certainly present in Oxford, are not enough. Things are not getting better fast enough.

It is not for us to defend privilege at the cost of excellence. It must be to advance opportunity in pursuit of excellence. David Blunkett is right to examine measures that will help broaden intake - measures that enhance rather than dilute standards.

Different studies of UK universities conclude that once they get to university, state school pupils do better academically. So, if state school pupils do better by their finals, but fare badly in entrance numbers, something is going wrong in the selection system.

Despite Oxbridge's efforts, there is a need for greater commitment and coordination. David Blunkett has announced measures which will help the process along if universities are prepared to show initiative.

We might consider links between schools and universities to break down some of the barriers between sixth forms and universities. Schools need to show more interest in their local universities by inviting professors and lecturers to talk about their specialities to A-level groups. I am regularly asked to do this by private schools. In 33 years of teaching at universities I have had one request from a state school.

Oxbridge will continue with its interviewing system just because there are so many highly qualified candidates for limited places. It does, however, need to strain every sinew to ensure that this does not disadvantage students from the state sector. Applicants need to be given as much information and guidance as possible to demystify a process which I know produces a great deal of anxiety and not a little defeatism.

A policy that equalises opportunities cannot be dismissed as a policy that preaches equality of outcome or demands quotas. Nor can it be caricatured as a form of social engineering which demands entitlements without responsibilities. Now is the time for all of us - government and universities - to work together to make equality of opportunity a reality.
Raymond Plant
House of Lords

 When I received a letter of acceptance from Harvard, my parents had to declare all the family assets before a financial aid package could be calculated (The big boys, June 3). The value of our house and my parents' retirement fund was included, with the implication that we should be prepared to sacrifice one or both. I went instead to a land-grant university in my native state. If the chancellor seriously thinks Harvard is a good example of egalitarian access to an university education, then, as Godfrey Hodgson suggests, his American friends must be misleading him.
Jonathan Winkler
Oxford
jonathan.winkler@queens. oxford.ac.uk

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Apology : An article by Leanda de Lisle, page 24, May 25, referred to "a hermaphrodite called Lady Colin Campbell, but I understand her manly bit was very small". We accept that the description of Lady Colin Campbell as a hermaphrodite is both untrue and insulting and that, as she has never had a manly bit of any size, the use of such a term was both tasteless and misleading. We apologise to Lady Colin Campbell for the pain, distress and embarrassment this caused.
fields.body:
Apology : An article by Leanda de Lisle, page 24, May 25, referred to "a hermaphrodite called Lady Colin Campbell, but I understand her manly bit was very small". We accept that the description of Lady Colin Campbell as a hermaphrodite is both untrue and insulting and that, as she has never had a manly bit of any size, the use of such a term was both tasteless and misleading. We apologise to Lady Colin Campbell for the pain, distress and embarrassment this caused.

In a report headed Brother and sister lose bid to leave mother in the freezer, page 19, May 31, we controversially added an "s" to the already plural noun "Inuit". The individual is an "Inuk". Collins Millennium allows the addition of an "s" as an alternative plural form. However, a correspondent from the government of the Northwest Territories, Yellowknife, Canada, says adding the "s" is like saying sheeps or mices.

The suburb of Abidjan, the legislative capital of Cte d'Ivoire - not Abdijan, as we had it - page 12, Friday Review, June 2, is Treichville, not Trashville.

Homophone corner, from page 19, The Editor, June 2, in perhaps a Freudian transcription of a remark by Boris Johnson in a BBC radio programme, "You want people to have the liberty to look after themselves and their families without being bullied by an over-weaning state, don't you?"

fields.headline: William Simon
fields.standfirst: Nixon's chief of energy rationing, and begetter of the leveraged buy-out on Wall Street
fields.trailText: William Simon, the man to whom President Nixon gave the near-hopeless task of curbing America's insatiable appetite for petrol, has died aged 72. He had been a famously hard-nosed Wall Street bond dealer when he was recruited to the treasury team at the start of Nixon's second term in 1973.
fields.body:
William Simon, the man to whom President Nixon gave the near-hopeless task of curbing America's insatiable appetite for petrol, has died aged 72. He had been a famously hard-nosed Wall Street bond dealer when he was recruited to the treasury team at the start of Nixon's second term in 1973.

There could hardly have been a worse moment to come on board. As the growing Watergate scandal gradually paralysed the White House, the Yom Kippur war erupted and Arab oil-producing countries embargoed supplies of crude to any nation which supported Israel. Both these crises merged when Nixon simultaneously ordered a massive airlift of weapons to Tel Aviv and lost most of his domestic political credibility by arbitrarily sacking the Watergate special prosecutor.

With the impact of the oil embargo increasing, Simon was put in charge of the newly-created Federal Energy Office. He immediately read the riot act to the country. "With 6 per cent of the world's population," he pointed out, "we are consuming 33 per cent of the world's energy." Among the remedial measures he recommended were a national speed limit of 55mph, cuts in the heating and air-conditioning level of all government buildings, and the imposition of all-year-round daylight saving for two years.

But the administration's political troubles made it hard to pull Congress into line, particularly when members found themselves bombarded with letters from outraged constituents obliged to queue for hours to fill their gas-guzzling cars. The mounting pressure on Simon triggered his famously short temper. He attacked the Shah of Iran as "irresponsible and reckless", and publicly advised one of his administration colleagues to "keep his cotton-picking hands off energy policy".

With the oil crisis pushing the US into a worrying recession, Nixon promoted Simon, a political and economic right-winger, to the crucial post of Treasury Secretary. He immediately set about trying to reverse the administration's addiction to deficit spending. When President Ford assumed office after Nixon's resignation, Simon stayed on and persuaded the new president to establish a federal body to oversee wages and prices. Though the 1974 mid-term elections were looming, Ford brought in a 5% tax surcharge, which Simon forecast would lower the federal deficit from $9,400m to $3,000m.

It was too little and too late. When President Ford lost the 1976 election and Simon left office, Jimmy Carter's new administration was obliged to impose yet further economic restrictions and try even harder (and with little more success) to persuade America to reduce its energy consumption.

Simon, meanwhile, returned to the financial world from which he had sprung. Born in Paterson, New Jersey, he studied at Lafayette College in Easton, Pennsylvania, and at the age of 25 started work as a dealer in municipal bonds. His skill and aggressive salesmanship soon brought him to the notice of the leading brokerage house, Salomon Brothers.

Within a decade of joining, he had become one of that firm's senior partners and (long before the era of telephone number salaries) was said to be earning $2m a year. His rather disappointing stint in government had clearly not affected his capacity to enhance his personal finances. Within weeks of his return to Wall Street, he and a partner borrowed $75m to buy an old-established greetings card company. It was the first example of a leveraged buy-out, a technique which Simon more or less invented.

Gibson Greetings certainly established the viability of the technique, later used ferociously by Michael Milken and others to fuel the merger mania of the 80s. Within 14 months of the purchase, Simon and his partner publicly floated the company for $290m, yielding each of them a profit of $70m.

He was invited to become president of the US Olympic Committee, taking over a body which was $9m in debt and facing a bill of nearly $90m to stage the Los Angeles Olympiad. Simon's wheeling and dealing with the local organising committee even tually resulted in a business partnership which brought the Olympic Committee more than $100m, cash that has been helping fund America's amateur sports ever since.

Simon continued to add to his personal fortune through his own investment company, until Forbes magazine estimated it at $300m. In his later years he set out to create a merchant banking network operating across the western states. But one of its component mortgage houses went embarrassingly bankrupt and was seized by the federal authorities. In later years Simon concentrated on charitable activities.

Throughout his life, in fact, he had seemed to be in the game more for the intellectual stimulation than the riches. A deeply religious Roman Catholic, he noted recently that "my Eucharistic ministry is the most important thing that I do and have ever done". He was reported to have donated $80m to various medical charities during his life, and to have arranged for the rest of his fortune to be similarly distributed after his death.

He was married for 45 years to his first wife Carol, who died in 1995. He is survived by his second wife, Tonia, and by the two sons and five daughters of his first marriage.

fields.headline: Norman Wainwright
fields.standfirst: Britain's freestyle swimming champ who struck out of a 20-yard pool
fields.trailText: Norman Wainwright, who has died aged 85, contested with Bobby Leivers the title of Britain's most accomplished freestyle swimmer in the 30s. Wainwright won medals at two Commonwealth Games, two European championships and represented his country in three Olympic Games. He captured 21 national titles and broke British freestyle records at every distance from 150 yards to a mile.
fields.body:
Norman Wainwright, who has died aged 85, contested with Bobby Leivers the title of Britain's most accomplished freestyle swimmer in the 30s. Wainwright won medals at two Commonwealth Games, two European championships and represented his country in three Olympic Games. He captured 21 national titles and broke British freestyle records at every distance from 150 yards to a mile.

Wainwright was the youngest of four sons, and was introduced to swimming by his father William, who managed the local pool in his hometown of Hanley, one of the towns of the Potteries. The pool was open-air and just 20 yards long, a very modest construction compared to today's 50-metre indoor pools. The young Wainwright revelled in it, however, and was a confident swimmer before he was four.

As a teenager, swimming for the Hanley club, his progress was given impetus by the achievements of Leivers, who competed for the neighbouring Longton club. The local rivalry spurred him on and, in 1931, Norman persuaded his elder brother George, also a pool manager, and the Northern Counties coach, Jack Laverty, to help with his training. The new coaching regime worked, and in 1932 Norman was selected for the British Olympic team, despite never having won a national title.

At the Games in Los Ange les, Wainwright, 18, failed to reach the final, but he did become the fastest-ever British swimmer over 400m and, when he returned to England, enlisted help from a new coach, Harry Koskie, whose scientific training methods radically advanced the sport.

That year, Wainwright's father died. No longer able to use the Hanley swimming pool, he rented a cottage in Trentham Gardens and trained in the open-air pool there. He was also offered work by a company which made tiles for pools.

In 1933, Wainwright won the first of his ASA 21 titles (over a mile) and a year later enjoyed his first major international successes with a bronze medal in the 1,500m freestyle at the European championships in a lake at Magdeburg, Germany. That same year, the swimming events in the Commonwealth Games were held in the new indoor pool at Wembley Arena, and there Wainwright won two silvers, in the 400m freestyle and the 4 x 200m freestyle relay, and a bronze, in the 1,500m freestyle.

Wainwright would enjoy further successes at European and Commonwealth level in 1938, notably when he anchored home the 4 x 200m freestyle relay for the gold medal at the latter event, in Sydney. He did not return home from the Commonwealth games until over six months later, staying on in Australia to sell his company's tiles. On his return for the 1939 season, he won all five single national freestyle titles, the championship for each distance, being held at a different meeting.

But he gained nothing from his Olympic endeavours. In 1932, he had travelled to Los Angeles as a raw youth. In 1936, he went to Berlin with higher hopes, but was defeated by a stomach ailment. (Koskie suspected foul play.) Although the second world war intervened - he served in the RAF and was based in Iraq - Wainwright did reach a third Games, earning selection for the Olympics of 1948, where he was one of the three leaders of the team in the opening ceremony at Wembley. At 34, though, he was past his best in the pool.

After the war, Wainwright continued to sell tiles. He later served as treasurer and president of the Staffordshire county swimming association, and retired to live in a house which backed on to Trentham Gardens, remaining modest about his sporting achievements.

He leaves a wife, Betty, and a daughter, Elisabeth.

webTitle: 400 flee Hong Kong jail after riot

fields.headline: 400 flee Hong Kong jail after riot
fields.trailText: Police in Hong Kong were searching yesterday for about 400 prisoners who fled a drug treatment centre for convicted criminals after a riot that left at least 19 people injured.
fields.body:
Police in Hong Kong were searching yesterday for about 400 prisoners who fled a drug treatment centre for convicted criminals after a riot that left at least 19 people injured.

The prisoners escaped after violence broke out between Vietnamese and Hong Kong inmates at the Hei Ling Chau centre on an outlying island, the correctional services department said in a statement.

The sparely populated island is located far from Hong Kong's urban areas, so there was little likelihood that the prisoners could remain at large for long, it said.

The Hei Ling Chau centre was built in 1975 to treat male drug addicts convicted of crimes. It is run by Hong Kong's correctional services department and has slightly more than 400 inmates.

It was unclear what triggered the argument between the inmates, who fought each other with iron pipes and homemade weapons.

S. Y. Pang, the deputy commissioner of the department, said the prisoners set fire to some offices in the centre and at one stage threatened to ignite a liquefied petroleum gas cylinder.

Four injured correctional services officers were flown off the island by helicopter for treatment at a hospital on the main Hong Kong island, he said. Eight police officers and seven inmates also were injured and treated.

Marine police boats surrounded the island after receiving a call for assistance from the drug centre. Prison officers regained control of the situation after four hours, Mr Pang added.

There may have been a racial element to the riot. It is not known how many Vietnamese were receiving treatment at the centre. Many arrived in Hong Kong after the communist takeover in 1975.

In 1998, a brawl between mainland Chinese and Hong Kong prisoners at a medium-security prison left 54 people injured. That trouble was triggered by the beating of two local prisoners by a number of mainland Chinese inmates, who were serving prison terms for entering Hong Kong illegally.

fields.headline: Elizabeth Durack
fields.standfirst: Oz artist with two identities: her own and Aboriginal 'Eddie Burrup'
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Durack, who has died aged 84, was an acclaimed artist of pioneering outback stock. At the age of 81, she created a national storm by revealing that she also painted Aboriginal art under the name of Eddie Burrup. Durack, who was brought up close to Aboriginal life in the remote northwest of Australia, was taken aback at the controversy, because even though she entered indigenous art exhibitions as the man she claimed to be, there was no deception.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Durack, who has died aged 84, was an acclaimed artist of pioneering outback stock. At the age of 81, she created a national storm by revealing that she also painted Aboriginal art under the name of Eddie Burrup. Durack, who was brought up close to Aboriginal life in the remote northwest of Australia, was taken aback at the controversy, because even though she entered indigenous art exhibitions as the man she claimed to be, there was no deception.

While some Aborigines in the Kimberley region of Western Australia protested at her use of a black alter ego, others, including senior men from the Nyoongar people, supported her, believing she was possessed by the spirit of an Aboriginal artist.

Durack was bewildered by the attacks, but continued her inspired paintings under the name of Burrup until the last weeks of her life. The writer Susan McCullough-Uehlin pointed to the artist's great belief in intuition and the strength of unseen forces in synthesising her style: "Unlike other artistic frauds, Du rack did not appropriate or copy a style, indeed her images are not appropriated Aboriginal ones at all, but rather a persona, which to her was separate but real."

Elizabeth was the sister of the late author Dame Mary Durack, who wrote the classic account of graziers, Kings in Grass Castles, and Elizabeth's outback sketches often matched Mary's writing. In the 19th century the Duracks were among the few major pastoral families in the massive Kimberley not to shoot at Aborigines.

After school in Perth, Elizabeth returned to the family home, Ivanhoe, where she and Mary immersed themselves in local culture. Her sketches began with Aboriginal workers on the station and developed into oils tracing their traditional way of life. Years later she remembered: "I felt as though I were looking at the last of something and I just wanted to record it."

She drew a unique record of a passing era and became an important figure in the early battles for a reconciliation and recognition of the first Australians. London gallery owner and friend Rebecca Hossack said that Durack's work under her nom de brush was unlike any other Aboriginal work and used none of its iconography: "Elizabeth used to tell me that sometimes the Aboriginals on the station would say, 'Come with me'. And they would go. She would go walking for three weeks, not knowing when she was going to come back. I think she started extrapolating from those experiences. And I think the persona of Eddie Burrup freed her up."

Durack had some art training in London in 1936, before moving to Sydney and marrying journalist Francis Clancy, with whom she had two children: the couple eventually separated, but did not divorce. She also started collaborating with her sister Mary, and eventually illustrated nine of her books.

In 1946, Durack moved back to the Kimberley, and settled in the pearling port of Broome, where she stayed during a long career which produced work to furnish 65 exhibitions in Australia, London, New York and Dublin. The 50s and 60s saw growing recognition for her paintings of the Miriuwong people and their life in camps along the Ord River. In 1961 she was chosen with other leading Australian artists, including Sidney Nolan and Arthur Boyd, for a landmark exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery in London.

But unlike others, because of family commitments she chose to return to Western Australia, where she carried on working quietly and began to develop her Eddie Burrup aspect. In 1997, fearing, in her own words, that the situation was getting out of hand, she asked her friend, the art historian Robert Smith, to reveal the truth in the journal Art Monthly.

Despite the storm, she still produced works by Burrup, with the latest only two weeks before her death after a long battle with cancer.

Her son and daughter confirm that a major exhibition called the Art of Eddie Burrup will be held as planned at the Cork Street Gallery, London, July 24 - August 5.

webTitle: Ancient Egypt yields its underwater secrets

fields.headline: Ancient Egypt yields its underwater secrets
fields.standfirst: Archaeologists show off relics and footage from cities beneath the sea off Alexandria
fields.trailText: Archaeologists show off relics and footage from cities beneath the sea off Alexandria
fields.body:
New archaeological techniques are helping to uncover the secrets of the lost cities of ancient Egypt, astonishingly well preserved beneath the sea.

Relics and underwater video film of the cities - believed to be Herakleion and Menouthis - which lie in Aboukir Bay off Alexandria, were shown by an Egyptian-French team for the first time at the weekend. They were submerged more than 1,000 years ago.

Although the existence of the cities was known from classical Greek writings, there had been little tangible evidence until now.

"We are very excited," said Gaballah Ali Gaballah, head of Egypt's supreme council of antiquities. "We are used to finding the remains of a tomb, a church or mosque. This time we are finding complete cities."

The area around Alexandria, linked to some of the most famous names of history -Alexander the Great, Anthony and Cleopatra, Julius Caesar - is rich in land-based archaeological treasures. Millions of people live on top of the ancient remains, about 12 metres below street level.

Some relics have almost certainly been destroyed by the foundations of modern buildings, though there are still hopes of finding the tomb of Alexander the Great.

The difficulty of working on land has led archaeologists to the sea, where ancient fragments have been turning up since the 18th century. The water is shallow and the ruins, relatively untouched, lie as little as five metres below the surface, covered by a thin layer of sand.

"This century the sea is going to tell us a lot about the Ptolemaic and Roman periods," said Ibrahim Darwish, director of the department of underwater archaeology in Alexandria. In preparation, the degree in archaeology at the city's university includes diving lessons.

How the cities became engulfed by the sea is still a mystery. "Most probably they disappeared because of seismic causes," said Franck Goddio, head of the Paris-based European Institute of Marine Archaeology, who has been leading the exploration.

In 1934, a marble head of Alexander was recovered with the help of local fishermen who could spend long periods underwater without breathing equipment. But until now the detailed examination of the underwater ruins has been held back by a lack of suitable technology.

Modern techniques used by Mr Goddio's team, including global positioning systems, sonar scanners and magnetic imaging, mean that only a few relics need to be brought to the surface. The rest will remain undisturbed on the seabed.

Archaeology in Egypt has become increasingly influenced by politics and showbusiness. Mindful of its beneficial effect on the tourist industry, government ministers often become directly involved in projects, while major discoveries are carefully stage-managed and invariably televised.

A team of 150 people from Fox Television recently descended on the Bahariyya oasis to record "Opening the Tombs of the Golden Mummies - Live!" For the two-hour £2m production Fox imported a mobile clinic and a chef from Los Angeles, as well as bringing in donkeys to add local colour. The council for antiquities reportedly collected £65,000 for the film rights.

The sea may save Herakleion and Menouthis from a similar fate.

"As recently as 1967 you could see the remains from the surface with a snorkel," Mr Darwish said. But pollution has since made viewing impossible. Only last month a Syrian cargo vessel sank in the bay, spilling 321 tonnes of nitric acid.

Mr Darwish hopes that anti-pollution measures will have cleared the water sufficiently by 2003 to allow visits in glass-bottomed boats.

"This century the sea is going to tell us a lot about the Ptolemaic and Roman periods," said Ibrahim Darwish, director of the department of underwater archaeology in Alexandria. In preparation, the degree in archaeology at the city's university includes diving lessons. How the cities became engulfed by the sea is still a mystery. "Most probably they disappeared because of seismic causes," said Franck Goddio, head of the Paris-based European Institute of Marine Archaeology, who has been leading the exploration. In 1934, a marble head of Alexander was recovered with the help of local fishermen who could spend long periods underwater without breathing equipment. But until now the detailed examination of the underwater ruins has been held back by a lack of suitable technology. Modern techniques used by Mr Goddio's team, including global positioning systems, sonar scanners and magnetic imaging, mean that only a few relics need to be brought to the surface. The rest will remain undisturbed on the seabed. Archaeology in Egypt has become increasingly influenced by politics and showbusiness. Mindful of its beneficial effect on the tourist industry, government ministers often become directly involved in projects, while major discoveries are carefully stage-managed and invariably televised. A team of 150 people from Fox Television recently descended on the Bahariyya oasis to record "Opening the Tombs of the Golden Mummies - Live!" For the two-hour £2m production Fox imported a mobile clinic and a chef from Los Angeles, as well as bringing in donkeys to add local colour. The council for antiquities reportedly collected £65,000 for the film rights. The sea may save Herakleion and Menouthis from a similar fate. "As recently as 1967 you could see the remains from the surface with a snorkel," Mr Darwish said. But pollution has since made viewing impossible. Only last month a Syrian cargo vessel sank in the bay, spilling 321 tonnes of nitric acid. Mr Darwish hopes that anti-pollution measures will have cleared the water sufficiently by 2003 to allow visits in glass-bottomed boats.

webTitle: Russia and US in nuclear deal

fields.headline: Russia and US in nuclear deal
fields.trailText: In what President Bill Clinton described as "a milestone in enhancing strategic stability", the US and Russia yesterday agreed to set up the first ever joint early warning centre in Moscow, aimed at reducing the chances of a nuclear war being launched by accident.
fields.body:
In what President Bill Clinton described as "a milestone in enhancing strategic stability", the US and Russia yesterday agreed to set up the first ever joint early warning centre in Moscow, aimed at reducing the chances of a nuclear war being launched by accident.

It is scheduled to begin operation by next autumn. It would initially run for 10 years, and could extended for five-year periods, senior American officials said. The initiative was prompted by US alarm at the dilapidated state of Russia's system of satellites and radar facilities monitoring ballistic missile launches.

A pilot programme involving US and Russian military personnel was conducted in Colorado at the end of last year.

"The purpose of this whole effort is to provide a near real-time exchange of the detected information about the launch of ballistic missiles and space-launch vehicles that are detected by the warning systems of the two sides," said a senior US official yesterday at the end of Mr Clinton's two-day summit with President Vladimir Putin in Moscow.

"It will be the first time that American and Russian military personnel will be permanently involved in a joint military operation over an extended period."

The US and Russian leaders also announced agreement on a deal costing almost $6bn which would dispose of 68 tonnes - 34 tonnes each - of weapons-grade plutonium over the next 20 years.

Mr Clinton said that the plutonium being put into storage or civilian nuclear energy projects was enough to build thousands of warheads. "It will never now fall into the wrong hands," he declared.

The disposal of the US plutonium would cost $4bn, the Russian $1.75bn. US officials said other unnamed countries would be expected to contribute to the cost.

The agreement stipulates the "safe, transparent and irreversible" disposal of the plutonium. Neither side would be able to use the plutonium for military purposes.

Reflecting US unease at the Russian supply of nuclear materials and technology to Iran, where Moscow is building a power plant at Bushehr, Mr Clinton said he had insisted on "strict export controls".

Mr Putin has just signed a decree making it easier for Moscow to strike commercial deals for exports of civilian nuclear technology, a move that has alarmed western nuclear proliferation experts.

American officials said that the Moscow centre, which entailed 16 US and 17 Russian military officers working shifts 24 hours a day and seven days a week, would use space-based satellites, infrared systems, and early warning radar.

But the Americans also hope that the establishment of the centre will reduce stiff Russian opposition to US plans for a national missile defence system, the sore point of the weekend summit, by helping to persuade them that it is no threat to strategic stability and the Russian nuclear deterrent.

"The purpose is to avoid the possibility of false warning of attack ... But there are other purposes that are also served by the creation of this centre," admitted the US official. "One of those purposes is to increase the mutual confidence between the sides about the effectiveness of their early warning systems. And it also is a way to focus attention on the continuing worldwide proliferation of ballistic missiles."

Within a minute of a missile launch from the US or Russia, information on the launch site, type of missile and timing of the impact would be shared. This would eliminate "uncertainties" about the intention of any launch.

Information about launches by other countries will also be provided, but only if the missile or spacecraft is crossing the territory of the US or Russia, the official said. Otherwise, detected missile launches by third countries would be "filtered out" of the joint early warning operations.

webTitle: The low down: Online flight booking

fields.headline: The low down: Online flight booking
fields.trailText: It's not often you see a company actively promoting its rivals but it seems dot.coms do things differently. Ten European airlines, including British Airways, Lufthansa and the Scandinavian airline SAS have linked wings to launch an online ticket service later this year that will enable customers to make what may be unflattering price comparisons.
fields.body:
It's not often you see a company actively promoting its rivals but it seems dot.coms do things differently. Ten European airlines, including British Airways, Lufthansa and the Scandinavian airline SAS have linked wings to launch an online ticket service later this year that will enable customers to make what may be unflattering price comparisons.

For the first time, consumers will be able to plan complex itineraries online. The service, run as an independent agency, will also help with extras such as car hire.

The aim is to bump up the amount of business travel booked online. The vast majority of flights sold online in this country are to independent travellers, with business fliers making up only a tiny percentage. Compare this to the US, where 30% of business flights are booked online, and it's obvious why the airlines want to get this service off the ground. After all, travel is already the biggest online money spinner in Europe, amounting to $9m worth of business in 1999, with experts forecasting a leap to $27m by 2003.

But who will be making the money? Customers could be tempted to deal directly with the airlines, snatching business away from high street agencies. The airlines have well-established brand names - if we can trust them with our lives, why not let them pick our hotels?

They also have the money to invest. BA alone is planning to spend £100m on online ventures over the next two years, and unlike traditional agencies, it isn't saddled with a costly high street operation.

In the short term it seems that the customer can't lose, but what of the long term? The danger is that the travel agencies, faced with such stiff competition, will join forces themselves, through mergers and takeovers, leaving travellers with even less choice.

webTitle: Arm your office for electronic warfare

fields.headline: Arm your office for electronic warfare
fields.standfirst: The I Love You virus was just the latest in an increasing number of attacks on computer systems - and office support staff are in the front line of defence.  Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: The I Love You virus was just the latest in an increasing number of attacks on computer systems - and office support staff are in the front line of defence.
fields.body:
Tell your colleagues you're having a hellish week because of a virus, and there's a good chance they'll know you're not referring to the biological variety. If you mention to a workmate that you think you've got the "Viagra", which makes a new hard drive out of an old floppy, or the "Mike Tyson", which quits after two bytes, and it's likely she'll get the joke. With around 60,000 known computer viruses now circulating in cyberspace, few office workers are unaware of the risks from these silent saboteurs. But as their numbers and sophistication increases, recognising the early symptoms is becoming more and more difficult.

The latest nasty infection has been dubbed the "killer résumé" because it disguises itself as a seemingly innocent job application. Opening the attachment entitled "Résumé - Janet Simons" activates the virus, sending out emails to everyone in your address book while deleting important system files and then disabling your computer altogether.

Although the "I love you" virus - which cost businesses an estimated £3bn when it hit hundreds of thousands of computers last month - is by far the most destructive to date, bugs have played serious havoc since "Michelangelo" wiped countless PC hard disks on March 6 1991, the painter's birthday. Four years later, "Word.Concept" did the rounds, copying itself to the template of Microsoft Word documents. Within 12 months it was the most prevalent computer virus in the world. Next to cause global chaos was "Wazzu" in 1996, but it was probably "Melissa" three years later, which disguised a list of pornographic sites as a text file, that brought the computer virus to wide public awareness. Opening the file emailed the virus to 50 or more people; before long it had hit an estimated 1 million computers.

There is something about computer saboteurs that is almost romantic, the image of a lone geek bringing global companies to their knees. But those who have experienced the effects of viruses know that there is little that is innocent about them. And according to Graham Cluley, spokesman for anti-virus company Sophos, bugs are getting more advanced and sinister by the day. "At the moment, the majority are written by youngsters who think it's cool to wipe as much as possible in as short a space of time as possible. The real problem occurs with the recent increase in the more sinister, unrecognisable viruses that have more subtle corruptions. They might, for example, multiply a random number on your spreadsheet every now and then by 0.05, or wipe random paragraphs from text files over several months." These sophisticated viruses, he says, are considerably more dangerous. "First, they're less easy for anti-virus software to spot, and second, by the time you've noticed the effects, all your back-ups will probably be corrupted too."

Since office support staff are often the first to open emails in their own or their bosses' queues, it is vital that they are tuned in to the risks from viruses. But vigilance in itself can be dangerous - some cunning hackers have begun to disguise viruses as public service circulars warning of other virus threats. "We've also noticed a rise in vicious rumours about viruses," says George Coleman, spokesperson for computer security company Content Technologies. "Someone sends out the warning by email and asks the receiver to send it on to everyone they know. Because the system can't cope with the sudden overload of email sending, everything breaks down. Secretarial staff, who like to be on the ball in terms of caution about computer problems, are particularly vulnerable to this one."

And if you think your digital organiser or internet WAP phone is safe from these millennial bugs, think again. Mobile phone viruses could copy conversations and forward them to others, delete money from "electronic wallets" or rack up huge telephone bills. "The easier communication becomes, the more damage can be done by viruses," points out a spokesperson at IBM.

So what prompts someone to create a destructive email? According to Aled Miles, managing director of anti-virus company Symantec, many smaller viruses are designed by disgruntled employees with the purpose of eradicating one particular business. But the biggest fashion, he admits, is mass destruction, "simply because it's possible". Miles has found that these cyber-criminals are usually male, under 21, with one of three psychological profiles: "The self-publicist; the person who is into cyber-graffiti - which is intended to be relatively harmless; and the wannabe cyber-terrorist."

The good news, according to Coleman, is that many virus authors aren't set on a trail of destruction. Instead, they're simply playing a game. "They'll write the virus and send it to companies like ours - rather than out into the wilds of cyberspace - to fix. It's almost like a challenge: 'Here's my latest. See if you can cure it.' "

In addition, he points out, some internet service providers are considering taking on viruses themselves. "Rather than having the [anti-virus] software in-house, and having to constantly update, you would pay a subscription for them to do it for you." The advantage of this is that no email would come anywhere near your company until it had been checked. The battle against viruses, he says, is akin to a war, and just as the number of hackers is growing, so is the opposition. Many of the nerdy but sophisticated hackers of yesteryear have turned into cybersleuths, offering freelance services to police forces in Europe and America. The police's hands can be tied, however. It is almost impossible to catch cyber-criminals and many countries simply do not have adequate laws to deal with computer-related crimes. "In the UK, under the Computer Misuse Act, the longest sentence is just a few years," says Graeme Moffett, a solicitor specialising in technology law with Shepherd & Wedderburn. "If you're hellbent on causing global mayhem, that's not really going to put you off."

Rather than despairing about the risks, Jack Clark, European product manager of anti-virus company, Network Associates, believes there is an urgent need for both employers and employees to get clued up on the threat from viruses. "I am amazed at the number of staff who automatically open every attachment they're given," he says. If you're not expecting an attachment, he advises, always phone or email the sender to check they meant to send it. "Make back-ups of everything and have as few email addresses in your address book as possible. Most importantly, make sure you continually update your anti-virus software." The first rule of combat, after all, is to be properly armed against the enemy.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: Deborah McNamara, PA to the headmaster at the Angmering School in West Sussex talks about prioritising your work
fields.body:
Working in a school, the first priority always has to be the students," says Deborah McNamara, PA to the headmaster at the Angmering School in West Sussex. "As well as assisting the head, Richard Evier, I am also the senior administrative officer and clerk to the governors. I manage a team of seven staff who oversee all the administration for the school, which includes producing resources for the teaching staff, working for the deputy teachers, reception duties and most of the day-to-day running of the school."

The combination of responsibilities means that McNamara has to keep tight control over what she is doing. "Lists are essential," she says. "My first priority is to ensure that the head knows exactly what is in his schedule each day and we meet every morning to go through what's in the diary. The school publishes a calendar of events at the end of each year for the following one, which includes everything from sports day to exam dates to the annual AGM. This makes it easy to keep track of what needs the head's attention from one week to the next, and I type up a list each day of what are the top priorities for him."

McNamara admits that balancing all these demands can be quite difficult. "Sometimes I will be dealing with something for the head and then I'll take a call from the chair of the governors, and then I might get a query from one of the office staff. Usually I'll use my discretion: if it's something that the head should know about, then I'll deal with that first. If I'm not sure what should take precedence, then I may well ask the head for his opinion. Although I do have quite a lot of autonomy, I'm more than happy to ask his advice."

Prioritising work is made far easier, McNamara believes, if aims and objectives are clearly understood. "We have a mission statement at the school and a development plan that everyone carries in their diaries," she says. "It says that we work to recognise the value and potential of each student - and therefore that is always my first priority. We have a structure for student support but if anything happens with a pupil that I feel the head should know about, I will tell him straightaway."

With constant telephone calls, queries and correspondence to deal with, careful organisation is essential. "The list that I make in the morning I go through again in the evening to tick off everything that has been dealt with," says McNamara. "It's hugely important to keep abreast of what's happening; there are a lot of demands on a head teacher and you have to be flexible enough to accommodate sudden changes."

Tips for prioritising your work:

* Have a clear understanding of what the priorities are in your organisation, rather than just in your own job.

* Be flexible - recognise that priorities can change quickly.

* Plan ahead so that if something throws you off course, you have a plan to return to.

* Keep abreast of what's happening in your organisation so that you can identify emerging priorities.

* Keep an ongoing list of things to be done.

webTitle: How to get a good review

fields.headline: How to get a good review
fields.standfirst: Many employees - and managers - fail to see the point of appraisals, yet carried out properly they can be an extremely useful career tool.  Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: Many employees - and managers - fail to see the point of appraisals, yet carried out properly they can be an extremely useful career tool.
fields.body:
Ever get the feeling that you're not sure what your responsibilities really are? Or that you don't get enough recognition for them either verbally or financially? Or that your job title doesn't reflect them? It's time to take advantage of your appraisal. Faced with the prospect of a lengthy and often ineffectual liaison with the boss to "review performance", secretarial staff can be as relieved as managers when the diary proves just too inflexible and a meeting has to be cancelled at the last minute. But, warn human resources experts, staff neglect their appraisal at their peril.

Contrary to popular opinion, appraisals are not simply about assessing your past performance to allow your boss to see if you deserve a pay rise. "The 90s witnessed a clear trend away from linking appraisals to salaries," says Debra Allcock, head of campaigning at the Industrial Society. A recent study found that of the 77% of British companies that have a formal appraisal system in place, almost half claim there is no association with wages. "Today's appraisals have less focus on past assessment and more on the future of the staff member in terms of development needs."

The problem, says Allcock, lies in the fact that all too many employees don't really understand the point of appraisals. And more worrying still, nor do many of the managers themselves. The Institute of Personnel and Development (IPD) have found that a third of employees say their bosses treat appraisals as "a bureaucratic chore". One in eight managers said they would rather visit the dentist than carry out an appraisal.

So what can secretaries do to help themselves? "First, request a preliminary discussion about what the method and potential results will be," advises Max A Eggert, management psychologist and author of Managing Your Appraisal. "Find out in detail what's going to be asked, what you need to bring along, and if you can make requests. It will make any complacent managers ensure they get it right and that you get the fairest appraisal." You may even want to enquire about appraisal systems at interview stage, suggests Allcock - "and don't assume that the bigger the company, the better the system". It's never a bad idea to keep hold of any notes people write applauding your work - and if someone simply tells you that you've done a great job, write it down yourself. Keep all the notes in a file and bring them along to the meeting.

 Was your appraisal conducted in a friendly but business-like manner?

 Was your performance discussed with examples to illustrate the points that your interviewer was making?

 Did you review and agree your future training requirements and career aspirations?

 Was there sufficient time set aside for your appraisal?

 Were the goals and standards of your job made clear to you?

 Were your views and explanations welcome?

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • MIND THE GAP
fields.body:
 MIND THE GAP

Thirty years after the Equal Pay Act came into force, women are still earning less than men. A TUC report, Campaigning to Close the Gap, charts the improvements in women's pay over the last century, and highlights some landmark legal cases. But there is still, depressingly, a long way to go. The report points out that women working full time in the year 2000 earn only around 80 pence for every pound earned by male workers, or just 60 pence for part-time employees.

 ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT

Do you work in a funky office? Is your colour scheme cutting edge? If so, office technology firm Gestetner would like to hear from you. The company's digital office collection will celebrate the most visually inspiring and functionally efficient places to work, particularly those that show technology and design working well together. The 100 best offices will be unveiled at a gala event this autumn. For details, contact Melanie Dias on 020 7630 1411 or complete the online entry form at www.gestetner.co.uk.

 TABLE TALK

Ever grow weary of booking tables for your boss without so much as a doggy bag for your trouble? Online reservation service www.toptable.co.uk not only offers exclusive bookings in restaurants across the UK and in Paris, but has just started a loyalty scheme for PAs that lets you earn prizes even when booking for other people. You can even take a 360-degree look at the venue before booking. The more bookings, the better the rewards - from CDs to health spa breaks and airmiles.

 DRIVING AHEAD

If your boss breaks a leg and can't drive, chances are he or she won't be the only one to have a frustrating few weeks, as you're charged with finding new ways to get them from A to B. Chauffeurplan is an insurance policy that will keep your senior execs on the road when they're unable to drive. Alternative transport costs will be covered for up to a year and several drivers can be insured. Cover starts from £50 a year. For details, call 0800 242420 or visit www.chauffeurplan.co.uk.

 GOING, GOING, GONE!

If you think your skills are outstanding, why not sell them to the highest bidder? A new online people auction allows you to ask potential employers to bid for your services. Post your CV on the website at InterviewMe.co.uk, where employers can take a look at it and then make a pay offer. The site guarantees anonymity and security, so the job seeker is free to take the best offer available.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Desktop icons No 22: The executive toy

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 22: The executive toy
fields.trailText: You can tell a lot about someone from their desktop clutter.
fields.body:
You can tell a lot about someone from their desktop clutter. Fluffy gonk mascots, framed photos of the kids or incriminating pictures of the work night out . . . what you choose to put between the cold cups of discarded coffee says a great deal about your working style, priorities and extracurricular activities.

So what are we to surmise about those whose desk sports an executive toy? That they are exciting, stimulating individuals with a rich inner life? Maybe not. These desktop diversions serve no purpose other than a decorative one. But if nothing else, they are useful in warning colleagues to approach said individual with care at the Christmas party.

An executive toy on your desk says minimalism, order, fastidiousness. It speaks of spotless Barratt homes, ties with a Mickey Mouse design, an alphabetically catalogued CD collection, perhaps dominated by 80s soft rock. They don't sit well with clutter: an executive toy only really works on a vast, empty desk, tucked between the phone and the multicoloured pen pot. You don't have time to divert yourself with fiddly toy things if your desk is piled high with filing, after all.

Like anything else, executive toys are subject to the fickle whims of fashion. In the 80s, it was all about shiny chrome minimalism - suspended ball bearings that (ooh) clicked against each other, or finely balanced little spacemen figures that rocked when you jiggled them. In the 90s, the toy of choice featured dribbling coloured liquids, as workers tried to recreate that retro Lava lamp look on their desk tops.

But the executive toy may finally be falling from favour. It takes an ingenious contraption to drag bored executives away from Minesweeper, after all. And those wanting to demonstrate a little workplace wackiness now need only install a comedy screensaver or desktop wallpaper to prove their anti-establishment credentials.

webTitle: Who brought down the Lockerbie trial?

fields.headline: Who brought down the Lockerbie trial?
fields.standfirst: Why is the most important trial in the world being ignored by the media?  Joshua Rozenberg reports on the legal muddles that threaten justice
fields.trailText: Why is the most important trial in the world being ignored by the media?  Joshua Rozenberg reports on the legal muddles that threaten justice
fields.body:
The Lockerbie case is probably the most interesting and important criminal trial taking place anywhere in the world. But you're not likely to be reading or hearing very much about it in the weeks and months to come. Bringing the two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing before a court of law was a major achievement. But that's about as far as the compliments go.

Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah have denied murder, conspiracy to murder, and destroying an aircraft. They are being tried under Scots law by three judges. A fourth judge sits with them, ready to step in if one of the others dies before the verdict. The judges sit without a jury in a specially built court near Utrecht in the Netherlands.

Drive off the motorway and you know you have reached Camp Zeist when you see pairs of Scottish police officers in flak jackets and baseball caps, cradling automatic weapons. The police are friendly enough when you speak to them, but it's hard to forget that they could kill you at any moment. Your car may be checked by Dutch sniffer dogs (from a company called K9); one day I saw a burly security guard vacuuming the courtroom carpet after his dog had become a trifle overenthusiastic.

Huge sums of money have been spent by the Scottish Court Service on providing facilities for the media, but no attempt has been made to give reporters what they actually need to cover the trial. As a result, journalists have all but melted away. A vast structure has been erected so that 16 television reporters can simultaneously broadcast live from sheltered positions overlooking the court. But television companies aren't allowed to bring editing equipment to the site: reporters have to drive, walk or cycle to a car park one kilometre away. Or they can wait for the bus.

Print journalists have been given a huge media centre with places for 240 reporters to watch the trial on a closed circuit television link. But the Crown Office, which is responsible for Scottish prosecutions, won't provide even the most basic information - such as who the witnesses are and how they spell their names. The lists of witnesses and items of evidence are attached to the published indictment and, arguably, are therefore public documents. But there seems little point in challenging the Crown's decision to withhold them.

Prosecution lawyers are thought to be afraid that reporters might approach witnesses if they knew who they were. It's thought unlikely that the court would order witnesses' names to be released against the Crown's wishes: attempts to have the trial televised were doomed to failure once the prosecution argued that broadcasts might deter witnesses from giving evidence. Prosecution witnesses now tend to enter the court complex through a side entrance, well away from the only position where cameras are allowed.

Witnesses are normally kept on the other side of the floor-to-ceiling glass screen that separates press and public from the courtroom itself. In any other court case, reporters normally find out what's going on by having a quiet word with the lawyers during adjournments. But that's impossible when the lawyers spend all day "airside" - visible through the glass partition but totally inaccessible to reporters. Both prosecution and defence lawyers have offices in the court building, so you can't even see them at lunchtime.

No doubt, this suits the prosecution very well. The Lord Advocate, Colin Boyd, seems pleasant enough when you ambush him in the car park, but you can tell he'd much rather not be answering difficult questions. Why, for example, does an official from the United States Justice Department sit next to prosecution lawyers in court? What does he tell the American victims' families at briefings every evening? Why did Boyd run out of witnesses on several occasions during the early days of the trial, forcing unnecessary adjournments?

Boyd could hardly have been surprised that there was little by way of defence cross-examination to prolong the witnesses' evidence: the two accused don't deny that a plane exploded over Lockerbie, killing 270 people. Even the judges got fed up with hearing an endless succession of police officers explain which piece of wreckage was found in which particular field; most reporters had lost patience some days earlier. Why couldn't the prosecutor have agreed the uncontroversial evidence with defence lawyers in advance? Under Scots law, if facts are agreed or evidence is undisputed, oral evidence need not be called at the trial.

Prosecution sources subsequently pointed out that it takes two to make a deal. But this perfectly reasonable (if somewhat unconvincing) response was not available from the Lord Advocate's press officer at the time; the Crown Office in Edinburgh is about as uncommunicative today as its nearest English equivalent, the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, was some 15 years ago.

All this would have mattered less if the media had more to go on than the outline of the prosecution's case contained in the formal indictment. In English trials, the prosecution summarises the case against the defendant in an opening speech, making it easier to understand the significance of the evidence when it comes.

There are no opening speeches in Scottish criminal trials, presumably to avoid the risk that juries will decide cases on the strength of what's alleged rather than what can be proved. But what harm would an opening speech have done in a case where there is no jury?

Without a solid framework, journalists must struggle to make sense of prosecution witnesses and defence cross-examination. When the evidence is so confusing, disjointed or repetitious, it's little wonder that news organisations find it hard to justify the cost of keeping reporters and television crews at the Scottish court in the Netherlands.

Attempts to fill the information gap were made by a group of academics from Glasgow university. Unfortunately one of their number was a retired diplomat, Andrew Fulton, who'd spent time in Saigon and East Berlin; he was not to be seen again after the Guardian Diary guessed he must be from MI6. In this climate of conspiracy, it's hardly surprising that the Sunday Herald ran a story in Scotland last month headlined "Lockerbie report leaves trial in chaos". The specific story - that the prosecution had been forced to seek an adjournment because one of its star witnesses had cast doubt on where the bomb had been positioned on Pan-Am 103 - was roundly and convincingly denied by the Lord Advocate.

But two things were true. A different prosecution witness, from the government's Air Accidents Investigation Branch, admitted under questioning by the defence that he had wrongly calculated the likely position of the bomb on board the aircraft, which could be crucial in establishing whether it was in the suitcase allegedly put on the plane in Malta by the two accused. And the prosecution had indeed been forced to seek an adjournment so it could examine new scientific evidence.

That came about because of precognition, one of the mysteries of Scots law. Lawyers from the Procurator Fiscal's office - the nearest Scottish equivalent to the Crown Prosecution Service in England - visit defence witnesses before they give evidence and ask them what they plan to say in court. Defence solicitors precognosce prosecution witnesses in the same way.

You might wonder whether witnesses ever find a visit from the other side in any way intimidating. Even if everyone behaves impeccably, you might wonder why the two sides don't simply exchange written statements, as they do in England. And you might also wonder why nobody thought of changing the rules that left the prosecution with just 10 days to precognosce more than 100 defence witnesses, many of them living abroad.

The judges have been fighting a losing battle to avoid unnecessary adjournments. Nearly two weeks were lost while defence scientists were interviewed. While that was going on, somebody rewired the courtroom; as a result, the sound system no longer worked and another day was wasted while technicians fixed it.

Defence advocates had told the prosecution they wanted a crucial piece of evidence brought into court - a wrecked baggage container in which the bomb was allegedly placed. Prosecution lawyers did nothing to meet this entirely legitimate request. They pointed out that none of the doors in the specially-built courtroom was wide enough. So another day was lost while the baggage container was cut into two pieces.

It would be wrong to blame Boyd for everything that has gone wrong. But he has admitted he was not ready for the start of the trial. That was understandable; he had only become Scotland's senior law officer a few months earlier when his predecessor, Lord Hardie, was appointed to the bench. And the prosecution team give the impression that they are struggling to keep up with events, that the defence have all the best tunes. With a trial as unbalanced as this, the fear is that justice will be the loser.

Joshua Rozenberg is one of the BBC's correspondents at the Lockerbie trial

fields.headline: Contempt of the caught
fields.standfirst: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins on the issue of prejudicial media coverage
fields.body:
During the three days or so that Barry Bulsara (I call him by the name he calls himself) was under police questioning, before being charged with Jill Dando's murder, the media, mainly the tabloids, published a constant stream of information, tittle-tattle, rumour and speculation, almost all of it showing him in thoroughly negative light. The main thrust of the coverage was to present Bulsara as a weirdo. The key word to look out for is "loner".

Once you can describe someone as a loner, it's only a short step to weirdo. If you can throw in "fantasist" or "liar" as well (as the papers did), the case is made. A fully fledged weirdo, and we all know what they can do, don't we? There was other proof of his weirdness. One respectable chap was interviewed on television and told how, when he'd come home at two or three in the morning, he'd seen Bulsara out walking. Wow, we can't get much more damning than that, can we?

It reminded me of the coverage the tabloids gave to Colin Stagg, the man acquitted of the murder of Rachel Nickell on Wimbledon Common. In Stagg's case, there were pictures of him as well, wearing black (weird or what?), even though identification could have been an issue in the trial. At least Bulsara has been spared that.

The issue is not whether the media's treatment of Bulsara was offensive and unpleasant, but whether or not it was against the law: the Contempt of Court Act 1981. That in turn depends on whether what was published created a "substantial risk of serious prejudice" to his getting a fair trial. Would his jury be so potentially prejudiced by the pre-trial media coverage as not to be able to reach a verdict purely on the evidence in court?

A few years ago, I interviewed the then Attorney General, Sir Nicholas Lyell, to ask him why he hadn't taken contempt proceedings against newspapers in the Stagg case. His main reasons, the same as those usually given to me by lawyers, judges and editors, were twofold.

The first argument is that jurors, their minds concentrated on the proceedings before them in the hothouse atmosphere of the courtroom, listening to witnesses giving live evidence and being cross-examined, are highly unlikely to pay attention to some thing they may have seen or read before the trial.

The second, linked, point is that by the time of the trial, in nine months or a year's time, the jury will have pretty much forgotten what they'd read all that time ago. They won't be saying: "The evidence I've heard here in court is total rubbish, but I remember the Sun nine months ago saying that the accused took walks at night, so he must be guilty."

But if such arguments are true, they're true of almost every highly publicised case. Where does that leave the law on contempt?

Apart from cases where the accused's grave previous criminal record is revealed to the jury (which happens rarely), the contempt law seems now to be of little use. We either have to get used to the volume and nature of the publicity that attends suspects in big cases, and accept that it won't prejudice their trials, or, if we want to catch the Bulsara/Stagg sort of coverage, we have to change the definition in the 1981 Act to something less than "substantial risk of serious prejudice".

Or can name any member of Britain's highest court, the House of Lords, (other than Lord Hoffmann) or identify the Master of the Rolls? I'm frequently taken aback at the level of ignorance, among otherwise knowledgeable people, about our important judges.

Tomorrow, there's a big turnaround in the top judiciary. Lord Woolf, Master of the Rolls, becomes Lord Chief Justice instead of Lord Bingham, who becomes the head law lord. I don't expect these significant changes to receive much publicity.

In the US, such appointments would be front page news in many newspapers (and not just the posh ones) and there would be background articles and analyses. They still believe that judges - whether elected or appointed - are the people's judges, an essential part of the democratic system. Here we still tend to think of them as a race apart, a kind of dusty adjunct.

fields.headline: Stand up and be counted
fields.standfirst: Although we may hate public speaking, it's a vital skill, says  Esther Addley
fields.trailText: Although we may hate public speaking, it's a vital skill, says Esther Addley
fields.body:
Unaccustomed as most of us are to public speaking, it is a skill that few office workers can do without these days. Whether secretaries ever got by with the ability to type fast and make a good cup of tea, today's office support staff daren't turn up on day one without being able to rustle up the odd detailed presentation or two on Powerpoint - and then deliver it to the board of directors.

It is a task that requires a bit of nerve, nonetheless. There is nothing like standing up in front of one's boss and a couple of colleagues to turn the most confident, articulate worker into a stammering, white-faced bag of nerves. All the flow charts and neatly typed handouts in the world won't save you if you can't manage to introduce yourself without bursting into tears and running for the ladies'.

The good news - for presenting PAs at least - is that it happens to the best of us. A survey released this week by communications consultancy the Aziz Corporation discovered that company directors find public speaking every bit as terrifying as the humble PA. Three quarters of the survey's respondents said they found getting up in front of colleagues to be more nerve-wracking than any other office activity - including presenting this year's accounts to their own bosses, or managing employees. Among finance directors, oddly, the percentage too terrified to take the lectern rose to 88%.

Some tasks are more stressful than others, of course, with television or radio interviews rated the most intimidating. But 7% of bosses admitted that they were even reduced to the jitters at the thought of addressing employees at a social gathering. If you can't even find the fortitude to say a few words over mince pies at the Christmas party, you have problems indeed.

These figures are alarming because, as the respondents agreed, being able to present information or findings to colleagues, bosses or outsiders is an essential of the modern business environment. Almost two thirds of directors felt that presentation skills were vital for success in business - more even than those who valued intelligence - but only 7% thought they were any good at it.

Perhaps managers would do well to learn from their secretaries. Recruiters consistently report a shortage of office support staff skilled in communication and blessed with initiative: candidates who have developed these "soft skills" are snapped up by employers as soon as they enter the job market - or can afford to be choosy and hang on until their ideal position comes along.

PAs and office support staff have had to adapt to the vast changes that have taken place in their role over the past few years, becoming just as comfortable with training a group of colleagues as dealing with a pile of filing. It is about identifying the skills that are important to your job and setting out to acquire them. Managers would do well to pay attention.

"It may be that many directors are still labouring under the misapprehension that great public speakers are born and not made," says Khalid Aziz, chairman of the Aziz Corporation. "They understand the importance and benefits of effective public speaking skills, yet are still afraid of the task."

This may indicate a complacency, he believes, about acquiring and developing new skills that few secretaries could get away with. Your boss may need you to give a little gentle prodding to sharpen up his public speaking. Better still, why not put together a short presentation on the subject and show him how it is done?

webTitle: Time was right for Queen to meet Camilla, says palace

fields.headline: Time was right for Queen to meet Camilla, says palace
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Buckingham Palace yesterday left the door open to Camilla Parker Bowles' greater involvement in royal family life as speculation over a possible marriage to the Prince of Wales intensified after her first meeting with the Queen.
fields.body:
Buckingham Palace yesterday left the door open to Camilla Parker Bowles' greater involvement in royal family life as speculation over a possible marriage to the Prince of Wales intensified after her first meeting with the Queen.

The Queen lifted her effective boycott of meeting Mrs Parker Bowles on Saturday at a 60th birthday party for King Constantine of Greece. The Queen had avoided meeting her son's mistress, but a royal source told the Guardian that she had been advised that "the time was right" for her to demonstrate at least a degree of acceptance about the heir to the throne's choice of companion.

The meeting follows a choreographed rehabilitation of Mrs Parker Bowles' public image and represents a victory for the Prince of Wales's campaign to win acceptance for his divorcee friend in the face of newspaper criticism.

Mrs Parker Bowles was blamed by Diana, Princess of Wales, for the break-up of her marriage to Prince Charles.

Saturday's meeting took place at Prince Charles's home, Highgrove, and was witnessed by Princes William and Harry.

It lies in sharp contrast to Prince Charles's 50th birthday celebrations in 1998. When the Queen discovered that Mrs Parker Bowles was hosting the event she refused to attend.

The royal source said of the timing of Saturday's meeting: "Basically we're talking about the public mood, and there's just been a very successful tour in Scotland, when the general assembly of the Church of Scotland was welcoming to the fact that the Prince of Wales was there with Mrs Parker Bowles." Attention will now focus on whether Mrs Parker Bowles will attend the next big royal function at Windsor Castle on June 21.

This will mark not only the Queen Mother's 100th birthday, but the Duke of York's 40th birthday, Princess Margaret's 70th birthday, and Prince Willam's 18th birthday.

In an enigmatic statement, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said: "The question of Mrs Parker Bowles' attendance of private royal family functions will depend on circumstances.

"There's not much to be gained by trying to long-range forecast these things."

It was also stressed that Prince Charles has said that he has no plans to remarry.

A spokeswoman for St James's Palace said the prince was "very pleased" about the meeting.

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Paul Gouge
fields.trailText: Paul Gouge: Founding director of BattleMail.com and ex-stockbroker.
fields.body:
Age? 23.

Who is he? Founding director of BattleMail.com and ex-stockbroker.

What's the clever idea? "A free multiplayer game that you download on to your system and play against other people via email. We wanted to give people a better, more interactive and fun email opportunity and thought the best way was through a computer game. The other side to it is revenue generation. We send all this through advertising on the bottom of the games console. We look at the intended recipient, see if we have any adverts relevant to their profile, and stick one in the outgoing mail."

What's the thinking behind it? "Email is about communication with friends, entertainment, passing jokes around. It governs 91% of online user time, but has mainly been disregarded. Rather than send corny jokes, why not play computer games? Look at how big the online gaming market is. BattleMail allows us to hold that important gateway to users but also to provide a more apt method of receiving advertising. It's not intrusive because it's part of an attachment; it's permission-based because it comes from a friend; it occurs offline, so doesn't need live connection; it's profiled and it's free."

How does it work? "One: by going to the website and downloading it; two: by being sent it as an attachment. The games have been developed by a team of high-level games designers. At the moment there's a kung-fu game, and a soccer game is coming out, based on penalty shoot-outs, timed for Euro 2000. All you have to do is double click on the file, install the 1.35meg software, enter the email address and some profile information, select the character you want to play, some moves, a particular celebration, the text you want if you win, and then press go. It's not full-screen, so you can play it at work and get rid of it quickly."

Possible shortcomings? "Bandwidth. We have huge potential to offer better entertainment opportunities, but are restricted by how big attachment files can be. But we can see that reducing in time."

What's next? "We've got five clients waiting to go with adverts. We've had over 50,000 players since we launched three weeks ago and more than 5,500 unit users. We're developing our Wap and digital applications. What we want to do is offer a product which unifies all those mediums, so I can play you on your Wap phone, you can play somebody else on digital TV, and it wouldn't matter because our central database and technology allows the conversion of those different formats. "
