webTitle: Has Caroline got her hooks into you yet?

fields.headline: Has Caroline got her hooks into you yet?
fields.standfirst: Tom Harvey updates us on Freeserve's web drama
fields.trailText: Tom Harvey updates us on Freeserve's web drama
fields.body:
The iMac in the corner of the office pings away as it receives yet more emails for Caroline. I've just emptied the messages from Caroline's mobile phone. It was full again, as it is every morning. Caroline has so many friends trying to contact her that it's almost a shame she isn't real.

Caroline is the lead character in the interactive fiction Online Caroline that we launched on the web, with Freeserve, six weeks ago. In the first month thousands of people have gone online to meet Caroline, receiving one or more of her friendly, chatty, slightly needy emails and starting their journey through the episodic drama she inhabits.

It is fascinating to watch the way people "play" this drama. Over 3,000 users have emailed Caroline or called her on her mobile. We set out to create an interactive drama, but we didn't think for a moment that Caroline would take on the life that she has. Caroline has become a believable character, created by my colleagues in XPT, the show's director and writer, Rob Bevan and Tim Wright, and by Mira Dovreni who plays Caroline. The strength of the character is partly the reason that people become so immersed in the whole thing, but there is something else going on here.

First, there is the plot. There is the spooky fictitious XPT and its odd operatives who have set Caroline up in the first place, and for whom her mysterious boyfriend, David, played by Paul Duncan, works. There are her friends, whom she trusts, but perhaps shouldn't; her lifestyle, which she values but should perhaps leave behind; her own stumbling career which she should perhaps change; and her budgie who is perhaps her only ally. Apart from you, that is.

Beyond the characterisations and the plot, there is the interactivity to hook users in. Getting interactivity right is complex. Users want to be told intriguing stories. They don't necessarily want to develop them themselves. Online Caroline is a very carefully written story, and the users' path through it is channelled so that, to an extent, we are dictating how they experience the story. There are no closed interactive moments where the user decides on one narrative route or another. All the narrative strands remain open, ready to be explored and presented in episodic form as the site updates with each visit.

With online drama, usability and design also become key storytelling tools. Cinema and television currently have a passive user interface; we sit back and absorb the unfolding drama on the screen before us. On the web the technology is not yet there to allow this for a mainstream audience - and an interactive approach requires more involvement. An audience which is allowed to decide how it explores a narrative is just as likely to decide to go and explore another website as it is to investigate yours. The site design and functionality have to lure them in - each click has to offer a little narrative reward, a new piece of information, a new twist in the story.

To begin with, some people think XPT has really placed a webcam in Caroline's house and the "live" pictures are of events happening as they watch. Witness the number of calls to Caroline's mobile, warning her that her house is being burgled. Some people are almost certain it is fiction, but Caroline's emails, which are now becoming increasingly tailored to the likes, dislikes and traits of the individual users, draw people in. She wants advice, she values your opinion, she likes you, and you are her friends - soulmates even. You can't desert her now, especially now boyfriend David is about to return from Africa.

C aroline knows about you, she knows the name of your best friend, the colour of your hair, she even knows if you have been unfaithful or not, because you have told her. But when this information comes back to you incorporated into her emails, it doesn't matter that you told her all about it just three days before, it feels like she's known you all along. This allows the user to feel like an intrinsic part of the story, but without affecting the plot significantly. Users tailor the drama to themselves.

This is a channelled, immersive drama. In the end people get involved with it, not because they are lonely and have nothing better to do, but because it is genuine drama, with strong characters and an interesting plot. The question of whether it is reality or fiction soon becomes irrelevant. People cease to care if it is true or not. They play along, they suspend their disbelief in order to enjoy the experience, and, importantly, it's an experience they feel part of.

But then again perhaps they sign up because it is just a bit more fun than another cops or frocks drama on the telly.

Tom Harvey is managing director of interactive entertainment company XPT Ltd. Caroline is at www.onlinecaroline.com

webTitle: A slow start to the revolution

fields.headline: A slow start to the revolution
fields.standfirst: Looking for an exciting and fast-paced work environment? Don't join an internet start-up, says  Charles Miller. He should know, he's just spent six months filming inside dot.coms
fields.trailText: Looking for an exciting and fast-paced work environment? Don't join an internet start-up, says Charles Miller. He should know, he's just spent six months filming inside dot.coms
fields.body:
After six months lurking in the offices of half a dozen internet start-up companies, I can confidently report that they are very . . . quiet. People who work in dot.coms love to claim that things move unbelievably fast in their business. A month in the internet is said to represent the experience and progress of a year anywhere else. I beg to differ.

According to Mark Fletcher, founder of the email group service OneList.com, if you want to describe the start-up experience "take every emotion you can imagine and multiply it by 100." After six months in the offices of half a dozen internet start-up companies, filming their progress for a television documentary series, we saw surprisingly little emotion. Fletcher himself, a self-confessed "nerd by birth", was calm and relaxed, typical of the informal, serious types who run the companies we filmed.

Indeed, the pace of dot.com life was less frenetic than the mythology had led us to expect. Investment arrives months after it has been promised. Meetings with venture capitalists take forever to schedule. Even writing a business plan seems to take as long as writing a novel.

But having millions of pounds of investors' money can make things happen. Dot.coms can hire new staff as quickly as they can find them. In the US, the British method of filling a job, by seeing several candidates before picking the best, is considered too slow. In most Silicon Valley start-up positions, if you don't take a plausible candidate as soon as the interview is over, it will be too late.

A key staff member in a British company we filmed confessed she had been hired after falling into conversation with her new boss when sitting opposite him on a train. She knew nothing about the internet, and had never considered a job in it before that journey.

The prevailing myth of dot.com life is to do with money. But asking most dot.commers about money produces the kind of weary sigh you get in Chicago if you ask about gangsters. The usual line is that the real satisfaction in internet businesses comes from providing great service for customers.

One or two entrepreneurs were more open: Ernesto Schmitt, the founder of Peoplesound.com, said to be worth £17m, told me he couldn't get a mortgage on the strength of that, and couldn't even borrow money to buy a car. Since the value of his stake in the company is only based on what investors are now paying for a slice of it, it really is theoretical money. But even that has a certain sentimental value. One dot.commer told me he cracked open a solitary bottle of champagne at home the evening he calculated that his stock options made him a paper millionaire. Being able to shrug off one's paper millions is a new status symbol: "Of course it doesn't really mean much . . . yet."

If Peoplesound's initial public offering (IPO) goes according to plan, even the most junior staff who joined when the company started last year could each make $5m. Staff joining today would still make about $160,000 from their share options. Ernesto Schmitt muses about the possibility of Peoplesound creating 100 millionaires at its IPO. Another company we filmed, Wcities, started by a 32-year-old former marketing consultant, Tan Rasab, is hoping for a valuation of about $500m on its flotation. That would make Tan and his wife, a co-founder, worth about $150m between them.

If this seems like a lot of money, the standard line is that nobody earns it without working incredibly hard. That may be true, but on the whole internet offices seem to empty surprisingly promptly around 5.30pm. I don't think we came across anyone who had worked later than midnight. There were occasions when we wanted to get some shots of hustle and bustle, but had to give up because it was the end of the afternoon. We returned to our office at the BBC, where we make comparatively leisurely-paced political documentaries, to find everyone still on the phone and screaming at each other.

The office of a typical start-up is more like a library in a new university. Email is the preferred medium of communication, often for people sitting next to each other. I had the feeling that talking ("going offline"), or making phone calls are considered, somehow, interruptions to the real work at keyboards. The dramas we had in mind before we started filming - stormy business deals, programmers working all night and sleeping on the floor, were few and far between.

Being TV people on internet territory has been an interesting social situation: the start-ups realise that, even with a comparatively esoteric BBC2 series, we can provide them with more eyeballs in 40 minutes than they could hope to draw to their name and website in months or even years, without paying for a blitz of advertising. For our part, there's a realisation that we are watching the rapid development of something that will one day dominate - or swallow - television. And yet, for the moment, we have the upper hand. Everyone has television. When programmes are transmitted, they don't freeze, or force you to switch off before trying again. Television sets actually work.

Feeling comfortable in a dot.com depends on buying into the mythology of the future. Anyone who sounds sceptical about world domination by the internet is dismissed as not "getting it". Nicholas Barnard, chief executive of Petspark, led a group of his staff to San Francisco, to visit their new US partners, Pets.com. Seeing the phenomenal growth of Pets.com gave the visiting Brits what Barnard called "a sense of destiny" about their own company's future. Unfortunately, since that visit in January, Pets.com shares have floated on the US stock exchange and have sunk from $12 to around $2. Pets.com has become something of an icon of the anxieties surrounding "b to c" (business to consumer) dot.coms. Undeterred, Petspark is still expanding, and is still planning to raise more money.

Another dot.com myth is about youth. While there are many twentysomethings running successful internet companies, youth is not essential. Sally Robinson, a middle-aged farmer's wife in Yorkshire, started AmpleBosom.com, to sell bras and underwear to "the larger lady" from one of the farm outbuildings. Uniquely among the companies we filmed, Sally hopes to break even, and may even start to make a profit, on the loan of £80,000 she took out to start the business. With orders of around £1,000 a day, she has only three computers. A dot.com run on the same principles of her bed-and-breakfast business looks like a good idea in the current financial climate.

Some dot.coms even import older people to create a better image for their team. "Get some grey hair" is the advice of Ernesto Schmitt of Peoplesound. He talks openly about hiring Martin Turner, a former president of Compuserve, because he was older. Turner, he says, gave his investors confidence.

My colleagues and I have had a number of muttered job offers during the filming process. It's nice to think money would be forthcoming if we ever felt like taking them up on the offer, but this is probably just the dot.com equivalent of "you must look us up next time you're in the States".

To our surprise, we have also received a number of calls and furtive emails from people in internet start-ups who want to know how to get into television. One said he found his work in one of the trendier internet start-ups "boring". It's reassuring to think television still holds some attractions to new media types. It helps - just a little - to alleviate the oppressive feeling of almost everyone in television that they're missing out on something big.

Charles Miller's series, Inside Dot Coms, begins tonight on BBC2

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
* The introduction of BT's flat rate internet access service or SurfTime last Friday - which will allow free home internet access and give e-commerce a massive boost in the UK - has caused chaos and celebration in equal measure amongst operators and ISPs. LibertySurf, the Kingfisher-backed ISP, has had to withdraw its unmetered access installation disks from service, unable to cope with the surge in demand. AltaVista and NTL have also experienced major setbacks in the roll-out of their services and indeed BT itself will not be making the package available to its own customers until next month. While subscription services like AOL are "cracking open the champagne", according one executive, there will be losers: namely the hundreds of free ISP services that have grown up in the opportunistic climate of the last 12 months, which will now have to rely on commerce and advertising.

*While other B to Cs are struggling to stay in business, the teenybop portal market is positively precocious. Wowgo.com, the soon-to-launch teenage girls' portal featured in last week's New Media Guardian, has just signed a six-figure deal with Capital to sponsor its Party in the Park website - a tie-in with Capital's live event on July 9 in Hyde Park - with a long-term partnership on the cards. A shrewd move in the light of last week's announcement that Channel 4 and Emap will be launching a joint venture digital service aimed at the teen market, particularly the teenage girls' market which is worth £16bn in the UK alone.

*Express Newspapers are rumoured to be launching two interactive portals within the next 12 months. The first, a parenting portal developed in conjunction with Debenhams, is set to launch in July. The group refused to comment on the rumours that they had been discussing advertising briefs worth £9m with agencies to promote the new products. The fledgling new media arm recently received a £370m boost from parent company, United News and Media.

*Bad news for start-ups who've just spent half their budget on advertising. A new report from Ogilvy Interactive suggests that the average consumer is confused or "turned off" by dot.com ads. Out of a total 1,000 adults asked to name a new media company, 72% were unable to recall a name without a prompt and even then didn't know what the company did.

*Handbag.com, the women's portal, is branching out into drama. In its latest bid to attact more after-hours surfers to its site, it is launching its own fly-on-the-wall docu-soap about three "lads about town" who share a flat together in London's chic N1. Don't hold your breath for real life grit, however - two of them work in advertising, two in finance, they all went to school together and at least one of them, one suspects, is dating a member of the Handbag team.

fields.headline: Hostages snub offer of liberty
fields.standfirst:
Women MPs refuse to leave male colleagues held by Fiji rebels
The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Women MPs refuse to leave male colleagues held by Fiji rebels
fields.body:
The four women among the 31 hostages being held by the Fijian rebel leader George Speight rejected an offer of freedom at the weekend because they did not want to desert the remaining captives, their husbands said yesterday.

As the stalemate that began as a coup attempt but has since developed into a wider crisis of national identity ended its 17th day yesterday, the husbands said they had asked to exchange places with their wives, who are cooped up in the parliament compound in the capital, Suva.

"We have written a letter to Mr Speight asking that the four of us husbands swap places with them so they can enjoy some freedom," said Adishwar Padarath, the husband of a deposed cabinet minister, Lavinia Padarath. Mr Speight has not yet replied.

Robert Rigamoto, the husband of assistant minister Marieta Rigamoto, said that he feared he would never see her again. "The longer this goes on, the more I fear for her safety," he said. "On the spur of the moment one of the gunmen could turn round and do something silly."

The other two women hostages are Adi Koila Nailatikau, a minister, and Akanisi Koroitamana, a backbencher. An aide to Mr Speight said the women should no longer be considered hostages because they had refused to leave. "They cannot say they are hostages from now on because they are here as voluntary supporters of their colleagues."

The other woman captured when the rebels seized the parliament on May 19, Adi Ema Tagicakibau, was freed last Thursday to attend a relative's funeral and was told she did not have to return to captivity.

Fiji's military rulers and the rebels said yesterday that they had reached a draft accord to end the crisis and restore the South Pacific country to civilian rule.

Both Mr Speight - who wants to restore the dominance of indigenous Fijians over ethnic Indians - and the military which seized executive power and declared martial law last Monday after the collapse of the government, said last night that negotiations to end the crisis were making good progress.

"We are coming to the end now," a military spokesman, Lieutenant Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini, said.

Mr Speight agreed: "We have come up with a draft accord, a document that captures the essence of our discussion. I do not want to put any specific timetables on this [process] except to say that we're well on the way now."

The main sticking point of the accord remains the composition of any interim government after the release of the hostages, in particular the involvement of Mr Speight's supporters and the military. The military wishes to retain control for a period after the release of the hostages.

Last Friday Mr Speight said that the hostages would be released yesterday and a deal would be finalised today, but negotiations with the military stalled on Saturday amid mutual recrimination.

All the hostages are in regular communication with their families. "We are able to exchange letters with them," Mr Padarath said. "They are given 20 minutes a day to do exercises and they're holding regular prayer sessions. They seem to be holding up well."

Mr Rigamoto said the hostages' greatest problem was finding ways to fill their days. "They are all very strong people, both physically and spiritually, but they are complaining about being bored; about having nothing to do."

Mr Speight admitted last night that while the hostages appeared to be in good physical health, "perhaps emotionally they have endured stress".

fields.headline: That's entertainment
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Weekend TV: Ruby's American Pie/History Zone Films: The Houdini Myth/Sing It Your Way
fields.body:
Some people will do anything in the name of entertainment. Take death-match wrestler Angel, who appears nightly in fight clubs around North Carolina being beaten to a bloody pulp by her male opponents. Such is her dedication that she scatters the ring with drawing pins to ensure extra blood for your money.

The unlovely Angel lurked in the lower depths of Ruby's American Pie (BBC1), a wide-eyed excursion into the world of female pro wrestling that was by turns hilarious and chilling. Star of the show was stripper-turned-fighter Strawberry Fields, a self- confessed "hoochie-mama slut" who could do tricks with her breasts. Her deadpan account of a misspent youth (morphine addiction by 14, several spells in prison for assault) was a masterpiece of comic timing, leaving an awestruck Ruby Wax lost for words. Miss Fields then welcomed Miss Wax into her gracious home, where she said her prayers ("and God bless that bitch that pisses me off on a daily basis") with a loaded gun on the bedside table. A quick bout with big-boned sparring partner Lei Lani, and it was time for a girls' night out at the Diamond Club, where Fields upstaged younger stripping rivals with a bit of old-school showmanship, attaching candles to her nipples and lighting people's cigarettes with them. Like Showgirls directed by John Waters.

Wax's shows get better and better. Now that she's seemingly dumped celebrities - after all, where could she go after Fergie? - there's a freshness and enthusiasm about her interviewing technique that allows these obscure stars to shine more brightly. Lei Lani chattered cheerfully about her favourite hobby - hog wrestling - while Strawberry Fields let Wax root around in her collection of sex toys. Of course it's voyeuristic, but Wax observes the first rule of voyeurism - first find your exhibitionist. For the most part, this seemed like a marriage made in heaven. The "death-match" footage, complete with coagulating gore dripping from the fighters' noses, closed the show on a sombre note; in certain benighted states, you can watch this stuff on pay-per-view TV. Wax didn't actually say it - it scarcely needed saying - but this doesn't bode well for the US entertainment industry.

Harry Houdini was another old trouper who'd do anything to entertain his public. After a lifetime of broken bones and bruised internal organs, he was finally sent to his reward by a burst appendix, popped by a fan who punched him playfully in the stomach. History Zone Films: The Houdini Myth (BBC2) cantered agreeably through the escapologist's life, making the most of some spectacular restored footage of Houdini's later stunts and his ill-advised move into films. Mercifully there was minimal reconstruction; nor were the effects buttons overused. Pundits trotted out unconvincing theories about escapology as a social and political metaphor, and David Copperfield was wheeled on for no apparent reason. But none of this got in the way of the real substance of the programme, revealing Houdini as the first great master of media manipulation, enlisting the new tabloid press to hype his feats to astronomical heights. The tricks were explained, but strangely this didn't diminish him one iota; in fact, one could only admire the cunning with which he achieved his illusions.

Houdini's later campaigns against bogus spiritualists ("It takes a flim-flammer to catch a flim-flammer") led to the final great poetic climax of the story when, ten years after his death, he failed to "come through" to his grieving widow at a seance, having promised on his death bed that "if anyone can do it, it will be me". After hysterical imprecations from the medium, nothing happened. "My last hope is gone," said Mrs Houdini, and Houdini passed forever into legend.

ITV fielded a new format on Saturday night with Sing It Your Way, in which various "legends" were invited to perform the song of their choice to Denise Van Outen and Ian Wright. They promised surprises, the biggest of which was B*Witched's funk-free interpretation of Play That Funky Music. Tension mounted as verse headed towards chorus. Would they change the words to "Play that funky music, Irish girl"? Alas, no. They jigged on in the usual way. Gene Pitney tackled Robbie Williams' Angels. Stephen Gateley had a stab at Michael Jackson. Of the Honeyz' passion-killing rendition of Love To Love You Baby, the less said the better.

After a lifetime of broken bones and bruised internal organs, he was finally sent to his reward by a burst appendix, popped by a fan who punched him playfully in the stomach. History Zone Films: The Houdini Myth (BBC2) cantered agreeably through the escapologist's life, making the most of some spectacular restored footage of Houdini's later stunts and his ill-advised move into films. Mercifully there was minimal reconstruction; nor were the effects buttons overused. Pundits trotted out unconvincing theories about escapology as a social and political metaphor, and David Copperfield was wheeled on for no apparent reason. But none of this got in the way of the real substance of the programme, revealing Houdini as the first great master of media manipulation, enlisting the new tabloid press to hype his feats to astronomical heights. The tricks were explained, but strangely this didn't diminish him one iota; in fact, one could only admire the cunning with which he achieved his illusions. Houdini's later campaigns against bogus spiritualists ("It takes a flim-flammer to catch a flim-flammer") led to the final great poetic climax of the story when, ten years after his death, he failed to "come through" to his grieving widow at a seance, having promised on his death bed that "if anyone can do it, it will be me". After hysterical imprecations from the medium, nothing happened. "My last hope is gone," said Mrs Houdini, and Houdini passed forever into legend. ITV fielded a new format on Saturday night with Sing It Your Way, in which various "legends" were invited to perform the song of their choice to Denise Van Outen and Ian Wright. They promised surprises, the biggest of which was B*Witched's funk-free interpretation of Play That Funky Music. Tension mounted as verse headed towards chorus. Would they change the words to "Play that funky music, Irish girl"? Alas, no. They jigged on in the usual way. Gene Pitney tackled Robbie Williams' Angels. Stephen Gateley had a stab at Michael Jackson. Of the Honeyz' passion-killing rendition of Love To Love You Baby, the less said the better.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Case Of Sigmund Freud/Chris Barber At 70/
fields.body:
So deeply has psychoanalysis entered our lives that the latest Oxford dictionary lists 90 words derived from it. "Abreaction" doesn't crop up much over the breakfast table, but "wish-fulfilment" became one of the prime industries of the ensuing century. In The Case Of Sigmund Freud (11.0am, Radio 4) Lisa Appiganesi celebrates the publication centenary of The Interpretation Of Dreams. In this first programme she discusses Freud's cultural legacy with writers like AS Byatt and Hanif Kureishi.

He was all set for a career as an actuary until diverted by a second-hand trombone. Now, after years of him playing it around the world, we're still listening to Chris Barber At 70 (8.30pm, Radio 2). Among the old stagers joining him at the Golder's Green Hippodrome are Van Morrison, Lonnie Donegan and Kenny Ball. None dreamed of a musical career stretching into the next century. They say they just carried on, waiting for the bubble to burst.

webTitle: Work experience The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Gwyneth Paltrow
fields.body:
Gwyneth Paltrow in Hook (Steven Spielberg, 1991)

Who? The new Grace Kelly - she wishes. The daughter of director Bruce Paltrow and actress Blythe Danner, Gwyneth is a competent actress who managed to become far more famous than she really deserved by dating her co-star in Seven, Brad Pitt. She showcased her oh-so-accurate (and oh-so-annoying) English accent in Emma and Sliding Doors, before winning her Oscar for Shakespeare In Love - but let's try to forget about that. Gwyneth has an on-off relationship with Ben Affleck, with whom she stars in her latest project, Bounce.

The role: Young Wendy - shown in flashback, she's the girl who Peter Pan falls in love with. Despite the fact that this is, in fact, the first outing for her terrible, screeching English accent and she insists on braying "Peet-ah! Peet-ah!" at every available opportunity.

Best line: Well, it's pretty much just "Peet-ah!", to be honest.

Cringe factor: After that Oscar speech, there's nothing on earth that could be more embarrassing for her.

Other wannabes: No stranger to turgid balladeering, but a newcomer to acting, Phil Collins played Inspector Good.

Critical judgement: Roger Ebert of the Chicago Sun-Times had "the uncanny suspicion that Hook was written and directed according to the famous recipe of the country preacher who told the folks what he was going to tell them, told them, and then told them what he had told them". He didn't like it much, then.

Also not starring in: Shout, in 1991, with a pre-career rehabilitation John Travolta. And in Cruel Doubt, a 1992 TV movie, where the lead role was played by her mother.

Lucy Barrick

Hook, Sci-Fi, Saturday June 10, 8.0pm

fields.headline: E-numbers
fields.trailText: Now a fascinating quartet of reports called Inside Dot Coms: Tales Of The Electronic Goldrush (Monday-Thursday, 11.20pm, BBC2) follows would-be net entrepreneurs in Britain and America.
fields.body:
Although the BBC has invested millions in internet services - and whole radio shows now consist of reading out emails - the corporation has been commendably more sceptical than newspapers about the worldwide web. A Panorama report highlighting the fantasy valuations of many dotcom enterprises almost certainly influenced the subsequent retreat by small investors from new technology stocks.

Now a fascinating quartet of reports called Inside Dot Coms: Tales Of The Electronic Goldrush (Monday-Thursday, 11.20pm, BBC2) follows would-be net entrepreneurs in Britain and America. The risk with this was that the BBC would give priceless free advertising to a handful of web wannabes, but this is prevented by the presence throughout of a proper journalistic scepticism.

The opening programme - in which three e-commerce dreamers seek investment from venture capitalists - captures the two most important aspects of the new technology phenomenon. The first is a change in the popular attitude to business. Ten years ago, people who left salaried employment to start a company were regarded as arrogant mavericks who would soon come crawling back. But internet entrepreneurs are viewed as super-rich tycoons from the day they announce their idea.

And a crucial scene in the first show exposes the fantasy maths on which many of these ventures depend. A woman whose website - directing foreign students to language schools - currently has two customers watches as a business adviser does some rough sums before declaring that her company is worth £50 million. A later scene in which she selects a smart company car makes the same point about these companies' rejection of established business sense.

The approach isn't Luddite - four students are shown receiving serious money for a web business with some record of sales - but this compelling fly-on-the-wall series is a brave fly in the ointment of the more dangerous of the e-commerce myths.

webTitle: Hey, that'd look great in a theme park

fields.headline: Hey, that'd look great in a theme park
fields.standfirst: Expo 2000 in Hanover is, like its predecessors, full of startling innovations - but they have little to do with real life, writes  Steve Rose
fields.trailText: A management model for civilisation? A test lab for utopian technology? A global love-in? A theme park ride around the future? After 150 years of existence, the World Exposition, or Expo as it is commonly known, is still a mystifying phenomenon.
fields.body:
A management model for civilisation? A test lab for utopian technology? A global love-in? A theme park ride around the future? After 150 years of existence, the World Exposition, or Expo as it is commonly known, is still a mystifying phenomenon.

One crops up every few years, enticing millions of visitors into a deranged fun fair - usually somewhere outside a middle-ranking first-world city centre - with an array of architectural panache, spectacular events and previews of how the future is expected to pan out. They have invariably benefited their host towns, and have made the reputation of many an architect and designer, but how have they changed the outside world? Has the future ever panned out the way they said it would? Have they ever achieved anything beyond amusing and confusing the public?

For Expo 2000, which began in Hanover last week, these questions are more pertinent than ever. This is, after all, the 21st century; both the dawning of a new era and the sell-by date for many of the utopian promises of Expos past. On the 160-hectare site, there are five huge shedfuls of exhibits addressing the typically Expo-esque theme of "Humankind, Nature Technology: The creation of a new world". Armed with a multimedia arsenal and with the emphasis on societal and ecological harmony, these exhibitions outline the future of work, transport, nutrition, etc, most of it sponsored by multinational corporations (there's a Coca-Cola machine on every corner - try buying a Pepsi at Expo 2000).

At the far ends of the site, linked by cable car, are the national pavilions, which compete like an architectural version of the Olympics. Pavilions typically display the most cutting-edge design their countries can come up with, or create a tourist-friendly pastiche of vernacular styles, little of which sits easily alongside the ecological and environmental themes.

Thus nations such as Portugal, Italy or Spain offer stylish, sober constructions, Nepal offers half a Hindu temple and half a Buddhist stupa stuck together, the United Arab Emirates a stage-set desert fortress, and Monaco a deluxe steel structure with a speedboat moored outside. The UK has effectively opted out of the game this time round, having burnt its fingers at Seville's Expo 92 with Nicholas Grimshaw's expensive ultra-rational structure (which is still sitting in crates somewhere waiting for a buyer). Britain's pavilion is easily the worst in Hanover: a cheap, off-the-shelf steel box filled with sub-trade fair exhibits and the original door from 10 Downing Street.

Wandering around this collection of follies, there is a nagging sense that it's not the future we are looking at any more, it's the past: a nostalgic attempt to recapture the days when these things really mattered. Even the souvenir shops are still selling lava lamps and kinetic desktop sculptures. For Expo's purposes the future peaked in about 1969, just after the moon landing, when space travel was on the up and Stanley Kubrick's 2001 was taken more as a promise than a fantasy, when the limitations of the earth's resources and the damage humanity had inflicted on the environment were not yet fully acknowledged. Progress was a one-way street and all we needed were a few navigational aids.

Expo 70, in Osaka, was the best attended World Exposition of all, with 64.2m visitors. Attractions included a giant inflatable US pavil ion (filled with trophies from the moon); Kenzo Tange's space-frame Japanese pavilion; the flying saucers of the Sumitomo Pavilion; and the Takara Beautilion, dedicated to the "joy of being beautiful" and graced by a daily international fashion show.

Looking back, Expo 70 was possibly the largest monument to kitsch the world has ever created, a global tribute to triviality. But like every Expo before or since, it purported to offer serious architectural innovation. Clearly, there has been some straying from the path. The equation between progressive architecture and world exhibitions was once demonstrably successful.

It is no coincidence that chapter one of Expo is also chapter one of modern architecture, and perhaps that is where the trouble started: Joseph Paxton's magnificent Crystal Palace was the high point of the first Expo, London's Great Exhibition of 1851. The steel-and-glass exhibition hall was the perfect test subject for Paxton's revolutionary construction techniques, which paved the way for skyscrapers to come. The result was stylish, practicable and radical, and Expo architecture has been expected to supply these qualities ever since.

The formula continued to develop, particularly in London, Paris and the US during the 19th century, producing another futuristic landmark, the Eiffel Tower, in 1889, and introducing such innovations as the typewriter, Edison's gramophone, the automobile and the saxophone. Expos became so popular that a regulating body, the Bureau International des Expositions, was founded in Paris in 1928 to decide where, when and how Expos would be held.

In the modern era, the list of archi tectural milestones that Expo produced is, on the face of it, respectable: Mies van der Rohe's 1929 Barcelona Pavilion; Frei Otto's tensile structures; the space frame; the geodesic dome; Moshe Safdie's Habitat 67 apartments; the monorail; the Ferris wheel; and, er, the Brussels Atomium.

On closer inspection, however, the world has been conspicuously unaltered by these innovations. Take the monorail. A steam-powered prototype was unveiled at the Philadelphia World's Fair way back in 1876. It only travelled 500ft, but it was applauded none the less. Fast-forward 100-odd years, and where are all the monorails? Ah, there's one, at Expo 67, gliding into the US pavilion. Outside of Expo-land, monorails are still pretty thin on the ground; a few airports, the odd city centre, and theme parks, where they have been employed more for their futuristic associations than any practical advantage.

Likewise for the geodesic dome. The aforementioned US pavilion for Expo 67 was an impressive 250ft-diameter three-quarter sphere by Mr Dome himself, Richard Buckminster Fuller. Again, the interior was devoted largely to space travel, but the highlight for visitors was simply entering this vast sphere - especially as they were travelling by monorail. The geodesic dome was an innovation, undeniably, but again, one which has failed to make an impression on our skylines. Aside from climbing frames, the only place you'll find geodesic domes is in theme parks and other Expos: the German pavilion at Osaka 70, Disney's Discovery Centre, the US pavilion at Seville 92. Given free rein to explore the wildest architectural fantasies in a parallel universe, little of this Expo architecture has translated back into the real world. In fact, the prime beneficiary of Expo's innovations seem to have been Expo itself and its cousin, the theme park.

Paxton's Crystal Palace satisfied the demands both for new aesthetic forms and for practicable technological advancement, but today's Expo architecture has absolved itself of the latter responsibility, reducing itself to a series of theatrical emblems and stylistic pointers. It's not architecture, it's Expotecture.

This explains why the architecture at Expo 2000 is a freestanding diversion while the serious future-divining takes place elsewhere. Only one or two designs try to address the problems of the outside world. The Dutch pavilion attempts a radical layered reorganisation of urban space (even if the "forest" level is actually made of hollowed out tree trunks with steel girders inside). And the Japanese pavilion, designed by Shigeru Ban, elegantly satisfies all requirements. It is a tranquil, translucent tunnel made entirely of paper: beautiful, progressive and totally recyclable.

It is fitting that Japan will host the next world Expo, in Aichi in 2005. A radically different approach has been outlined, along the lines of "rediscovering nature's wisdom". Instead of levelling and denuding a natural site then importing architecture and landscaping, the organisers intend to place eco-friendly buildings between the natural features of the woodland site, and to address issues such as conservation and recycling waste. No national pavilions, no monorails. It might be the end of Expo as we know it, but hopefully, it's where the real future begins.

fields.headline: End of kidnap ordeal
fields.standfirst:
Teenage Israeli rescued in Russia after 10 months in cellar
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: After surviving 10 grim months of torture, cold, and hunger as a hostage in western Russia, the 13-year-old son of a wealthy Israeli businessman flew home from captivity last night.
fields.body:
After surviving 10 grim months of torture, cold, and hunger as a hostage in western Russia, the 13-year-old son of a wealthy Israeli businessman flew home from captivity last night.

Russian police declined to provide many details of the circumstances surrounding Adi Sharon's abduction.

He was held for a ransom that was never paid and the boy's father was on hand on Friday after crack units of heavily armed special police stormed the bleak cellar where the teenager was being held outside the town of Penza in western Russia.

During the incarceration, the boy's tormentors severed parts of his little fingers and sent them to his father, demanding an $8m ransom (£5m) for his release.

A police video of the rescue operation showed the boy looking pale and terrified as paramilitary police secured an end to his ordeal.

Emaciated and gaunt, he was barely able to walk. He was taken to a Moscow hospital, where he spent the weekend. Russian state television showed him surrounded by breathing equipment and being treated with glucose drips.

The Russian authorities blamed Chechen gangsters for the kidnapping.

Moscow has been at war with Chechen separatist guerrillas for eight months. In the three years prior to the outbreak of the war, hundreds of Russians and foreigners were kidnapped in Chechnya in an epidemic of hostage-taking.

Russian officials say that hundreds of hostages are still being held in the breakaway republic, including many foreigners.

Six Chechens and seven other people were arrested in the police raid outside Penza, a police spokesman said yesterday.

Adi was taken to Moscow airport by ambulance yesterday and put on a special aircraft with the interior minister, Vladimir Rushailo, who was flying to Israel for talks on action against criminals.

Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister, phoned the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, yesterday to thank him for the boy's rescue and safe return.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Amazon Women/This Happy Breed/Out Of Sight/Manhunter
fields.body:
Amazon Women

6pm, History

Around 600BC, ancient Greeks recorded tales of fearsome warrior women called "Amazons", which meant "one-breasted" as they were said to cut off a breast to better aim a bow. These stories were seen as myths until the discovery in 1994 of a series of graves in Kazakhstan region. Several skeletons, buried with full warrior accoutrements belonged to women. This documentary traces historical accounts of female aggressors, from Boadicea to the Amazons of South America.

This Happy Breed

(David Lean, 1944)

5pm, Carlton Cinema

Lean's first solo effort: he'd made another accomplished wartime propaganda piece, In Which We Serve, with Noël Coward, who provides the script here from his own play. It's a fascinating picture of a lower-middle-class family between the wars - low-key and convincing. The cast includes Robert Newton, Stanley Holloway, Celia Johnson, John Mills and Lean's first wife, Kay Walsh.

Out Of Sight

(Steven Soderbergh, 1998)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

This hip and witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh storming into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott Frank, who also did Get Shorty, plots an intricate path through Elmore Leonard's twisty novel, and hangs on to the master's snappy dialogue. These stories were seen as myths until the discovery in 1994 of a series of graves in Kazakhstan region. Several skeletons, buried with full warrior accoutrements belonged to women. fields.headline: Going back to the bottle
fields.standfirst: At 13, Carol Morley had a reputation for sleeping with anyone and drinking men under the table. Now she has put her past on film.  Fiona Morrow finds out why
fields.trailText: At 13, Carol Morley had a reputation for sleeping with anyone and drinking men under the table. Now she has put her past on film.
fields.body:
Carol Morley had put her teenage years in Manchester to the back of her mind until a man she was introduced to 15 years later, in London, recounted a story he'd heard about her. Intrigued that her reputation could have travelled so far, Morley put an ad in a Manchester paper, asking anyone who had known her in the mid-80s to get in touch. The resulting interviews with many of Manchester's most famous names (club promoter Alan Wise, writer Dave Haslam, Pete Shelley, lead singer of The Buzzcocks) make up The Alcohol Years, Morley's wonderfully frank and intimate film study of the person she once was.

It had been a time of excess, of drinking, of sex. Lots of sex. Morley was the girl who always left with someone; she was up for anything and everyone knew it. "Manchester was a real boys' town and I would freak people out because I'd fuck anybody, men or women. And of course I had this huge reputation."

Morley's father had committed suicide when she was 11 and, as her mother's world fell apart, she was left to her own devices. At 13, she was hitting the local nightclubs every night, drinking the men under the table. "I'd have a bottle of Thunderbird before I went out, to take the edge off. Then it was spirits and cocktails all night. There was definitely a competitive side to it."

Back then, Morley dressed like a child, carried toys around with her and was desperate to be liked; these days she is a youthful 34-year-old, at ease with herself, who talks about her past as though it happened to someone else. Like Tracey Emin's quilted list of all the men she ever slept with, The Alcohol Years is a challenge to those who would write off a promiscuous woman as "just another slag" and tut disapprovingly at those who refuse to hide their sexuality under a sensible skirt. But because Morley took everything to extremes, the film pushes even the most liberated among us to confront our own boundaries of what is, and is not, acceptable behaviour.

We see Morley only fleetingly in The Alcohol Years and her decision to keep herself mostly absent provides a large part of the film's power. Morley may have had the reputation, but here she is unpeeling its construction. For this is a film about attitude and myth: in presenting their perceptions of Morley as they remember her, the men and women on screen become part of a study of both the power of memory and the endurance of received morality.

Dave Haslam (author of Manchester, England) describes how he was unique as the man Morley read books with and never slept with, and suggests that she had actually been sexually ill. "It's a very male response, don't you think?" Morley says. "I mean, women used to be locked away in mental institutions for far less."

Nevertheless there are shocking revelations here: picking up old blokes off the street, shagging the gas man ("Actually, it was the postman"), charging for sex. "I just thought if I was going to do it, I might as well get paid. It was quite a desperate time, I had nowhere really to live and it was an easy way to make some money. I don't think it's a big deal and I think it's funny how prostitutes are made out as these terrible transgressors."

And perhaps it isn't such a leap from sleeping with the guy who bought you dinner, to putting out in order to be put up, to asking for cash. Many might see it as either brave or completely crazy, though, to be so open about it. "I don't think it was brave because I wouldn't have gone back without the camera. It was always there, mediating for me and protecting me. And I didn't ever think about it being seen as self-publicising, which is ironic because at that time, all I wanted was to be noticed. When you're a teenager, you only define yourself through other people's eyes."

Despite being aware of her erstwhile notoriety, Morley was still surprised at how much people had to say about her. The 40 hours of interviews at times proved gruelling, caused her unpleasant dreams and made her question the entire project. "It was so strange, because before we filmed, I didn't tell any of them anything about my life now, so some people still thought they knew me. When I saw Alan Wise, it was so weird because he had his hands all over me, but then he surprised me with the degree of tenderness and thoughtfulness he got over on film. It was nice because this was a man I cried after I shagged because I couldn't believe I'd done it and then he turned out to be all right, really."

Morley left Manchester abruptly; in the narrative of the film, her departure is precipitated by an impressionistic sequence of what could be interpreted as a rape scene. She left it ambiguous because she didn't feel the need to be explicit: "It wasn't a rape scene, but that happened somewhere else, by someone I knew. That night was more to do with losing control, drinking too much and starting to become really paranoid."

So is it a cautionary tale? "I think there are consequences to actions, but I also think that attempts to control promiscuous women are often expressed as concern for their wellbeing. You get pushed inside by fear and made to disappear. Going to the edge and doing anything is an adventure, and I don't regret it."

The Alcohol Years is showing at BFI regional cinemas, details at www.bfi.org.uk

fields.headline: A world apart
fields.standfirst: The Wooster Group is one of the few companies to merit the term 'legendary'. It has changed our notions of theatre - and produced stars such as Willem Dafoe in the process. On the eve of a rare visit to Britain,  Elisabeth Mahoney  caught up with the troupe
fields.trailText: The Wooster Group is one of the few companies to merit the term 'legendary'. It has changed our notions of theatre - and produced stars such as Willem Dafoe in the process.
fields.body:
In Bergen, on Norway's craggy west coast, it rains so much that an umbrella comes as standard in swankier hotel rooms. This moist way of life does not dampen spirits in the place - far from it. But it does mean that even in the height of summer, when other parts of the country are basking in sunshine almost round the clock, Bergen can be masked by drizzle. And in Norway's famously lights-out winter, Bergen can be wild and wet and dark, almost round the clock

No surprise, then, that in this context House/Lights, the latest project from New York performance troupe the Wooster Group, was received in an unusual fashion at this year's Bergen international festival. If it can be said to be about anything, House/Lights is about Faust making a pact with the Devil so that he can invent electricity. In Paris they howled with laughter, apparently; in Glasgow, I'll wager, there will be some rolling in the aisles. In Bergen, its last stop on tour before the UK, they loved it, but it got a rather sombre reception all the same. "People here," says Roy Faudree, one of the Woosters in the show, "have said to us, yes, life is different if you lose the boundary between day and night, and it hardly ever gets dark, or light."

Life - theatrical life, at least - is also different in the Woosters, the ensemble of artists who, for more than 20 years, have worked on productions stretching every received notion of theatre. The only pattern in the radical yet accessible history of work under the direction of co-founder Elizabeth LeCompte is the group's restaging of classic texts incorporating found materials, films and videos, dance and music.

Eugene O'Neill has had the Wooster treatment, as has Chekhov's The Three Sisters (in Brace Up!, the last Wooster production seen in the UK, at Tramway in 1992). Their next project is a stage version of Racine's Phèdre (their radio version - a work in progress of sorts - can be heard on Sunday on Radio 3). Now, though, it's the turn of Gertrude Stein's 1939 opera-libretto Doctor Faustus Lights the Lights, a tricksy number even by Stein's impenetrable standards. "Someone heard that the Wooster Group was doing Stein," laughs Faudree, "and they said, 'They deconstruct texts - Stein is already deconstructed. What are they gonna do, put it back together again?' "

For a long time, LeCompte admits, the group did not exactly know what they were going to do with Stein's highly literary, highly abstract text in which she throws out conventional syntax, grammar, character and plot. After a year of musing and almost giving up on it, a friend showed LeCompte a film, Olga's House of Shame, a Joseph Mawra cult B-movie from 1964 available only, appropriately enough, from an outfit called Something Weird Video. The film has an excitable plot featuring female dominance, submission, and soft-core seduction. If that weren't enough, the plot then meets, apart from Stein, Mel Brooks's Young Frankenstein, Senor Wences (a Spanish ventriloquist who appeared on US television in the 50s), I Love Lucy and just about every big musical, police shoot-out, car chase and slapstick moment from American popular culture you can think of. Weren't they satisfied with just the Stein?

"The Mawra was the under- pinning for the whole thing. I don't think I would have done the Stein without it," explains LeCompte, reminding us that she comes to the classics via mass media and not the other way around. "I like the Mawra with Stein, it's almost a joke on her - she who eschewed any linear story. We've put a linear story right through it; we start at the beginning and tell it to the end. The only way I could do that was to do what she does in her writing and that's to bring in what's happening at the moment and repeat it until it infects and subverts everything else."

LeCompte's grounding in mass culture and sub- culture is just one of the reasons she can open up these classic texts for new audiences. That, and her steely intellect and great sense of humour - clearly a huge shaping force in the work to date. The third Wooster I speak to is Kate Valk, a co-founder of the group, along with the likes of Spalding Gray and Willem Dafoe. Her two characters in House/Lights are Faustus and Elaine (the ones tempted by power and ill-gotten gain in both narratives). She is very much the centre of the show, reciting Stein's unwieldy lines in an Eleanor Roosevelt voice, in a set that resembles a drug-fuelled video concept for the the craziest Tom Waits song imaginable. How does she hold it all together, with all the sound and fury around her - the barking dog, the six TV screens, the talking viper, the sounds from a Powerbook keyboard pinging through the action, let alone a very kinky sub-text?

For Valk, who also directs and stars in the radio version of Phèdre, it's all about the simple, almost miraculous parallels between the two main texts, somehow uncovered by LeCompte. "There are so many connections - in the film, the voiceover actually says 'to make her mad is to invoke the Devil itself' - and they get beyond the problem we were first faced with: how to do the Stein? It has got all the baggage of being important and the Mawra has that of being not important enough. And have you ever seen productions of Stein? Formal black dress, abstract movements, carefully spoken words. We had to have a world to place that in, our world." The Wooster world and ours, too. As the Devil might say, do what you have to for a ticket.

House/Lights is at Tramway, Glasgow, June 7-10. Box office: 0141 287 3900. Racine's Phèdre is broadcast on Radio 3 at 7.30pm on June 11. For information about The Wooster Group, see www.thewoostergroup.org. The Bergen international festival runs annually in May and June. Details: www.fib.no.

fields.headline: A form of madness
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: The age of dissent: Here is another fabulous advantage of growing old. One can leave the teaching profession, as I have done.
fields.body:
Here is another fabulous advantage of growing old. One can leave the teaching profession, as I have done. My friends Fielding, Olga and Jacqueline are all still stuck in it and fairly desperate to get out. Last weekend, Jacqueline came to visit. She brought her seven-page Threshold Assessment Form with her, because it was written in the usual crapola education jargon and takes hours of study before anyone can understand the questions and several more days to write the answers in matching mumbo-jumbo, and she had to hand it in by today.

"Please summarise evidence that you consistently and effectively use information about prior attainment to set well-grounded expectations for pupils and monitor progress to give clear and constructive feedback," said the form. We were flummoxed by this. You grasp one end of a sentence and the other end wiggles away like an octopus's legs.

But if Jacqueline could fill in her form properly and if Headmaster writes her a glowing assessment and if the external examiner (paid up to £375 a day) agrees, then she could earn £2,000 more per year. Is it worth the bother? Anyway, she hasn't the time, what with her class of 36 juniors, 36 detailed end-of-year reports to write, plus the usual daily, weekly and long-term lesson plans. An obsessive monomaniac with no social life might have better luck.

I rang Fielding for a Threshold Form translation. He was also in a defiant mood. He's being bullied to fill in his form but won't, even though he could. "After 25 years' teaching," said he drearily, "I'm very adept at translating bollocks." This wretched business of Performance Related Pay has sent his staffroom to hell and back: colleagues are close to tears and depression, squabbling and even pretending they haven't sent the form in when they have. And all for nothing. Government could have done without the forms, explanatory booklets, teachers' time, assessors' wages, and just paid every teacher £2,000.

Meanwhile Olga, at art school, is in a permanent boiling rage, Fielding, at his comprehensive, is in turmoil, Jacqueline, at primary school, is worn to a frazzle and her local Labour Party has shrunk by 80%. It used to be full of teachers.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Nearly 2,000 soldiers - one in every 48 - went absent without leave last year but only a minority were deserters, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday. However, the high levels have also been attributed to bullying, mistreatment, or lack of sympathy for requests for compassionate leave.
fields.body:
2,000 solidiers go missing

Nearly 2,000 soldiers - one in every 48 - went absent without leave last year but only a minority were deserters, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday. However, the high levels have also been attributed to bullying, mistreatment, or lack of sympathy for requests for compassionate leave.
Richard Norton-Taylor

Job hopes for deaf worsen

Job discrimination against deaf people has got worse despite legislation, the Royal National Institute for Deaf People says today. People with no or limited hearing are two and a half times as likely as others to be unemployed, against twice as likely before the Disability Discrimination Act.
David Brindle

Laptop thief missed out

A thief who stole a laptop computer from the home of the armed forces minister John Spellar missed two red boxes containing potentially sensitive information, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday. The computer, stolen in March from his home in Bromley, Kent, held only information about his Warley constituency.

Bridge blast taxis traced

Two taxis seen near Hammersmith Bridge, west London, shortly before the bomb blast in the early hours of Thursday have been traced, Scotland Yard said last night.

Murder trial for nail bomber

A nail bomber is due to go on trial at the Old Bailey today accused of murdering three people in a pub blast in Soho, central London, last year after his plea of guilty of manslaughter, on the grounds of diminished responsibility, was rejected by the prosecution. David Copeland, 23, an engineer from Farnborough, Hampshire, has also admitted causing explosions in Brixton and Brick Lane, London.

Man drowns as girl is saved

A father of one died while trying to rescue an 11-year-old girl in the sea at Dovercourt, Essex. David Brett, 42, of Little Oakley got into difficulty in 8ft water as the girl was being plucked to safety by two women.

Two share £7m

Two tickets shared the £7.2m lottery jackpot with numbers 3, 8, 19, 35, 36 and 48. The bonus ball was 21. There were two winners of the £250,000 Thunderball draw with numbers 7, 10, 18, 29 and 34. The Thunderball was 10.

fields.headline: The man with two brains
fields.standfirst: Four years ago David Willets was forced to resign as paymaster general in a cloud of sleaze. Now shadow welfare spokesman, he has reinvented himself as a family man, and he's the brightest spark in the Conservative party
fields.trailText: Four years ago David Willets was forced to resign as paymaster general in a cloud of sleaze. Now shadow welfare spokesman, he has reinvented himself as a family man, and he's the brightest spark in the Conservative party
fields.body:
Pandemonium in the kitchen of David Willetts, Conservative politician and family man. Children in pyjamas and catapults at large. Cries of "Ker-cha" as pellets whizz off in the direction of the guinea pigs in the garden. Bottles of Bud falling out of the fridge ("I'll just pop open another two, shall I?"), cheese and onion crisps tumbling from a cupboard. Then an unidentified crash.

"What's that, my love?" calls Willetts. His wife Sarah, an artist, emerges from behind a canvas. She's barefoot. "Just me, knocking over the Pokémon Gameboy," she says cheerfully. She's holding a rabbit which is chewing something. "Aha!" says Willetts. "Cottontail!" "I've got a new way of holding him," she says, swivelling round to show us, "so he can look out." For a moment we all look at Cottontail looking out at us. The Willetts family may not have a newborn baby at hand, Blair-style, but at least they have a rabbit.

Willetts is the Conservative party's current great hope. As shadow welfare spokesman he has been behind, or to be more precise, in front of, the new Tory pension plans (among other things, restoring war widows' pensions to women who remarry), and the dismantling of Labour's New Deal. Six months ago, he says, no one would report a word he said: "When you whinged, they said, 'Come up with something then.' And if you came up with something, they said, 'We're not interested, you'll never be in power anyway.'"

But now - with a tightening in the opinion polls - not a week goes by without "what I regard as a meaty statement" on this single parent or that social policy. He is, in his own words, "on a bit of a roll". Last week, his office even issued a press release containing excerpts "from a letter to his constituency chairman". Actually, he confesses, it wasn't even a letter. It was just a joke. "I went into Central Office and I said, 'God, all these recycled Labour initiatives, it's like Groundhog Day.' And they said, 'You've got to get that out. We'll send that out: Brown's Groundhog Day.'" He gets quite excited remembering his own joke. He laughs a lot. His voice goes high and cracks. "It is, isn't it? All these repeats. Over and over again. It is. It is."

More vitally, in a party that is rather low right now on small infants and soft animals, Willetts, 44, MP for Havant, is the closest thing to a photo opportunity. Banish all memory of "two brains", of his nerdy days in the Treasury or the Downing Street Policy Unit, or the Thatcherite director of the Centre of Policy Studies. Erase from your mind his clever-dick dissembling in the Cash for Questions enquiry. Ignore references to him as "the most intelligent man in the Tory party". Think touching domestic detail. Think fridge magnets. (Though, actually, his fridge magnets are those black and white words that generally turn into rude poems.)

We're sitting in his west London garden as the sun goes down over the fruit trees and Willetts is smiley and chatty and for lots of the time, as the light catches his glasses, and the rabbit nibbles his ankles, he looks less like the son of Douglas Hurd and Michael Howard, and more like the tax inspector in The Darling Buds of May who's wandered into a different world and grown to like it.

When he was a minister, he said, he neglected the family, hardly saw his own kids (Imogen, 12 , Matthew, eight) in the week at all. Now, he always gets them up and takes Imogen to school "which is worth a hell of a lot". He says this is where the Tories went wrong at the last election. "People thought we either didn't grapple with school runs, or we didn't care about them. We were trapped with economics - like the Oscar Wilde quote, we knew the price of everything the value of nothing." It wasn't the election that drove that home, but the death of Princess Diana.

"I used to think there was this thing called Public Policy and Public Man and Woman, and that you turned up at the Commons and you donned your toga and you were a Roman senator and whatever your family life, or your personal background, you set that aside. And rightly or wrongly, that is disappearing. Nowadays, in order to engage you can't say, 'Here I am, a guy in a suit who has a view about a better social security system' without people wanting to know where you're coming from. If you are to be an effective opposition you can't just sit in a thinktank having bright ideas, you have to communicate them, you have to reach people at the level of emotion. Princess Di's death was the most vivid encapsulation of that."

He uses his new pension plans as an example of how he has learnt to tap into how people think. Critics of the new proposals might say he's just rearranging the same money into different parcels. Exactly, he says. "Even if there wasn't even an extra penny - and it so happens there is from the New Deal, for example - it would still be the right thing to do. The economists might think that the contributory factor, how the money is broken down, is mumbo jumbo, irrelevant - stop eating the flowers Cottontail! But in terms of psychology for pensioners it does matter. The guaranteed weekly pension is an entitlement, what's owing to them; special schemes for heating or TV licences is a Gordon Brown handout. For pensioners it's a big difference. Labour failed to value that. Shall we let Cottontail have a crisp? No, no Cottontail, not the flowers, a crisp. No!"

He's learned some lessons of a more personal nature, too. He's learnt, he says, not to be as ambitious as he was. "I've seen enough marriages break up . . . there is real life to be got on with. Though, obviously," he adds quickly, "I am ambitious to be social security secretary of this country." He's learnt to smile at opprobrium, the Tory infliction. "In 97, we felt like we were a bleeding corpse in the gutter," he says with a big grin, "but they just wanted to give you a final kick to check you were inert." He giggles. He's become a dab hand at the political insult.

Did he admire Blair's response to Diana's death? "At the time, yes," he says. "I think Blair is too saccharine and syrupy but early on and in small doses, like all very sweet things, it went down very nicely." In general, he finds Labour "a strange mixture of the complacent and the nervy. They remind me of one of those sea creatures which if you get too close suddenly retract or change shape."

He has also become adept at his own political defence. A common charge laid at his door is that he's a fly-by-night, the economics-driven Thatcherite who transmogrified smoothly into the softer Majorite. "Aha!" he says. "My politics did change but that was when I had Imogen and Matthew. As I was just saying to my good friend Danny Finkelstein, my definition of a Conservative is a free-marketeer with children." And, anyway, he adds, Thatcher had a wider context, too, religion "which in our increasingly secular society had no purchase in political debate and just seemed eccentric".

And then there's the arrogance. And the whole sleaze parade. In 1996, during questioning by the Standards and Privileges Committee, Willetts tried to explain away a memo he had written as a junior whip regarding Neil Hamilton by playing with definitions of the word "want" (in the phrase "he wants advice"). The committee found him guilty of "dissembling"; others of being too clever by half.

"Too clever by half," he says in his garden, four years on. "The big Tory criticism. I probably did try to argue my way out. It was chastening. Until then I thought you could argue your way round anything. It was the right thing to resign straight away [he was paymaster general] and it did bring me down to earth with a bump. As a political event it was dreadful. But personally it was marvellous. Sarah was still here and my friends were supportive. We tried to protect the children, though I discovered Imogen did see the cover of the Mirror with me pictured as some ogre. Still, the ups and downs of politics."

It was a bit more than that, though, wasn't it? You did all behave very badly? There's a long silence. A dog barks next door. The guinea pigs squeak. "Were there misdemeanours? Were there mistakes? Were there personal failings? Yes. Was there a widespread perception that we were sleazy? Yes. But nothing on the scale of Ecclestone paying his million pounds and as a result getting his meeting with Tony Blair which enabled policy on advertising on Formula One to change . . ."

For a moment, he forgets to look repentant. "It all started with Back to Basics. After that people thought that any Tory MP who wasn't happily married was a hypocrite. But I would say the family is far too important to be left to saints. It should be possible to say, 'I am a fallen man. I've had my share of failings. But this is what I believe in.'"

It's getting a bit cold and the rabbit has given up eating the pansies so we go inside where a piano practice has just finished and pans are boiling on the stove. Matthew, still busy with his complicated catapult, tells me how to make a simpler one with a pencil and an elastic band. "It's very useful in French lessons," he says. "Because French is very boring." Willetts, who had his hand on his wife's shoulder, laughs fondly, strokes his son's back.

"You seem to rather like opposition," I say. He says, straightening up, "It's different. You have to adjust. But I think that . . . yes, in terms of political ideas and everything, I find it quite satisfying."

fields.headline: Fan-tastic!
fields.standfirst: The countdown to Euro 2000 has begun and it isn't just the lads who are looking forward to it.  Emma Lindsey charts the rise of female supporters
fields.trailText: The countdown to Euro 2000 has begun and it isn't just the lads who are looking forward to it.  Emma Lindsey charts the rise of female supporters
fields.body:
Football, said Welsh international Trevor Ford in 1957, "is not a woman's game, it's not a pastime for milksops or sissies, it's a man's game". The days of that sort of thinking are dead and buried. As the start of Euro 2000 looms, remember this: you don't have to walk as if you've got a marrow stuffed down your pants to like watching football. The game has left its tribal cave for good.

The fact is, more women than ever are going to football matches. In a survey of 22,000 fans conducted last season by the Premier League, it was revealed that 14% of all those watching matches in England's top division were women. Not only that but Derby County, Leicester City and Nottingham Forest all have large numbers of female season ticket holders, and Leeds United sell almost 50% of their season tickets to women.

The shift began when football stadiums and facilities were overhauled in the wake of the Hillsborough tragedy, making going to a match less like a white knuckle ride and more of a good day out. The formation of the Premier League gentrified the game, television rights were sold, a massive publicity drive was launched, players discovered the benefits of Clinique and Clarins, and had no qualms about saying so, and football became a new toy. Nick Hornby caught the zeitgeist by writing Fever Pitch and the nouveau fan - lover of "footie" as opposed to plain old football - was born.

Potential female fans were courted in the run-up to Euro 96 with ad campaigns in women's mags showing people who looked vaguely like us, talking formation instead of foundation. A lot of women bought into the scene big time - but appeared unsure as to whether it was possible to retain female characteristics and enjoy the most popular sport on the planet.

Jeannie Parker, a 34-year-old supply teacher and long-time QPR supporter, admits to having felt uncomfortable at the arrival of these "ladette" new fans. She, after all, can remember as a child going to matches with her father and brother. "Football was always part of the furniture in our house," she says simply. "My dad used to scout for talent in his spare time and me and my brother were always kicking a ball around in the garden."

Like many established female fans, she rather resented the sudden intrusion into cherished territory. "I think a lot of the stigma that became attached to women fans was caused by those who got into the sport just because it seemed like the trendy thing to do. I know loads of women who have grown up around the game and love it but don't make a big fuss about it. I've also got women friends who don't like football."

Catherine Trent does like football. A 36-year-old arts administrator, she discovered its joys six years ago, but admits: "I am less fanatical now than I was then. I may have been the only one of my friends who knew when the first day of Euro 2000 was, but I don't have a season ticket any more and I hardly ever go to matches now. I suppose I would call myself a lapsed Gunner [Arsenal fan]."

These days, Trent is more likely to be watching from her armchair than from the stands, though she confesses that she has a wall chart of match nights pinned up in her newly refurbished kitchen and refers to it when organising her social life. She and her friends will take it in turns to go to each other's houses to watch, bringing a bottle - or several. "Most of my friends have children now or are working flat out running their own businesses," she says, explaining why their attendance at matches has fallen. "We'll watch quality games, then get on the phone afterwards or at half-time to talk about them."

Discussing tactics and the merits or otherwise of particular players has brought men and women closer, at last talking a language both can understand. But while most men have grown up absorbing football-speak, women have had to go out of their way to learn it. This could account for the finding, in a recent Guinness survey of 2,000 football supporters, that more women than men know the offside rule.

Trent understands the reasons for this attention to detail. "When I first got into football," she says, "I would start a conversation, then flounder after about two sentences. I felt I needed to prove my credentials when talking to my male friends, otherwise I would look stupid. That worry has faded since then - when I watch football, I want to do it on my own terms. If I don't know the proper football terms to describe something, that won't stop me voicing my opinion."

fields.headline: Snatched from jaws of death
fields.standfirst: Last return to Dunkirk evokes indelible memories
fields.trailText: Last return to Dunkirk evokes indelible memories
fields.body:
It was, they said, rather different last time round. As they clambered gingerly aboard the same little ships that had carried them to safety 60 years ago, a few of the sprightlier Dunkirk veterans could not stop themselves stealing a quick glance up at the pale blue sky.

"That's where the nasty stuff, the Stukas, came from," said Dennis Kinnell, 81, who spent two days on the beaches outside the French channel port before finally being ferried out to the destroyer HMS Anthony in a fragile 26ft wooden motor yacht called Firefly.

Sitting in the Firefly's stern yesterday for the first time since the early morning of May 31 1940, Mr Kinnell said the last time he had set eyes on that squat, white-painted hull, he had never been happier to see anything in his life.

"I'll never forget the chap at the wheel," he said. "I didn't ask him his name at the time, because things were a little frantic, but I found out later he was a Commander Bowen. We were only on this little boat for about 20 minutes, but he was very good to us. Very, very good."

Driven into a small pocket around Dunkirk by the rapid advance of the German army in early May 1940, Mr Kinnell was one of nearly 340,000 allied soldiers plucked from the port's piers and beaches under heavy enemy fire.

The operation involved, as well as some 80 Royal Navy vessels, a 370-strong armada of yachts, fishing smacks, launches, barges, and even houseboats.

Some 75 of the little ships were back in the French channel port yesterday, participating with nearly 800 veterans in the last official commemoration of the evacuation. Their number now dwindling rapidly, the increasingly frail old soldiers have decided to disband their association later this year.

The Prince of Wales took the salute at the veterans' final march past, and laid a wreath at the town's war memorial.

In a brief speech to the old soldiers, many in wheelchairs, he described the evacuation, codenamed Operation Dynamo, as "a monument to improvisation" that had allowed the British army to withdraw, rebuild and fight again.

"Without the fierce fighting that took place around Dunkirk, without the sacrifices made by those who never returned home, the D-Day landings in Normandy might never have been possible at all," he said.

"I salute you, and everything you stand for."

Later, veterans mingled with small children in swimming costumes at a memorial service on the promenade, and as the little ships circled just offshore, a Lancaster bomber, a Spitfire and a Hurricane flew overhead. A planned poppy drop, however, failed to take place.

Prince Charles went on to Ranville in Normandy to inaugurate a new museum and memorial at Pegasus Bridge, which was captured in the early hours of June 6 1944, as the first target of the 6th Airborne Division's D-Day cam paign. He laid a wreath to mark the fall of the first British fatality of D-Day.
