fields.headline: The people v Monsanto
fields.standfirst: For decades the GM food giant brought much-needed jobs to the people of Anniston, Alabama. Now more than 3,000 residents believe they have been poisoned by the company - and are determined to prove it in court.  Nancy Beiles  reports from a town where the river ran red
fields.trailText: For decades the GM food giant brought much-needed jobs to the people of Anniston, Alabama. Now more than 3,000 residents believe they have been poisoned by the company - and are determined to prove it in court.
fields.body:
Problem: Damage to the ecological system by contamination from polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB). Legal liability: Direct lawsuits are possible. The materials are already present in nature having done their "alleged damage". All customers using the products have not been officially notified about known effects nor [do] our labels carry this information.
Memo from Monsanto committee studying PCBs, 1969

In a small brick house strung year-round with Christmas lights, behind curtains made of flowered sheets, Jeremiah Smith is listening to his favourite preacher on the radio. As tonight's instalment of the gospels winds down, he takes a seat at a table draped with a zebra-print cloth and drifts back 30 years, to the brief period when he was a pig farmer. Like others in Anniston, Alabama, Smith used to raise vegetables and livestock in his yard to provide additional food for his family.

"We were poor people," he says, in a thick drawl. "We had to raise food ourselves . . . We were trying to survive and live." Smith also had a cow and rabbits, but most of his time and attention went to his pigs. In 1970 he had about 50 - too many for his small plot of land, so he led them past the labyrinth of pipes and smokestacks that surrounded the Monsanto chemical plant his father helped build, to a grassy hill where they could graze. Each evening, Smith would give them some feed and, when the need arose, he would bring home some bacon.

One night, as he was feeding the pigs, a man from the Monsanto plant drove up the hill and made him an offer: $10 apiece for the pigs and a bottle of whisky. Smith had begun to notice that something was wrong with some of his pigs anyway; their mouths had turned green. And, ever in need of cash, he could hardly afford to pass up $500. He sold. But for more than 20 years, he wondered what on earth a chemical company would want with his pigs.

Many people Jeremiah Smith's age are old enough to remember Monsanto's glory days in Anniston. The company provided well-paid jobs and helped nurture this friendly southern town's sense of community. Most never thought to connect the chemical industry to some of the odder features of life there. Like the creek, known locally as "the ditch", which passed through town carrying water that ran red some days, purple on others and occasionally emitted a foggy white steam.

But over time, the residents of Anniston came to believe that they had been poisoned for decades by Monsanto. The change in attitude was spurred by what at first seemed a straightforward real estate transaction. In December 1995, Donald Stewart, a former state legislator who served briefly in the US Senate, received a phone call from Andrew Bowie. A deacon at the Mars Hill Missionary Baptist church, Bowie explained that a Monsanto manager had approached him about buying the church. "It doesn't seem like we're going to achieve a satisfactory deal," Bowie told Stewart. "I think we need a lawyer."

"I thought it was a simple case," Stewart says. "It just mushroomed."

Stewart soon learned that Monsanto wanted to buy the church because it had discovered high concentrations of PCBs in the area and was planning a clean-up.

Before production was restricted in the US, PCBs were used as insulating material in various types of electrical appliances, including television sets. They are non-flammable and take the form of either oily liquids or solids.

After an open meeting at the church, Stewart began fielding a flood of calls from concerned residents, who had a dizzying array of health problems which they now attribute to the contamination. The neighbourhood around the plant is populated by people with cancer, young women with damaged ovaries, children who are learning-impaired and people whose ailments have been diagnosed as acute toxic syndrome. The question is, are these illnesses caused by exposure to PCBs? Medical studies have shown that PCBs may cause liver problems, skin rashes and developmental and reproductive disorders in humans, and the US department of health and human services has determined that PCBs "may reasonably be anticipated to be carcinogens".

In addition to the church, which filed its own suit against Monsanto, more than 3,000 Anniston residents who have high levels of PCBs in their blood and on their property have filed suits against the company since 1996, alleging that the company knew it was introducing PCBs into the environment, knew the hazards of doing so, failed to inform the community and tried to conceal what it had done. Monsanto denies the allegations.

Karen McFarlane lives in plain view of the plant. It's a mild morning in February and she didn't sleep much last night. Clothed only in a T-shirt and underwear, with a sweater draped over her lap, she lights her first cigarette of the morning and promptly drops it on the shaggy blue rug. Dakota, McFarlane's 16-month-old, is playing with the severed head of a Barbie knock-off and there's not much to eat in the house. But Karen has other worries: she has PCBs in her body fat.

According to tests done by a local doctor, her husband Ryan's blood has nearly triple the level considered "typical" in the US; for Tiffany, their six-year-old, it's double. Nathan, eight, has severe developmental problems, and everyone in the family suffers from respiratory problems and the skin rashes associated with PCB exposure. Chris, McFarlane's 11-year-old son, lifts his T-shirt to reveal brownish-red blotches climbing up the sides of his chest. "It smells like decaying flesh," Ryan warns. "Like it's rotten."

Most of their friends and family have already left, but the McFarlanes can't afford to. Karen was recently hospitalised for respiratory-stress disorder and had two strokes at the age of 30. Ryan, who has small pink growths dotting his neck, wistfully talks of going to an oncologist for a full cancer screening, something he's unlikely to get soon because he does not have health insurance. The McFarlanes are stuck in a place where, according to the Alabama department of public health, cancer rates are 25% higher than in the rest of the state. Whether these health problems are linked to Monsanto's PCBs is at the heart of the case.

While it concedes that much of Anniston is contaminated by PCBs, Monsanto says its chemical discharges were negligible - and maintains that it did not fully understand how PCBs affected the environment at the time they were released, in the 60s and 70s. The US government didn't restrict the manufacture of PCBs until 1979.

"As soon as we discovered there were PCB discharges from the plant, we began our operations to limit and hopefully eliminate those discharges," says Bob Kaley, director of environmental affairs for Monsanto's chemical division. "At the time, there were no federal regulations with regard to PCBs . . . Everything was done voluntarily, and there was really almost no understanding of the effect of PCBs on the environment and human health. I think as we've moved forward in the past 30 years, there are potentially some effects at high levels in the environment. But we do not believe even today that there are concerns for human health at those environmental levels."

The Anniston case stands out in the annals of PCB litigation in the extent of damage to property and people it alleges. It is also among the first brought by ordinary citizens rather than corporations. The black binders the plaintiffs' lawyers have filled with internal memorandums and reports are branded "Hot Documents" and "Hottest Documents" with yellow Post-it notes. Many have never been seen by the public but they will become public record when the trial begins and could make or break Monsanto's defence.

The chemical producers arrived in Anniston during the first world war, and in 1929, the Theodore Swann Company became the nation's first maker of PCBs. By 1935 Monsanto recognised PCBs as big business and bought Swann's Anniston facility.

In the 60s, a team of Swedish researchers discovered that PCBs were present in the environment. Each time the chemical prevented an electrical wire from overheating, some of it had been escaping.

At the time, the government had not yet declared PCBs to be hazardous to human health, but suspicions had been growing for quite a while. In 1956 Monsanto considered the chemicals toxic enough to give workers protective gear and clothing. Along with other chemical manufacturers, the company publicly expressed scepticism about PCBs' association with disease, but over the next decade the evidence became harder to ignore. Studies published in leading medical journals showed that PCBs may damage the immune system, the reproductive system and the nervous and endocrine systems.

Monsanto had hundreds of millions of dollars in PCB sales to lose if regulators placed restrictions on use. By 1969 the company established a committee to keep abreast of the state of knowledge on PCBs. The issue was beginning to look like "a monster", in the words of one former executive.

"The Dept of Interior and/or state authorities could monitor plant outfall and find [discharges] of chlorinated biphenyls at . . . Anniston anytime they choose. This would shut us down depending on what plants or animals they choose to find harmed."
Monsanto researcher, 1969

At issue in the Anniston lawsuit is whether the company was aware of the extent and harmful effects of the PCB contamination and whether it could have protected or warned the community. Many of the answers may be found in the documents. According to a 1970 report, Monsanto was dumping about 7.2kg (16lb) a day of PCB waste into the town's waterways. The year before, the company had been dumping about 113kg (250lbs) a day.

Monsanto began commissioning animal toxicity studies in the early 70s; the results did not look good. "Our interpretation is that the PCBs are exhibiting a greater degree of toxicity in this study than we had anticipated," an executive wrote.

In 1975 the lab submitted its findings from a study using rats. An early draft said that in some cases, PCBs had caused tumours. George Levinskas, a Monsanto manager, wrote to the lab's director: "May we request that the report be amended to say 'does not appear to be carcinogenic'." The final report dropped all references to tumours.

Anniston residents got their first glimpse of Monsanto's troubles with PCBs in late 1993. A contractor dredging on the nearby Choccolocco creek noticed largemouth bass with blistered scales. Tests showed the fish contained extremely high levels of PCBs. Around the same time, the Alabama Power company broke ground on land it had acquired from Monsanto in the 60s, opening up a PCB landfill that bled black tar. Alabama Power insisted that Monsanto take back the land and reported its discovery to the Alabama department of environmental management. Soon after, the company made its quiet buyout offer to the church.

But Adam Peck, one of Monsanto's lawyers, isn't sweating. The company, which spun off its chemical division as a stand-alone firm, Solutia, in 1997, assigned an environmental manager to lead a $30m clean-up operation. They bulldozed buildings, laid thick plastic tarpaulins over the contaminated land and covered them with clean soil. The company plans to convert some of the contaminated land into a wildlife refuge. It has built perching posts near the landfill to attract purple martins. In Peck's mind, these activities demonstrate convincingly that the corporation has behaved responsibly. "We have offered to acquire property. We've offered to clean property. What does that mean? Does that mean we acted responsibly or that we should have done more?" After a pause, he adds: "I'm not sure what more we could have done."

Residents are anxiously awaiting the EPA's decision on whether to order a federal clean-up. The lawsuit is also taking longer than residents anticipated. Two weeks before the case was to go to trial, in March 1999, Monsanto appealed to the state supreme court to establish procedural rules for the circuit court. The court still hasn't returned its rulings.

In the meantime, Stewart prepares for trial and works on other cases. He's hoping the jury will award compensatory damages for the property contamination and punitive damages for the fear the exposure has engendered. He also wants Monsanto to pay for regular health screenings.

Early settlement talks went nowhere, both sides say. Monsanto did settle the original suit on behalf of the Mars Hill congregation. It made no admission of guilt but paid $2.5m (£1.5m) to rebuild the church at another location. "In the Mars Hill case they protested all the time that they didn't do a thing," Stewart says. "Then they paid $2.5m for a church they said was worth $400,000. I wonder how they arrived at that decision."

After he sold them, Jeremiah Smith's pigs were shot and buried. Why? Because, Monsanto says, it was concerned about them trespassing on company property.

fields.headline: No: 1649 David Prowse
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
I sense something. A presence I've not felt since . . . 1984?

How did you know? That was the last time the 65-year-old Prowse made a film: Return of the Jedi.

I have you now: it's Darth Vader! Prowse played the Empire's asthmatic bootboy in the original three Star Wars films.

He doesn't look like Darth Vader. Prowse has been peeved these 20 years that both his face - when Vader was unmasked - and his voice were replaced by those of other actors.

Peeved? Of the distinguished thespian James Earl Jones, who supplied Vader's voice, Prowse will concede only that "he is very famous for phone commercials".

So what else is Prowse famous for? He was Britain's Strongest Man between 1965 and 1970, and once shredded phone books under the stage-name Jack the Ripper. Prowse is so hard he even trained Christopher Reeve to be Superman.

The Force is strong in this one. Royalty agrees - Prowse is to be garlanded by the Queen tomorrow.

For services to acting? I don't think his performance in Frankenstein and the Monsters from Hell would justify it.

I find your lack of faith disturbing. Quit the quotes - or I'll force you to watch The Phantom Menace.

Anything but that . . . No, Prowse is being MBE'd for services to charity and road safety - he was the Green Cross Code Man in the 70s, and now runs the charity David Prowse Forces Against Arthritis.

Your powers are weak, old man . . . Stop it!

Wait. MBE? That "E" stands for . . . Empire! As in Strikes Back!

It's all coming true! Help! Reach for your light sabres!

Most likely to say to the Queen: With our combined strength, ma'am, we can end this conflict and bring order to the galaxy.

Least likely to say to the Queen: Don't thank me for the charity work - James Earl Jones is the real talent behind it.

Not to be confused with: Darth Maul, Geoff Capes, the Tufty Club.

Prowse has been peeved these 20 years that both his face - when Vader was unmasked - and his voice were replaced by those of other actors. Peeved? Of the distinguished thespian James Earl Jones, who supplied Vader's voice, Prowse will concede only that "he is very famous for phone commercials". So what else is Prowse famous for? He was Britain's Strongest Man between 1965 and 1970, and once shredded phone books under the stage-name Jack the Ripper. Prowse is so hard he even trained Christopher Reeve to be Superman. The Force is strong in this one. Royalty agrees - Prowse is to be garlanded by the Queen tomorrow. For services to acting? I don't think his performance in Frankenstein and the Monsters from Hell would justify it. I find your lack of faith disturbing. Quit the quotes - or I'll force you to watch The Phantom Menace. Anything but that . . . No, Prowse is being MBE'd for services to charity and road safety - he was the Green Cross Code Man in the 70s, and now runs the charity David Prowse Forces Against Arthritis. Your powers are weak, old man . . . Stop it! Wait. MBE? That "E" stands for . . . Empire! As in Strikes Back! It's all coming true! Help! Reach for your light sabres! webTitle: Naked truth gets clothed in rancour

fields.headline: Naked truth gets clothed in rancour
fields.trailText: Shakespeare has King Lear strip while a storm rages to show that, monarch, madman or fool, man is ultimately just a "poor, bare, forked animal".
fields.body:
Shakespeare has King Lear strip while a storm rages to show that, monarch, madman or fool, man is ultimately just a "poor, bare, forked animal".

As Edward Pope, 52, bobbed up and down strumming his mandolin, the Sussex constabulary took a more strictly legalistic view of his nudity.

"There are young people about," a middle-aged constable told the small band of naked men outside Brighton Pavilion. "I cannot allow you to expose yourself. This is a public place - there are people around."

The protesters, gathered by the seaside on World Naturist Day to highlight the "injustice" of being forced to wear clothes all the time, compromised with strips of cloth and a strategically placed sandwich-board.

Shepherded by stoical policemen and led by 28-year-old Vincent Bethell, a veteran of naked protests outside the Houses of Parliament and Buckingham Palace, they marched to the seafront to be cheered ironically by afternoon drinkers, giggled at by teenage girls, and barred from going on to the pier.

But if Mr Bethell and his coterie succeed in irking officialdom yesterday, he has long proved himself far more effective as a thorn in the side of the mainstream naturist movement in Britain.

"The first thing to make clear is that I'm not a naturist. The name of our campaign is Freedom to be Yourself, and we are having a protest on World Naturist Day because the label of being a naturist is damaging to what we are trying to do."

Mainstream naturists, by retreating to segregated resorts and camps, had accepted "the repression of the human body", he said.

Mr Bethell, a former fine art student at Coventry University, describes challenging one of society's greatest taboos as a liberating, "almost spiritual" experience.

His criticism of the naturist establishment, represented by the Central Council for British Naturism, is backed by Mark Nesbit, editor of Health and Efficiency magazine, bible of naturism in the UK.

"The leadership is moribund and old-fashioned," said Mr Nesbit. The failure to organise a high profile event for World Naturist Day, leaving Mr Bethell's group to steal the limelight, showed "typical British lack of organisation". He added: "The CCBN will then groan about Vincent getting all the press coverage."

On the one hand, there was the confrontational radicalism of Mr Bethell and his allies. On the other, the "prim and proper cheeriness" of the CCBN.

Membership of the official body was fairly static, Mr Nesbit said, hovering at around 20,000. "Quite a few people join each year, don't see its relevance, and leave. There are a lot of unrecorded naturists, lots of rambling groups - Yorkshire is the county with the most."

Pat Thompson, vice-president of the council, who exudes a cheery and sensible approach to nudism ("For me it has to be nice and warm") is unfazed by the criticism.

"Within any organisation you have always got to have one who goes over the top. There are times when I would dismiss him and times when I have heard him talk quite sensibly.

"I don't want to walk through the middle of town with no clothes on. There is a time and a place for everything," she said. British naturism reckons its membership at 25,000 and says it has grown by 20% in the past five years. The organisation estimates, however, that about half a million people in the UK practise the lifestyle.

Meanwhile, Mr Bethell's campaign to bare all goes on. His next court appearance is on July 14 to appeal against a conviction for indecent exposure in Birmingham last year.

And the next day, New Scotland Yard will be the target for a dose of direct action.

webTitle: Plans to create new golden age of canals

fields.headline: Plans to create new golden age of canals
fields.standfirst:
Trust seeks to exploit British 'love affair' with waterways
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Trust seeks to exploit British 'love affair' with waterways
fields.body:
Plans for two huge canal restoration projects that would link the Thames to the Severn and take tourists into the Lake District are being considered by waterways executives who want to create a new golden age for water transport.

A charity, the Waterways Trust, formed to exploit the growing love affair between Britons and their canals, will get government backing this month. And John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is considering new rules that would force road developers crossing old waterways to leave room for restoration.

Limited editions of reproductions of original drawings by the great canal, bridge and docks designers such as Telford and Brunel, and the transformation of old lock gates as household furniture, are among money-spinning ideas being considered.

British Waterways wants to build on the recent boom, helped by national lottery funds, in reviving both old canals, and the urban centres along their banks. Its board believes it could soon enlist 1m supporters ready to help via direct debit and could raise funds from people all round the world interested in helping to preserve the canals.

Trust leaders are already looking at restoring 37 miles of waterways in the Cotswolds between Lechlade and Stroud in Gloucestershire, which would help to create a huge "tourist loop" including the Thames and Kennet and Avon, and provide continuous waterway from the Thames estuary to Sharpness on the Severn estuary.

Fifteen unnavigable miles of the Lancaster canal between Tewitfield, Lancashire, and Kendal, Cumbria, crossed by the M6 three times and closed up when the motorway was built in 1968, may also be brought back to their former glory.

Up to 10m Britons a year are thought to visit canals to walk, cycle, fish, enjoy the wildlife, and use boats. But there is often tension between leisure boat users, wildlife enthusiasts - who believe restoration to navigable use may damage important habitats - and those who want far more commercial use of the 2,500 miles of waterways for which the board is responsible.

A national water grid, shifting supplies between parts of Britain, and a big increase in the delivery of rubbish to "green" power stations are both on the agenda.

The board is technically only responsible for upkeep and safety and has a huge backlog of repairs.

webTitle: Otters' revival hit by death on roads

fields.headline: Otters' revival hit by death on roads
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Environmentalists have reported a dramatic increase in the number of otters being killed on roads - damaging efforts to boost otter numbers in rivers across England and Wales.
fields.body:
Environmentalists have reported a dramatic increase in the number of otters being killed on roads - damaging efforts to boost otter numbers in rivers across England and Wales.

In the past three months 34 otters were reported to Water UK and the Wildlife Trusts Otters and Rivers Project as having being killed on roads in England and Wales, double the number in the previous three months, and more are being reported each week.

Most of the reports are from Cornwall, Devon, Somerset, parts of Wales, Northumberland and the River Severn catchment.

Over the past 20 years the number of adult male otters killed in road traffic accidents in Wales has increased fivefold, with 40 animals found in 1998 compared with an average of eight between 1980 and 1989.

Eight otters were killed on roads near the River Axe, on the Devon and Somerset border, in the past three months - nearly a fifth of the estimated otter population on the river.

Male otters appear to come off worst in the survey, probably because population expansion forces young adult males to seek new territories. They often see roads as an easier alternative to swimming against strong currents, particularly in flood-swollen rivers.

Female otters are less likely to travel widely and encounter roads, although in Northumberland, where the otter population is high, females are increasingly being killed.

Lisa Schneidau, director of the Water UK and the Wildlife Trusts Otters and Rivers Project, said: "As otters are starting to move back into areas where they have not lived for 30 years, road deaths are a serious threat to their re-establishment. The recent increase in road deaths is alarming."

She called for tunnels and ledges to be included in road schemes, to protect the animals. The Highways Agency has already published guidelines for local authorities.

The Otters and Rivers Project has a network of 24 conservation officers based at Wildlife Trusts in England and Wales, working with the Environment Agency.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Councillor dies in ETA attack
A gunman shot dead a city councillor in Spain's Basque region yesterday in the latest attack blamed on the separatist group ETA, which ended its 14-month ceasefire in December.
fields.body:
Councillor dies in ETA attack

A gunman shot dead a city councillor in Spain's Basque region yesterday in the latest attack blamed on the separatist group ETA, which ended its 14-month ceasefire in December.

Jesus Maria Pedrosa, of the conservative Popular party, was shot in the head in Durango, near Bilbao, officials said.

Anti-capitalists fail to halt talks

North and South American foreign ministers met in a virtual fortress yesterday in Windsor, Ontario, to discuss democracy and human rights, wary of plans for a Seattle-type siege by anti-capitalist protesters.

A loose coalition of anti-free-traders, environmentalists and other activists had pledged to shut down the meeting, which was guarded by around 2,000 police in Windsor and 4,000 across the river in Detroit.

Death toll rises in Kashmir

Three Indian policemen were killed and two wounded yesterday when separatist guerrillas fired at police patrols in Jammu and Srinagar, police said.

Meanwhile, five Indian soldiers and three rebels died in two gun battles in Poonch district, an official said. Elsewhere, police said militants shot dead three civilians, taking the number of people killed since last Friday to at least 39.

Polish leader's remains return

Thousands of Poles attended the reburial of the post-war opposition leader Stanislaw Mikolajczyk yesterday. His remains were returned from the US after a half-century in exile and buried in the western city of Poznan.

fields.headline: Rain hits north
fields.standfirst:
Hundreds of homes evacuated
The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Emergency services were yesterday trying to reach hundreds of homes in the Calder Valley area of West Yorkshire after heavy rain hit many parts of the north of England.
fields.body:
Emergency services were yesterday trying to reach hundreds of homes in the Calder Valley area of West Yorkshire after heavy rain hit many parts of the north of England.

Passengers on the east coast main line rail services between London and Scotland faced delays and driving conditions were described as hazardous on blocked roads.

Figures supplied by the PA WeatherCentre showed heavy falls in the 24 hours to 6am yesterday, including an inch and a half at both Leeming in North Yorkshire and Tynemouth in Tyne & Wear.

Forecasters said the worst had past although some parts of the north could expect heavy down pours over the next 24 hours. The average monthly rainfall for June of two inches had already fallen in some parts.

The worst area was in West Yorkshire. Roads and hundreds of homes in Todmorden, Hebden Bridge and Mytholmroyd were flooded. About 50 homes in Mytholmroyd had to be evacuated and around 100 people spent the night in the town hall and a school.

Senior divisional officer Simon Pilling said: "Mytholmroyd was the first town to be hit, where we had to evacuate around 50 homes. The rain has eased off just now, but the forecast is for more over the next two days.

"The worst of the rain fell between midnight and three o'clock this morning, when the River Calder rose rapidly. The topography of the area means that a lot of water has been running off the steep valley sides."

In County Durham, 200 homes in Bishop Auckland were evacuated after the River Gaunless burst its banks. About 80 residents at a care home and a nursing home were evacuated after water caused a power failure.

About 50 rescuers, including Territorial Army volunteers and fell rescue teams, ferried residents to safety. The Durham fire brigade also reported flooding in Durham city and Chester-le-Street.

Station Officer Alan Wray said: "It's like a battle scene, with the Territorial Army out in boats ferrying people to safety."

Floodwater covered the east coast main line at Croft, near Darlington, in County Durham. Trains ran between London and York and Newcastle and Scotland, but there was no through service.

webTitle: Gene maps pose legal risk to chemical firms

fields.headline: Gene maps pose legal risk to chemical firms
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Advances in genetic technology which allow scientists to tell the precise effects of chemicals on the body mean that the companies that produce them face a bleak future of lawsuits over allergies and toxicity, says a report by Friends of the Earth.
fields.body:
Advances in genetic technology which allow scientists to tell the precise effects of chemicals on the body mean that the companies that produce them face a bleak future of lawsuits over allergies and toxicity, says a report by Friends of the Earth.

With the human genome project near completion, it will be possible to measure the effects of chemicals on the body's immune system and predict whether individual chemicals can cause cancer, birth defects or other genetic effects.

The report, Crisis in Chemicals, said this will leave companies open to legal action. Until recently it was not possible to tell the precise effects of chemicals on humans, and manufacturers have failed to test many of them for potential health effects. But genetic medicine means that effects on susceptible individuals can be measured for the first time.

The government welcomed the report, saying it "highlighted the possible implications of emerging research into the genetic susceptibility of individuals to chemicals". It had made some useful recommendations for new EU legislation on chemicals which the government would "consider carefully."

The report said individuals vary in their ability to break down chemicals, and in how much they respond to the toxicity of chemicals. Much of this variation is genetically determined. Scientists believe that susceptibilities to individual chemicals will be indentified and that people will be able to be screened easily and cheaply to see if they are in a susceptible group.

The report predicts that this will result in industries being hit by legal actions by people who have been exposed to particular chemicals in their workplace, in the products they use, from factory pollution and from pesticides in their food.

People taking legal action are likely to include workers or people living near polluting factories, and those who are most susceptible to chemicals in products - pregnant women and young children.

Michael Warhurst, author of the report said: "In English law the person claiming injury will not have to prove absolutely that the chemical plant he lives next to or the product he is using has caused damage to him, merely that on the balance of probabilities it has."

He added: "Companies that fail to clean up their act will face a heavy bill. So will insurers and investors. The biomedical revolution is now underway. Industry, governments and the financial sector cannot ignore it."

webTitle: Sleeping Beauties stir world of ballet

fields.headline: Sleeping Beauties stir world of ballet
fields.standfirst: Mighty Kirov ranged against English crowd-pleaser
fields.trailText: A battle of the ballets is rocking the genteel world of British dance, with sharp words being traded as two gigantic productions of Sleeping Beauty clash this month.
fields.body:
A battle of the ballets is rocking the genteel world of British dance, with sharp words being traded as two gigantic productions of Sleeping Beauty clash this month.

In one corner is the mighty Kirov. Having survived the post-communist meltdown, the pride of St Petersburg is again staking a claim to being the world's greatest ballet company by lavishly reconstructing its lost masterpiece: the original, legendary 1890 version of Sleeping Beauty that Marius Petipa created to go with Tchaikovsky's score.

With 160 dancers, 550 cos tumes and a 350-piece wig wardrobe, Sleeping Beauty - which opens next Monday at the Royal Opera House - is the backbone of the biggest season of Russian ballet and opera seen in this country since Diaghilev electrified Covent Garden nearly 90 years ago.

Ranged against the Russian hordes - though only barely outnumbered by them - is the English National Ballet, the chippy, unashamedly populist company which, sick of playing second fiddle to the Royal Ballet, developed its own crowd-pleasing style of "stadium ballet".

Having danced its Swan Lake to 11,000 hot dog-munching Australians a night in football and tennis stadiums down under, and having repeated the trick of "ballet in the round" with Romeo and Juliet last year, it is returning to the wide open spaces of the Royal Albert Hall on Thursday with what it claims will be Britain's first £1m ballet. More than 60,000 people are expected to see the production during its 12-night run.

The artistic director, Derek Deane - though swift to blame the clashing Sleeping Beauties on what he calls "another Royal Opera cock-up" - said a showdown with the Kirov held no fear for him: "The Russians are very proud of their old warhorses, but they can be a bit stuffy and old fashioned for the rest of us. Reconstructing the old original is all very well, but they can seem very heavy and dated to today's audiences." Fighting talk indeed.

For added piquancy, there is the presence of the beautiful former Kirov ballerina Anastasia Volochkova as Deane's evil fairy, Carabosse. Volochkova, 24, spent most of last week denying that her relationship with her patron, Anthony Kerman, lawyer and supporter of the English National Ballet, was anything more than professional.

The final spice in the stew is Deane's prickly relationship with Covent Garden, which was not helped when he was passed over for the top job at the Royal Ballet for the Australian Ross Stretton.

"We will have two very different Sleeping Beauties, and I think we have the edge because of the way we use the Albert Hall," Deane argued. "By doing it in the round with so many dancers, our Sleeping Beauty will be cinematic, the audience will feel like they are inside the ballet. We have a more modern, lighter approach.

"After all, it is a pantomime really, a wonderful fairytale to be enjoyed by everyone. That is why I get so angry when people accuse us of cheapening ballet with populism."

While the Kirov prefers not to trade insults, its inference is clear: there can be no contest between the mighty Mariinsky's Russian Imperial Ballet and London's second troupe. The Russians are still the undisputed snobs of the ballet world.

Even though it is ensconced in the rebuilt ROH - and so cannot compete in sheer weight of numbers with the 5,000-capacity Albert Hall - its ticket prices push the ENB and its impresario, Raymond Gubbay, very close, giving the lie to accusations of elitism.

But Faith Wilson, who is promoting the Kirov, would much rather concentrate on the "amazing spectacle" of Petipa's original ballet and the designs for the costumes and choreography which were smuggled to the west in 1917 and ended up in a Harvard archive. fields.headline: Tycoon plans to launch secondTitanic
fields.trailText: Like a movie sequel, the world's most famous ship, the Titanic, could return to the high seas after a South African multi-millionaire unveiled plans to build a new version of the doomed vessel.
fields.body:
Like a movie sequel, the world's most famous ship, the Titanic, could return to the high seas after a South African multi-millionaire unveiled plans to build a new version of the doomed vessel.

Sarel Gous will visit Belfast this week for talks about building a successor to the Titanic, which sank on her maiden voyage in 1912, killing 1,500 people.

Titanic II would be the biggest cruise liner in the world - larger than the original Belfast-built Titanic, and would even dwarf the Queen Mary 2, whose contract the Harland and Wolff shipyard failed to win several weeks ago.

Mr Gous, who has already had talks with the head of the technical department at Harland and Wolff, is due to return on Friday for discussions with Belfast city council.

Harland and Wolff said it regularly received calls from around the world asking about the chances of building a new Titanic, immortalised recently in a Hollywood blockbuster.

The company was satisfied Mr Gous was serious about building the ship, which would now cost more than £500m. He approached the yard's technical services division two years ago and paid for a feasibility study on the commercial viability of reconstructing the Titanic.

While a new Titanic would not be an exact replica, it could have the same external lines and level of luxury, the company said. But under the skin it would be a very modern ship.

A former Lord Mayor of Belfast, assemblyman and Titanic buff Ian Adamson, who had discussions with Mr Gous on his previous visit, does not believe people would be put off by the tragedy. He said: "This is not a pipe dream. The magic of the Titanic name would make this the cruise ship the rich and famous would want to sail on."

webTitle: UK is healthier than the US

fields.headline: UK is healthier than the US
fields.standfirst: Japan heads life expectancy table with Britain 14th
fields.trailText: The British weather might usually be grey and wet, and our diet might leave much to be desired, but life here is officially healthier than life in America.
fields.body:
The British weather might usually be grey and wet, and our diet might leave much to be desired, but life here is officially healthier than life in America.

According to the World Health Organisation, the US ranks a sickly 24th in a global table of healthy life expectancy. Compared with most other advanced countries, you die earlier and are more prone to disability in the land of the free.

The UK is placed an unremarkable 14th in the table, the first such rankings produced by the WHO, although that falls a long way short of the picture of life in Japan - the healthiest country on earth by some margin.

At the other end of the scale, the rankings reflect graphically the ravages of Aids in much of Africa. All 10 lowest rated countries are in sub-Saharan Africa and healthy life expectancy in strife-torn Sierra Leone, at the foot of the table, is put at less than 26 years.

Alan Lopez, co-ordinator of the WHO's epidemiology and burden of disease team, said: "Healthy life expectancy in some African countries is dropping to levels we haven't seen in advanced countries since medieval times."

Previous exercises of this kind have been based purely on death rates. These new rankings, published last night, aim to assess the number of years lived at "full health", with periods of illness weighted by severity and subtracted from overall life expectancy.

On average, people in the healthiest regions lose some 9% of their lives to disability; in the worst-off countries, where disease often strikes young, people lose 14%. For the UK, babies born in 1999 can expect 71.7 years of healthy life. But there is a marked difference between females (73.7) and males (69.7).

This gender gap is even more pronounced in France, which is placed third most healthy nation largely because of the striking healthy life expectancy of females (76.9) rather than that of males (69.3).

The WHO attributes this to the fact that French women have not been heavy smokers. But it says a recent upsurge in smoking among young women will inevitably cause a rise in tobacco-related disease and knock France down the table.

The US's bleak showing is linked partly to smoking and to high rates of heart disease and Aids, but also to violence and the plight of groups such as native Americans, rural blacks and the inner-city poor, whose health is said to be "more characteristic of a poor developing country than a rich industrialised one".

Average American healthy life expectancy is put at 70.0, below Israel and just above Cyprus and Dominica (both 69.8) and Ireland (69.6).

Christopher Murray, director of WHO's global programme on evidence for health policy, said: "The position of the US is one of the surprises of the new rating system.

"Basically, you die earlier and spend more time disabled if you're an American rather than a member of most other advanced countries."

Post-unification Germany is ranked 22nd in the table, while Denmark comes 28th and New Zealand 31st - in contrast to Australia's second place on 73.2 years.

The latter's performance is attributed to steep falls in smoking.

The pre-eminence of Japan (74.5) is put down to traditionally low tobacco use and a low-fat diet, though both of these factors are changing.

In sub-Saharan Africa, Aids is now the leading cause of death and is considered to have cut life expectancy in some countries by as much as 20 years.

fields.headline: Couch kids warning
fields.trailText: A generation of couch potato children are storing up health problems for the future because of their poor diet and inactive lifestyles, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
A generation of couch potato children are storing up health problems for the future because of their poor diet and inactive lifestyles, according to a report published today.

The British Heart Foundation's report, Couch Kids - the Growing Epidemic, has found there has been an alarming decrease in children's activity levels over the past decade.

The charity is calling for an integrated approach between the government, local authorities and schools to halt the decline, which will result in more premature deaths from coronary heart disease in later life.

The charity's study discovered that a third of boys and 38% of girls aged two to seven were not taking part in enough physical activity, and that over the past five years primary schools in England and Wales have more than halved the amount of time devoted to PE lessons.

Nearly threequarters of children aged between 11 and 16 spend more than two hours a day watching television.

A further quarter watch television for more than four hours a day.

webTitle: Sherpas take new pride in their Everest conquests

fields.headline: Sherpas take new pride in their Everest conquests
fields.trailText: It was at more than 8,000 metres, in darkness and with the weather turning bad that Temba Tseri made what turned out to be a disastrous mistake. He took off his gloves to tie his shoelace. Then he set off for the summit of Mount Everest.
fields.body:
It was at more than 8,000 metres, in darkness and with the weather turning bad that Temba Tseri made what turned out to be a disastrous mistake. He took off his gloves to tie his shoelace. Then he set off for the summit of Mount Everest.

Six and half hours later, the 15-year-old Sherpa was nearly there. He had climbed to the Hillary Step - a 30 metre spur of ice and rock about 100 metres from the summit - but he could no longer feel his fingers and his Nepalese guide had been blinded in one eye by the raging snow.

Instead of placing a bronze idol of Buddha on the summit and offering a prayer for world peace as he had planned, an exhausted Temba turned back, staggering down the mountain past a trail of discarded oxygen bottles.

"I wasn't short of breath. But I no choice," he said yesterday, speaking from a hospital in Katmandu, as surgeons prepared to amputate five of his frostbitten fingers.

"From childhood it was my wish to reach the summit," he added. "My mother didn't want me to go. No one made me do it."

Though Temba's bid to become the youngest person to climb the Everest has attracted criticism - "He was lucky to live," one mountaineer grumbled - it marks a patriotic coming of age for Nepalese mountaineering.

Ever since the British climbers Mallory and Irvine mysteriously disappeared near the 8,848 metre (29,028ft) summit of Everest in 1925, the Sherpa people who live in the Himalayan foothills have made a huge but largely unrecognised contribution to such expeditions.

The relationship, which was defined in colonial times, has been one of master and servant. During the 1960s and 70s when expeditions grew larger, as many as 100 Sherpas and 2,000 porters would virtually push western teams up the mountain. In recent years Sherpas have been treated more as equal partners, but the relationship is still a cash one: they are rewarded with $1,000 bonuses for making it to the summit.

Now the balance is beginning to shift and several Nepalese Sherpas have reached the summit in their own right.

Two weeks ago, the Sherpa Babu Chheri, 34, knocked four hours off the record for the fastest ever Everest ascent, reaching the top in 16 hours and 56 minutes. Remarkably, the climb was made in treach erous conditions and without oxygen.

"I would have made the climb in about 13 or 14 hours if it had not been for the heavy wind and snow," he said. "But I had full faith in myself and never doubted I would do it."

During his ninth ascent last year, he set another record by spending 21 hours at the top. A team of four female Sherpas also mounted a high-profile Everest bid last month, with mixed results. One woman managed to reach the summit but another had to be taken off the mountain suffering altitude sickness.

The Nepalis, nonetheless, viewed their attempt, as a source of pride. "Every time they came through camp our Sherpas were cheering and waving and asking them over for a cup of tea," said James Ross, a mountaineer who returned from Everest on Saturday as the spring climbing season ended with the onset of the monsoon.

Three weeks ago a female Sherpa guesthouse owner with no climbing experience also made a successful solo ascent of Everest's Chinese north face - "purely for enjoyment", according to her friends. And in a reversal of traditional roles, another Sherpa, Ang Dorje, scrambled to within 100 metres of the summit, supported by a New Zealand guide.

"The Nepalese are finally discovering Everest for themselves," Kanak Dixit, the editor of Himal magazine said yesterday. "There has been an unprecedented surge of Nepalis trying to climb Everest this season. They have come to realise that the mountains are their own."

The Katmandu government has also woken up to the fact that expeditions by Nepalis are good for the country's morale. For its own nationals, the cabinet has discreetly waived the $70,000 permit fee it levels on Everest teams - an enormous source of revenue for the poverty-stricken country.

In a further display of patriotic pride, Temba was paraded by jeep in Katmandu over the weekend, his blackened fingers tactfully hidden under bandages. And interest from advertisers is also growing: San Miguel beer and Yeti Airlines sponsored Temba's summit bid.

At the smoky Rum Doodle bar in Katmandu, where mountaineers gather to swap tales, the names of the climbers who have made it to the summit of Everest are written on the wall.

Many of them are among the most famous names in mountaineering. Increasingly, the names are Nepalese.

webTitle: Queen no longer fits the bill

fields.headline: Queen no longer fits the bill
fields.trailText: The Queen is is to be dropped from five dollar banknotes by the reserve bank of Australia next year as the country marks the centenary of its federation, Sydney's Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported.
fields.body:
The Queen is is to be dropped from five dollar banknotes by the reserve bank of Australia next year as the country marks the centenary of its federation, Sydney's Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported.

Sir Henry Parkes, a 19th century British immigrant and politician who helped to steer Australian states toward federation in 1901, will replace the Queen on the banknote.

The Sunday Telegraph said that there were no plans to remove the monarch's image from coins. The A$5 (£1.90) bill is the only one which still carries her image.

Scrapping the Queen from the currency was discussed last year during a debate about whether Australia should become a republic and replace Britain's monarch as its head of state with an elected presi dent. The move was rejected at a referendum in November.

"This step demonstrates yet again the vanishing symbol and irrelevance of the British monarchy to Australians," said Greg Barnes of the Australian Republican Movement. "Despite last year's defeat, the mood of the nation is still republican."

Australia is one of the few former British colonies which still recognises the Queen as its head of state.
AP in Sydney

webTitle: Religious gaffe may cost Japanese PM his job

fields.headline: Religious gaffe may cost Japanese PM his job
fields.trailText: By all conventional wisdom the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, should be a shoo-in in the general election on June 25. Yet he may face a humiliating backlash at the ballot box, all because of one remark.
fields.body:
By all conventional wisdom the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, should be a shoo-in in the general election on June 25. Yet he may face a humiliating backlash at the ballot box, all because of one remark.

Mr Mori is backed by the biggest coalition in post-war Japanese history, the opposition is weak and the economy is at last starting to pick up after years in the doldrums. But his popularity is in free fall. After hitting a high of about 40% two months ago - when he took over from the dying Keizo Obuchi as prime minister - his approval rate has slumped to a dismal 12%.

This curse can be traced back to a single sentence Mr Mori uttered last month, which raised an issue that many Japanese would rather ignore: religion.

At a gathering of lawmakers promoting the indigenous Shinto religion, Mr Mori said that Japan was a "country of gods with the emperor at its core".

Critics say those words, repeated daily by every newspaper and television station in the country, are a throwback to the pre-war era of religious nationalism, when Shinto taught that the emperor was a god and Japan a divine nation.

Mr Mori has repeatedly denied that this was his intention, but on Saturday he put his foot in it again by referring to the need to protect the Japanese kokutai (national essence); a concept associated with the pre-war Shinto beliefs.

"It was an unbelievable mistake," said Professor Takeshi Sasaki of Tokyo University. "I've never seen such an unpopular prime minister."

After the war, in which millions of Japanese died fighting for a supposedly divine emperor, the separation of religion and state was enshrined in the constitution. Schools are prohibited from teaching religious beliefs and public funds cannot be used for religious events.

Now, according to a poll by the Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper, the proportion of the population who believe in religion of any kind has declined from more than 60% in 1950 to 20%.

Opposition politicians say that Mr Mori's use of terms associated with pre-war religious nationalism show that he is out of touch, and many voters agree.

"His views are so out of date," said Yuichi Matsuo, an office worker. "He's an embarrassment."

The "nation of gods" comment has also upset the prime minister's main coalition partner - the Buddhist-backed Komeito party, whose presence in the government has already ensured that religion will play an unusually prominent role in this election. Its leaders have asked Mr Mori to retract his words.

On the surface, leading politicians from Mr Mori's Liberal Democratic party say they welcome a debate on religion.

"If Mr Mori's comments are an issue, then we'll win, because the election will become a race between the atheist opposition and believers in the supernatural," said Shizuka Kamei, the party's combative policy chief. "This will create a kamikaze [divine wind] of support for the LDP."

But such bravado masks a growing sense of crisis in the ruling party at the evaporation of support. Mr Mori is seen as such a liability that LDP candidates are shunning his offers of campaign help. Behind the scenes, party leaders are said to be plotting whether to remove him immediately after the election or to wait until the G8 summit in July.

webTitle: June 5: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 5: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Mission:Impossible 2 holds on to US top spot, Arnie turns down guns, Dr Who rumours, Spinal Tap on DVD, and Gabriel Byrne and Nick Moran on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Mission: Impossible 2 fell off 53% from its opening weekend box-office total, to narrowly retain the top spot with an estimated $27m takings in US cinemas. Second to Cruise and co came the Martin Lawrence comedy Big Momma's House, which opened with a $25.6m haul. Disney's Dinosaur took third place with $12m.

 Arnold Schwarzenegger has refused to pose with a gun for the marketing campaign of his latest film, The 6th Day. The film, directed by Roger Spottiswoode (Tomorrow Never Dies), is an action movie about a man who is cloned and must fight to rid himself of his double. While that struggle is highly likely to involve heavy artillery, Arnie will have none of it on the poster, despite MGM's pleas. "If people say movies lead to violence," he growls, "we should make a concession."

 Ain't It Cool News reports that former Dr Who producer Philip Hinchcliffe, helmsman during the show's 1970s golden years, is to oversee production of the sci-fi classic's much-mooted transfer to the big screen. Highlander director Russell Mulcahy is "95% on to direct," claims the site's correspondent. The report goes on to cite Terence Stamp as most likely to play the eponymous timelord.

 This Is Spinal Tap is to be released on a DVD boasting more than 100 minutes of extra footage, including never-before-seen outtakes. Four music videos, three commercials, a press conference and a TV appearance round out the package. The original "band members", Christopher Guest, Michael McKean and Harry Shearer are scheduled for a live performance on VH1 later this month.

 Gabriel Byrne has been approached to appear in the Star Wars sequels, claims the actor in an interview in the Irish press. "The people from Star Wars called the other day to offer me something, but I don't know what it is yet," he says in Dublin's Evening Herald. "It's probably already been announced on the internet," he adds, wrongly, "but I still don't know myself."

 Lock, Stock star Nick Moran has joined Gary Oldman and Catherine Deneuve on Paramount Pictures' $50m feature, D'Artagnan. Directed by Peter (End Of Days) Hyam, D'Artagnan follows one of the three musketeers who seeks revenge for his parents' murder amid the mayhem of pre-revolutionary France.
